column1: 1615;d2a228f70dcadada821b494ad5837fa0dc9b62d8;0;;2016-11-17T22:28:00.000+02:00;Life: 6 People Who Came To My Garage Sale Who Seem To Be Sticking Around For Dinner;"I had a garage sale today
column2: and a number of people came and bought stuff. Most of them left. Here are the ones who are still sticking around. 1. The Guy Who Bought My Lamp

column1: I expected the guy who bought my lamp to leave after he bought my lamp. But he did not leave. He sat down on my lawn and started reading the newspaper. I went up to him and asked him if he needed help with anything
column2: and he said
column3: ‚ÄúNope. Been saving my appetite all day.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt really know what that meant
column4: but someone had a question about my foosball table at that moment so I didn‚Äôt have time to get clarification on that. 2. The Couple Who Didn‚Äôt Buy Anything But Spent A Lot Of Time Browsing My Box Of National Geographic sAnd Then Got In Their Car And Took A Nap

column1: These people seemed really into my National Geographic s
column2: so I was pretty surprised when they decided not to buy them. I was also surprised when
column3: instead of leaving
column4: they just got in their car and started napping. They‚Äôre still asleep
column5: and there‚Äôs a little Post-it on their window that says
column6: ‚ÄúWake us up when it‚Äôs ready.‚Äù 3. The Old Woman Who Bought My Vacuum

column1: When the old lady who bought my vacuum offered to pay for my vacuum by vacuuming my house
column2: I thought it was a little odd but also kind of nice. My place is a little dusty these days
column3: and definitely could use a good vacuuming. So I said yes. I wish that she had left after she finished vacuuming my house. She is now in the kitchen and has been vacuuming the same corner for the last 20 minutes. Plus
column4: she keeps chiming in on how to make the pasta sauce. I have to admit she did a pretty good job cleaning my house
column5: though. I don‚Äôt know how to ask her to leave without sounding rude. 4. The Lady Who Bought A Plate
column6: A Fork
column7: And A Knife

column1: I assumed this woman bought these items for her own home
column2: but it‚Äôs been three hours and she is just standing by the front door sneaking peeks at the kitchen through the window. This is becoming stressful. 5. The Kid Who Bought My Toaster Even Though I Told Him It Was Broken And Then Handed Me A List Of His Allergies

column1: When this kid asked me how much I wanted for the toaster
column2: I was up-front about the fact that it was broken. But that didn‚Äôt matter to him. He bought the thing for 50 cents and then handed me a list of allergies he had. Now he is sitting out on the lawn along with the guy who bought my lamp
column3: and I think they‚Äôre working on a crossword puzzle together. I really don‚Äôt think I have enough ingredients to make food for all these people. Also
column4: there are a lot of allergies on this list. 6. The Older Gentleman Who Brought A Raw Steak To My Garage Sale And Then Bought A Coatrack

column1: I don‚Äôt know why the old man who bought the coatrack brought a raw steak to my garage sale. After he purchased the coatrack
column2: he placed the raw steak in a dish to marinate
column3: then put it in my garage fridge. I asked him what he was doing
column4: and he said
column5: ‚ÄúGotta marinate this bad boy for dos horas
column6: compadre. Buon appetito.‚Äù He is still here
column7: and his steak is still marinating. Overall
column8: I‚Äôd say the garage sale itself was a success because I made about $250. But it ended hours ago and all these people have not left yet
column9: and I don‚Äôt know what to do.";english;2016-11-18T01:56:20.402+02:00;clickhole.com;US;16425.0;Life: 6 People Who Came To My Garage Sale Who Seem To Be Sticking Around For Dinner;0.0;http://images.onionstatic.com/clickhole/3469/7/16x9/1200.jpg;0;0;662;0;662;satire

column1: 1617;9562177768a0e58b943a130e514f2e4c9afcd199;0;;2016-11-18T20:10:25.886+02:00;News: Animal Welfare FTW! Oscar Mayer Now Requires Pork Producers To Give Their Pigs One Thrilling Sexual Experience Before Sending Them To Slaughter;"Email
The cruelty of factory farms is a daily nightmare for billions of animals
column2: but that might soon start to change thanks to a forward-thinking initiative by one of the biggest names in the meat industry. In a humane act of compassion for their livestock
column3: the Oscar Mayer Company now requires its pork suppliers to give their pigs one thrilling sexual experience before sending them to slaughter.

column1: It‚Äôs pretty difficult to overstate what a huge leap forward this is for animal rights.
The details of the new policy are extremely promising: Once a pig reaches sexual maturity
column2: factory workers must lather it in a warming lubricant and place it in an outdoor pen
column3: where it will encounter dozens of sows in heat and boars specially bred to produce voluptuously potent pheromone levels. The pigs will then be encouraged to partake in any variety of sow-on-boar
column4: sow-on-sow
column5: boar-on-boar
column6: or autoerotic swineplay they prefer. Only after they‚Äôve bellowed long
column7: guttural squeals of satisfaction will these pigs be killed
column8: processed
column9: and separated into their desirable parts for human consumption.

column1: Conscious consumers can rest assured: Oscar Mayer pork will have been treated to full prostate and teat stimulation via double-prodded toys
column2: clamps
column3: and strategically placed ice cubes before being sent to the slaughterhouse. Farmers will even have to install sprinklers emitting warm hog urine for any pig who might be into that.

column1: Wow. It seems like Oscar Mayer is truly dedicated to setting a new bar for ethical animal treatment.
To put this in perspective
column2: not even free-range operations keep pig behavior specialists on-site to spot hogs nearing ejaculation and pull them away in order to temporarily evade orgasm
column3: thereby extending the hog‚Äôs arousal and making their eventual climaxes that much more explosive. For a household meat brand like Oscar Mayer to endorse this kind of practice is a really
column4: really big deal.

column1: ‚ÄúBefore slaughter
column2: we intend to treat our pigs to nothing less than the absolute highest order of hoof-shattering orgasms
column3: ‚Äù said Oscar Mayer President Mark Magnesen in a press release. ‚ÄúOur commitment to the well-being of animals means ensuring that no pig reaches an abbatoir without first experiencing a flesh romp so sensational it causes their numbing limbs to buckle under full-bodied tail-to-snout pleasure.‚Äù

column1: Just yes. Even PETA has to admit that this is a great new direction for pork producers.

Taste tests held by the company revealed that customers unanimously preferred meat from sexually gratified pigs over meat from pigs raised under typical factory-farm stresses. Interested in trying some yourself
column2: or just want to support the cause? Look for the special label they‚Äôve created to specify that their products came from a pig they made squeal in wanton rapture.

column1: Well
column2: it looks like Oscar Mayer is finally getting on the right side of animal rights history. This is exactly the thoughtful kind of action consumers want to see food companies enact. They could have easily just asked suppliers to masturbate a few pigs to completion and called it change
column3: but the level of care they‚Äôre pouring into these bacchanalian thrills shows that they‚Äôre truly making animal welfare a priority.

column1: Any progress for farm animals is welcome progress
column2: and hopefully this is a sign of even better living conditions to come. One blowout circus of carnal delights is the least they can do for these pigs.";english;2016-11-18T20:10:25.886+02:00;clickhole.com;US;16425.0;News: Animal Welfare FTW! Why not brush up on these apple-picking rules so you don‚Äôt end up in the Punishment Orchard?
1. Don‚Äôt climb the trees: Apple trees are for picking
column2: not climbing! Fail to heed this rule and you might just find yourself stuck in the cruel autumn shadow of the Punishment Orchard. Swinging from a tree branch in the regular orchard won‚Äôt seem worth it once you‚Äôre lashed to a hayride and dumped in the middle of this sprawling
column3: 100-acre wasteland where the fog never lifts and the apples are all way too hot to pick.

column1: 2. Twist
column2: don‚Äôt pull: Heads up: Pulling an apple can inadvertently knock down other fruit and risks damaging the tree. Better to carefully twist the apple upwards than be consigned to the Punishment Orchard‚Äôs sea of wet
column3: beige trees with no end in sight. Keep this rule in mind and you will never get trapped in the pitch-black sap oozing out of all the trees
column4: nor will you be driven mad by the winds that constantly whisper a summary of Dale Earnhardt‚Äôs death.

column1: 3. Don‚Äôt waste fruit: The stench of bleach and pennies will be the surefire sign that your decision to just toss imperfect apples onto the ground of the normal orchard has landed you in the wicked
column2: seething grove of the Punishment Orchard. A chorus of middle-aged men shrouded by crude scarecrow masks will taunt you with their vexing rhyme: ‚ÄúWe are the men who have picked before / Your hands are bags
column3: your days no more.‚Äù Looking down
column4: condemned travelers will realize the infectious verse has replaced their hands with reusable grocery bags and they can no longer remember important birthdays.

column1: 4. Don‚Äôt eat the apples until you‚Äôve paid: You‚Äôll want to pay up-front if you don‚Äôt want to wake up in the wicker prison at the base of the Tree of Despair
column2: a beige monstrosity whose sprawling tendrils lie directly under the approach path of the regional airport. You must sit in your atonement basket while the depraved
column3: orphaned children of the Punishment Orchard throw scalding apples at your head as part of one of their simple-minded religious rituals.

column1: 5. Don‚Äôt pick outside the designated areas: Follow the clearly posted signs in sunny and cheerful normal orchard and you should be fine! Wanderers will have their names recorded on the Punishment Orchard‚Äôs Ledger of Bad Deeds
column2: a shameful blight that nearly cost William Rehnquist his appointment to the Supreme Court in 1971. Then they will be given incorrect directions which will only send them deeper into the bowels of the Punishment Orchard
column3: where the Cider Warden bathes himself in bleach and spare change. Even years after a stay in the Punishment Orchard
column4: the smell of either of these items will send you into a vivid Vietnam flashback
column5: regardless of whether or not you fought in Vietnam.

column1: 6. No running: It‚Äôs natural to let the excitement of apple picking get the best of you. Just don‚Äôt be surprised if you draw the ire of the Punishment Picker. Setting aside his chisel and cigar
column2: he will take an afternoon off from making sculptures of Mussolini having a great time in order to make a sculpture of you getting stung by a bee. Your cries of remorse will be drowned out by the children of the Punishment Orchard cheering ‚ÄúGather your coins
column3: friends! The Punishment Man of the forest has taken a day off of sculpting a happy Mussolini in order to immortalize a delinquent being humiliated by a bee!‚Äù

column1: 1621;a97390391169a0f8e7e67e9f1b7514e7126eb93e;0;;2016-11-18T21:45:28.657+02:00;Life: Finding Common Ground: This White Man And This Muslim Woman Both Have ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô Painted On Their Garages;"Email
Get ready for the most heartwarming story you‚Äôll read all day.
If you met Paul Langdon or Ayesha Qamar on the street
column2: you might think they have nothing in common. Paul is a retired firefighter
column3: Ayesha is a law student. Paul has lived in the same suburb of Columbus for his entire life
column4: Ayesha immigrated to Ohio from Pakistan when she was a teen. Paul is a devout Christian
column5: Ayesha is Muslim. But if you dig a little deeper
column6: you‚Äôll find that they share a common bond: Both Paul and Ayesha have ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô painted on their garages!

column1: Beautiful! Take a look at the side-by-side pictures above to see just how similar these two really are.
When Donald Trump announced his campaign last summer
column2: Paul knew he wanted to show his support by painting a large sign of the candidate‚Äôs name on his garage door. But Paul probably never would have guessed that one year later
column3: just a few towns over from him
column4: Ayesha‚Äôs own garage would be painted with literally the exact same word! Paul and Ayesha may be from totally different walks of life
column5: but when it comes to the name currently painted on their garages
column6: these two have more in common than they ever could have imagined.

column1: At the end of the day
column2: it doesn‚Äôt matter whether their skin is white or brown. It doesn‚Äôt matter whether they worship God or Allah. And it doesn‚Äôt matter whether the word ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô has been carefully lettered or hastily scrawled across the garage in brusque spray paint. All that matters is the commonality they share in having the word ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô painted on their homes for the entire neighborhood to see.

column1: Amazing! It just goes to show
column2: you should never judge a book by its cover.

column1: At a time when our country feels so divided
column2: stories like this one give us hope for humanity. On the surface
column3: Paul and Ayesha couldn‚Äôt be more different
column4: but the messages painted or spray-painted across their garages are one in the same. What an amazing reminder that we‚Äôre not so different after all!";english;2016-11-18T21:45:28.657+02:00;clickhole.com;US;16425.0;Life: Finding Common Ground: This White Man And This Muslim Woman Both Have ‚ÄòTrump‚Äô Painted On Their Garages;0.0;http://images.onionstatic.com/clickhole/3472/7/16x9/1200.jpg;0;0;0;0;0;satire

column1: 1622;189ecea1c1832afa8e3a7be3d25bdce98d3f5675;0;;2016-11-22T02:45:00.000+02:00;Blog: Our Country Has Become Worryingly Desensitized To Violence In Hot-Sauce Names;"Email
As a parent
column2: you always have to be aware of what lessons your child is learning from the world around him or her. I know that I won‚Äôt be able to protect my 9-year-old James from every bad thing out there
column3: but on a recent trip to the grocery store
column4: I was utterly appalled by a disturbing trend: Our country has become desensitized to violence in hot-sauce names
column5: and it‚Äôs a big problem.

column1: You can‚Äôt walk down your grocer‚Äôs sauce isle without being bombarded by hot-sauce names that romanticize violence. Tears of Blood
column2: Nuclear Bombardment Chile Extract
column3: and Death on the Toilet have become standard fare in the hot-sauce industry. An innocent trip to purchase a simple bottle of ketchup now subliminally exposes shoppers
column4: and our impressionable children
column5: to dozens of gruesome descriptions of burning flesh
column6: brutal deaths
column7: and massive ass damage.

column1: As soon as the hot-sauce industry agreed it was okay to allow names like Cremation in a Bottle Pepper Sauce and Ass Grave Cajun Sauce to appear on store shelves
column2: any shred of decency went out the window. An arms race began to see who could come up with the most violent and gory sauce name
column3: society be damned. And it needs to stop before our children internalize these sorts of brutal names as the norm for hot-sauce labels.

column1: Hot sauce has always been hot
column2: but the names used to imply the hotness without going into the graphic detail you see today.

column1: I took my son James to my favorite Mexican restaurant this past weekend
column2: and he didn‚Äôt even blink when he saw a bottle with ‚ÄúVolcanic Crucification‚Äù written out in flames. If he isn‚Äôt bothered by this
column3: who‚Äôs to say if he would even think twice if he one day saw a hot sauce called Ghost Pepper Throat Thresher?

column1: I pray that we correct course in this country before anyone decides to make that hot sauce.
It wasn‚Äôt always like this. Hot sauce has always been hot
column2: but the names used to imply the hotness without going into the graphic detail you see today. Names like Frank‚Äôs Red Hot let you know you were in for some serious heat
column3: but left something to the imagination. But there is no longer a moral standard for hot-sauce names. Now
column4: all it takes to begin leading a child down a bad path is for them to glance at a sauce bottle in a friend‚Äôs refrigerator door.

column1: Whether it‚Äôs Screaming Suicide Moruga Scorpion Sauce or Habanero Holocaust Sauce
column2: the lengths to which today‚Äôs sauces are going to outdo one another with disturbingly violent names has gotten out of control. And if you‚Äôre a parent
column3: you know that we must do something to stop this
column4: before it‚Äôs too late for our children.";english;2016-11-22T05:16:37.494+02:00;clickhole.com;US;16425.0;Blog: Our Country Has Become Worryingly Desensitized To Violence In Hot-Sauce Names;0.0;http://images.onionstatic.com/clickhole/3473/5/16x9/1200.jpg;0;0;0;0;0;satire

column2: Jane Goodall Shares Her 6 Most Fascinating Discoveries About Chimpanzees;"Email Jane Goodall has dedicated her life to studying primates
column3: and the insights she has gained into our evolutionary ancestors are truly powerful. Prepare to have your breath taken away by Dr. Goodall‚Äôs words.

column1: 1. Chimps will betray their own to get their hands on Italian food: ‚ÄúAs with all chimps
column2: the ones I studied in Gombe were absolutely obsessed with Italian food and would go to extraordinary lengths to get their hands on some. One day
column3: the troop‚Äôs alpha male
column4: whom I called Goliath
column5: managed to acquire a plate of linguine. Humphrey
column6: a younger male
column7: saw Goliath‚Äôs linguine and became incredibly jealous. He offered to give Goliath his most prized possession‚Äîa vacant hornet nest that he enjoyed having sex with‚Äîin exchange for the linguine
column8: but Goliath declined
column9: as he already had a hornet nest of his own. Desperate to eat the linguine
column10: Humphrey threw some pebbles to divert Goliath‚Äôs attention
column11: then snuck up behind him and ripped his head off
column12: allowing him to take the Italian food from his superior. It was a gruesome yet utterly fascinating scene.‚Äù

column1: 2. When chimpanzee communities encounter a Japanese researcher
column2: they will try to put them in jail: ‚ÄúMy colleague
column3: Dr. Kiyoshi Yamamoto
column4: discovered this when chimps dragged him from his tent in the middle of the night down to the local prison. The apes would then approach the town‚Äôs sheriff with their hands out
column5: expecting a food reward. It was truly shocking to learn that chimpanzees are capable of such things. Nature is not always pretty.‚Äù

column1: 3. Most chimps can vocalize the phrase ‚Äúoh no‚Äù: ‚ÄúThey like to yell it while they defecate.‚Äù 4. Chimps don‚Äôt like it when you blow up one of their family members with a grenade: ‚ÄúOne of my young researchers
column2: Sofia Manfredi
column3: discovered this after rolling an active grenade into a ditch where several male siblings were sharing a lunch of termites and soup. The grenade exploded the youngest one into a red mist of viscera and bone
column4: and
column5: curiously
column6: the other brothers seemed to become rather disheartened.‚Äù

column1: 5. Chimps revere hippos: ‚ÄúWhen they become aware of a hippo in the vicinity
column2: chimps stop whatever they‚Äôre doing and take turns honoring the beast. They bring offerings of plump salamanders
column3: crushed soda cans
column4: and other treasures they‚Äôve found in the dirt
column5: and they join together in an angelic chorus of growls to soothe the hippo. New mothers will rub their infants against the hippo‚Äôs groin to bless them with his virility. The troop‚Äôs elders will break off their incisors with a rock and fashion a crude crown of teeth for the hippo to wear. If the hippo becomes aggressive towards them
column6: they do not resist; in fact
column7: it is an honor for them to be crushed by the hippo
column8: and they will often place their heads on the ground next to his hooves in hopes that he might accidentally stomp their skulls flat.‚Äù

column1: 6. If a chimp dunks its head into a bucket of horchata for an hour
column2: it will die: ‚ÄúWhenever chimps discover a large pail of horchata in the forest
column3: the eldest female of the group will approach it and slowly lower her head into the liquid
column4: remaining there for an hour or more until another chimp yanks her out of it. It was fascinating to observe the way their social structure altered afterwards
column5: with the next eldest female unfailingly rising up to lead the group‚Äôs children in licking the sweet rice milk from their deceased matriarch‚Äôs body.‚Äù";english;2016-11-22T05:16:39.972+02:00;clickhole.com;US;16425.0;Life: After 55 Years Of Research
column6: Jane Goodall Shares Her 6 Most Fascinating Discoveries About Chimpanzees;0.0;http://images.onionstatic.com/clickhole/3473/2/16x9/1200.jpg;0;0;297;0;297;satire

column1: 2207;ea516e37b3c49060a77a03868c3c1ec957040432;0;;2016-10-28T02:04:22.410+03:00;Flash Mob of Black Teens Assault Whites
column2: Media Silent On If It's A Hate Crime. | Daily Wire;"Aaron Bandler October 27

column1: A flash mob of over 150 blacks teens assaulted numerous people on Friday in Philadelphia in an attack that appears to have been racially motivated
column2: and yet the media is silent about this possible motivation.

column1: LifeZette reports that the racial component of the attack was evident in a Facebook post written by Joe Lauletta
column2: whose daughter
column3: Christina
column4: was attacked by the flash mob on Friday. Lauletta wrote that he received a phone call from Christina
column5: who tearfully explained that she ""was jumped"" and ""beat up pretty bad.""

column1: I find out that her and her 2 male friends where badly beaten by a group of 30-40 black teenagers on their way home from the Temple football game
column2: Lauletta wrote. ""This happened after they got off the subway at Broad and Cecil B Moore. These sick animals held her down and kicked and stomped on her repeatedly. Thank god
column3: the people from the pizza place intervened.""

column1: While no bones were broken
column2: Christina was ""badly bruised"" throughout her body
column3: Lauletta said ""it makes me cry just thinking about it.""

column1: Lauletta's post seemed to indicate the racial aspect of the attack
column2: and on Tuesday he posted on Facebook that ""the FBI is investigating"" and ""are analyzing all video coverage
column3: signaling that the FBI is looking into the attack as a hate crime.

column1: In an interview with the New York Post
column2: Lauletta wouldn't explicitly say the attack was racially motivated but sort of implied it:

column1: ‚ÄúWell
column2: I haven‚Äôt been saying that because everybody is trying to get me to say it and I don‚Äôt know if I want to be that person
column3: ‚Äù Lauletta told The Post. ‚ÄúEveryone can draw their own conclusions.‚Äù

column1: Lauletta said the possibility of the attacks being motivated by race ‚Äì perhaps as a sort of gang initiation ‚Äì was part of the reason why his story was shared so frequently and as far away as Africa.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why it spread so fast
column2: ‚Äù Lauletta said. ‚ÄúIf you read my Facebook page
column3: everybody‚Äôs saying it.‚Äù

column1: However
column2: Philadelphia Police Lt. John Stanford insisted to the Post that ""there hasn‚Äôt been any indication that race is involved in this in any shape or form.""

column1: Even still
column2: the media hasn't reported that the attack is possibly a hate crime
column3: as LifeZette points out:

column1: Friday violence as teen mob attacks Temple students
column2: police; four arrested
column3: ‚Äù read the headline on Philly.com
column4: while the Philly Voice reported ‚ÄúTeens arrested after flash mob leads to assaults on Broad Street.‚Äù The Associated Press headline read: ‚ÄúSTUDENTS BEATEN
column5: HORSE PUNCHED IN MOB ATTACKS AT UNIVERSITY.

column1: The Washington Post buried the possibility in their story and then dismissed it with Stanford's quote.
LifeZette also noted that Temple University described the attack as ""a large group of approximately 200 juveniles causing disruption along Broad Street.""
Maybe Stanford is correct that it was a random attack
column2: or maybe the black flash mob was targeting whites. But there is no doubting the media's hypocrisy: if this were a flash mob of white teenagers that attacked blacks
column3: the media would be screaming about it being a hate crime. But since the incident in Philadelphia does not advance the media's racial narrative
column4: they will not treat it in the same manner. Tags ";english;2016-10-28T02:04:22.410+03:00;dailywire.com;US;15846.0;Flash Mob of Black Teens Assault Whites

column1: 2213;729bb73b9c8f998e2ad84eaa0d898bb1ab9bdc9b;0;;2016-10-27T08:29:00.000+03:00;George And Laura Bush Celebrate Their 70th Birthdays | Daily Wire;"George And Laura Bush Celebrate Their 70th Birthdays By: Hank Berrien October 26
On Saturday
column2: former president George W. Bush and former first lady Laura Bush celebrated their 70th birthdays together in Crawford
column3: Texas.

column1: President Bush‚Äôs birthday was July 6
column2: and Laura‚Äôs is on November 4.

column1: Some of the attendees included former commerce secretary Donald Evans
column2: Dallas Cowboys owner and general manager Jerry Jones
column3: and Ross Perot Jr.
column4: the son of H. Ross Perot. George Strait performed
column5: and sang ‚ÄúHappy Birthday
column6: ‚Äù per People. Typical of Bush‚Äôs down-home style
column7: he wore jeans
column8: a western-style shirt and a prominent belt buckle.

column1: The dinner included an avocado and grapefruit salad
column2: Mesquite smoked peppered beef tenderloin
column3: Southern fried catfish
column4: roasted corn and poblano pudding
column5: bourbon carrots
column6: and cheddar and black pepper biscuits. The dessert was a Texas chocolate sheet cake.

column1: Bush also invited guests to his art studio at the ranch
column2: dubbed Studio 43
column3: where he works on his paintings.

column1: Laura Bush was working as a librarian in the Austin Independent School District when she met George in 1977; their friends Joe and Jan O'Neill invited them to a barbecue. They were married in November 1977 at the First United Methodist Church in Midland
column2: where she had been baptized. She wore a tan
column3: two-toned dress she had bought off the rack.

column1: George W. Bush later called his proposal to his wife the ""best decision of my life."" Laura
column2: an only child
column3: said she gained ""brothers and sisters and wonderful in-laws"" and made her feel part of the family. column1: Trump was on defense on the election map as he had to defend states like Arizona

column2: Too.;"Christie Lost Republicans The 2012 Election. He May Be Losing Them The 2016 Election
column3: Too. By: Ben Shapiro November 4

column1: Ambition can be dangerous. Not just for the ambitious man or woman
column2: but for the country ‚Äì for all those who ally with the ambitious person.

column1: For the last eight years
column2: one of the most ambitious men in politics has been New Jersey Governor Chris Christie. Hailed as a conservative darling after taking on teacher‚Äôs unions in New Jersey ‚Äì brash language about ‚Äúpunching them in the face‚Äù marked his rise as a political force and an up-and-comer in presidential politics ‚Äì Christie has nearly singlehandedly destroyed the Republican Party in two straight presidential elections.
Christie was considered and rejected for vice president by Mitt Romney ‚Äì but then gave the keynote speech in primetime at the Republican convention. There
column3: he spent the bulk of his time talking about his own wonders
column4: ignoring Romney completely. Fox News‚Äô Chris Wallace called the speech ‚Äúthe most curious keynote speech I have ever heard‚Ä¶For a moment I forgot who was the nominee of the party.‚Äù

column1: Then
column2: the week before the election
column3: Hurricane Sandy hit the East Coast. While New York Governor Andrew Cuomo told President Obama that his presence was unnecessary
column4: Christie invited Obama to New Jersey
column5: then hugged him and took him on a tour of Atlantic City
column6: where they made political love along the boardwalk underneath the cloudy skies. ‚ÄúI cannot thank the president enough for his personal concern and compassion for our state
column7: ‚Äù Christie said
column8: adding that it was ‚Äúmy honor‚Äù to introduce President Obama. Christie was
column9: at the time
column10: facing down rumors that then-Newark Mayor Corey Booker
column11: who is black
column12: would run against him. As The New York Times noted
column13: ‚ÄúThe scene played out on televisions around the country like a stirring campaign ad that hit themes of bipartisanship and crisis management ‚Äì only it was run free of charge.‚Äù

column1: Obama surged in the final days and beat Romney handily.
Fast forward three years.

Christie was running in the Republican primaries. He‚Äôd done nothing much in the polls; his only hope was to somehow do well in New Hampshire. He had no support in states like South Carolina or Nevada
column2: or southern states dominated by support for Donald Trump
column3: Ted Cruz
column4: and Marco Rubio. So
column5: naturally
column6: he used his presence at the debate before the New Hampshire primary ‚Äì a state in which Rubio was surging following his Iowa showing ‚Äì to destroy Rubio. Christie rightly labeled Rubio a robotic candidate
column7: Rubio repeated himself
column8: Christie hit him again ‚Äì and Rubio fell apart in the polling. Trump ran away with the state. Almost immediately
column9: Christie quit the race and fell in behind Trump. Thanks in large part to Christie‚Äôs help
column10: Trump won the nomination.

column1: Now
column2: with Trump surging in the polls the week before his general election against Hillary Clinton
column3: Christie has struck again: this time
column4: two of his top aides have been found guilty on all charges related to Bridgegate
column5: the scandal in which the Christie administration allegedly blocked bridges in order to punish a local Democrat who wouldn‚Äôt endorse Christie‚Äôs re-election bid . This story will allow the media to shift its focus to the Trump campaign
column6: since Christie is leader of Trump‚Äôs White House transition team. In a tight election
column7: it could be enough to hand Hillary the White House.

column1: So thanks
column2: Chris Christie.

2241;0b7d8c639f8c9549f9d998cad74a161817cb74eb;0;;2016-10-27T06:16:00.000+03:00;11 Stupid Things Vox.com's Matthew Yglesias Has Said | Daily Wire;"11 Stupid Things Vox.com's Matthew Yglesias Has Said By: Aaron Bandler October 26
Matt Yglesias of Vox has always been a gold mine of comedy fodder
column2: given his penchant for saying things that are mind-bogglingly asinine. Apparently Yglesias agrees with this sentiment: Matt Yglesias deleted something like 30
column3: 000 tweets yesterday. Clearly a man proud of his history of astute analysis and voxplanations.

column1: Fortunately
column2: the Internet is forever and all of the stupid things that Yglesias has said can still be found and mocked mercilessly.

column1: Here are 11 things Yglesias has said that are incredibly dumb.
1. Yglesias was convinced that people would love Obamacare. That is
column2: until he didn't: . @mattyglesias Obamacare marker - which was solid as of 15 minutes ago - appears to no longer be markering pic.twitter.com/a0EyXImI8g ‚Äî Omri Ceren (@cerenomri) October 26

column1: His 2013 piece is still available though
column2: and in it he whines about how supposedly ""the media
column3: for non-ideological reasons
column4: is just massively biased toward negativity about this kind of thing."" Yglesias also links to another piece of his in which he claimed that ""when Obamacare becomes the status quo
column5: people will still be happy with the status quo quo and easy to frighten.""

column1: In other words
column2: Yglesias felt that the plebs would eventually succumb to his way of thinking. That all fell by the wayside when the Obama administration admitted that premiums were set to increase by an average of 25 percent.

column1: 2. Yglesias made a racist comment toward former Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal (R). In a 2013 tweet that is now deleted
column2: Yglesias wrote
column3: ""Is Bobby Jindal‚Äôs reputation for intelligence anything other than ethnic stereotyping?""

column1: Yglesias doubled down on his nasty comment when he received backlash
column2: tweeting: ""Oh
column3: fun. Conservative twitter is in bogus outrage mode.""

column1: Eventually
column2: Yglesias backed down
column3: tweeting: ""For the record
column4: now that I know more about Jindal‚Äôs life it‚Äôs clear that he‚Äôs a very smart man who just says lots of very dumb stuff.""

column1: The irony of Yglesias saying this was not lost on Twitter: Good thing you don't say dumb stuff. MT @mattyglesias It‚Äôs clear that Jindal‚Äôs a very smart man who just says lots of very dumb stuff. ‚Äî jon gabriel (@exjon) June 18
3. Yglesias once ranted against ""dumb Jewish politicians."" The leftist pundit wrote a ThinkProgress piece in 2009 that was seriously titled ""Dumb Jewish Politicians
column2: in which Yglesias highlighted a passage from Jonathan Chait
column3: who wrote in the New Republic that then-Sen. Joe Lieberman (I-CT) had to be stupid for not supporting the public option.

column1: I suspect that Lieberman is the beneficiary
column2: or possibly the victim
column3: of a cultural stereotype that Jews are smart and good with numbers
column4: Chait wrote. ""Trust me
column5: it‚Äôs not true. If Senator Smith from Idaho was angering Democrats by spewing uninformed platitudes
column6: most liberals would deride him as an idiot. With Lieberman
column7: we all suspect it‚Äôs part of a plan. I think he just has no idea what he‚Äôs talking about and doesn‚Äôt care to learn""

column1: Yglesias agreed:
I‚Äôve long held a related theory about Eric Cantor.
Anyways
column2: this reminds me that at a meeting this morning I pitched the idea of trying to do health reform in a secret Christmas morning session that only Jewish Senators would attend. There‚Äôs a whole bunch‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBoxer
column3: Cardin
column4: Feingold
column5: Feinstein
column6: Franken
column7: Kohl
column8: Lautenberg
column9: Levin
column10: Lieberman
column11: Sanders
column12: Schumer
column13: Specter
column14: and Wyden. It‚Äôs a very progressive bunch and Lieberman could easily be outvoted

column1: 4. Yglesias advocated for ending time zones. Seriously. In what was a typical example of Vox being a waste of space
column2: Yglesias wrote a 2014 piece titled ""The case against time zones: They're impractical & outdated."" Yglesias pontificated:

column1: Northern Idaho is connected via I-90 to Spokane and Seattle to its west
column2: but not to Boise to its south so the Couer d'Alene area is on Pacific Time rather than Mountain Time. India has broken with the general scheme and adopted a half-hour staggered time zone so as to place the entire country on one time.

column1: Yet while these zig-zags and 30-minute zones destroy the pristine geometry of railroad time
column2: they serve a very practical purpose. It is genuinely annoying to schedule meetings
column3: calls
column4: and other arrangements across time zones. The need to constantly specify which time zone you're talking about is a drag. Commuting across time zones would be more annoying still
column5: which is why the suburbs of Chicago that are located in Indiana use Illinois' Central Time rather than Indianapolis' Eastern Time.

column1: But the ultimate solution to this problem is not a lot of ad hoc deviations. It's to shift the world to one giant time zone.
Ygleasias then called for ""One time to rule them all""‚Äìa phrase that prompted J.R.R. Tolkien to weep in his grave‚Äìand then wrote this doozy:
If the whole world used a single GMT-based time
column2: schedules would still vary. In general most people would sleep when it's dark out and work when it's light out. So at 23:00
column3: most of London would be at home or in bed and most of Los Angeles would be at the office. But of course London's bartenders would probably be at work while some shift workers in LA would be grabbing a nap. The difference from today is that if you were putting together a London-LA conference call at 21:00 there'd be only one possible interpretation of the proposal. A flight that leaves New York at 14:00 and lands in Paris at 20:00 is a six-hour flight
column4: with no need to keep track of time zones. If your appointment is in El Paso at 11:30 you don't need to remember that it's in a different time zone than the rest of Texas.

column1: Pejman Yousefzadeh explained just how stupid Yglesias's time zone piece was
column2: writing at Ricochet : ""I grant you that there are times when confusion does take place
column3: but seriously
column4: who cares? Is befuddlement regarding time zones really such a pressing issue that Matthew Yglesias has to take to writing an article demanding that we abolish them? Don‚Äôt the people at Vox have anything better to write about?""

column1: Apparently they don't.
5. Yglesias doesn't understand Florida's geography very well. Yglesias wrote a short blurb in The Atlantic in 2007
column2: in which he began thinking aloud about the city of Miami.

column1: I'd been interested to know what
column2: if anything
column3: is legally or practically preventing the city from just expanding further and further west if anyone happens to know
column4: Yglesias said.

column1: People immediately pointed the obvious answer: Miami couldn't do so because there was this thing called a swamp‚Äìmost of which is The Everglades National Park‚Äìcausing such development to be difficult to accomplish.
Yes
column2: yes
column3: commenters I know it's a freaking swamp but there's plenty of development on ex-swampland in Florida -- hence all the canals and weird-looking lakes
column4: an exasperated Yglesias wrote in an update.

column1: Except that the land is not ""ex-swampland
column2: it's an actual swamp . Maybe Yglesias shouldn't write a blurb that involves him thinking aloud.

column1: 6. Yglesias thinks that lying is perfectly fine...if you're a politician. Yglesias found himself getting smacked around on Twitter after he advocated for high-speed rail advocates to provide an ""unrealistically optimistic"" projection about the number of riders that will use the boondoggle program to obtain funding from the government.
For better or for worse
column2: that‚Äôs politics
column3: Yglesias wrote at ThinkProgress .

column1: On Twitter
column2: Yglesias attempted to justify it by writing: ""Fighting dishonesty with dishonesty is sometimes the right thing for advocates to do
column3: yes.""

column1: And yet
column2: Yglesias had the temerity to accuse journalist Eli Lake of being dishonest on Twitter.

column1: Yglesias must have realized how badly he put himself in a Catch-22 when he told the Daily Caller to ""go f*** yourself"" when they tried to interview him about the Twitter incident.

7. Yglesias once hailed the Department of Veteran Affairs as a healthcare model the country should emulate. The Federalist 's Sean Davis pointed to Yglesias writing in 2009 that the VA was ""producing the highest quality care in the country. Their turnaround points the way toward solving America‚Äôs health-care crisis."" Yglesias also tweeted at GOP chairman Reince Priebus in 2013
column2: ""Will @Reince be explaining the evils of socialized medicine to veterans?"" This tweet was also deleted
column3: and for good reason
column4: since the VA has caused 307
column5: 000 veteran deaths due to ""systemic"" problems with the agency.

column1: 8. Yglesias doesn't understand the purpose of the Senate. Yglesias wrote the following for ThinkProgress in 2009
column2: per the Guardian :

column1: If you add together the two Republican Senators from Wyoming with the one from Alaska
column2: one from South Dakota
column3: one from New Hampshire
column4: two from Maine
column5: two from Idaho
column6: two from Nebraska
column7: one from Nevada
column8: two from Utah
column9: two from Kansas
column10: two from Mississippi
column11: one from Iowa
column12: two from Oklahoma
column13: two from Kentucky
column14: one from Louisiana
column15: two from South Carolina
column16: and two from Alabama
column17: the 28 of them collectively represent (on a system in which you attribute half the population of a given state to a senator) 11.98 percent of the American population. Meanwhile
column18: Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein together represent 11.95 percent of the American population.

column1: Now of course Texas is also a big state (though at 7.81 percent of the population it's a lot smaller than California) and there are small states (like Vermont and North Dakota) that have two Democratic Senators. So the point here isn't a narrowly partisan one
column2: though the wacky apportionment of the Senate does have a partisan valence. The point is that this is an unfair and bizarre way to run things. If you consider that the mean state would contain two percent of the population
column3: we have just 34 Senators representing the above-average states even though they collectively contain 69.15 percent of the population. The other 66 Senators represent about 30 percent of the people. If the Iranians were to succeed in overthrowing their theocracy and set about to write a new constitution
column4: nobody in their right mind would recommend this system to them.

column1: In three paragraphs of rambling
column2: incoherent nonsense
column3: Yglesias missed the fact that the purpose of having two senators representing each state was so states with smaller populations would be properly represented and not have their interests swallowed up by states with larger populations.

column1: 9. Yglesias doesn't understand America's financial system. Yglesias showed his ignorance of the issue when he wrote in a 2013 Slate column that there were ""far far far too many banks"" in the country
column2: as there were 6
column3: 891 at the time. Yglesias bloviated that all these small banks were somehow dangerous:

column1: 1. They are poorly managed: You know how the best and brightest of Wall Street royally screw up sometimes? This doesn't get better when you drill down to the less-bright and not-as-good guys. It gets worse. And since small banks finance themselves almost entirely with loans from FDIC-ensured depositors
column2: nobody is watching the store. In effect
column3: the well-managed banks are being taxed to subsidize the poorly managed ones. The dubious decision-making doesn't get as complicated as what you see on Wall Street‚Äîit's mostly just classic boom-and-bust pro-cyclical commercial real estate loans‚Äîbut it creates all the same problems. 2. They can't be regulated: Since these banks are so small
column4: they could be easily driven out of business by high regulatory compliance costs. So since American public policy is perversely committed to preserving them
column5: small banks regularly get various kinds of carve-outs from regulations. And once the carve-outs exist
column6: they create pressure for extension further up the food chain. Other times the compliance issues of small firms become a reason to simply not do tight regulation. 3. They can't compete: If you want the JPMorgan Chases and Bank of Americas of the world to be held to account
column7: you need both regulation and competition. But a bank serving a handful of rural counties or a single midsized city doesn't offer any real competition. Having a large share of America's banking sector tied up in tiny firms only makes it easier for a handful of big boys to monopolize big-time finance.

column1: Davis debunked Yglesias's argument
column2: which was devoid of citations and falsely claimed that there haven't been any new banks formed in recent years (there were at least four in 2013.)

column1: Yglesias' arguments are so poorly reasoned and so poorly supported that it leads one to question whether his post was thoughtlessly regurgitated from anti-community bank talking points promoted by the big banks ('You guys
column2: the Wall Street banks that nearly destroyed America aren‚Äôt the problem. Small community banks where bankers actually know the borrowers are the real problem. Don‚Äôt worry about the facts. Just go with it.')
column3: Davis wrote in The Federalist . ""I'm actually at a loss to come up with a more charitable explanation.""

column1: 10. Yglesias thinks that black conservatives are a recent phenomenon. After reading a review of a Booker T. Washington biography
column2: Yglesias started thinking about ""'black conservative' political tradition
column3: prompting him to write in a 2009 ThinkProgress post
column4: ""It's only extremely recently that the idea of an African-American aligning himself
column5: √† la Clarence Thomas
column6: with the mainstream conservative movement in America could be remotely possible. But even so
column7: that didn‚Äôt mean there was no ideological conflict in black politics or that general rightist sentiments somehow didn‚Äôt exist.""

column1: This is patently false
column2: as Damon Root explained in Reason :

column1: Actually
column2: the great Harlem Renaissance author and journalist George Schuyler‚Äîwho was known as the ‚Äúblack H.L. Mencken‚Äù‚Äîpublished ‚Äúgeneral rightist sentiments‚Äù long before Clarence Thomas came on the scene
column3: including Schuyler‚Äôs unambiguously titled 1966 autobiography Black and Conservative. And the celebrated novelist and folklorist Zora Neale Hurston both endorsed conservative Sen. Robert A. Taft in the 1952 presidential election and repeatedly attacked FDR‚Äôs New Deal...

column1: 11. Yglesias expressed joy when Andrew Breitbart died. Following Breitbart's death
column2: Yglesias tweeted : ""Conventions around dead people are ridiculous. The world outlook is slightly improved with @AndrewBrietbart [sic] dead.""

column1: This tweet has also been deleted
column2: and for good reason‚Äìcelebrating the death of someone just because of political differences is worse than stupid
column3: it's ghoulish
column4: vile and reprehensible. And Slate defended Yglesias
column5: stating that he ""is a very passionate journalist and Slate values that passion.""

column1: Apparently Slate believes that ""passion"" trumps basic human decency and a reasonable IQ level
column2: and Yglesias certainly does not possess the latter two qualities. column1: A YouTube video that's making the rounds appears to show a man being beaten and robbed in the middle of the street by a group laughing and shouting that he voted for Trump.
In the clip (below)

column4: dummy
column5: while a woman next to him shouts
column6: ""You voted Trump? You voted Trump? Damn! Yeah
column7: he voted Trump! Damn!""

column1: The man continues to struggle against his two attackers until he gets up and sees that a woman
column2: presumably associated with the attackers

column1: Get out of my car
column2: the man yells as he approaches the women
column3: who shouts back
column4: ""You're gonna pay for my shit!"" One of the attackers returns and starts punching the man from behind in the back of the head and then continues swinging as the man turns around.

column1: The camera man and his companion continue their color commentary by laughing and yelling

column1: The video ends with the group acknowledging that they should leave before the police arrive.

column1: 2261;f069b0cc434cc1994a090dc8dc02e16abbfcc894;0;;2016-11-11T03:38:00.000+02:00;This Is The Best Picture In Human History | Daily Wire;"This Is The Best Picture In Human History By: November 10
This is the best picture in human history.
It is the best picture in human history because it tells the entire tale of both parties
column2: the republic
column3: and why we are where we are.

column1: On the left side of this picture
column2: we have Donald Trump ‚Äì a reality television star and lifelong vulgarian
column3: the new president-elect of the United States. He points his fingers and smiles that Apprentice smile as he makes a point.

column1: On the right side of this picture
column2: we have Barack Obama ‚Äì a man who considered himself a paragon of dignity and rectitude
column3: who thought of himself as a transformative figure and an intellectual giant. He sits next to the man who maintained for years that his birth certificate was a fraud
column4: the man who has the opportunity to undo virtually his entire agenda within the first month of his assumption of office. And Obama
column5: rightly
column6: looks like a man with a pole shoved so far up his rectum that the glint of steel is visible behind his eyes.

column1: Behind Obama sits a bust of Abraham Lincoln
column2: his eyes downcast
column3: mourning for his country.

column1: Yep.
Greatest picture ever.
This is a picture of justice done and karma ascendant. Barack Obama‚Äôs image of himself is not accurate ‚Äì to Americans
column2: Obama is a reality TV show star. He transformed the presidency from a dignified office into a selfie-stick
column3: celebrity-ridden sinkhole of Hollywood glitterati
column4: hobnobbing with Glozell and Macklemore
column5: cracking wise about the presidency with Jimmy Kimmel before saying that a reality star like Trump could never be president.

column1: This picture looks like the chickens coming home to roost
column2: as Obama‚Äôs former pastor might put it.

column1: And then there‚Äôs Lincoln.
Lincoln
column2: who gave his life and spent his presidency building the groundwork for racial toleration
column3: mourning behind Barack Obama
column4: who has spent his presidency polarizing for electoral gain.

column1: Lincoln
column2: who represented wisdom
column3: mourning behind a clown as the clown gestures to the assembled crowd. Given Republicans‚Äô domination of the Senate and the Congress
column4: I have hopes for Trump‚Äôs presidency ‚Äì I hope he keeps his promises and that he becomes a better man and a wonderful president
column5: and believe he has every obligation to fulfill his conservative campaign promises ‚Äì but Trump occupying Lincoln‚Äôs office is
column6: at best
column7: a jarring visual.

column1: 2266;df9cb42d62d6bcaff8f21a17365c48df313a6724;0;;2016-11-14T20:10:54.044+02:00;3 Thoughts On Steve Bannon As White House ‚ÄôChief Strategist‚Äô - dailywire.com;"3 Thoughts On Steve Bannon As White House 'Chief Strategist' By: Ben Shapiro November 14
So
column2: in a not-unexpected move
column3: Donald Trump has elevated former Breitbart News CEO Steve Bannon to chief strategist of the White House.

column1: When I left Breitbart back in March
column2: I accused Bannon of turning Breitbart News into Trump Pravda ; as I wrote
column3: ‚ÄúIndeed
column4: Breitbart News
column5: under the chairmanship of Steve Bannon
column6: has put a stake through the heart of Andrew‚Äôs legacy. In my opinion
column7: Steve Bannon is a bully
column8: and has sold out Andrew‚Äôs mission in order to back another bully
column9: Donald Trump; he has shaped the company into Trump‚Äôs personal Pravda
column10: to the extent that he abandoned and undercut his own reporter.‚Äù

column1: That decision paid off for Bannon ‚Äì in August
column2: he became Trump‚Äôs campaign ‚ÄúCEO.‚Äù At that point
column3: I wrote this piece describing who Bannon was
column4: and this one for The Washington Post describing his probable impact on the campaign .

column1: With Bannon‚Äôs accession to a top White House role
column2: it‚Äôs time to answer some brief questions about the man and what he‚Äôs likely to do.

column1: Is Bannon Anti-Semitic And Racist? I have no evidence that Bannon‚Äôs a racist or that he‚Äôs an anti-Semite; the Huffington Post‚Äôs blaring headline ‚ÄúWHITE NATIONALIST IN THE WHITE HOUSE‚Äù is overstated
column2: at the very least. With that said
column3: as I wrote at The Washington Post in August
column4: Bannon has openly embraced the racist and anti-Semitic alt-right ‚Äì he called his Breitbart ‚Äú the platform of the alt-right .‚Äù Milo Yiannopoulos
column5: the star writer at the site
column6: is an alt-right popularizer
column7: even as he continuously declares with a wink that he‚Äôs not a member. The left‚Äôs opposition to Trump
column8: and their attempts to declare all Trump support the alt-right have obfuscated what the movement is. The movement isn‚Äôt all Trump supporters. It‚Äôs not conservatives unsatisfied with Paul Ryan
column9: nor is it people angry at the media. Bannon knows that. He‚Äôs a smart man
column10: not an ignorant one. The alt-right
column11: in a nutshell
column12: believes that Western culture is inseparable from European ethnicity . I have no evidence Bannon believes that personally. But he‚Äôs happy to pander to those people and make common cause with them in order to transform conservatism into European far-right nationalist populism. That means that the alt-right will cheer Bannon along as he marbles Trump‚Äôs speeches with talk of ‚Äúglobalism‚Äù ‚Äì and that Bannon won‚Äôt be pushing Trump to dump the racists and anti-Semites who support Trump anytime soon. After all
column13: they love Bannon ‚Äì actual white supremacists like Peter Brimelow called his August appointment ‚Äúgreat news
column14: ‚Äù and Richard Spencer explained
column15: ‚ÄúBreitbart has elective affinities with the Alt Right
column16: and the Alt Right has clearly influenced Breitbart. In this way
column17: Breitbart has acted as a ‚Äògateway‚Äô to Alt Right ideas and writers. I don‚Äôt think it has done this deliberately; again
column18: it‚Äôs a matter of elective affinities.‚Äù That doesn‚Äôt mean Bannon will push racist or anti-Semitic policy
column19: or that he‚Äôll be anti-Israel himself ‚Äì unless it serves his interests.

column1: What Does Bannon‚Äôs Accession Mean? Bannon has goals. One of those goals is maximization of personal power
column2: which is why he spent the last decade and a half glomming onto powerful right-wing personalities (Bachmann
column3: Morris
column4: Palin)
column5: kissing their asses
column6: and then moving on up the chain. With Breitbart and Trump
column7: he picked two winners in a row ‚Äì and that means he‚Äôs now at the pinnacle of American power.

column1: So
column2: what will he do with that power? He‚Äôll target enemies. Bannon is one of the most vicious people in politics
column3: which is why I‚Äôve been joking for months that should Trump win
column4: I‚Äôd be expecting my IRS audit any moment. That wasn‚Äôt completely a joke. He likes to destroy people.

column1: But more importantly
column2: Bannon‚Äôs interested in turning the Republican Party into a far-right European party. Because Republicans will like some of the policy that comes with that
column3: it could happen. Here‚Äôs what I wrote in March about the Trump movement :

column1: Trump is a European-style response to the European-style leftism of Barack Obama. He‚Äôs a soft European-style populist
column2: from his interventionist economics to his closed-borders foreign policy. As I wrote in December
column3: ‚ÄúCompare Trump‚Äôs platform with that of Marine Le Pen
column4: whose French National Front poses a significant threat to the national political establishment. She calls for harsher penalties for criminals
column5: significant restrictions on Muslim immigration to France
column6: protectionism on trade
column7: a restoration of the Franc as the national currency rather than the Euro
column8: and big government in terms of health care. This sounds a lot like Trump.‚Äù But the European right is not the American right. The American right believes in Constitutional ideas about checks and balances and federalism and negative rights from government. The European right doesn‚Äôt believe any of these things. Should Trump win
column9: we could watch American conservatism lose the only party it has ever had.

column1: That‚Äôs the plan. Yesterday
column2: The Daily Beast reported that Bannon reached out to Le Pen for ‚Äúglobal ultra-right coalition.‚Äù Over the weekend Le Pen met with Nigel Farage of the UK Independent Party. And Trump met with Farage shortly after being elected. Bannon has always wanted to burn down the GOP. That‚Äôs still his goal. He wants it replaced with an American National Front party in fact if not in name.

column1: Which War Will Bannon Lead? Bannon considers himself a wartime consigliore ‚Äì always at war. Always. So the only question left is this: what will Bannon‚Äôs actual role be? It‚Äôs difficult to tell
column2: since Trump announced the Bannon hire at the same time he announced that former RNC chairman Reince Priebus as his chief of staff. What will their relationship be like? Ed Morrissey of HotAir thinks that Bannon will lead the anti-media fight
column3: and Reince will coordinate with Congress. That would be the best possible scenario.

column1: Others have speculated that Bannon has been added to the team as a sop to the populist base
column2: which would be angry at Trump hopping into bed with the most establishment-y fellow in Washington. That
column3: too
column4: would be fine.

column1: It‚Äôs hard to tell from the outside what‚Äôs happening
column2: but here‚Äôs a third theory: Reince is the bagman for Trump
column3: and Bannon‚Äôs whispering in Trump‚Äôs ear. That would fit the fact pattern here
column4: given Reince‚Äôs outsized praise for Bannon this morning: ‚Äúwise and smart‚Ä¶very
column5: very smart
column6: very temperate.‚Äù Bannon is anything but temperate to those who disagree. He‚Äôs a consummate bully to anyone who disagrees; he's actually malevolent. Priebus may not have seen a lot of disagreement because he‚Äôs the one catering to Bannon‚Äôs agenda.

column1: If Bannon‚Äôs leading and Reince is following
column2: that bodes ill for the Republican agenda. Bannon opposes the Republican Party
column3: hates Paul Ryan ‚Äì minutes after the joint Bannon/Priebus announcement
column4: Breitbart News approvingly tweeted about a Congressional rebellion against Speaker Ryan ‚Äì and wants to watch it all ‚Äúburn.‚Äù Bannon loves the firefight. The only question is which direction he‚Äôll turn his fire. column1: 2269;8554a69aa72a1b278ca7dd5cb53b5db32b03b11e;0;;2016-11-17T13:03:00.000+02:00;Shapiro Eviscerates Raucous Protesters At University Of Wisconsin | Daily Wire;"Shapiro Eviscerates Raucous Protesters At University Of Wisconsin By: Hank Berrien November 16
Daily Wire Editor-in-Chief Ben Shapiro spoke at the University of Wisconsin-Madison on Wednesday night
column2: and amid raucous leftist protesters who consistently tried to interrupt him and even blocked him from being seen by the audience by creating a human wall in front of him
column3: found a way to respond with hilarious repartee that left the audience howling and the protesters eventually filing meekly out of the auditorium.

column1: After the ovation he received on entering
column2: Shapiro quipped
column3: ‚ÄúHey look at this. A campus that doesn‚Äôt actually try to arrest me when I come.‚Äù He continued
column4: ‚ÄúBefore I begin
column5: I did come bearing gifts for the social justice warriors in this room. I hear you‚Äôve started wearing these safety pins around because you want to show your fellow college students how you‚Äôre not one of these awful
column6: terrible Trump people
column7: that you‚Äôre sensitive
column8: and that you want to signal your virtue
column9: so I‚Äôve brought along these safety pins
column10: (holding up safety pins) and I also brought you something to wear them with ‚Äì this diaper.""

column1: Shapiro then held up a diaper
column2: prompting huge laughs from the audience.

column1: When a protester yelled at Shapiro that he should be ‚Äúwearing a swastika
column2: ‚Äù Shapiro held out his yarmulke
column3: then fired back
column4: ‚ÄúIn case you hadn‚Äôt noticed
column5: the folks with the swastikas aren‚Äôt too nice to my type.‚Äù

column1: Shapiro continued
column2: ‚ÄúStop being self-indulgent children; stop pretending that everybody who voted for Trump is a vicious racist; it‚Äôs your right to protest
column3: of course
column4: but you just make yourself look like an idiot when you cry over a duly-held election ‚Ä¶ Donald Trump doesn‚Äôt care about your protest. Donald Trump is sitting somewhere in Trump Tower eating a steak and bathing in your salty
column5: salty tears.‚Äù

column1: Referring to the attempt by leftists to prevent people who weren‚Äôt university students from attending Shapiro‚Äôs lecture
column2: Shapiro opined: ‚ÄúI hear that a lot of folks at this publicly-funded university want this campus to become a sanctuary campus for illegal immigrants. I do have a quick question: if this campus can be a sanctuary for people in the country illegally
column3: why are so many people trying to ban American citizens from this community from coming to this lecture? And by the way
column4: I‚Äôm aware of this private Facebook page titled ‚ÄòF(***) White Supremacy: Interrupting Ben Shapiro.' With all due respect
column5: ‚ÄòF‚Äô you right back
column6: gang.‚Äù

column1: After the applause subsided and Shapiro joked about how both Black Lives Mater and the KKK target him
column2: the real fun began. Protesters stood up
column3: chanting
column4: ‚ÄúShame‚Äù over and over again.

column1: Shapiro quipped
column2: ‚ÄúWow
column3: it‚Äôs like Game of Thrones . Should I get undressed and walk down the aisle?‚Äù

column1: The bulk of the crowd started booing the protesters. Shapiro addressed the protesters
column2: saying
column3: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to talk with you
column4: ‚Äù but they responded by screaming ‚Äúsafety‚Äù over and over. Shapiro joked
column5: ‚ÄúDid somebody fart?‚Äù The crowd responded to the protesters by chanting
column6: ‚ÄúUSA.‚Äù

column1: Shapiro replied
column2: ‚ÄúI tell you try not to be children; the first thing you do is start screaming like my two-year-old.‚Äù He added
column3: ‚ÄúYou see
column4: this is how conservatives actually treat people; you stand up and you interrupt and you shout ‚ÄòSafety
column5: ‚Äù and you‚Äôre perfectly safe. Look at that. It‚Äôs amazing.‚Äù That provoked sustained applause.

column1: When the protesters started screaming ‚ÄúShame‚Äù again
column2: Shapiro eviscerated them
column3: pointing out
column4: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre going to pick a chant like ‚ÄòShame
column5: ‚Äô watch Game of Thrones first. The bad guys shout ‚ÄòShame.‚Äô‚Äù The audience loved that line. On a roll
column6: Shapiro continued
column7: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not changing anybody‚Äôs mind
column8: All you‚Äôre showing everybody is that your collective IQ
column9: if it were channeled into electricity
column10: night be able to toast a piece of bread lightly.‚Äù

column1: He continued
column2: ‚ÄúOkay
column3: can we talk now
column4: or are you going to keep shouting? Now‚Äôs your chance to get it out. Let‚Äôs hear your feelings. C‚Äômon. Just go for it. Or is it going to be like every thirty seconds; like an annoying microwave timer?‚Äù

column1: When the protesters resumed chanting
column2: Shapiro responded
column3: ‚ÄúIf you guys want to talk
column4: we can talk
column5: If you want to shout
column6: get the hell out.‚Äù More applause.

column1: Shapiro fired
column2: ‚ÄúFor God's sake
column3: at least wait until I say something that offends you before getting offended.""

column1: Shapiro returned to deconstructing the term ‚Äúsocial justice.‚Äù When the protesters started again
column2: a woman who runs a soup kitchen stood up
column3: and admonished the protesters that she had driven for ten hours that day
column4: and that they should ‚Äúshut freaking up and listen to the man speak.‚Äù That prompted a standing ovation from the crowd and Shapiro. too. He added
column5: ‚ÄúSee
column6: that‚Äôs what a decent
column7: hard-working person sounds like as opposed to a loser student here on the public dime
column8: presumably.‚Äù

column1: Shapiro returned to his speech: ‚ÄúRacial diversity doesn‚Äôt mean anything; decency means everything ‚Ä¶ Diversity isn‚Äôt our strength; decency is our strength.‚Äù He turned to the protesters: Remember that? Decency.‚Äù
The protesters screamed back
column2: ‚ÄúShame!‚Äù Shapiro fired back
column3: ‚ÄúDecency!‚Äù The protesters chanted ‚ÄúShame‚Äù but the crowd soon joined Shapiro in chanting ‚ÄúDecency
column4: ‚Äù shutting the protesters up.

column1: As Shapiro spoke of the falsity of ‚Äúwhite privilege
column2: ‚Äù the protesters formed a line in front of Shapiro
column3: prompting him to quip
column4: ‚ÄúIf you guys are all going to come up here
column5: can we all just have circle time or something?‚Äù

column1: The protesters chanted ‚ÄúSafety‚Äù for a minute and a half
column2: but then the crowd started yelling back
column3: ‚ÄúFree speech matters.‚Äù Shapiro turned to the blackboard behind him and wrote in capital letters
column4: ‚ÄúMORONS‚Äù That again prompted cheering.

column1: One member of the audience yelled to the protesters
column2: ‚ÄúAt least tell us what you want
column3: or otherwise
column4: just get out!‚Äù That brought a sustained ovation.

column1: After one protester tried to deliver a whiny monologue
column2: the protesters started shouting ‚ÄúSafety‚Äù again
column3: then filed out
column4: yelling ‚ÄúF*** white supremacy‚Äù while flipping off Shapiro and the entire audience. That prompted the crowd to sing
column5: ‚ÄúNa-na-na-na
column6: na-na-na-na
column7: hey
column8: hey
column9: good-bye.‚Äù It also promoted this from Shapiro:

column1: Even after leaving the lecture hall
column2: protestors continued to pound on the door.

column1: After Shapiro explained why the protesters had not been arrested
column2: as the university stated that it gave the protesters time to protest at the front of the stage
column3: or otherwise it would have to shut down the entire event
column4: he continued
column5: ‚ÄúAll I can wonder is if the administration would allow the same sort of privilege for any sort of conservative who decided to do this at a leftist event.‚Äù

column1: Even after leaving the lecture hall
column2: protestors continued to pound on the door
column3: prompting Shapiro to quip
column4: ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt this school give homework? Does anybody have a job around here? I guess when you‚Äôre majoring in gender and diversity studies you have a lot of time on your hands.‚Äù

column1: Shapiro noted that he had engaged in a back-and-forth with one of the protesters
column2: who accused him of being a white supremacist. When he asked her why she thought so
column3: she replied that she got that impression from his image. He fired back
column4: ‚ÄúReally? Was it the yarmulke that did it for you?‚Äù

column1: He took another shot at the protesters during the speech
column2: noting that people were born unequal
column3: and adding
column4: ‚ÄúSome people us are born rich; some of us are born poor; some of us are born smart; some of us are born protesters.‚Äù

column1: The rest of the speech was vintage Shapiro
column2: as was the Q&A afterward. Even the chalk was impressive:

column1: Went back to the lecture hall and grabbed the EXACT piece of chalk @benshapiro used to write MORONS! #FactsNotFeelings #onlyatYAF pic.twitter.com/W0Ch06SaGR ‚Äî Japheth Patterson (@japhood) November 17
Video of entire event below:

2270;503fbf2eb5f540b51fb866037222721dad652a94;0;;2016-11-17T06:06:00.000+02:00;Gallup: Americans More Confident In Trump Since Election | Daily Wire;Gallup: Americans More Confident In Trump Since Election By: Robert Kraychik November 16, 2016 A Gallup poll published on Wednesday indicates that 51% of Americans are more confident in Donald Trump‚Äôs ability to serve as president following last week‚Äôs presidential election. 40%, conversely, are less confident. Partisanship was strongly correlated with the poll‚Äôs respondents‚Äô responses: 95% of Trump voters said they were more confident in presidential capacity after the election, with 75% of Clinton voters saying they were now less confident. The same question was put to Americans by Gallup following the 1992 and 2000 presidential elections. Five weeks after the 1992 election, 84% of Bill Clinton voters said they were more confident in his presidential capability as opposed to 23% of George H. Bush voters and 37% of Ross Perot voters. In 2000, 85% of George W. Bush voters were more confident in his ability to be president as opposed to 29% of Al Gore voters. 2273;50bb0f1a1e8e9ecbc8c2e8b327863a1a0d05b6f4;0;;2016-11-18T19:01:54.993+02:00;Media Claim Trump Transition Chaos. Trump's Way Ahead of Schedule. | Daily Wire;Media Claim Trump Transition Chaos. Trump's Way Ahead of Schedule. By: Ben Shapiro November 18
The media
column2: desperately in search of a narrative to cast the incoming Trump administration as dangerously incompetent
column3: are once again overplaying their hands. Instead of focusing on the nepotistic fact that Trump relies heavily on his son-in-law
column4: Jared Kushner
column5: and his daughter
column6: Ivanka ‚Äì he invited them to a state meeting with Japan ‚Äì they‚Äôre trying to claim that he just isn‚Äôt moving fast enough on appointments.

column1: That‚Äôs nuts.
Barack Obama didn‚Äôt name his picks for Secretary of State
column2: Defense
column3: or Attorney General until December 1
column4: nearly a month after the November 4
column5: 2008 election. George W. Bush didn‚Äôt name his picks for State
column6: Defense
column7: or Attorney General until mid-December (December 16 for Colin Powell
column8: December 28 for Donald Rumsfeld
column9: December 22 for John Ashcroft). Bill Clinton didn‚Äôt name his picks for those positions until at least December 22. George H.W. Bush was the fastest off the mark ‚Äì he named James Baker Secretary of State the day after the November 8 election. Ronald Reagan waited until December 11 to get started; Jimmy Carter waited until December 3.

column1: We‚Äôre still waiting on Trump‚Äôs State and Defense picks
column2: but he‚Äôs already out of the gate with Senator Jeff Sessions for Attorney General. It‚Äôs November 17.

column1: The media are so eager to bury Trump‚Äôs administration that they are falling all over themselves to do so. Instead of soberly covering potential problems with top level picks ‚Äì Steve Bannon
column2: for example
column3: is a rotten pick
column4: but not because he‚Äôs a racist or anti-Semite ‚Äì the media keep proclaiming THE END IS NEAR. This sort of alarmism doesn‚Äôt convince Americans
column5: who don‚Äôt really see why there‚Äôs any giant rush to appoint people who aren‚Äôt going to be formally considered by the Senate until January 20 anyway.

column1: If this election was about repudiation of the media ‚Äì and it was ‚Äì the media aren‚Äôt doing themselves any favors when they promulgate fact-free narratives while simultaneously attempting to label conservative outlets ‚Äúfake news.‚Äù For years
column2: Americans have assumed that the leftist media are ladling them fake news each day. Each day
column3: the media seem determined to prove them right. Tags ";english;2016-11-18T19:01:54.993+02:00;dailywire.com;US;15846.0;Media Claim Trump Transition Chaos.
