column1: 2275;b4e745077e89a96f14636315c4e221e366bf95f7;0;;2016-11-19T06:09:00.000+02:00;7 Things You Need To Know About Trump Attorney General Pick Jeff Sessions | Daily Wire;"7 Things You Need To Know About Trump Attorney General Pick Jeff Sessions By: Aaron Bandler November 18
President-elect Donald Trump has announced that his selection for attorney general is Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-AL)
column2: who has long been a favorite of conservatives. The Democrats already have the long knives out for Sessions
column3: spit-balling their usual accusations of racism‚Äìwhich should indicate that Sessions will be an effective attorney general.

column1: Here are seven things you need to know about Sessions.
1. Sessions has a 78 percent liberty score on Conservative Review . Sessions has been in the Senate for 20 years
column2: and has been described by the Washington Times as ""a tea partier before the tea party was cool
column3: per Conservative Review 's biography .

column1: 2. Sessions has been one of the leaders in the Senate in fighting against amnesty. For instance
column2: Sessions was among the most prominent members of the Senate leading the opposition to the Gang of Eight Bill. National Review
column3: which dubbed Sessions ""amnesty's worst enemy
column4: explained how Sessions would reveal ""true facts"" about the bill in an attempt to persuade some senators that hadn't decided how to vote on the legislation. Sessions and Sen. David Vitter (R-LA) would find other clever ways to oppose the bill
column5: such as ""an amendment to a resolution honoring the late Latino union organizer Cesar Chavez"" in which Vitter noted Chavez's opposition to illegal immigration
column6: putting Sen. Bob Menendez (D-NJ) in ""an awkward position.""

column2: Sessions introduced a bill that would overhaul the immigration system
column3: according to Conservative Review : Overturned the Zadvydas v. Davis Supreme Court case that Obama is using as an excuse to release criminal aliens after six months of detention Explicitly deputized the states to enforce federal immigration law Eliminated sanctuary cities by cutting off DHS and DOJ law enforcement grants Expedited deportation of gang members Applied the ramifications of treating illegal aliens as criminal aliens to those convicted of drunk driving Clamped down on loopholes that allow legal immigrants who commit crimes to continue on the path to citizenship instead of getting deported (this would address cases like the legal immigrant who murdered the family in the Washington
column4: D.C. ‚Äúmansion murders‚Äù)

column1: Sessions has also fought efforts to increase legal immigration
column2: as he has railed against it as ""the primary source of low-wage immigration into the United States.""

column1: What we need now is immigration moderation: slowing the pace of new arrivals so that wages can rise
column2: welfare rolls can shrink and the forces of assimilation can knit us all more closely together
column3: Sessions wrote in a 2015 op-ed in the Washington Post .

column1: 3. Sessions has also spearheaded efforts to crack down on budgetary issues. According to Conservative Review 's biography of Sessions:
In January 2011
column2: he was named Ranking Member of the Senate Budget Committee. In this capacity
column3: he led the Republican charge against Majority Leader Harry Reid and Barack Obama for not offering a serious budget proposal
column4: given that the Senate had not passed a budget since April 2009. He has fought guerilla warfare
column5: often a lonely battle
column6: against Democrats spending by raising budget point of orders against the breach of budget caps. He has even fought his own party when his office put out devastating research against the Ryan-Murray budget deal. Sessions has also been a strong leader on welfare reform and publishing studies and data on the extent of the welfare state.

column1: Sessions has voted against the TARP bailout
column2: stimulus bills
column3: and increases to the debt limit and has traveled through his state ""with charts warning of the United States' 'crippling' debt
column4: per the Washington Post .

column1: 4. Sessions endorsed Trump early on. To the surprise of many in the establishment
column2: Sessions endorsed Trump in February
column3: declaring
column4: ""I believe we are on a movement that must not fade away. This is a campaign
column5: this is a movement. The American people are not happy with their government.""

column1: It shouldn't have come as a surprise though
column2: given Session's record on immigration and that Sessions tends to be more protectionist on trade.

column1: 5. Sessions is well-liked by his Senate colleagues on a personal level. According to the Washington Post :
Say what you will about him
column2: former longtime Senate Democratic communications aide Jim Manley told the Almanac of American Politics. ""He was always nice to [the late Ted] Kennedy and other Democrats as well.""

column1: Even people who have run against him have nice things to say about him. Stanley-Becker talked to Susan Parker
column2: a Democrat who tried to unseat Sessions in 2002. During a debate
column3: she asked for a tissue and Sessions handed her one. She joked she would use it to dry her eyes when Sessions made her cry
column4: and he responded: ""Please don‚Äôt say that. That‚Äôs my nightmare. I promise I‚Äôll be nice.""

column1: It's no wonder then that Sessions will likely be confirmed by the Senate.
6. Accusations of racism against Sessions are absurd. When President Ronald Reagan nominated Sessions
column2: who at the time was a U.S. attorney
column3: to a federal judge
column4: the Democrats smeared Sessions with accusations of racism
column5: which included: Calling a black attorney ""boy."" Quipping about the Ku Klux Klan: ""I used to think they were OK
column6: but they are pot smokers."" Joking that a white attorney was ""a traitor to his race"" because he was collaborating with civil rights groups. Calling the NAACP and ACLU ""un-American."" Prosecuting a civil rights organization for voter fraud.

column1: The last point isn't racist at all. The jokes
column2: as Ben Shapiro has written
column3: were made ""in front of the black lawyer; even the lawyer accusing Sessions of racism acknowledged that Sessions was joking."" Clearly Sessions meant them as harmless jokes. Sessions has also denied calling the lawyer ""boy."" The civil rights group Sessions prosecuted has faced accusations of voter fraud for many years.

column1: Sessions' record on race actually shows that he has consistently fought against racism
column2: as The Weekly Standard 's Mark Hemingway writes:

column1: As a U.S. Attorney he filed several cases to desegregate schools in Alabama. And he also prosecuted the head of the state Klan
column2: Henry Francis Hays
column3: for abducting and killing Michael Donald
column4: a black teenager selected at random. Sessions insisted on the death penalty for Hays. When he was later elected the state Attorney General
column5: Sessions followed through and made sure the Hays executed. The successful prosecution of Hays also led to a $7 million civil judgment against the Klan
column6: effectively breaking the back of the KKK in Alabama.

column1: 7. As attorney general
column2: Sessions would uphold the rule of law. The reason why Sessions has been such an immigration hawk is that he supports the rule of law. He has also fought against judicial activist nominees and is a strong supporter of the death penalty. Between that and his legal background as a U.S. attorney and Alabama attorney general
column3: there is every reason to believe that Sessions will follow the law and not politicize the Justice Department.

column1: His interpretation of the law will not please everyone
column2: but I predict it will be fairly applied without fear or favor
column3: Robert Driscoll
column4: former deputy assistant attorney general
column5: wrote in National Review . ""Clear cases will be prosecuted with vigor. Creative interpretations of the law may cease
column6: but the meat-and-potatoes work of the division (intentional discrimination
column7: police misconduct
column8: disability law) will continue apace
column9: conducted without impropriety or political favoritism. That alone will be a breath of fresh air."" column1: 2280;54195421d39faf3fc79d210f5bae04faf39bb68e;0;;2016-11-21T21:18:43.762+02:00;Democratic Congressman Threatens Violence If GOP Tries To Defund Planned Parenthood | Daily Wire;"Democratic Congressman Threatens Violence If GOP Tries To Defund Planned Parenthood By: Hank Berrien November 21
The Democratic congressman who is challenging House Minority leader Nancy Pelosi
column2: Ohio Rep. Tim Ryan
column3: threatened a ‚ÄúYoungstown street fight‚Äù if Donald Trump attempts to defund Planned Parenthood.

column1: Speaking with Jake Tapper on CNN‚Äôs State of the Union on Sunday
column2: Ryan intimated that defunding Planned Parenthood wasn‚Äôt the only stimulus he would need to launch violence. He stated
column3: ‚ÄúIf he tries to defund Planned Parenthood
column4: if he tries to kick people off their health insurance
column5: if they try to privatize Medicare or cut taxes for the wealthy
column6: you know
column7: we are going to have a Youngstown street fight in the Capitol.‚Äù

column1: Youngstown has been plagued by violent street fights in the recent past; last May and August violence erupted on the streets of the city.

Ryan called Trump‚Äôs infrastructure plan ‚Äúa bunch of smoke and mirrors.‚Äù He added that he didn‚Äôt blame Pelosi for focusing any specific economic issues: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt in good conscience hang this election around Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs neck
column2: of course. But
column3: moving forward
column4: we have to win congressional seats in areas of the country that voted for Donald Trump
column5: even in my district
column6: where they voted for me and they voted for Donald Trump.‚Äù

column1: Ryan‚Äôs campaign to replace Pelsoi is picking up steam; on Sunday
column2: New York Rep. Kathleen Rice endorsed him
column3: stating
column4: ""He has a lot of good ideas
column5: but maybe most importantly
column6: he also isn‚Äôt suggesting he has all the answers ‚Äî he has stressed that he wants these conversations to be ongoing
column7: that he wants more voices in the conversation so that we can work together to craft our message and forge a winning strategy
column8: Rice said in a statement.

column1: Rice tweeted: Excited to announce my support for @RepTimRyan to serve as our next Democratic Leader. Full statement: https://t.co/LiwFUAxzxa #Dems4Change ‚Äî Kathleen Rice (@RepKathleenRice) November 20

column1: 2281;198c34f79e7e70b936057a7c21af2f021e2a02f1;0;;2016-11-21T23:32:00.000+02:00;SNOWFLAKE: Colbert Didn‚Äôt Want To Write Jokes About Trump Winning | Daily Wire;"SNOWFLAKE: Colbert Didn‚Äôt Want To Write Jokes About Trump Winning By: Hank Berrien November 21
Conversing with fellow Daily Show ‚Äúcomic‚Äù John Oliver at the Montclair Film Festival on Saturday night
column2: Late Show unfunny host Stephen Colbert admitted that he couldn‚Äôt even conceive that Donald trump would win the presidency; so much so that he couldn‚Äôt write jokes bout Trump winning for election night.

column1: In the roughly two-hour discussion and Q&A titled ‚ÄúWow
column2: That Was Weird
column3: ‚Äù Montclair Film Festival executive director Tom Hall set the somber tone by allowing
column4: ""When we planned this evening
column5: I think we all thought we'd be looking back with laughter instead of looking forward with deep concern about the uncertainty we face.""

column1: Speaking of the Late Show ‚Äôs Election Night special on Showtime
column2: Colbert admitted that the staff was prepared for every result of the election except the one that actually transpired:

column1: There was not a bear big enough in the world that we weren't loaded for. We were so loaded for every possible eventuality. We had so many guests. We had so many pre-taped pieces
column2: all based on a different eventuality. We had three shows: Hillary Clinton wins and we know; Hillary Clinton wins and we don‚Äôt know
column3: because it‚Äôs not called before the show‚Äôs over; Donald Trump's going to win and we don‚Äôt know
column4: because everyone said he had such a narrow path to victory. That's not wishful thinking
column5: that's what everyone was saying.

column1: And then there was the last show
column2: which is the show we did
column3: which is Donald Trump is going to win and we know he's going to win. My execs and my writers were like
column4: ‚ÄúYou don't want to write something for that?‚Äù and I'm like
column5: ‚ÄúNo! There is nothing you can write. You don't understand. I have 400 people in my theater. If we know Donald Trump is going to win
column6: it's going to be like doing stand-up comedy for one of those Chilean soccer stadiums where the villagers watch you execute one of the natives. There will be no laughter!‚Äù We only did about 20 minutes of material before we went
column7: ‚ÄúF‚Äî it
column8: it's going to be him
column9: let's just talk for another hour.‚Äù So I think we have two and a half whole shows that you will never see of material that we had to kill that night.

column1: Colbert moaned that the special was ""the hardest thing I've ever done in my life
column2: adding
column3: ""I was tying my tie at 10:30 and I went
column4: 'Oh
column5: he took Ohio. Oh
column6: well
column7: we expected that. He took it by 11 points. Wow! That's not expected.' And then over my guests' shoulders
column8: people kept holding up signs that said
column9: 'Florida
column10: Iowa
column11: Nebraska.'"" He revealed that numerous fake commercials were prepared
column12: but ""none of them were appropriate once we knew we were playing to an audience of the condemned. Our audience was sobbing openly. And those are people who work for me
column13: like my cameramen.""

column1: As Daily Wire Editor-in-Chief Ben Shapiro pointed out years ago
column2: Colbert's manipulative act has been laced with hatred of conservatives:

column1: He engages in Conservativeface. He needs no makeup or bulbous appendage to play a conservative ‚Äì after all
column2: conservatives come in every shape and size. Instead
column3: he acts as though he is a conservative ‚Äì an idiotic
column4: racist
column5: sexist
column6: bigoted
column7: brutal conservative. He out-Archie Bunkers Archie Bunker. His audience laughs and scoffs at brutal religious ‚ÄúColbert‚Äù who wishes to persecute gays; they chortle at evil sexist ‚ÄúColbert‚Äù who thinks men are victims of sexism. This is the purpose of Colbert‚Äôs routine. His show is about pure hatred for conservatives in the same way that blackface was about pure hatred of blacks. In order to justify their racism
column8: racists had to create a false perception of blacks; in the same way
column9: Colbert and his audience can justify their racism only by creating a false perception of conservatives.

column1: On Saturday night
column2: Colbert waxed eloquent over his fear of a Trump presidency
column3: arguing
column4: ""I‚Äôm all for giving him a chance
column5: but don‚Äôt give him an inch. Because I believed everything he said
column6: and I remember everything he said. And it‚Äôs horrifying. It's possible. The job changes a man. That's the cliche of the presidency."" He pontificated:

column1: Every president tries to achieve what they promised and you can say
column2: ‚ÄúWell
column3: there are levers of power in Washington that can slow him down.‚Äù But two things: One is they're cowards. Second is that the levers in Washington are apparently merely attached to blinking red lights that make the people happy when they pull. Because they tried to stop Trump. Everybody tried to stop Trump
column4: do not delude yourself.

column1: Everyone except the people he's going to appoint tried to stop him and they didn't. He owes them nothing. He goes out on the balcony and he says to the crowd
column2: ‚ÄúShall I do it?‚Äù And they say
column3: '‚ÄùYes.‚Äù And he says
column4: ‚ÄúIt shall be so.‚Äù And the balcony is Twitter. He goes onto Twitter and he goes
column5: ‚ÄúWhat do you think? Do you think I'm right?‚Äù That's what scares me
column6: that he owes the checks and balances of Washington nothing because they tried to stop him and they couldn't. And he's a vindictive person. So it's all going to be fine. Merry Christmas. ‚ÄúNo! There is nothing you can write."" Stephen Colbert

column1: Colbert concluded
column2: ""The next person who says to me
column3: 'You must be happy on a certain level
column4: ‚Äô is going to have their eye carved out.‚Äù

So
column2: soon-to-be-ex-President Obama won‚Äôt be going away anytime soon.

column1: After George W. Bush left office
column2: he essentially went silent. He had no criticism for President Obama; he didn‚Äôt sound off about Mitt Romney or Donald Trump. He went away. Not so for Obama. It seems that Barack Obama will follow the Jimmy Carter pathway to Annoyingland: he‚Äôll be commenting whenever possible. After acknowledging that Bush ‚Äúcould not have been more gracious to me when I came in
column3: ‚Äù Obama said
column4: ‚ÄúAs an American citizen who cares deeply about our country
column5: if there are issues that have less to do with the specifics of some legislative proposal or battle or go to core questions about our values and ideals
column6: and if I think that it‚Äôs necessary or helpful for me to defend those ideals
column7: I‚Äôll examine it when it comes.‚Äù

column1: This comes as welcome news for Republicans. Obama‚Äôs policy unpopularity ‚Äì and his tendency to lecture from on high to Americans in rural areas ‚Äì means that he‚Äôll suck all the oxygen out of the room when it comes to criticizing Trump and Republicans. Middle Americans voted for Trump in order to sound off against Obama‚Äôs obvious scorn for them. Here‚Äôs what Obama had to say about those who didn‚Äôt vote for Trump in today‚Äôs Der Spiegel :
If you look at the new generation of Americans
column2: they reflect the vision that I spoke about. They're diverse. They believe in tolerance. They're accepting of things like same-sex marriage. They believe in integration. The problem
column3: though
column4: is that young people are less likely to vote than older people. What results is a situation in which sometimes the elections don't fully reflect the views of the American population. Essentially
column5: the president-elect was supported by about 27 percent of the American population. One of our challenges
column6: historically
column7: is that we have very low voting rates
column8: even during presidential elections.

column1: This sort of language drove Americans to Trump. And if Obama continues to critique Trump from the outside with this sort of language
column2: not only will he be doing Trump a favor
column3: he‚Äôll be preventing any other Democrat from taking a leading role in opposing Trump. He‚Äôll become the point of resistance for his own party ‚Äì and his party won‚Äôt be able to escape his shadow.

column1: Obama‚Äôs ego has already cost his party the presidency
column2: the Senate
column3: the House
column4: a bevy of state legislators and governor‚Äôs mansions. Now it may cost them the future.

2286;d1f7facc438fb3222fa2a09a8800ebb7d4d6d0af;0;;2016-11-22T16:37:31.350+02:00;Meet All The Pundits Pandering For A Trump Adminstration Job | Daily Wire;"Meet All The Pundits Pandering For A Trump Adminstration Job By: Aaron Bandler November 22
With Donald Trump set to take office in a couple of months
column2: a number of his lackeys have reportedly been in talks about possibly serving in the administration. As of this writing
column3: there are three pro-Trump pundits that might be in the Trump administration.

column1: Eric Bolling. Politico reported that Bolling was seen at Trump Tower and was reportedly discussed for a position in the Department of Commerce. What exactly that position that will be is not clear. Bolling told Politico that he ""can't confirm anything.""
Geraldo Rivera flat-out asked Bolling on The Five if he had been offered a job
column2: and Bolling gave a non-answer .

column1: Bolling has been with Fox News since 2008
column2: where he is the co-host of The Five and hosts the weekend show Cashin' In . Before then
column3: he had been an analyst on CNBC and a New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) trader. Bolling has been an ardent supporter of Trump from the get-go
column4: to the point where he resorted to some loony ideas .

column1: Laura Ingraham. According to CNN Money
column2: Ingraham is being heavily considered for President Trump's press secretary. Here is what Ingraham has said on the matter:

column1: I am honored to be considered for that job and other jobs. So we'll see what happens
column2: Ingraham said on Fox News.

column1: She cautioned: ""I think people are getting a little far ahead of the narrative."" But she strongly suggested that some sort of Trump administration post is in the works.
It's a big decision
column2: but I'm at the point where
column3: if my country needs me
column4: and if I can do something to actually
column5: you know
column6: advance the Trump agenda
column7: which is stuff I have written about now for 15 years
column8: with trade
column9: immigration and just renewing America
column10: then I obviously have to seriously consider that
column11: she told Fox's Tucker Carlson.

column1: Like Bolling
column2: Ingraham
column3: who has been a nationally syndicated radio host since 2001
column4: has also been an early supporter of Trump
column5: going as far as saying that #NeverTrump conservatives support partial birth abortion
column6: and her website
column7: LifeZette
column8: attacked conservatives like Ben Shapiro for opposing the Alt-Right. (As usual
column9: Shapiro punched back hard .)

column1: Jeanine Pirro. Pirro
column2: accompanied by Rudy Giuliani
column3: was seen headed inside Trump Tower
column4: which has led to speculation that she is being considered for a job in the Trump administration
column5: according to Page Six . What that job would be is not known.

column1: Pirro also has been an early Trump supporter
column2: and she has claimed to have known him for 30 years . Pirro's ex-husband
column3: Al Pirro
column4: has been described as ""a man Donald Trump keeps on retainer"" as a real-estate lawyer
column5: and Trump once donated $20
column6: 000 to Pirro when she ran for New York state attorney general.

column1: Pirro has been with Fox News since 2006 and hosts Justice with Judge Jeanine on Saturdays. She also has an extensive legal career as a prosecutor in the state of New York and initially challenged Hillary Clinton when she ran for re-election in the Senate before dropping out to run for state attorney general. column1: 2292;f557f41b568a18029d6354bcf0fa963c98477b7e;0;;2016-11-23T22:22:36.856+02:00;Video: Underwater Handgun Takes Fishing to the Next Level of Fun | Daily Wire;"Video: Underwater Handgun Takes Fishing to the Next Level of Fun By: Chase Stephens November 23
For some people
column2: fishing is a long
column3: boring day of sitting and staring endlessly at a rod and reel that may never get a bite. But what if you could get down with those mocking water-breathers and have high-noon shoot-out with them the way nature intended?

column1: Well
column2: that's just what some Florida boys thought when they decided to take their modified Glock 9mm pistol into the Gulf of Mexico to help deal with the infestation of Lionfish.

column1: TheSickest provides some more details on the Lionfish overpopulation problem and the boys' creative way to address it:

Lionfish are an invasive species with no natural predators who‚Äôs females lay a staggering two million eggs a year. The intersection between ammunition-happy Americans and the determent of an overpopulated species is where the the use of this new sporting phenomenon was birthed.
Lionsfish were never intended to be in the Gulf of Mexico
column2: and while its speculated that their transplant may be linked to a hurricanes back in the 90‚Äôs
column3: because of their rapid reproductive nature the waters have become flooded by their presence.

column1: A single Lionsfish consumes 80% reef‚Äôs edible baitfish within five weeks of arriving on that reef ‚Äì incredibly damaging to plant that is the cornerstone of the underwater ecosystem. The issue has gotten to a point where entering the Florida coast at any time can mean running across thousands of Lionsfish
column2: just posted up chilling.

column1: The good news is that the introduction of the gun has the potential of bringing hunters and otherwise uninterested fishers to the gulf for a fun filled time of shooting underwater
column2: an activity that actually looks like a blast.""

column1: The video below shows just how fun it can be:
Shooting invasive Lionfish over 100ft underwater with customized Glock 9mm handgun in the Gulf of Mexico
column2: the video description states. ""The project started to see if we could shoot a gun underwater and it evolved into much more with the right people involved. Lionfish are an invasive species that need to be eradicated. All weapons modifications done under supervision of Airborne Arms Inc license holder ""07-Manufacturer of Firearms other than Destructive Devices"" with support of Lone Wolf Glock Parts. www.lonewolfdist.com""

column2: Illinois' Asian carp problem:

column2: Senator

This would take a lot of negotiation and would also take making it clear to the Russians and Syrians that our purpose here was to provide safe zones on the ground ‚Ä¶ I think we could strike a deal and make it clear to the Russians and the Syrians that this was something that we believe was in the best interest of the people on the ground in Syria.‚Äù (Fox News

2336;5cec179198f28258b8c8cddd9a24a668b6165c6c;0;Dr. Patrick Slattery;2016-10-31T10:59:32.036+02:00;How they could steal the election from Trump even if he is announced the winner next Tuesday;"How they could steal the election from Trump even if he is announced the winner next Tuesday October 31
How they could steal the election from Trump even if he is announced the winner next Tuesday
By Dr. Patrick Slattery ‚Äî There has been a great deal of talk recently about the ‚Äúrigging‚Äù of elections. Trump talks about it
column2: and then the media accuses him of being a threat to democracy by refusing to accept the will of the voters. Nobody asks Hillary if she will accept the will of the voters‚Ä¶

column1: Of course
column2: we know that our electoral system is unfair
column3: biased
column4: and even rigged at a variety of levels. Without going into detail
column5: the media
column6: which plays an absolutely crucial role in staging our elections
column7: has abandoned even the pretense of neutrality. Ballot access is unfair. Campaign finance is corrupt. Electronic voting machines are vulnerable. Voting by foreigners and dead people exists
column8: as does multiple voting by individuals.

column1: But one massive threat has so far gone completely unmentioned: the vulnerability of the electoral college to post-election shenanigans.
What people are not aware of is that
column2: under the Constitution
column3: the president is not elected on November 8. The Tuesday after the first Monday in November is designated for Congressional elections. It just so happens that over the years all the states decided to have their electors to the Electoral College selected by the voters on that day. In the early days of the Republic
column4: it was actually more common for state legislatures to select the electors
column5: and the Constitution allows the state legislatures to determine how the electors are selected.

column1: It is actually the Electoral College that elects the president
column2: and that happens on the Monday after the second Wednesday in December
column3: which this year will be December 19. On this day
column4: the electors will meet in their respective state capitals to cast their ballots
column5: which will then be sent to Washington to be opened by Vice President Biden before a joint session of Congress on January 6 of next year. Some of you may remember the scene from Michael Moore‚Äôs Fahrenheit 911 showing Vice President Gore reading votes that elected President Bush
column6: ironically denying the objections raised by some Congressmen to Florida‚Äôs electoral votes
column7: which Bush won over Gore amidst the greatest of controversy.

column1: So if this system is enshrined in the Constitution
column2: what could possibly go wrong? Plenty.

column1: Unless Hillary goes into complete meltdown over the next week
column2: a Trump victory on November 8 will likely be a narrow one in terms of the electoral college map. One very plausible scenario has Trump losing Pennsylvania but winning the rest of the main battleground states plus one of Maine‚Äôs congressional districts. (Maine
column3: along with Nebraska
column4: allow for electors to be elected on a congressional district basis rather than winner-take-all.) Under this scenario
column5: 270 Republican electors would be elected
column6: a bare majority
column7: while 268 Democrat electors would be elected.

column1: Notice I did not say ‚ÄúTrump would get 270 electoral votes
column2: ‚Äù which is what we are used to hearing. The fact is that the electoral votes are not cast until December 19
column3: and there is no guarantee that every single one of the 270 Republican electors would actually vote for Trump. Do you remember a few months ago how alarmed we were at the prospect of supposed Trump delegates to the Republican National Convention deserting Trump and voting for Cruz? It was only that Trump piled up such large victories in the final primaries that he had big enough majority of delegates to cause the Never Trump people in the Republican establishment to give up on rigging the convention.

column1: So who are these electors? Just as the method of electing the electors is left up to the states
column2: the method for nominating the candidates for the electoral college is also left up to the states. Some states allow the presidential candidates to nominate their own slate of electors. Presumably
column3: these people could be counted on to be loyal. But in other states the party‚Äôs slate of electors is chosen at state party conventions and even electoral district conventions.

column1: As a young man I attended one such convention and had my name put into nomination as a Democratic elector. Myself and the other three contenders then made short speeches to the convention. The other three talked about being precinct captains or hard-working party volunteers. Then I gave a speech calling for the direct election of the president and the abolition of the electoral college. I got a huge round of applause. I would have easily won
column2: but as a matter of principle I withdrew my name from nomination.

column1: The point of the story is that most of the electors are unknown to the public
column2: typically cogs in the party apparatus
column3: and not even necessarily high-level ones
column4: and some of them may even be smooth-talking slicksters like me
column5: unknown to the party itself.

column1: So how likely is it that one or more Republican electors would betray Trump? Such a person is known as a ‚Äúfaithless elector
column2: ‚Äù and while faithless electors have never ultimately altered the outcome of a presidential election
column3: there have been 179 faithless electors in our history. In fact
column4: faithless electors caused the Congress to have to decide the 1836 election for Vice President.

column1: It is true that about half the states have laws punishing faithless voters
column2: but in all but a few states the votes of faithless electors would still count.

column1: The nightmare situation would be after a close election the Hillary people
column2: or the Never Trump people
column3: could bribe or pressure Republican electors
column4: some of whom may not like Trump anyway
column5: not to vote for Trump. They could vote for Hillary
column6: they could vote for Pence
column7: they could vote for anyone else
column8: or they could even abstain from voting.

column1: Then what happens? If enough Republican electors are cajoled into voting for Hillary (in the above 270-268 scenario
column2: it would only require two)
column3: then Hillary gets inaugurated on January 20. If it‚Äôs a tie
column4: then the House of Representatives breaks the tie. Obviously
column5: there have been Republican members of the House that say they won‚Äôt vote for Trump for president in November
column6: so there is no reason to assume they would vote for him in January.

column1: However
column2: not only are Republicans likely to retain a significant majority in the House
column3: but the voting for president by the House is not one vote for each representative
column4: but one vote per state. This means that California
column5: which currently has 39 Democratic representatives
column6: would get only one vote
column7: while Alaska‚Äôs single representative
column8: who is a Republican
column9: would also get one vote. This heavily favors the Republicans and means that if Hillary cannot flip enough Republican electors to herself to win a majority of the electoral votes
column10: she is finished. There is no real prospect of the House of Representative electing Hillary.

column1: But what if enough Republican electors vote for other people
column2: Paul Ryan for example
column3: so that no candidate gets a majority? Then the House of Representatives gets to choose between the top three vote finishers in the electoral college vote. You could get a coalition between Democrats and Republican defectors that would deny Trump the presidency and give it to someone like Ryan. (The same applies in the case that Mormon ex-CIA operative and never-Trump independent presidential candidate Evan McMullen wins Utah
column4: which some polls predict is possible.)

column1: While none of the above scenarios may come to pass
column2: we do have to face the fact that the establishment has so far stopped at nothing to try to defeat Trump
column3: and so it is not too far fetched to think that they would try these tactics
column4: especially if the November 8 voting produces a very narrow victory for Trump. The media could start inventing more reasons why Trump is uniquely unfit to become president and claim that the Constitution allows for these scenarios (which is the case)
column5: and that this in fact was why the framers of the Constitution created the Electoral College (which is not the case).

column1: It would then be incumbent on us to make it clear to the members of the Electoral College and the Congress that any violation of the people‚Äôs will would not be tolerated.";english;2016-10-31T10:59:32.036+02:00;davidduke.com;US;;How they could steal the election from Trump even if he is announced the winner next Tuesday;0.0;https://s0.wp.com/i/blank.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;hate

Tulsi Gabbard for Secretary of State! An example of the need for political realignment
By Dr. Patrick Slattery ‚Äî On Monday Donald Trump met with Hawaii Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard. She has been mentioned as a possible Secretary of State
column2: or even Secretary of Defense (she is an Iraq War combat veteran and Major in the Hawaii National Guard). It‚Äôs not just that she would be preferable in these jobs to John Bolton
column3: Rudi Giuliani
column4: or Mitt Romney
column5: but is probably the very best candidate from the ranks of the Washington establishment.

column1: In particular
column2: she is unique in being a strong and principled opponent of any intervention in Syria. She wants the United States to stop supporting ISIS and other ‚Äúrebel‚Äù groups and let the Russians
column3: Iranians
column4: and Hezbollah help President Assad defeat the jihadists and end the Syrian Civil War (which is more an armed invasion than a real civil war). This is exactly the right approach.

column1: And it‚Äôs not just that she is on the right side of this issue. It is her signature issue. She is on the Armed Services and Foreign Affairs Committees
column2: so this is what she has spent her time on.

column1: It‚Äôs not that she‚Äôs perfect. It has been noted that she at the very least pays lip-service to Israel. Everyone on Capital Hill does. Let‚Äôs face it
column2: Zionism is the established religion in America
column3: and there IS a religious test for office. But her fault goes further than that. She condemned the government of then-Ukrainian President Victor Yanukovich in February 2014
column4: just as Hillary Clinton‚Äôs erstwhile Secretary of State Victoria Nuland was organizing his overthrow. Gabbard
column5: like everyone else in Congress
column6: then supported arming the Jewish-dominated government that Nuland put in place in Kiev.

column1: Even so
column2: her Congressional website does not carry any mention of Ukraine since 2014
column3: and her vocal opposition to starting World War III with Russia over Syria seems to indicate that her view towards Russia have become more realistic. This
column4: as has been noted elsewhere
column5: is in line with Trump‚Äôs view.

column1: But there is one more significant benefit of appointing Gabbard as Secretary of State. It could help trigger a badly needed realignment of American politics. As people like Ralph Nader have long been telling us
column2: there is no significant difference between Democrats and Republicans. That is because the most divisive issues in politics are not the existential issues that face our society and the world.

column1: If there has been one litmus test in politics during my lifetime it has been abortion. It may engender strong emotions
column2: but it hardly ranks with nuclear war as a threat to humanity. Yet I cannot tell you how many staunchly anti-war people in 2004 voted for pro-war Democrat John Kerry because they were worried about Bush appointing pro-life judges to the Supreme Court. Talk about getting your priorities backwards!

column1: This year

column5: it would take care of war

column7: Israel currently has no role as an organizing feature in America‚Äôs political alignment as both parties so unanimously support it blindly.) But as the realignment proceeds along an America First non-interventionist foreign policy

column1: 2475;fcb7dd2bbf848ca75aa405764549f2b81ddb36e4;0;;2016-10-29T17:41:00.000+03:00;Only Geniuses & Schizophrenics Can Pass This 3 Question Quiz! - David Avocado Wolfe - DavidWolfe.com;"0 - items Only Geniuses & Schizophrenics Can Pass This 3 Question Quiz!
Many neuroscientists estimate that as much as 98% of all brain activity is unconscious. Just think about that for a second ‚Äì 98%.
All that unconscious activity is influenced heavily by the world around its subconscious cues. To demonstrate that
column2: we‚Äôre going to call on a super cool quiz. The premise is simple; only geniuses and schizophrenics can answer the following three questions. Which one are you? Continue to find out!

column1: There are no hints! You either know it or you don‚Äôt!

The test you‚Äôve just done relies on what researchers call the ‚Äòcontraposition method.‚Äô This method tests the extent of a person‚Äôs awareness and brain processing power. It‚Äôs a super complicated method with tons of ‚Äòmoving parts
column2: ‚Äô so to speak
column3: but here‚Äôs what you need to know for the purpose of this article: There are objects which one can reasonably say are unrelated. Most people would assume
column4: for example
column5: that a race car and a hurricane have very little connection. A genius who thinks outside of the box
column6: however
column7: would deduce some sort of connection. A schizophrenic patient would also deduce a connection because of the way the illness makes people see non-existent connections in just about everything. In other words
column8: if the quiz in this article left you scratching your head
column9: you‚Äôre normal. If not
column10: one of two things is true ‚Äì you‚Äôre brilliant
column11: or you have schizophrenia.

column1: Don‚Äôt worry
column2: I won‚Äôt leave you guessing. Here are some facts that will help you figure out which one you are: Geniuses will have taken their time to think before blurting a response. Did you get the answers right? What do you think ‚Äì are you a schizophrenic or a genius? As far as the schizophrenia angle goes
column3: this post is not a diagnostic tool. It can get you thinking about schizophrenia and
column4: if you have concerns
column5: you can see a psychiatrist for a proper evaluation.

3684;0a3e065489dfe7d3fea814c00f5d92281d6f835c;0;Daniel Greenfield;2016-10-26T08:50:00.000+03:00;Jewish Pirates of the Caribbean;"Jewish Pirates of the Caribbean October 25

column1: Brooding and bearded face shadowed by an odd hat
column2: cutlass scars on his arms and a dark patch where his eye ought to be. The pirate is a familiar stereotype. Countless movies have worn him down to a smooth and unremarkable cliche.

column1: But what if that cliche has depths that have yet to be mined by the movie industry?
That is the question that Israeli-American director Arnon Z. Shorr (Blood and Stone: A Legend of the Golem
column2: A Modest Suggestion
column3: Glimpse) has chosen to tap into with the Pirate Captain Toledano . Beneath the pirate's hat hides another sort of hat. A Jewish one. For the Pirate Captain Toledano is a Jewish pirate. What sort of Jew becomes a pirate and why?

column1: Touching on true history
column2: that is one of the questions that Shorr's film proposes to answer.

column1: Recent years have seen growing interest in the history of Jewish pirates. And what initially seems absurd quickly becomes a fascinating exploration of how much of history is lost when legend becomes cliche. As a pioneering filmmaker
column2: Arnon Z. Shorr has chosen to tackle this ambitious project with the aid of two vessels at the Ocean Institute
column3: a dedicated cast and support from the public.

column1: Though the process of bringing the Pirate Captain Toledano from vision to reality has only begun
column2: the journey has already been marked by fortuitous coincidences
column3: including the discovery that cast member Stephen DeCordova (Captain Toledano) hailed from ancestors who were Jewish pirates and a treasured Kiddush cup in his possession
column4: which likely dates back from those days
column5: will play a key role in the story.

column1: Like the ocean
column2: history has unseen depths and strange currents that can only be glimpsed from the right angle. Arnon Z. Shorr is currently laboring to bring up a lost piece of history from the deeps.";english;2016-10-27T04:21:35.434+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Jewish Pirates of the Caribbean;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/shooting_crowdfunding_video267.jpg?itok=hKpgo1cI;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column4: electoral advocacy has to take place close to an election.

Children are told that "" it will all return to us "" on kids' TV programs. The PA National Security Forces regularly post photos from all over Israel presenting the places as ""Palestine
column3: and even crossword puzzles portray Israeli cities as ""occupied Palestine.""

column1: The PA's exploitation of Palestinian children's innocence is precisely what PMW has been highlighting and warning about for years. The PA and Fatah repeatedly demonize Israel as a monster whose only intention is to harm Palestinians. Israel is "" Satan with a tail "" on PA TV children's programs and "" Satan's project "" fighting ""Allah's project"" in sermons delivered by Mahmoud Abbas' advisor. Similarly

One drawing specifies ""Freedom for Ahmad Manasrah"" - a child terrorist who stabbed and critically wounded two Israelis

column1: 3691;af386d6b50a5a5059d5c16b4b01f05d2d7505d31;0;Dr. Majid Rafizadeh;2016-10-27T09:20:34.163+03:00;45 Weird Bans on Women in Iran;"45 Weird Bans on Women in Iran Gender apartheid in the Islamic Republic. October 27
column2: 2016 Dr. Majid Rafizadeh

column1: Under Iran‚Äôs Islamic laws
column2: women are prohibited from performing basic day-to-day activities. I had firsthand experience of witnessing many of these strange and bizarre bans while living in Iran and other Muslim countries. Millions of women
column3: including my relatives in Iran and Syria
column4: continue to face these injustices. Some of the following rules
column5: which are derived from Iran‚Äôs Islamic constitution and moral police codes
column6: were recently reported on by Deutsche Welle Farsi . They exist in may other Islamic countries as well:

column1: 1. Women are prohibited from taking selfies with soccer players. Specifically
column2: Iran‚Äôs ‚Äúmoral committee‚Äù has banned women from taking selfies with famous soccer players.

column1: 2. Iranian women are prohibited from riding bicycles. Iran‚Äôs Supreme Leader
column2: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei
column3: recently issued an Islamic fatwa regarding officially banning women from riding bicycles. He argued that ""riding bicycles often attracts the attention of men and exposes the society to corruption
column4: and thus contravenes women's chastity
column5: and it must be abandoned
column6: ‚Äù according to Iran‚Äôs state-run media.

column1: 3. Coffee shops are prohibited from hiring women. According to Iran‚Äôs police
column2: women are banned from working in any caf√©s.

column1: 4. Iranian Muslim women cannot marry non-Muslim men. But Iranian Muslim men can marry non-Muslim women.
5. It is forbidden for women to wear boots over their pants. (Why? I am not sure what is Iran‚Äôs Islamic logic behind this.)
6. Women are not allowed to wear hats instead of veils to cover their hair.
7. Women are not allowed to wear tight clothes that show their body curves.
8. Women are prohibited from wearing tight clothes for swimming.
9. Women are forbidden from changing their religion or criticizing Muhammad
column2: Allah
column3: the Supreme Leader and other Muslim leaders.

column1: 10. Women are prohibited from entering sport stadiums and watching men‚Äôs sports.
11. In Iran
column2: buses and subways are divided in two sections. The larger front section is for men
column3: the smaller back section is for women. Women are prohibited from entering the men's section even if there are no seats left in the back and there are plenty of empty seats in front of the bus.

column1: 12. According to Iran‚Äôs moral police
column2: women are banned from wearing leggings.

column1: 13. Women are prohibited from showing strands of their hair on any side. Article 683 states: ‚ÄúThose women that appear in the streets and public places without the Islamic hijab
column2: shall be sentenced from ten days to two months‚Äô imprisonment or fined from fifty thousand to five hundred thousand Rials.‚Äù

column1: 14. Women are banned from going camping with men.
15. Any kind of contraceptive surgery is not allowed for women.
16. Women are banned from entering coffeehouses or smoking hookah.
17. Women are not allowed to initiate divorce. Men have the right to do so.
18. According to Iran‚Äôs family code
column2: women cannot travel abroad except with the permission of their custodian or natural guardian (husband
column3: father
column4: etc.). They also cannot obtain a passport without the consent of their husbands.

column1: 19. Women are banned from wearing clothes with writing on them.
20. Women are banned from taking their hijab off in any sport event
column2: including in the Olympics.

column1: 21. Iranian women are prohibited from pursuing education in some academic fields. Iranian regime's oil minister argued that ‚Äúeducation of women in the field of operations such as drilling and processing and so on that require (physical) activities in operational areas and sites is useless and these are masculine (men‚Äôs) jobs.‚Äù
22. Women are not allowed to work in any occupation if their husband disagrees with it. Article 1105 of the Civil Code states
column2: ‚ÄúIn relations between husband and wife
column3: the position of the head of the family exclusively belongs to the husband.‚Äù In addition
column4: when it comes to employment laws
column5: Article 1117 of the Civil Code indicates
column6: ‚ÄúThe husband can prevent his wife from an occupation or technical profession which is incompatible with the family‚Äôs interests or the dignity of him or his wife.‚Äù

column1: 23. Women are banned from receiving the same amount of inheritance as their male relatives. Even if a husband dies
column2: the wife will receive only one-eighth of the inheritance if she has a child.

column1: 24. Women are forbidden from having any physical contact with men
column2: including shaking hands.

column1: 25. Women are banned from becoming a Supreme Leader.
26. Girls
column2: as young as 9 years old
column3: are not allowed to object to their parents decision to marry them off.

column1: 27. Women are not allowed to object to their husband‚Äôs requests for sex. The law of Tamkin means women‚Äôs submission
column2: obedience
column3: full accessibility and unhampered sexual availability to her husband. Sexual availability is considered a woman‚Äôs duty and a man‚Äôs right.

column1: 28. Women are not allowed to bring lawsuits if they are raped
column2: unless they have four witnesses.

column1: 29. Women are banned from socializing or dating men.
30. Women are banned from attracting attention in public through ‚Äúflamboyant behavior‚Äù such as laughing loudly.
31. Women are not allowed to show any part of their skin except the face. It is encouraged to cover the face as well.
32. Women are not allowed to have any kind of alcoholic drinks.
33. Women are not allowed to dance.
34. Women are forbidden from being lesbian. Sex between two women is adultery and the punishments range from stoning to execution.
35. Women are banned from listening to ‚Äúforbidden‚Äù music.
36. Women are not allowed to have pets
column2: such as a dog.

column1: 37. Women are banned from adopting except if they have a husband and he agrees to do so.
38. Women are prohibited from gambling in any kind of event.
39. Women are banned from having sex or marrying a man up to five or six months after their divorce.
40. Women are prohibited from having tattoos.
41. Women are not allowed to have premarital relationships with men.
42. In many of Iran‚Äôs provinces
column2: women are banned from performing music on stage.

column1: 43. Women are banned from being judges.
44. Women are banned from striking their husband
column2: but men are allowed to do so in some circumstances.

column1: 45. Women are not allowed to show their jewelry in public.
Some women continue to defy these rules
column2: but many face severe punishment and discrimination for performing some of these normal day-to-day activities. We need to raise our voice in helping Muslim women in Iran and other Muslim countries who desire to experience freedom
column3: social justice
column4: equality
column5: and do not want to be subjugated
column6: dehumanized
column7: treated as second class citizens
column8: or solely as sexual toys for men.";english;2016-10-27T09:20:34.163+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;45 Weird Bans on Women in Iran;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/women_in_shiraz_2.jpg?itok=-96JyH6F;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: The system is broken. It's deeply corrupted by insider politics . The situation at the center of power has reached the point of utter unaccountability. Insider politics function as a shadow government. That needs to change. Restoring America requires dismantling much of the Federal government not only for Constitutional reasons

column1: Hillary Clinton headlined a major fundraiser for a political action committee shortly before the group steered nearly $500
column2: 000 to the wife of the FBI official who oversaw the Clinton email investigation

column2: its governor - came under scrutiny this week after the Wall Street Journal reported that the group donated heavily to the state senate campaign of Jill McCabe.

Andrew McCabe
column2: now the deputy director of the FBI

column1: Common Good VA was the largest single donor to Jill McCabe's campaign
column2: election records show
column3: giving her $467
column4: 000 between June and October of 2015.

column1: Her campaign also received an additional $207

column3: a group over which McAuliffe exerts significant control. Combined
column4: the money made up nearly one-third of her total funding.

column1: Now McCabe
column2: a pediatrician

column4: 000 from Bill Clinton's business partner Ron Burkle in California and $50

But this is exactly what happened with Benghazi.";english;2016-10-27T20:39:44.307+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Wife of FBI Official Investigating Hillary Got $500K from Hillary Allied PAC;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/mccabe.jpg?itok=B2MuJXR0;0;1;0;0;0;hate
3696;c91fd608e7df9e2873b9273fb3e75600255d47b7;0;Paul Kengor;2016-10-27T12:05:00.000+03:00;Tom Hayden: From SDS and Viet Cong to Progressives for Obama;"Reprinted from Spectator.org .
Tom Hayden
column2: the Vietnam War protester and SDS founder
column3: died this past weekend at age 76.

column1: Hayden‚Äôs journey was in many ways tragic. Born December 1939 in the Detroit suburbs
column2: he was not
column3: unlike many radical leaders
column4: a red-diaper baby. His parents were Irish Catholics who named him after St. Thomas Aquinas and sent him to Catholic school. His father was a Marine who worked for Chrysler
column5: and an abusive drunk. Hayden‚Äôs parents had a rocky marriage and divorced when he was a boy
column6: which affected him terribly. Hayden‚Äôs friend and ex-radical
column7: David Horowitz
column8: observed that Hayden harbored what Irving Howe once described as an ‚Äúobscure personal rage
column9: ‚Äù possibly from his estrangement from his father. ‚ÄúTom was indeed an angry man
column10: ‚Äù wrote Horowitz
column11: ‚Äúwho seemed in perpetual search of enemies.‚Äù

column1: Hayden channeled that anger into a group that did much damage to America
column2: and was the antithesis of anything that Thomas Aquinas would have ever imagined: SDS
column3: Students for a Democratic Society.

column1: Hayden will be forever young and forever a hippie in the memories of many Americans
column2: the snarling activist who married ‚ÄúHanoi Jane‚Äù Fonda and literally wrote the script for SDS. Hayden wrote SDS‚Äôs manifesto
column3: its founding Port Huron Statement
column4: which Hayden‚Äôs cream-puff obituary in the Washington Post generously referred to as ‚Äúan expansive utopian manifesto that extolled ‚Äòparticipatory democracy‚Äô as an antidote to the complacency and conformity of the Eisenhower decade.‚Äù

column1: Right.
Hayden‚Äôs odd expressions of ‚Äúparticipatory democracy‚Äù included another writing he scribbled: an infamous June 4
column2: 1968 letter wishing ‚ÄúGood fortune!‚Äù and ‚ÄúVictory!‚Äù to the North Vietnamese colonels who were killing American boys in Southeast Asia ‚Äî using the same kind of artillery that Hayden‚Äôs sweetheart Jane posed beside in her stint as a Viet Cong cover-girl. That was just one of countless disturbing actions by Tom Hayden at the time
column3: all of which today‚Äôs leftists merrily sweep under the rug as they uphold him as a crusader for civil rights and (of course) ‚Äúsocial justice.‚Äù

column1: But not etched in our memory was what might have been Tom Hayden‚Äôs swan song long after his and his wife‚Äôs cheerleading for the Viet Cong: namely
column2: the document that he wrote for our President of Fundamental Transformation. Few know this
column3: but Hayden was a founder of another group of destructive forces
column4: a group called Progressives for Obama.

column1: The group‚Äôs members came together in 2008
column2: coalescing around the only Democratic presidential nominee in their lifetimes who was far-left enough for them to support. They constituted a Who‚Äôs Who of the ‚Äô60s SDS crowd. Among the nearly 100 formal ‚Äúsigners‚Äù to Progressives for Obama were Mark Rudd
column3: Carl Davidson
column4: Jane Fonda
column5: Thorne Dreyer
column6: Daniel Ellsberg
column7: Richard Flacks
column8: John McAuliff
column9: Jay Schaffner
column10: and more. Columbia University was naturally well-represented
column11: if not through the likes of Rudd
column12: who shut down the campus in 1968
column13: then through current faculty such as Todd Gitlin
column14: a former SDS president who today is professor of journalism
column15: sociology
column16: and chair of Columbia‚Äôs doctoral program in communications.

column1: Whereas the likes of Obama friends Bill Ayers and Bernardine Dohrn were thrust into the national spotlight in 2008 by conservatives like Glenn Beck and Sean Hannity
column2: Progressives for Obama flew under the radar
column3: largely unnoticed even by the right.

column1: Appropriately
column2: spearheading Progressives for Obama was the man who had spearheaded SDS. Tom Hayden was one of the four ‚Äúinitiators‚Äù of Progressives for Obama
column3: along with Barbara Ehrenreich
column4: Bill Fletcher
column5: Jr.
column6: and Danny Glover.

column1: It is no exaggeration to say that the signers list of Progressives for Obama resembled the roster of SDS-ers called to testify before Congress in December 1969 for their subversive activities. Aside from the likes of Hayden
column2: Rudd
column3: and Davidson
column4: other SDS-ers among Progressives for Obama were Bob Pardun
column5: who was SDS education secretary from 1966-67
column6: and Paul Buhle
column7: a professor who has recently sought to revive SDS.

column1: Among these names from the insane ‚Äô60s
column2: all were fired up in 2008 over the unique opportunity that a fellow far-left radical
column3: one Barack Obama
column4: offered. They saw Obama as a golden chance
column5: a once-in-a-lifetime moment
column6: and they got it on November 4
column7: 2008. Obama won the day
column8: and they at last won the day
column9: too.

column1: And therein
column2: among the Progressives for Obama
column3: the testimony of leader Tom Hayden was especially revealing.

column1: Understand that after his early life establishing SDS
column2: meeting with and expressing ‚ÄúGood fortune!‚Äù and ‚ÄúVictory!‚Äù to the Viet Cong
column3: and vigorously protesting the American system
column4: Hayden went into politics
column5: professional activism
column6: and education. Like his erstwhile SDS brethren
column7: Hayden grasped the power of higher education (which they have pervaded)
column8: and served as a professor at Pitzer College and also at Obama‚Äôs alma mater
column9: Occidental College.

column1: Like Mark Rudd
column2: like Bill Ayers
column3: like Bernardine Dohrn (all of them now in higher education)
column4: Hayden had come to view a quick ‚Äúrevolution‚Äù of the system as too daunting
column5: if not impossible. He had become much more patient
column6: instead advocating a ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù evolution of slower
column7: measured change . By 2008
column8: he was seeking to advance the ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù cause within the established
column9: mainstream Democratic Party.

column1: Of course
column2: Hayden once helped blow up the Democratic Party‚Äôs national convention in 1968. No matter: the party of 2008 was different and warmly accepted him.

column1: Hayden was ecstatic over Barack Obama‚Äôs presidential campaign. He jumped in with both feet
column2: looking to assist wherever he could
column3: with a rush of enthusiasm not seen since his days undermining America in Vietnam. Not one to tinker around
column4: Hayden got to work on a formal organization and unifying statement
column5: as he had done for SDS ‚Äî once again there at the creation. The man who drafted SDS‚Äôs pivotal Port Huron statement got to work drafting mission statements for Progressives for Obama.

column1: During the 2008 campaign
column2: a touched Hayden was moved to verse over the emergence of Obama. In one article
column3: titled
column4: ‚ÄúObama and the Open and Unexpected Future
column5: ‚Äù written for CommonDreams.org
column6: self-described as a website for ‚ÄúBreaking News & Views for the Progressive Community
column7: ‚Äù Hayden mused:

column1: I didn‚Äôt see him coming. When I read of the young state senator with a background in community organizing who wanted to be president
column2: I was at least sentient enough to be interested. When I read Dreams of My Father [sic]
column3: I was taken aback by its depth. This young man apparently gave his first public speech
column4: against South African apartheid
column5: at an Occidental College rally organized by Students for Economic Democracy
column6: the student branch of the Campaign for Economic Democracy which I chaired in 1979-82. The buds of curiosity quickened.

column1: Hayden saw in Obama a long-awaited vehicle for ‚Äúeconomic democracy
column2: ‚Äù an instrument to channel an equal distribution of wealth ‚Äî ‚Äúeconomic justice
column3: ‚Äù or ‚Äúredistributive change
column4: ‚Äù as Obama himself had once put it. Hayden wished that
column5: ‚ÄúWin or lose
column6: the Obama movement will shape progressive politics‚Ä¶ for a generation to come.‚Äù He also hoped that that progressive movement likewise ‚Äúmight transform‚Äù Obama as well. Both could reinforce and shape one another.

column1: Hayden wrote that in June 2008. When Obama was elected later the following November
column2: Hayden was beside himself with joy
column3: surely shocked that the American electorate had finally voted for a president that Tom Hayden saw as his kind of president. Once upon a time
column4: traditional Democrats like Hayden‚Äôs parents had shaken their heads in disgust at what Tom and his pals did to their party‚Äôs convention in Chicago in 1968
column5: at what they did during the Days of Rage the next year
column6: at what they did at Columbia during the student strike
column7: and on and on. But now
column9: the Democratic Party was theirs. It belonged to the ‚Äô60s kiddies.

column1: The former SDS founder became particularly vocal in his praise for Obama once the election was over. During the election
column2: the goal was to organize
column3: raise money
column4: but not speak too loudly
column5: out of fear of driving away the moderates and remaining traditional Democrat moms and pops who had worked in the mines and the mills
column6: who joined unions
column7: who ‚Äúclinged‚Äù to their God and guns
column8: who prayed rosaries and filled churches
column9: who were pro-life and anti-gay marriage. With the presidency now secured
column10: Hayden could open up. Joined by his former comrades at the take-no-prisoners website of Progressives for Obama
column11: he began regularly sounding off against Obama‚Äôs critics ‚Äî those opposing ‚Äúsingle payer‚Äù or the ‚Äúpublic option‚Äù in ‚Äúhealthcare reform
column12: ‚Äù or government ‚Äúmanagement‚Äù of General Motors ‚Äî with the subtlety of a howitzer.

column1: With the presidency won
column2: Hayden and his allies were free to express themselves
column3: to demonize health-insurance companies
column4: the financial-services industry
column5: AIG
column6: the Big Three automakers
column7: or whatever other capitalist ‚Äúreptile‚Äù (Lenin‚Äôs phrase) stood in the way of President Obama‚Äôs desire for ‚Äúreform‚Äù and mandate for ‚Äúchange.‚Äù

column1: In the two-term presidency of fundamental transformation under Obama
column2: Hayden and friends achieved many of their common dreams.

column1: By this election cycle

column1: 3697;f38bef9d1438cf44c3d21cc1b7c59df494f76a9d;0;Daniel Greenfield;2016-10-27T21:12:14.598+03:00;Obama Votes Against US at UN;"Obama Votes Against US at UN October 27
column2: 2016 Daniel Greenfield

column1: Obama's abstention from a UN vote against the US is a new low for the most anti-American administration in American history. Under Obama
column2: our foreign policy has been reoriented toward damaging our own interests as much as possible. But actively opposing US policy at the UN is a new low.

column1: The resolution A/RES/71/5 is on the ""Necessity of ending the economic
column2: commercial and financial embargo imposed by the United States of America against Cuba"".

column1: It was introduced at the request of Cuba back in '91 with a memorandum that accused America of ""pursuing an aggressive policy against Cuba with the declared aim of imposing on it the political
column2: social and economic order which the united States authorities consider most fitting. This policy has included direct military intervention
column3: the threat of nuclear annihilation
column4: the instigation and carrying out of countless acts of sabotage and plans to assassinate Cuban leaders.""

column1: As Obama's creepy toady Ben Rhodes tweeted
column2: ""No reason to vote to defend a failed policy we oppose.""

column1: Except the failed policy is that of the United States. By ""we""
column2: Rhodes means that Obama and the left aren't going to defend the United States in international forums when they disagree with the US.

column1: All this is yet another reminder that the people running the country are not of the country. They're a hostile foreign ideology that sees itself as separate from the United States and does not believe it has any responsibilities toward the United States.
At the UN
column2: Samantha Power took the anti-American positions to applause from a UN united with Obama against America.

column1: For more than 50 years
column2: the United States had a policy aimed at isolating the government of Cuba. For roughly half of those years
column3: UN Member States have voted overwhelmingly for a General Assembly resolution that condemns the U.S. embargo and calls for it to be ended. The United States has always voted against this resolution. Today the United States will abstain. [Applause.] Thank you. ""

But...but... I thought we were trying to help people.
ObamaCare visionary Jonathan ""Stupidity of the American Voter"" Gruber is back. When last we heard from the man with the same name as the Die Hard villain
column2: he was being ushered off the scene after explaining how stupid everyone was .

column1: An architect of the federal healthcare law said last year that a ""lack of transparency"" and the ""stupidity of the American voter"" helped Congress approve ObamaCare. In a clip unearthed Sunday
column2: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Professor Jonathan Gruber appears on a panel and discusses how the reform earned enough votes to pass.

column1: He suggested that many lawmakers and voters didn't know what was in the law or how its financing worked
column2: and that this helped it win approval. ""Lack of transparency is a huge political advantage
column3: ‚Äù Gruber said. ""And basically
column4: call it the stupidity of the American voter or whatever
column5: but basically that was really
column6: really critical for the thing to pass."" Gruber made the comment while discussing how the law was ""written in a tortured way"" to avoid a bad score from the Congressional Budget Office. He suggested that voters would have rejected ObamaCare if the penalties for going without health insurance were interpreted as taxes
column7: either by budget analysts or the public. ""If CBO scored the [individual] mandate as taxes
column8: the bill dies
column9: Gruber said.

column1: Now the Gruber is back... and ready to explain why the only problem with ObamaCare is the lack of severe beatings .
‚ÄúThere is no sense in which‚Äù the law ‚Äúhas to be fixed. The law is working as designed. However
column2: it could work better. And I think probably the most important thing experts would agree on is that
column3: we need a larger mandate penalty. We have individuals who are essentially free-riding on the system
column4: they‚Äôre essentially waiting until they get sick and then getting health insurance. The whole idea of this plan
column5: which was pioneered in Massachusetts
column6: was that the individual mandate penalty would bring those people into the system and have them participate. The penalty right now is probably too low
column7: and that‚Äôs something I think ideally we would fix.‚Äù

column1: Ideally we would penalize Gruber and everyone involved in inflicting this monstrosity on the public. But predictably Gruber's proposal is to offer up more beatings until morale improves.
