3699;7d4aafe022ce9da0a0892fe994d0de818e2af878;0;Richard Baehr;2016-10-28T07:54:59.211+03:00;The Left in Power: Clinton to Obama;"Search The Left in Power : Clinton to Obama David Horowitz explains how the Democrats became a leftwing party in Volume VII of the Black Book of the American Left. October 28
column2: 2016 Richard Baehr

column1: Below is Richard Baehr's review of David Horowitz's new book
column2: The Left in Power: Clinton to Obama (reprinted from American Thinker with permission). The book is volume 7 of The Black Book of the American Left
column3: a multi-volume collection of David Horowitz's conservative writings that will
column4: when completed
column5: be the most ambitious effort ever undertaken to define the Left and its agenda. (Order HERE .) We encourage our readers to visit BlackBookOfTheAmericanLeft.com which features Horowitz‚Äôs introductions to Volumes 1-7 of this 9-volume series
column6: along with their tables of contents
column7: reviews and interviews with the author.

column1: Every year
column2: there is some report of the blissful ignorance of American history demonstrated by the supposedly best and brightest at elite American universities. Suffice it to say the collected writings of David Horowitz on the American Left
column3: which constitute part of a solid foundation for understanding the last half century of American politics
column4: are nowhere to be found on any college or high school reading list.

column1: Horowitz‚Äôs latest book
column2: The Left in Power: Clinton to Obama
column3: is the seventh volume in his nine-volume collection
column4: The Black Book of the American Left . This new volume provides a collection of his writings over the last quarter century
column5: focusing primarily on the Left‚Äôs control in our government and culture. As Horowitz reveals
column6: even during the Bush years
column7: conservatives were on the defense and leftists controlled the narrative as they attempted to destroy Bush and his chances for re-election in 2004. Their primary mode of attack was to undermine America‚Äôs efforts in Iraq almost from the start of the conflict
column8: when just months earlier a majority of Senate Democrats and near half of House Democrats had supported the President. The Left then destroyed Bush‚Äôs second term with bogus charges of racist neglect in the handling of Hurricane Katrina. There was plenty of incompetence in the response to Katrina
column9: but local and state officials ‚Äî all Democrats
column10: of course
column11: and many of them African American ‚Äî were the principal operators on the ground during the crisis.

column1: The immediate abandonment of support for the Iraq war effort was a signal event in American history
column2: sending a message that a large part of the Democratic Party was not remotely concerned about the morale of our men and women fighting overseas. The weak effort by some Democrats to hold onto an ounce of patriotic resolve -- ‚Äúend the war
column3: support the troops‚Äù -- was designed more for campaign speeches than any meaningful attempt to convey national unity for the effort underway by our armed forces. So too
column4: the obsession with Abu Ghraib gave the lie to the Democrats‚Äô ‚Äúsupport our troops‚Äù message
column5: as a broad brush was used to paint the incident as somehow what you would expect from our military on a routine basis.

column1: Horowitz outlines this narrative
column2: faulting the Bush administration for failing to fight harder to present its story of why we went into Iraq and the risks if we had done nothing. Regrettably
column3: the Bush administration never had a chance to get a better defense of the Iraq war out to the media. Most in the media considered the Bush administration illegitimate due to its narrow victory in the 2000 presidential contest
column4: a lie to be sure . Unfortunately
column5: it is almost certainly true that the media today are far more in the bag for the left than ten or twenty years ago and work harder at pushing the left‚Äôs agenda. The soft liberalism of Walter Cronkite has been replaced by cable and national network anchors who routinely bury stories embarrassing to their side and focus on those that can do damage to the other side. During the current Presidential election cycle
column6: we have seen the most prestigious media organs explain why it is necessary and appropriate for them to be biased this year. It is a special time
column7: they argue
column8: because Trump is
column9: in their view
column10: a unique threat to the Republic.

column1: On the other hand
column2: the media have been loath to consider the damage to the country caused by Barack Obama -- the loss of respect abroad for America‚Äôs will to fight
column3: the degradation of our military readiness
column4: the fraying of ties with allies
column5: and the near obsessive outreach to America‚Äôs enemies that led to agreements such as the nuclear deal with Iran
column6: best described as an abject surrender of American interests that will lead to the funding of fanatical nuclear regime. About 85% of those supposedly sensible pro-Israel Democrats walked the plank behind their great leader on that deal
column7: with no visible regrets to date. There was simply too much political risk to oppose the first black president of their party. The media were happy to parrot the administration‚Äôs talking points for the nuclear deal
column8: something the manipulators crowed over at the White House.

column1: At least in the propaganda use of Abu Ghraib
column2: the Left was honest in revealing what it thinks about the military. As Horowitz outlines in article after article
column3: the Left is fighting a war that most Americans do not see
column4: disguising its intentions through its aggressive
column5: unceasing promotion of ‚Äúprogressive‚Äù policies ‚Äúto make America a better place.‚Äù This commitment to deception emerges
column6: Horowitz reveals
column7: from the allegiance to the ideology of Saul Alinsky‚Äôs ‚ÄúRules for Radicals
column8: ‚Äù a formative doctrine for both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. The progressive goal is to achieve a new society that has never been seen before in this country
column9: though it has been promised and has catastrophically failed in many places around the globe. In America
column10: the Left is not only unconcerned with selling their program to the public
column11: but also
column12: Horowitz argues
column13: it is fearful of the result of voters knowing what it is pursuing. One prime example was the admission of MIT professor and Obamacare architect Jonathan Gruber that health care law would never have made it through Congress if it had been presented honestly.

column1: The Left is also busy at work making it easier for itself to win politically. Horowitz provides chapter and verse on the Left‚Äôs efforts to rapidly change the composition of the voting pool -- motor voter registration with no birth certificate required
column2: fighting every effort to combat voter fraud with charges of racism and ‚Äúturning the clock back
column3: ‚Äù even when states were willing to pay for potential voters obtaining the needed documents to register
column4: support for open borders
column5: expansion of legal immigration
column6: and amnesty and citizenship (and voting rights) for more than ten million already in the country illegally. Here the Left‚Äôs mentor and financier is George Soros and his buddies
column7: who have funded dozens of organizations which fight on multiple fronts every day to advance the left politically. And Horowitz has done a great public service by his Discover the Network listing of the people responsible for America‚Äôs steady drift to the radical Left.

column1: The Left uses the racism charge in many of the confrontations it creates. Of course
column2: the problems of America‚Äôs inner cities
column3: all under complete control of one political party for half a century
column4: have never been of even near equal interest to the Democrats as their ability to continue to win enormous majorities among inner city voters
column5: particularly African Americans. The Left has fully endorsed the teacher unions‚Äô opposition to charter schools
column6: and voucher programs
column7: though both are popular with minority group parents and children. The two major teachers unions are simply too powerful a support group for the Democratic Party (campaign cash
column8: votes
column9: and volunteers) for the Left to support policies that might lead to a better future for kids as opposed to continued growth in expenditures for the teachers unions and their workforce.

column1: In the last two years
column2: the Soros-funded Black Lives Matter movement has created a near national hysteria over the alleged systematic effort by police to kill unarmed black men. Between two and three dozen unarmed blacks are killed by cops each year
column3: many of them in situations where the ‚Äùvictims‚Äù were almost certainly responsible for what happened to them -- Michael Brown in Ferguson is a prime example. One wonders where the news media are to report on the police shooting of unarmed whites
column4: which greatly outnumber those of unarmed blacks. Perhaps because there are no riots
column5: or looting
column6: these incidents have no cachet. More likely
column7: they do not fit the systemic racism charge now routinely thrown around by everyone from the current President to Hillary Clinton.

column1: In Chicago in 9 months this year
column2: over 400 blacks
column3: mostly men
column4: have been shot and killed
column5: almost exclusively by other black men. By year end
column6: over 4
column7: 000 Chicagoans will have been shot. One might think this was a bigger story of urban calamity and civil society breakdown than a shooting in Charlotte. Chicago‚Äôs mayor says that police ‚Äúhave gone fetal
column8: ‚Äù avoiding making stops in crime ridden neighborhoods
column9: with the ACLU looking over their shoulder demanding a report for every stop
column10: and activists in the neighborhoods treating the police with scorn and abuse
column11: following a bad police shooting captured on video and kept hidden from the public by Chicago‚Äôs mayor to protect his re-election bid. Rahm Emanuel must also have read Alinsky
column12: for he knows whose hide to protect first and foremost. The victims of the police pullback in Chicago
column13: Baltimore
column14: St
column15: Louis and other cities
column16: called ‚Äúthe Ferguson effect
column17: ‚Äù are many more dead black men
column18: killed in crime waves that are reminiscent of the 1990s. Even the FBI Director admits the Ferguson Effect is real
column19: when not covering for Hillary Clinton.

column1: Horowitz‚Äô latest book is full of insights and straight talk on the goals and the mission of the Left
column2: and how it has advanced its cause this last quarter century. He provides the kind of arguments that keep his books from getting reviewed by the New York Times. And there is always a horrible slur available from the Left to describe a viewpoint that counters one of its missions. The Left chooses to ignore the argument and uses character assassination for the people making it. It argues that these are people (Horowitz included) unworthy of serious consideration
column3: or respect.

column1: Silencing the critic or the dissident or limiting his visibility has been a long time weapon of the Left. So far
column2: Horowitz keeps writing
column3: and America is free enough that the Left
column4: though it clearly wants to
column5: cannot ban his books. George Soros and his family have another $20 billion to spend on changing America. The Alinsky acolytes have their mission laid out to make use of the funds and create an America where the smart bureaucrats can organize society and distribute its wealth
column6: so results are all equal. And we can all sing along with the Pete Seeger songs as we turn away from any role overseas (where of course we have primarily been an agent of evil) and disinvest in defense every year.

column1: Let‚Äôs hope that some of America‚Äôs young will read Horowitz‚Äô books
column2: and learn what their professors and teachers won‚Äôt teach them.";english;2016-10-28T07:54:59.211+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;The Left in Power: Clinton to Obama;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/bc.jpg?itok=4S4NGvbL;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3700;12ad072158a6e2fee30aa3f7404d1e1687a585c5;0;Matthew Vadum;2016-10-28T07:54:59.346+03:00;Bank Fines Elect Democrats;"An eyebrow-raising new study from a nonpartisan research institute. October 28
column2: 2016 Matthew Vadum

column1: The Obama administration is using billions of dollars in banking fines to fund radical left-wing activist groups that work to elect Democrats
column2: according to an eye-opening new study from a nonpartisan research institute.

column1: During Eric Holder‚Äôs term as attorney general from February 2009 through April 2015
column2: a little under $37.3 billion was paid by U.S. banks under the threat of federal lawsuits. All but $720 million of that sum came from three big settlements: Bank of America
column3: Citigroup
column4: and JP Morgan Chase.

column1: Many of the cases rest on bogus ‚Äúdisparate impact theory‚Äù which left-wing government lawyers use to make sure that ‚Äúbanks become liable for charges of racism based upon the perceived injustice of lending disparity in certain lower income areas
column2: regardless of the reasons for the disparity.‚Äù

column1: Instead of being used to help the supposed victims of these banks
column2: the money flows to leftist allies of President Obama.

column1: Adding insult to injury
column2: the process by which the money snakes its way to left-wing organizations is both corrupt and unconstitutional
column3: according to the report from the Government Accountability Institute that is called ‚ÄúFollow the Money: How the Department of Justice Funds Progressive Activists.‚Äù (Bestselling Clinton Cash author and anti-corruption crusader Peter Schweizer is GAI‚Äôs president. The full 115-page report is available in PDF form here .)

column1: The report states:

The [Department of Justice] has curated an opaque system wherein appointed attorneys can legally extract money from the private sector and redistribute the funds to third-party organizations outside of the appropriations process‚Äîan unprecedented and extraordinary disregard for Congressional authority.
It adds
column2: ‚Äú[t]hese funds directed by the DOJ effectively replaced funding to activist nonprofits previously denied by Congress.‚Äù

column1: Much of the cash moves through NeighborWorks. The nonprofit gave more than $53 million to the rabble-rousing group Neighborhood Assistance Corp. of America (NACA) whose leader
column2: Bruce Marks
column3: calls himself a ‚Äúbank terrorist.‚Äù It also gave over $4 million to Asian Americans for Equality (AAFE)
column4: ‚Äúan organization with communist roots and continued close ties to a very vocal North Korean sympathizer.‚Äù

column1: The ill-gotten funds extorted from the banks also trickle down to left-wing groups such as National Council of La Raza
column2: NHS of Chicago
column3: National Urban League
column4: and Operation HOPE.

column1: Many of the nonprofits that receive such funding spend the money to elect Democrats.
Catalist
column2: a George Soros-funded for-profit data analytics company specializing in left-progressive causes
column3: along with a group called Nonprofit VOTE ‚Äúmobilize these federally funded nonprofits ‚Ä¶ to get the vote out for those who ‚Äòtend to be reliably progressive
column4: ‚Äô‚Äù the report states.

column1: Catalist was founded by former Bill Clinton aide Harold Ickes in 2006 following Democrats‚Äô electoral wipeout in 2004. Left-wing activists believed Republicans owed George W. Bush‚Äôs re-election victory to heavy spending on voter contact technology
column2: including databases.

column1: According to a Capital Research Center report :
Catalist boasts it was vital to President Obama‚Äôs 2008 victory. By its own admission
column2: ‚Äúover 90 organizations
column3: campaigns and committees‚Äù used the company‚Äôs services. ‚ÄúBased on data that was loaded into the Catalist databases and then standardized
column4: ‚Äù a Catalist analysis of the 2008 cycle says
column5: ‚Äúprogressive organizations
column6: the Obama campaign
column7: and federal party committees attempted to contact more than 106 million people. This means that the progressive community attempted to contact over 46% of the U.S. adult population. Contacts were delivered in-person
column8: over the phone
column9: by mail and over the internet.‚Äù

column1: Of course
column2: leeching off others is generally how the activist Left funds itself. Apart from oceans of cash supplied by left-wing fat-cat mega-donors like George Soros and Michael Bloomberg and a galaxy of radical foundations
column3: the Left derives its sustenance by ripping off taxpayers at the federal
column4: state
column5: and local levels.

column1: The report states the evidence shows the Left is using the Department of Justice and ‚Äúthe power of the federal government to extract money from financial institutions for redistribution to progressive activists whose real intent is far more partisan than the housing and housing education for which they ostensibly exist.‚Äù
In other words
column2: the Left plays by a different set of rules than the rest of America. There is no level so-called playing field in American electoral politics. In a sense the system is rigged. There is the parasitic Left feeding at the taxpayer trough versus everybody else.

column1: Conservatives knew about this travesty already but few studies have been put together that follow the money trail. For a half century
column2: the Left has been using taxpayer dollars to fund efforts to advance radical
column3: subversive causes in the United States.

column1: Changes in federal social policy in the mid-1960s helped lay the groundwork for this insidious leftist astro-turfing. Under the profoundly antisocial War on Poverty
column2: the federal government has been handing out taxpayer money since 1965 to liberal and radical so-called community organizations to help them agitate against the status quo. One could say America declared war on itself and conscripted Saul Alinsky-inspired pressure groups to do the fighting. In recent decades those on the Left ‚Äì including groups like ACORN and money-grubbing con artists like Jesse Jackson Sr. ‚Äì have also become quite adept at working outside the public sector to shake down banks and other businesses to fill their war chests.

column1: Conservative groups receive no such largesse from Uncle Sam (and in fairness
column2: many such organizations would likely reject government funding on principle if offered it).

column1: This sue-and-settle corruption will undoubtedly continue if Hillary Clinton becomes president. Secretary of Labor Tom Perez
column2: no stranger to the shakedown business himself
column3: is said to be a top contender for the attorney general post in any new Clinton administration. Perez
column4: who previously ran the DoJ's Civil Rights Division
column5: is also a past president of Casa de Maryland
column6: a notorious advocacy group for illegal aliens funded by George Soros and the late Venezuelan strongman Hugo Chavez.

column1: The money-raising scam described in the GAI report isn‚Äôt the only way left-wing groups fill up their bank accounts.
Activist groups were encouraged to agitate by the Carter-era Community Reinvestment Act
column2: which enshrined in law a kind of lending protection racket. Banking regulators who had come under the influence of groups like ACORN had the power to make trouble for banks that failed to lend enough money to borrowers in so-called underserved communities. Banks that paid enough -- whatever that means -- got left alone
column3: but banks that didn't
column4: got their legs broken.

column1: Few serious economists doubt that the mortgage market debacle and the economic collapse of 2008 were caused by the deliberate weakening of underwriting standards carried out in the name of ending discrimination.

Leftists played both sides. They called banks racist and demanded more subprime lending for minorities and then when the loans went bad called the banks racist for supposedly targeting minority borrowers. It was (and is) pure gangsterism. Through the magic of dysphemism
column2: the once sought after subprime lending was transformed into ""predatory lending.""

column1: The shaking down of lenders intensified when then-Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin presided over the Clinton administration's effort to put the CRA on steroids. Banks began to make risky subprime loans and Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac aggregated them for sale in the secondary market as mortgage-backed securities. These practices made it easier for banks to give in to the demands of ACORN and other groups to originate more and more doomed mortgages because they knew they could offload their high-risk debt on quasi-governmental suckers Fannie and Freddie
column2: which were under intense political pressure to service the subprime market.

column1: President Clinton ‚Äúturned the Community Reinvestment Act
column2: a once-obscure and lightly enforced banking regulation law
column3: into one of the most powerful mandates shaping American cities‚Äîand as Senate Banking Committee chairman Phil Gramm memorably put it
column4: a vast extortion scheme against the nation‚Äôs banks
column5: ‚Äù Howard Husock of the Manhattan Institute wrote in City Journal .

column1: When Husock wrote in 2000
column2: U.S. banks had ‚Äúcommitted nearly $1 trillion for inner-city and low-income mortgages and real estate development projects
column3: most of it funneled through a nationwide network of left-wing community groups
column4: intent
column5: in some cases
column6: on teaching their low-income clients that the financial system is their enemy and
column7: implicitly
column8: that government
column9: rather than their own striving
column10: is the key to their well-being.‚Äù

column1: Enterprising left-wing levelers never tire of dreaming up these redistribution schemes.

And they never will.";english;2016-10-28T07:54:59.346+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Bank Fines Elect Democrats;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/dj.jpg?itok=FOQTWxFX;0;1;0;0;0;hate

3701;0f62d7cc46fe7b4ba6134e82da017a1f523a3caf;0;Daniel Greenfield;2016-10-28T07:54:59.950+03:00;What Will Replace ISIS?;"Search What Will Replace ISIS? This is a war to determine whether the future will belong to the West or to Islam. October 28
column2: 2016 Daniel Greenfield

column1: Daniel Greenfield
column2: a Shillman Journalism Fellow at the Freedom Center
column3: is a New York writer focusing on radical Islam.

column1: Before long the same administration that declared the fighting in Iraq over several times will claim victory over ISIS. The timetable for its push against the Islamic State appears to have less do with the victimized Christians and Yazidis who have been prevented from coming here as refugees in favor of Syrian Muslims than with the Clinton presidential campaign. Like Obama‚Äôs declarations that the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq were over
column2: the announcement that ISIS has been defeated will be premature.

column1: It is based on a profound misunderstanding and misreading of Islamic terrorism.
Long before its current string of defeats
column2: ISIS had begun evolving into another Al Qaeda; a multinational alliance of Jihadists scattered around the world. Bombing Mosul isn‚Äôt hard
column3: but try bombing Marseille
column4: Brussels or London. There is no doubt that the ability of ISIS to temporarily establish a caliphate allowed it to build a network that could carry out terror attacks from New York to Miami to Nice to Munich. But it would be dangerous to assume that losing Iraq and Syria will stop ISIS.

column1: ISIS doesn‚Äôt matter. The idea of ISIS does. And the idea of ISIS is Islamic supremacism.
The organization we think of ISIS has transformed and rebranded countless times. Even now our leaders vacillate between calling it ISIS
column2: ISIL or
column3: more childishly
column4: Daesh
column5: while it dubs itself the Islamic State. We have been fighting it in one form or another for over a decade. It would be unrealistically optimistic to assume that the war will end just as this old enemy has shown its ability to strike deep in our own cities.

column1: The bigger error though is to think that we are fighting an organization. We are fighting an idea. That is not to contend
column2: as Obama does
column3: that we can debate it to death. It is not the sort of idea that argues with words
column4: but with bullets
column5: bombs and swords. But neither does it just go away if you seize a city.

column1: Al Qaeda in Iraq not only survived the death of Zarqawi
column2: but it became even more dangerous under Baghdadi. It would be risky to assume that ISIS will die with him. Instead it may very well grow into a new phase of Al Qaeda
column3: one that ties together some of the world‚Äôs deadliest Islamic terror groups into a network that is decentralized enough that it will not suffer from Al Qaeda‚Äôs leadership fatigue.

column1: The rise of Islamic terrorism has been an incremental process in which new groups learn from the mistakes of the old and supersede them. If ISIS does recede into a localized oblivion
column2: reemerging only on occasion to suicide bomb something or someone in Baghdad
column3: then a deadlier and even more effective group is likely to take its place. Each group will move one step closer to realizing the caliphate.

column1: To break the cycle

column1: ISIS is not un-Islamic. It is ruthlessly and uncompromisingly Islamic in that

Taking in more Muslim settlers
column2: pressuring Israel and letting the Muslim Brotherhood colonize our foreign policy won‚Äôt do it. We‚Äôve tried it and it actually makes Islamic terrorism much worse.

column1: When the announcement is made

column1: The ‚Äúallies‚Äù we are aiding today will be the ones bombing us tomorrow.

Though even it found its Boko Haram affiliate in Nigeria occasionally a little too much to stomach.

column2: Islamic terrorism will be easier to dismiss. Or so the thinking goes. The Islamic State was better at viral videos than the media that tried to whitewash Islamic terror. It was hard to ignore. But a scattering of Islamic terror groups around the world will be forgotten by the public.

column1: History suggests that‚Äôs wishful thinking.
Islamic terrorism has shown no signs of receding. Growing Muslim populations
column2: both at home and in Muslim settlements in the West
column3: and the increase in travel and communications
column4: the infrastructure of globalism
column5: spread it from the most backward to the most advanced parts of the world. Wealthy and unstable Muslim countries
column6: rich in oil but poor in power
column7: finance its spread through mosques and guns.

column1: These are the ingredients that give us ISIS or any other combination or letters that stands for Islamic terror. To do anything meaningful about it
column2: we would have to reverse the decline of the West.

column1: Islam originally spread into a vacuum created by civilizational decline. Civilizational decline is why it is rising once again. An obscure local terror group eventually turned into ISIS by filling a power vacuum. Even as Obama performs another touchdown dance
column2: some other group will be making that same journey. Its mission will be the familiar one of replacing our civilization with its own.

column1: Until we come to terms with this civilizational struggle

column1: 3704;8fa780ee683b4bd32201336c2075b3aea56bdae5;0;Ari Lieberman;2016-10-28T07:55:01.169+03:00;The Battle at UNESCO;"The Muslim Bloc may have won the battle
column2: but did Israel win the war? October 28
column3: 2016 Ari Lieberman

column1: By now it should be clear to all but the blindest (or rabidly disingenuous) that the United Nations is an organization that has been co-opted by the nefarious interests of Muslim nations and their despotic third world allies. It is an organization rife with prejudice and hypocrisy. An organization that can undeniably and without equivocation be described as today's greatest purveyor of Judeophobia
column2: historical revisionism and conspiracy theories. This fact is best illustrated by three resolutions passed this year by United Nations Educational
column3: Scientific
column4: and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) that deny the indisputable Jewish nexus to the holy city.

column1: On April 12
column2: the 58-member body voted in favor of an asinine and wholly one-sided resolution that referred to Jewish holy sites in Jerusalem exclusively by their Muslim names and designated the Temple Mount
column3: Judaism‚Äôs holiest site
column4: as a ‚ÄúMuslim holy site of worship.‚Äù To add insult to injury
column5: the resolution also adopted wild conspiracy theories including a claim that Israel was ‚Äúplanting Jewish fake graves in other spaces of the Muslim cemeteries.‚Äù

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: the resolution
column3: which was submitted by seven Muslim nations
column4: passed by a wide margin with 33 votes in favor
column5: six against and 17 abstentions. Two nations were absent for the vote. France
column6: Sweden
column7: Slovenia and Spain shamefully supported the vile resolution.

column1: That the resolution would pass was never in doubt given the large number of Muslim and despotic third world nations that constitute the makeup of UNESCO but it was hoped that the resolution would fail to garner European support and Israel could thus claim a moral victory. France with its collaborationist past and proclivity to kowtow to the world‚Äôs despots did not disappoint and predictably voted with the rabble.
But following the vote
column2: a crack appeared in the fa√ßade of anti-Israel invective so prevalent at the U.N. It appeared that France was having a case of buyer‚Äôs remorse. In an address to the French parliament
column3: Prime Minister Manuel Valls termed the resolution ‚Äúclumsy‚Äù and ‚Äúunfortunate.‚Äù He then added in rather sharp and pointed terms that ‚ÄúFrance will never deny the Jewish presence and Jewish history in Jerusalem. It would make no sense; it is absurd to deny this history.‚Äù

column1: France is one of Europe‚Äôs strongest advocates for the Palestinians. The Palestinian Authority and their Muslim allies at UNESCO should have understood from Valls‚Äô statement that future resolutions with similar toxic content would no longer enjoy automatic European support. Instead of declaring victory and moving on
column2: they pressed their luck by introducing another vile resolution in October.

column1: The October 13 resolution
column2: sponsored by the usual suspects contained nearly identical language as the April resolution. It condemned Israel for various contrived transgressions and again severed the Jewish (and Christian) nexus to the city. This time however
column3: the Muslim bloc was in for a rude awakening. While the resolution passed
column4: the Muslim bloc was unable to garner a majority in the 58-member body.

column1: Of the 24 nations that voted in favor of the resolution (Mexico later withdrew support lowering the final tally to 23)
column2: 14 were composed of states with Muslim majorities while a fifteenth
column3: Nigeria
column4: is 50 percent Muslim
column5: making passage of the resolution a forgone conclusion. What was notable was the fact that this time around
column6: the resolution failed to garner a single western European concurrence. Other developing nations
column7: like India
column8: which had hitherto supported Arab-sponsored drafts also abstained. Israel‚Äôs behind-the-scenes political offensive aimed at exposing the lunacy of the Muslim initiative was paying dividends.

column1: Following the resolution‚Äôs passage
column2: the Palestinians and their Muslim allies suffered additional political reversals. Mexico
column3: asked for a revote because it wished to withdraw support for the motion. Mexico's Secretariat of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that his government‚Äôs changed position ‚Äúreiterates the recognition that the Government of Mexico gives the undeniable link of the Jewish people to the cultural heritage of East Jerusalem.‚Äù

column1: Brazil soon followed suit echoing Mexico‚Äôs position. In a statement
column2: the Brazilian government noted that it would no longer support such one-sided resolutions. Italy
column3: which had abstained
column4: went one step further and announced that it would actively oppose such resolutions in the future. Prime Minister Matteo Renzi told an Italian radio station that these resolutions were ‚Äúincomprehensible
column5: unacceptable and wrong.‚Äù He added that ‚Äúto say that the Jews have no links to Jerusalem is like saying the sun creates darkness.‚Äù

column1: Even UNESCO‚Äôs director-general
column2: Irina Bokova voiced disapproval by stating that ‚Äúthe heritage of Jerusalem is indivisible
column3: and each of its communities has a right to the explicit recognition of their history and relationship with the city.‚Äù She later received death threats for voicing objection to the motion.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: the Palestinian Authority and Jordan introduced a third draft resolution to UNESCO‚Äôs World Heritage Committee seeking to generate further political terrorism. The proposed resolution once again attempted to sever the Jewish nexus to the city and its holy sites. The 21-member WHC body was expected to pass the resolution by consensus but in a surprise move
column3: Croatia and Tanzania asked for a secret ballot which infuriated the Muslim bloc. Instead of the motion passing by consensus
column4: the vote was 10 in favor
column5: two opposed
column6: eight abstentions and one nation absent.

column1: The two nations opposing were Tanzania and the Philippines. Of the 10 ayes
column2: seven were Muslim. It was a pyrrhic victory at best.

column1: Given the large number of Muslim countries represented at the U.N. and the hostility that most of these nations harbor against Israel
column2: it is a virtual certainty that toxic resolutions of this nature will continue to be sponsored and passed. But as evidenced by recent Arab political reversals
column3: gone are the days that the Palestinians can rely on automatic European and non-aligned support.

column1: Israel has been effectively reaching out to the so-called non-aligned nations and it is having a significant positive impact. Part of the Israeli success lies in the fact that the Jewish state has much to offer these nations in the fields of water technology
column2: agriculture
column3: energy
column4: counter-terrorism
column5: cyber warfare and arms. This outreach has translated to political dividends at the U.N.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the UNESCO resolutions serve to highlight the noxious nature and malevolence of many U.N. member states. It also underscores the need for the United States to maintain its commitment and assurance to Israel that it will never allow the U.N. to impose terms and dictates on Israel.

column1: There have been rumors circulating that Barack Obama in his twilight months would seek to impose a deleterious settlement on Israel utilizing the UN Security Council. The White House has remained uncharacteristically mute on the subject raising fears that there may be some merit to the speculation.
The administration‚Äôs objective would be accomplished by actively supporting a proposed anti-Israel resolution
column2: likely introduced by France
column3: or by choosing to abstain rather than exercising a veto. In addition to betraying long-standing commitments to Israel and running counter to strong bipartisan opposition
column4: the notion that the United States would throw Israel under the bus and allow those who engage in despotism and blatant anti-Semitism to have a say on Israel‚Äôs fate
column5: is beyond asinine. Hopefully
column6: the outrageous conduct exhibited at UNESCO steers the administration in the right direction.";english;2016-10-28T07:55:01.169+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;The Battle at UNESCO;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/sw.jpg?itok=bxOjUWH-;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3705;d0be11bcd518e84364dc28b5cd6d919ab397c914;0;Caroline Glick;2016-10-28T07:55:02.971+03:00;Checkmating Obama;"Originally published by the Jerusalem Post .
In one of the immortal lines of Godfather 2
column2: mafia boss Michael Corleone discusses the fate of his brother
column3: who betrayed him
column4: with his enforcer. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anything to happen to him while my mother is alive
column5: ‚Äù Corleone said.

column1: Message received. The brother was murdered after their mother‚Äôs funeral. Last week it was reported that the Obama administration has delivered a message to the Palestinian Authority. The administration has warned the PA that the US will veto any anti-Israel resolution brought before the UN Security Council before the US presidential elections on November 8. Message received. Open season on Israel at the Security Council will commence November 9. The Palestinians are planning appropriately. Israel needs to plan
column2: too. Israel‚Äôs most urgent diplomatic mission today is to develop and implement a strategy that will outflank President Barack Obama in his final eight weeks in power. Lobbying the administration is pointless. Obama has waited eight years to exact his revenge on Israel for not supporting his hostile
column3: strategically irrational policies. And he has no interest in letting bygones be bygones. Before turning to what Israel must do
column4: first we need to understand what Israel can do. A good place to begin is by considering what just transpired at UNESCO
column5: where twice in a week
column6: UNESCO bodies resolved to erase 3
column7: 000 years of Jewish history in Jerusalem and the Temple Mount. The fight that Israel waged at UNESCO is not the fight it needs to wage at the Security Council. The stakes at the Security Council are far higher. Like the UN General Assembly
column8: UNESCO‚Äôs decisions are non-binding declarations that have no legal or operational significance. As such
column9: there is no reason to expend great resources to fight them. For Israel
column10: the goal of the fight at UNESCO is not to defeat anti-Israel initiatives. That is impossible given the Palestinians‚Äô automatic majority. The purpose of the fight at UNESCO is to humiliate European governments that side with antisemitic initiatives
column11: and to weaken the congenitally anti-Israel body itself. The government achieved both of these objectives. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi‚Äôs disavowal of his own government‚Äôs abstention from the vote on the first resolution ‚Äì like the similar position taken after the fact by the Mexican government ‚Äì was a diplomatic victory for Israel. So too
column12: the fact that UNESCO‚Äôs own Secretary-General Irina Bukova felt compelled to disavow her own agency‚Äôs actions by rejecting the resolution‚Äôs denial of the Jewish people‚Äôs ties to Jerusalem was a significant victory for Israel. Her statement was deeply damaging for UNESCO and its reputation. Finally
column13: the fact that Tanzania and the Philippines voted against the resolution was a testament to Israel‚Äôs capacity to convince other governments to abandon their traditional pro-Palestinian voting pattern. The Palestinians won the vote at UNESCO because they are more powerful diplomatically than Israel. They have an automatic anti-Israel majority. But they weren‚Äôt empowered by their victory. To the contrary. They were bloodied by it. In a sign of their weakening hold on member nations
column14: the Palestinians and Jordanians felt compelled to send a threatening letter to the members of UNESCO‚Äôs World Heritage Committee lest they dare to vote against the resolution. Powerful players don‚Äôt make threats. They don‚Äôt need to. Israel‚Äôs experience at UNESCO teaches us that there are governments that are open to counteroffers. Israel doesn‚Äôt need to hide in America‚Äôs shadow. It is capable of working on its own to blunt the impact of the Palestinians‚Äô automatic majority. And it will need to use all of its resources to fend off a US-backed assault at the Security Council. Unlike UNESCO
column15: the Security Council can pass legally binding resolutions. Israel needs to be prepared to bring all of its resources to bear to prevent such a resolution from being adopted against it. Obama‚Äôs intention to abandon Israel at the Security Council means that Israel comes to this battle severely hobbled. But there is one advantage to the US‚Äôs betrayal. Over the years
column16: Israel‚Äôs ability to trust the US to veto anti-Israel resolutions at the Security Council was been a mixed blessing. On the one hand
column17: the US has secured Israel from diplomatic assaults. But on the other hand
column18: our ability to trust Washington has made us diplomatically lazy and ineffective. Safe in Washington‚Äôs shadow
column19: we have behaved as through all diplomacy is public diplomacy. That is
column20: we have pretended that statecraft begins and ends with making the moral or strategic case for our side against the other guys. But public diplomacy is just one diplomatic tool. The Syrian regime
column21: for instance
column22: has no moral case for securing international support. Bashar Assad didn‚Äôt convince Russian President Vladimir Putin to support him by arguing that he is better than alternative regimes. He bought Putin‚Äôs support by offering him permanent air and naval bases in Syria. Then there is Morocco
column23: another weak state with no public diplomacy case to make. Last March
column24: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon outraged Rabat when he acknowledged the plain fact that Western Sahara
column25: which Morocco occupies
column26: is ‚Äúoccupied territory.‚Äù Morocco quickly secured the support of Spain and France and launched an all-out onslaught against Ban. How did Morocco manage? Morocco‚Äôs most powerful diplomatic resource is its control over migration flows from North Africa to Europe. Anytime it wishes
column27: Rabat can open the migratory floodgates just as easily as it can keep them shut. And the French and Spanish know it. In less than a month
column28: Ban issued repeated abject apologies. Game. Set. Match. Morocco. From reports to date
column29: it appears that shortly after the US elections on November 8
column30: the Malaysians or Egyptians will submit a Palestinian-backed resolution that defines Israeli communities in united Jerusalem
column31: Judea and Samaria as illegal. If the resolution is brought to a vote
column32: the US will fail to veto it. Such a resolution
column33: or a resolution obligating Israel to withdraw to the 1949 armistice lines
column34: would cause Israel grave harm. So what resources does Israel have to prevent this from happening? Of course
column35: we have public diplomacy. And that might work with some friendly nations. But it won‚Äôt get us over the top. We need to learn from the Syrian and Moroccan examples and consider what we have to offer Security Council members in exchange for their support in scuttling the approaching onslaught against us. One such resource is the US Congress. Israel‚Äôs allies in Congress are sickened by the Obama administration‚Äôs devastating Middle East policies. A solid majority of lawmakers can be trusted to support actions that will reinforce Israel‚Äôs position. Israel has other resources as well that we can trade on. We have natural gas. And we have technologies that the governments of the world require to surmount the challenges of the 21 century. There is no reason to give these resources away when we can trade them for diplomatic support. As for the Palestinians
column36: as the UNESCO vote showed
column37: they are less popular now than at any time in the past 40 years. All they have to offer is threats and antisemitism. Both are powerful weapons. But they are no longer invincible. Israel‚Äôs goal must be to use our resources at the Security Council in a manner that will make it impossible for Obama to enable an anti-Israel resolution to pass. A method for achieving this goal has two components. The first component is to convince a friendly country on the Security Council to propose a balanced resolution that would counter the Palestinian-backed Israel-bashing one. Such a resolution could include four points. First
column38: it could deplore efforts to deny Jewish history in Jerusalem and the Temple Mount. Second
column39: it can condemn the PA/PLO for their continued unlawful funding of terrorists. Third
column40: it can urge Israel to restrain settlement construction in areas that in previous negotiations have been identified as likely territory for a future Palestinian state. Fourth
column41: it can call on Israel and the PA to reinstate negotiations immediately without preconditions. Israel has friendly ties with a few Security Council members
column42: among them Uruguay and New Zealand. In the final weeks of the Obama era
column43: it is possible that Israel will be able to convince one of them to submit a balanced resolution along these lines. Obama would be hard-pressed to oppose such a resolution in favor of one that singles Israel out for rebuke. But that still is insufficient. Obama can make Uruguay and New Zealand a better offer if he wishes. And so we move to the second aspect of the plan. If we learn nothing else from the Obama era
column44: we must recognize that the time has come for Israel to stop sufficing with just one Security Council veto. Most states have several. And we need a few more. Russia today is the best place to start our search for a second veto. Putin is a dealmaker. As his agreement with Assad showed
column45: he is willing to consider attractive offers. Obviously
column46: Israel won‚Äôt offer Russia bases. But we do have other things to offer Putin in exchange for a veto. For instance
column47: in exchange for a Russian veto at the Security Council
column48: Israel can offer Putin to lobby the US Congress to cancel US sanctions against Russia over Russia‚Äôs annexation of Crimea. Israel has no dog in that fight. And the sanctions are not getting the US anywhere. Putin might go for the deal for two reasons. First
column49: by stepping into the breach and defending Israel against Obama
column50: he will humiliate Obama. Second
column51: if Israel succeeds with the Congress
column52: he will reap economic rewards. For his part
column53: Putin wouldn‚Äôt even have to openly side with Israel. All he would have to do is announce that in the interests of regional stability
column54: Russia will not support an unbalanced resolution on Israel and the Palestinians. If Putin supports a balanced resolution
column55: Obama will be checkmated. His plan to take revenge on Israel for not following him off the strategic cliff will be foiled. Israel will have survived his presidency. None of this will be easy. And success is far from assured. There are many more ways for Israel to fail than succeed. Our diplomatic weakness remains a millstone around our neck. But as the UNESCO resolutions showed
column56: attacking Israel is no longer cost free. We are not powerless in the grip of circumstances. We have cards to play. And now is the time to play them for all they are worth.";english;2016-10-28T07:55:02.971+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Checkmating Obama;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/barack_obama_with_benjamin_netanyahu_in_the_oval_office_5-18-09_2.jpg?itok=OagIot3x;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3706;d309e071cd1a3941ec26d8aace5068201b630fbb;0;Jack Kerwick;2016-10-28T07:55:05.430+03:00;Social Justice vs. Truth;"A look at the university‚Äôs new mission. October 28
column2: 2016 Jack Kerwick

column1: Jonathan Haidt
column2: a professor of social psychology at New York University
column3: argued in a recently published essay that while its traditional ‚Äútelos‚Äù (end or goal) has been truth
column4: within the last few decades the university has assumed another: Social Justice.

column1: The university
column2: however
column3: can only have one telos.

column1: The conflict between these two goals has raged for decades
column2: Haidt claims. Last year
column3: though
column4: it became unmanageable when student groups at 86 universities and colleges around the country issued ‚Äú demands ‚Äù to administrators
column5: demands for Social Justice that
column6: by and large
column7: were met.

column1: The following statement is posted at BlackLiberationCollective.org :
‚ÄúWe demand at the minimum
column2: Black students and Black faculty to be reflected by the national percentage of Black folk in the state and the country.

column1: We demand free intuition for Black and indigenous students.
We demand a divestment from prisons and an investment in communities.‚Äù

A statement of ‚Äúprinciples‚Äù follows. The Black Liberation Collective (BLC) opposes ‚Äúanti-Blackness;‚Äù ‚Äúsexism;‚Äù ‚Äúableism;‚Äù ‚Äúcapitalism;‚Äù ‚ÄúWhite privilege;‚Äù ‚Äúinequality;‚Äù and ‚Äúheteronormativity.‚Äù It rejects as well non-violence considered as a principle in contradistinction to a tactic .
‚ÄúAnti-Black racism is woven in the fabric of our global society
column2: ‚Äù says the BLC. ‚ÄúWhen social systems are racialized by white supremacy
column3: whiteness becomes the default of humanity and Blackness is stripped of its humanity
column4: becoming a commodity
column5: becoming disposable.‚Äù

column1: The BLC is ‚Äúanti-sexist‚Äù insofar as it affirms ‚Äúthe value of all Black women‚Äôs lives whether cisgender
column2: transgender
column3: or genderqueer.‚Äù In addition to rejecting ‚ÄúEurocentric beauty standards that are made to lessen the beauty of Black women and Black women‚Äôs features
column4: ‚Äù being ‚Äúanti-sexist‚Äù also means realizing that ‚Äúpolice brutality
column5: the prison industrial system
column6: school to prison pipeline‚Äù and the like are aspects of ‚Äústructural racism‚Äù that affect black women as much as they impact black men.

column1: Black liberation entails ‚Äúqueer liberation‚Äù and ‚Äútrans liberation.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe also seek to destroy the heteronormative norms that dehumanize Black queer people
column2: ‚Äù the BLC asserts. The ‚Äúhomophobia‚Äù within ‚Äúthe Black community‚Äù comes by way of ‚Äúthe same hands responsible for white supremacy.‚Äù

column1: Presumably
column2: ‚Äútransphobia‚Äù within the black community is also a legacy of white supremacy. In cooperation with ‚Äúcissexism‚Äù and ‚Äúthe gender binary
column3: ‚Äù ‚Äútransphobia‚Äù has ‚Äúbeen used as a means of invalidating and erasing our trans+ family members.‚Äù The BLC pledges to ‚Äúeliminate‚Äù such systemic biases.

column1: These Social Justice Warriors (SJWs) are staunch opponents of ‚Äúthe capitalist notions of infinite profit
column2: homogenized markets
column3: and a privatized means of production.‚Äù Capitalism
column4: they insist
column5: ‚Äúis the economic system‚Äù that‚Äôs been ‚Äúused to justify‚Äù the ‚Äúoppression
column6: ‚Äù ‚Äúmarginalization
column7: ‚Äù and ‚Äúexploitation‚Äù of blacks.

column1: Nor is the solution to this ‚Äúoppression‚Äù to be found in supporting black-owned businesses. The BLC explains that ‚Äúwe cannot adopt the patriarchal
column2: exploitative tools of our oppressors as we seek liberation.‚Äù Rather
column3: the solution is to ‚Äúdismantle anti-Black capitalist corporations that benefit from our oppression.‚Äù

column1: It isn‚Äôt only the ‚Äúcapitalist corporations‚Äù that these students want destroyed. They demand as well ‚Äúthe eradication of all institutional practices and policies that discriminate against the black community‚Äù and ‚Äúthe removal of all federal
column2: state
column3: and local government officials who do not abide by our principles.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúThe State and all its institutions that deny Black humanity and Black agency must be dismantled and replaced with those that produce Black liberty.‚Äù
Concerning its attitude toward America
column2: the BLC is clear: ‚ÄúThis country was built to systematically oppress groups of people
column3: and the Black Liberation Collective will not stand for it.‚Äù

column1: Haidt misspeaks in characterizing 2015 as the year when the university experienced a crisis of identity
column2: an unmanageable conflict of goals. To judge from the vast majority of liberal arts
column3: humanities
column4: and social sciences departments
column5: Social Justice long ago eclipsed truth as the raison d‚Äôetre of the academy. Interestingly
column6: it is these SJW demands from last year that bear this out.

column1: Perhaps it is because I‚Äôve spent the last couple of decades in the academy in the capacity of both student and faculty that I may be more privy to this than are some others
column2: but it‚Äôs painfully obvious that these student activists did not come up with these demands on their own. If they didn‚Äôt have their professors actually write the demands for them
column3: then the Black Liberation Collective unquestionably derived the concepts and language of their statement of demands from their mentors.

column1: To put it bluntly
column2: one must attend college
column3: major in the liberal arts and humanities
column4: and study under far left professors in order to think in the terms that are characteristic of Social Justice Warriors.

column1: Leftist ideologues are training their students to bend the university to their will. This is the first point. There is
column2: though
column3: another
column4: a rich irony that is lost upon these self-styled radicals.

column1: For all of their bluster over ‚Äúsystemic racism‚Äù and ‚Äústructural white supremacy
column2: ‚Äù i.e. phenomena that are omnipresent and
column3: hence
column4: largely unconscious
column5: these black students
column6: their white collaborators
column7: and their professors fail to realize that their thinking (for lack of a better term) on these issues is about as Eurocentric as one can get. The ‚Äú critical race theory ‚Äù to which the BLC subscribe is a version of Marxism
column8: the philosophical vision of a 19 th century German-Jewish man. The Marxist tradition within which they are enmeshed was fleshed out over a span of generations by mostly white heterosexual men.

column1: But there‚Äôs more to it than this.
The idea that ‚Äúracism
column2: ‚Äù ‚Äúsexism
column3: ‚Äù ‚Äúhomophobia
column4: ‚Äù ‚Äútransphobia
column5: ‚Äù ‚Äúableism
column6: ‚Äù and the like against which SJWs rail are evils to be defeated is itself peculiar to the moral traditions of European civilization. If these ‚Äúisms‚Äù and ‚Äúphobias‚Äù are immoral it can only be because those who are guilty of them fail to judge the individual as an individual. Color
column7: gender
column8: sexual orientation
column9: ability
column10: and so forth are neither constitutive of nor essential to the moral identity of the individual‚Äîbut only if the framework of the doctrine of individualism is accepted.

column1: Yet this conception of the sacrosanct individual is as Eurocentric as the proverbial ‚Äúapple pie‚Äù is American.

The Social Justice Warriors‚Äô intellectual landscape is as much a European ‚Äúcolony‚Äù as was any West African country in the 19 th or early 20 th centuries. Those in the Black Liberation Collective have most definitely internalized the modes of thought of their ‚Äúoppressor.‚Äù
Now
column2: they would have been well aware of all this had they received a genuine education in college rather than a training in Social Justice.";english;2016-10-28T07:55:05.430+03:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Social Justice vs. Truth;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/fd_1.jpg?itok=7y-_ZzGe;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3707;aaa12b761b881ac96572bbf50f5e320f92d523aa;0;Ilana Mercer;2016-10-28T07:55:06.853+03:00;Against Hillary's Malevolent Matriarchy;"What feminists can learn from Melania Trump. October 28
column2: 2016 Ilana Mercer

column1: In recent interviews
column2: Donald Trump's wife
column3: Melania Trump
column4: observed wryly that almost every malicious
column5: lie-filled article about herself or he husband was written by a ‚Ä¶ female. Indeed
column6: women seem to have a particular stake in bringing Mr. Trump down.

column1: The contrast between Mrs. Trump and the many histrionic shrews prosecuting her husband is stark. In both her interviews with CNN's condescending Anderson Cooper and Fox News's Ainsley Earhardt
column2: Mrs. Trump was the embodiment of ""strength.""

column1: When a liberal woman declares she's a strong woman (usually uttered in a tart-like
column2: staccato inflection)
column3: she's using a clich√©. Look at her actions. You'll see that ""strong"" to liberal distaff means kicking and screaming until she brings others into compliance with her worldview and ways.

column1: A ""strong"" liberal woman is one who hammers you about your obligation to fork-out for her Trojans and her Trivora. And if birth control fails our liberated libertine
column2: then you're on the hook for her abortions and abortifacients. And don't dare doubt any of the intemperate charges leveled by this prototype liberal succubus against a man
column3: any man. To doubt her is to harm her.

column1: It was not without significance that Hillary Clinton‚Äôs first general election speech
column2: in June
column3: was before Planned Parenthood. At the time
column4: media buried the story of one named Rajiv K. Fernando
column5: who had donated to the Clinton Foundation and was given a seat as Hillary‚Äôs nuclear weapons advisor. Watching this
column6: I was thinking endemic corruption
column7: the $19 trillion debt
column8: the dire jobs report
column9: the terrifying prospect of negative interest rates and the fate of savers. But Hillary and her gyno-brigade in media and across the country were cheering for a universal right to taxpayer-paid dilation and curettage (D&C).

column1: Melania Trump
column2: on the other hand
column3: is authentically strong.

column1: In her refusal to impart salacious tell-all tidbits to interviewers
column2: in the way she guards her privacy and that of her family; in her serene
column3: gracious
column4: and beautiful manners and bearing‚ÄîMrs. Trump exemplifies a European woman's good breeding. She's a class act. Her enemies are the cultural underclass.

column1: Nor does Mrs. Trump display any of the histrionics about men exhibited by her American counterparts. There are images on the Internet of presidents being inappropriate with women. In particular
column2: you can watch a grainy YouTube clip of Barack Obama appearing to be showing off his crotch to giggling female reporters. In another
column3: the president
column4: with France's Nicolas Sarkozy
column5: is eying the shapely behind of a young woman passing by. Much to media chagrin
column6: Melania refused to get worked up about the 2005 Access Hollywood tape in which her husband engaged in locker-room talk.

column1: Men will be men. If they're not saying it; they're thinking it.
More material than her mien were Melania Trump's words of reason. On the Soviet-style witch-hunt launched against her husband with media mediation
column2: she said this: ‚ÄúAll sexual assault allegations should be handled in a court of law. To accuse someone
column3: man or woman
column4: without evidence is damaging and unfair.‚Äù This was the exact verdict of famed defense attorney Tom Mesereau
column5: about the Bill Cosby pile-on. Quit the feeding frenzy. Give the man his due process. Investigate the women
column6: counseled Mesereau
column7: Esq.
column8: at the time.

column1: The very embodiment of the malevolent liberal matriarchy rising is the sainted Michelle Obama. The First Lady was lauded for an unhinged anti-Trump address to the nation's women. In a world where Americans have been beheaded on camera
column2: women raped en masse on Europe's streets
column3: and Christians exterminated in the Middle East‚Äîthe First Lady bewailed being ""shaken"" to her shallow core by raunchy words. ""I can't stop thinking about it
column4: groaned Michelle about Mr. Trump's Access Hollywood indiscretion. It ""has shaken me to my core in a way I could not have predicted.""

column1: The ritualistic decapitation on the altar of a Catholic priest by Muslim migrants in France: That's something ""I can't stop thinking about."" The machine-gunning of five Macy's shoppers and employees by a Turkish Muslim immigrant (Arcan Cetin)
column2: in my neck of the woods: That ""has shaken me to my core in a way I could not have predicted."" Again
column3: Mrs. Obama's pitiful case against Mr. Trump has strengthened nothing but her drama-queen credentials.

column1: Candidate Clinton crowed that Mrs. Obama's long whinge for women was a ""compelling and strong case about the stakes in the election
column2: about who we are as Americans."" Indeed
column3: the implicit case Michelle put to women is this: a mammoth national debt
column4: a shrinking job market
column5: rising lawlessness and racial strife
column6: an annual intake of mostly Third-World immigrants exceeding 3 million
column7: the dangers to life and limb of importing more Islam: fuhgeddaboudit. What counts
column8: whimpered Michelle Obama
column9: voice trembling‚Äîyes
column10: Mrs. Obama almost brought herself to tears‚Äîwas to ferret out microaggression
column11: and find a safe-place to hunker down.

column1: As I write
column2: Sen. Elizabeth Warren has stormed a stage somewhere for Hillary Clinton. Phony Pocahontas is hollering about the power of ""nasty women"" to immiserate. Clinton and Warren make for a resentful
column3: domineering
column4: power-hungry pair
column5: who‚Äôve made it big in life through the use of state power. The human backdrop to their displays of female force invariably looks the same.

column1: Whereas Trump rallies are packed with hope-filled
column2: beaming faces; a Clinton-Warren affair is festooned with malevolent-looking
column3: aggrieved women and their frightened
column4: low-T houseboys. The background music: enfeebled squeaking courtesy of a female pop ‚Äúsinger‚Äù like Katy Perry
column5: whose out-of-tune yelps and bedroom whispers would be unheard
column6: if not for the marvel of Auto-Tune. (Auto-Tune is the ‚Äúholy grail of recording‚Äù that ‚Äúcorrects intonation problems in vocals or solo instruments
column7: in real time
column8: without distortion or artifacts.‚Äù It was invented by a male engineer.)

column1: Shudder.
If this melodramatic

column1: Reprinted from NyTimes.com.
She leads a clandestine existence

column1: Shaken but undeterred by the fatwas and relentless

Fleeing Paris or abandoning her human rights activism
column3: and her unforgiving critiques of the religion she grew up with
column4: are also out of the question.

column5: as part of French president Francois Hollande‚Äôs delegation when he received the Appeal of Conscience Foundation‚Äôs World Statesman Award for 2016. ‚ÄúIf the French state protects me it is not little individual me: What is being protected is my freedom to be irreverent
column6: and freedom of expression

column1: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs totally crazy. I have done nothing against the law and have nothing to hide

column3: ‚Äù El Rhazoui declares with an air of shock and anger that underscores the arbitrariness and brutality visited on a 34-year-old woman condemned to living on the run and mostly in the shadows. ‚ÄúAnd if you call them by their names you are Islamophobic and racist. I am racist? I can teach them a few things about Arab culture. I can show them how to discover its richness and the diversity of their culture. I believe this culture deserves universality because you can be Arab
column4: Muslim and a free thinker.‚Äù

column1: Resisting terror
Sweeping in to the offices of Women in the World in Manhattan
column2: accompanied by bodyguards
column3: the world-renowned journalist is living proof of her pledge to keep ‚Äúliving her life beyond its limits‚Äù as a key way of resisting terror. Elegant and beautiful
column4: with her long
column5: wavy hair flowing freely and in an impeccably tailored black dress
column6: El Rhazoui is reminiscent of 1940s cinema‚Äôs cerebral heroines ‚Äî her eloquence and composure only occasionally betraying the trauma of the past 20 months. Each time we speak about the aftermath of the massacre at her magazine and how she is coping personally her voice quavers
column7: but when the subject comes back to her fight for reform in Islamic civilization she is fearless.

column1: In this spirit

column1: Zineb El Rhazoui feels she is carrying on the legacy of her dead Charlie Hebdo comrades.
After completing high school in Morocco
column2: El Rhazoui studied languages and the sociology of religion
column3: obtaining a Master‚Äôs degree from Paris‚Äôs prestigious social science graduate school EHESS. In her twenties she returned to the country of her birth to work as a journalist at Le Journal Hebdomadaire
column4: becoming a campaigner for secular liberties
column5: such as the right to break the fast and even snack in public during the month of Ramadan. This act of non-violent resistance earned her her first fatwa
column6: ahead of her involvement in the movement supporting the Arab Spring in 2011. The wave of personal attacks and threats that came after her collective protest against Ramadan rules prompted her to leave Morocco again for France where she began to report for Charlie Hebdo
column7: bringing her memories of having ‚Äúvomited up compulsory religious classes‚Äù in a country where ‚Äúbeing Muslim is not a choice‚Äù unless you‚Äôre Jewish or Christian.

Destroy Islamic Fascism aims to puncture the hypocrisy and faux-intellectual ‚Äúfakery‚Äù (the author‚Äôs word) of ‚ÄúIslamophobia whiners‚Äù and other ‚Äúcollaborationists‚Äù from across the political spectrum ‚Äî particularly the hard left

column1: Survivor syndrome
Women in the World asked El Rhazoui how she manages to keep up her spirits
column2: and continue her struggle for the freedom to dissent after everything that has happened since January 2015.

column1: ‚ÄúIt is a question people often ask me
column2: ‚Äù she said with a perceptible tremor in her voice. ‚ÄúBut when you live through these moments in which you are confronted by a reality as cruel and simple as life and death
column3: you realize can put many things in perspective.

column1: ‚ÄúStraight after the attacks
column2: like many of my colleagues I felt guilty for having stayed alive. I said to myself ‚ÄòThose who are dead are dead for all our work
column3: and some are dead when it wasn‚Äôt even their work. But it was my work because I am a journalist and I am still here.‚Äô And then you understand this is all part of survivor syndrome
column4: which is normal when you survive a massacre like that.

column1: ‚ÄúAs you start to heal you say
column2: ‚ÄòI am lucky to be alive and if I am still here perhaps that is because I still have something to do.‚Äô I understood long before the attack on Charlie
column3: when I engaged in a struggle for individual liberties and democracy in Morocco
column4: that when you fight against totalitarianism
column5: whether it is political or religious
column6: you should never give your enemies the pleasure of stopping living. We fight so that everyone can have a free and happy life and we must continue to live this same life.

column1: Life in a moving jail
Since January 2015
column2: the survivor from Charlie Hebdo has traveled frequently to speak at universities and meetings of the Freedom Forum
column3: in Europe and the U.S.
column4: under the protection assured by the French state and the countries that receive her. She says she would never complain about living under permanent armed guard and having her freedom of mobility curtailed
column5: because so many other writers and political figures around the world ‚Äî and especially in Islamist-controlled or influenced countries ‚Äî are taking the brave decisions to do as she does but without any security.

column1: ‚ÄúI always find some spaces of freedom. There are always little escape hatches. Life continues!‚Äù says the woman who has just written her second book since the Charlie attacks
column2: and recently became a first-time mother
column3: in what she laughingly called the surprise ‚Äúbaby boom‚Äù at a publication that used to have ‚Äúone of the lowest birthrates in French media.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúToday I wander around in a moving jail ‚Äî it‚Äôs a moving cage ‚Äî but in reality I am more free in my head than those who threaten me. Because their cage is inside their head. They have this cage in their brain and even if they have freedom of movement it is their spirit and their reason and intelligence that is imprisoned. I am much freer than them.‚Äù

column1: The persecution of Christians in the Islamic world has become endemic. Accordingly
column2: ‚ÄúMuslim Persecution of Christians‚Äù was developed to collate some‚Äîby no means all‚Äîof the instances of persecution that surface each month. It serves two purposes:

column2: if not chronic
column3: persecution of Christians.

column1: 2) To show that such persecution is not ‚Äúrandom
column2: ‚Äù but systematic and interrelated‚Äîthat it is rooted in a worldview inspired by Islamic Sharia.

column1: Accordingly
column2: whatever the anecdote of persecution
column3: it typically fits under a specific theme
column4: including hatred for churches and other Christian symbols; apostasy
column5: blasphemy
column6: and proselytism laws that criminalize and sometimes punish with death those who ‚Äúoffend‚Äù Islam; sexual abuse of Christian women; forced conversions to Islam; theft and plunder in lieu of jizya (financial tribute expected from non-Muslims); overall expectations for Christians to behave like cowed dhimmis
column7: or third-class
column8: ‚Äútolerated‚Äù citizens; and simple violence and murder. Sometimes it is a combination thereof.

column2: languages
column3: and locales‚Äîfrom Morocco in the West
column4: to Indonesia in the East‚Äîit should be clear that one thing alone binds them: Islam‚Äîwhether the strict application of Islamic Sharia law
column5: or the supremacist culture born of it.

column1: Sam Harris thinks it‚Äôs ‚Äúunbelievable‚Äù that Maajid Nawaz and Ayaan Hirsi Ali made it to the Southern Poverty Law Center‚Äôs hit list of ‚ÄúAnti-Muslim Extremists.‚Äù He said nothing about me or the other people whom the SPLC included
column2: which is not surprising
column3: since he has quite recently expressed willingness to acquiesce in other contexts to the demonization that the SPLC list exemplifies.

column1: Hemant Mehta of The Friendly Atheist blog ably sums up the outrage over Nawaz and Hirsi Ali being included: ‚ÄúIf criticizing religious beliefs makes them extremists
column2: then it won‚Äôt be long before other vocal atheists end up on that list too. And make no mistake
column3: that‚Äôs what Nawaz and Hirsi Ali are doing. That‚Äôs all they‚Äôre doing. They‚Äôre not anti-Muslim; they work with moderate Muslims. They‚Äôre critical of the worst aspects of Islam.‚Äù

column1: The problem with being angry about Nawaz and Hirsi Ali being on the SPLC list
column2: but silent about everyone else who is on it
column3: is that what Mehta says about Nawaz and Hirsi Ali can quite accurately said about everyone else on the list. If criticizing religious beliefs makes them ‚Äúextremists
column4: ‚Äù then it won‚Äôt be long before everyone who dares to utter a critical word about Islam will be on the list ‚Äî and that is indeed the objective of the list: to stigmatize and marginalize any and all such critics. Mehta protests that Nawaz and Hirsi Ali are ‚Äúnot anti-Muslim; they work with moderate Muslims. They‚Äôre critical of the worst aspects of Islam.‚Äù

column1: But no one would think that the other 13 were ‚Äúanti-Muslim‚Äù if it hadn‚Äôt been for the Southern Poverty Law Center and the Hamas-linked Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) and their allied groups insisting that we were all these years
column2: in their avidity to conflate opposition to jihad terror and Sharia oppression with hating a group of people ‚Äî a tactic designed to discredit opposition to jihad terror and Sharia oppression. Mehta and co. are falling for and validating the same smear tactics hey are decrying when used against their friends.

column1: And as for working with moderate Muslims
column2: for 13 years Jihad Watch has contained this invitation : ‚ÄúAny Muslim who renounces violent jihad and dhimmitude is welcome to join in our anti-jihadist efforts.‚Äù It is Nawaz (as well as other moderates) who has attacked me
column3: in what appears to have been a cynical attempt to gain support for himself among Muslims; I never attacked him
column4: and would have have been happy to work with him otherwise.

column1: In complaining that Nawaz and Hirsi Ali are merely ‚Äúcriticizing religious beliefs‚Äù and are ‚Äúnot anti-Muslim
column2: ‚Äù Mehta is strongly implying that the others on the SPLC list are doing something beyond ‚Äúcriticizing religious beliefs‚Äù and are indeed ‚Äúanti-Muslim.‚Äù On Twitter the last couple of days I‚Äôve seen many people express outrage that Nawaz has been lumped in with the likes of Spencer; but when I ask them what the big difference is between us
column3: or for quotes from me that are actually ‚Äúbigoted
column4: ‚Äù they go silent.

column2: Harris
column3: Haider and the others who are only angry with the SPLC‚Äôs hit list because it included Nawaz and Hirsi Ali are

column1: 3732;e201587fe7cab4ea8d0f26d1242243fe64daa307;0;Daniel Greenfield;2016-10-31T14:57:59.335+02:00;Is Hillary Panicking Over the FBI and Weiner Emails?;"Is Hillary Panicking Over the FBI and Weiner Emails?

column1: But now we have open hostilities between Lynch at the DOJ and the FBI. We have the Clinton campaign circulating a letter attacking the FBI. We have countless media hit pieces aimed at the FBI.
The obvious question is why. The Clinton campaign kept its cool

column3: before. It certainly didn't begin an ill-advised campaign against the FBI. That's the kind of tactic that may play to your core base

column1: So what's going on here?

column3: and now she's in a state of fury at having it put at risk.

The first is plausible. To a degree. But for all of Hillary's awkwardness

column1: Simply repeating the ‚Äúhard-working

column1: Who is this ‚Äúwe‚Äù?
