The war on law enforcement is epidemic. Every aspect of culture has been infected. The anti-police disease is highly contagious and rapidly spreading on social media
column2: in memes
column3: in movements
column4: in popular fast food restaurants
column5: at football games
column6: on campuses
column7: in media and in every aspect of American culture.

column1: An epidemic is defined as the rapid spread of infectious disease to a large number of people in a given population within a short period of time. Colin Kaepernick is the Typhoid Mary of the anti-police epidemic. Kaepernick refuses to stand while the U.S. national anthem is being performed at the start of NFL games as a protest against alleged racial injustice and police brutality. On Sept. 1 Kaepernick chose to kneel on one knee as his protest gesture instead of just sitting on the bench. His explanation for his decision to switch is that it was an attempt to show more respect to former and current U.S. military members. As if kneeling is somehow symbolically less offensive than sitting. He misinterpreted the meaning of the military expression
column2: ‚Äòtake a knee‚Äô which occurs when troops take a pause before continuing their mission. Similar to ‚ÄòHands Up Don‚Äôt Shoot‚Äô the anti-police gesture has been imbued with a trendy righteousness regardless of its original meaning. The media reverently refers to Kaepernick‚Äôs protest as ‚ÄòTaking a Knee‚Äô as if it is some kind of sacred act. There are no headlines that read ‚ÄòKaepernick Disses the Flag‚Äô or ‚ÄòKaepernick Takes a Crap on his Country‚Äô. Just in case his gesture didn‚Äôt send a clear enough message
column3: Kaepernick also uses clothing to symbolize his anti-police sympathies. He has worn everything from t-shirts honoring the militant Black Panther Party to socks that depict police as pigs. In addition to numerous other crimes the Black Panther Party was responsible for the murder of at least 15 officers and originated the expression ‚ÄòOff the Pigs‚Äô meaning murder police.

column1: Like the typhoid infected cook Mary Mallon
column2: Kaepernick is rapidly spreading the anti-police pathogen. In what has been dubbed the ‚ÄòKaepernick Effect‚Äô dozens of NFL and WNBA players have knelt
column3: sat
column4: or raised a fist during the national anthem. The disease has also spread to over 50 high schools
column5: 35 colleges
column6: and one middle school. In what can only be described as a bizarre symbolic contradiction there were two incidents where women performing the Star Spangled Banner got down on one knee in protest of what they were singing. One of the women
column7: Denasia Lawrence
column8: not only kneeled while performing the anthem but also opened her jacket to display a Black Lives Matter t-shirt exposing Miami Heat fans to the contagious disorder.

column1: Rapid spread is well known for infectious diseases. The anti-police disorder also contaminated the Navy. An unidentified sailor assigned to the Naval Air Technical Training Center in Pensacola
column2: Florida
column3: filmed herself deliberately not standing for the National Anthem and posted it on Facebook. She remained seated and raised a fist during morning colors and then praised Colin Kaepernick. Another sailor Petty Officer 2nd Class Janaye Ervin
column4: an intelligence specialist in the Navy Reserve
column5: stationed at Pearl Harbor
column6: did not stand for the national anthem while in uniform. She also posted a statement on Facebook saying she was inspired by Colin Kaepernick. The Navy acted decisively. She lost her security clearance and may be facing jail in response to her actions. It is yet to be known if facing real consequences will contribute to curing the virus or accelerating it.

column1: Kaepernick is just one carrier of the anti-police disease. The source of the infection can be attributed to specific movements such as Black Lives Matter that originated in Florida during the Trayvon Martin protests. The disease went airborne in Ferguson
column2: Missouri where it was transmitted to college students
column3: professional protesters and journalists who subsequently spread the disorder to towns and cities across the country. Currently the disease seems to cluster around populations that are susceptible to antipolice propaganda. The symptoms are irrationality
column4: excessive anger
column5: impaired perception
column6: anxiety
column7: hatred and delusions of oppression. Acute symptoms include sudden changes in behavior
column8: aggression
column9: paranoia
column10: loss of control and homicidal and suicidal tendencies. All indicators are expressed in severe disrespect for law and order.

column1: Early symptoms of the antipolice epidemic have been observed in various cultural manifestations of contempt for law enforcement officers. Anti-police graffiti is a common symptom of the virus. Writing has escalated from insults such as ‚Äòpolice are murderers‚Äô to threats of violence. A recent popular indicator is the expression ‚ÄòKill Cops‚Äô and related variations such as ‚ÄòKill All Police‚Äô

column4: ‚ÄòCops Lives Don‚Äôt Matter‚Äô and ‚ÄòShoot Cops‚Äô. Threats are also depicted in images such as guns to officers‚Äô heads. Violent anti-police rhetoric has also been seen in protest signs that read ‚ÄòAll My Heroes Kill Cops‚Äô
column5: ‚ÄòPut Wings on Pigs‚Äô [Kill Cops] and ‚ÄòCops Under Control Or Cops Under Flowers‚Äô. Disturbingly
column6: anti-police graffiti

column6: ‚ÄúI'm going to mess with them

column1: At its most critical stage the anti-police disorder is lethal. This is expressed in the dozens of ambushes and killings of police officers. In the most acute phase of the disease some of those infected become homicidal and suicidal targeting and killing officers knowing that they will die in the incident. A pattern has emerged that clearly demonstrates that attacks on police escalate from protest gestures to acts of vandalism to deadly shootings that inspire further demonstrations in a continual cycle of protest and violence. Consequently
column2: Kaepernick‚Äôs gesture is neither benign nor harmless. column1: 3742;ece9a79391801abca37e26d50515168759646ce6;0;Raymond Ibrahim;2016-11-01T07:32:55.554+02:00;Force and Fanaticism: Wahhabism in Saudi Arabia and Beyond;"Force and Fanaticism : Wahhabism in Saudi Arabia and Beyond Is ‚ÄúWahhabism‚Äù a complete distortion of Islam? November 1

column1: Note: In what follows

column3: by Simon Ross Valentine. A shorter version of the book review first appeared in the Middle East Quarterly (Fall
column5: vol. 23

column1: Valentine
column2: a British Methodist pastor and teacher who taught in Saudi Arabia
column3: has written a useful book about the desert kingdom. Most interesting is its exploration of how the monarchy is ""the single greatest force in spreading Islamic fundamentalism""; it ""has spent as much as $100 billion to spread Wahhabism in the West
column4: yet ""America and Britain have been
column5: and are continuing to be
column6: implicit supporters of Wahhabism.""

column1: Valentine discusses the background of how this ""unholy alliance"" came about. He warns: ""If the West simply ignores it
column2: Saudi Arabia's role in international terrorism seems likely to worsen rather than conveniently disappear."" This is troubling considering that ""ISIS is Saudi Arabia's latest monstrous contribution to world history.""

column1: The author explores important topics
column2: including the mutawwa
column3: or religious police
column4: and provides useful historical context
column5: discussing the origins of ‚ÄúWahhabism
column6: ‚Äù its alliance with the House of Saud
column7: and the oil discoveries that changed everything.

column1: The book‚Äôs primary defect is standard. Valentine regularly insists that ‚Äúit is of the greatest importance to distinguish between Wahhabism and Islam generally.‚Äù Anything good
column2: positive
column3: tolerant and peaceful is ascribed to Islam; anything bad
column4: negative
column5: intolerant
column6: and violent‚Äîmisogyny
column7: draconian punishments
column8: execution of apostates
column9: intolerance for and discrimination against non-Muslims‚Äîis ascribed to ‚ÄúWahhabism.‚Äù

column1: This position appears to be based on the author‚Äôs own cultural presuppositions. Thus he ‚Äúfelt confused and puzzled‚Äù to hear of Wahhabi intolerance
column2: including the ‚Äúattempt to propagate their beliefs by force
column3: ‚Äù prompting him to wonder: Can you force someone to love God?.... In all the conversations I had with ulema
column4: imams
column5: Mutawa [religious police] and Saudis generally there was never a mention of ‚Äúlove
column6: ‚Äù the idea that God loved me
column7: just frightful talk of hell
column8: burning and future pain if I did not believe and accept the Wahhabi faith.‚Äù

column1: Had Valentine engaged in a critical reading of Islamic doctrine and history‚Äîas opposed to projecting his Christian notion of God onto Islam‚Äîhe would‚Äôve known that Muhammad
column2: followed by countless caliphs and sultans throughout the centuries
column3: did ‚Äúpropagate their beliefs by force‚Äù (the overwhelming majority of today‚Äôs Muslim world was taken from non-Muslims ‚Äúby force‚Äù) and that although Islam attributes 99 characteristics to God
column4: ‚Äúlove‚Äù is not one of them.

column1: Valentine's readers would‚Äôve benefit much more had he simply laid out his useful information concerning the inner workings of the Saudi regime and its unholy alliance with the West
column2: without trying to tackle the deeper question of what Islam really is‚Äîleading to yet another book marred by Islamic apologetics.";english;2016-11-01T07:32:55.554+02:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Force and Fanaticism: Wahhabism in Saudi Arabia and Beyond;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/wahhabism.jpg?itok=GdDbglA9;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: The political left keeps announcing

column1: Have they never read Thomas Gray's ""Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard
column2: more than two and a half centuries ago? What about economic historian David S. Landes' statement: ""The world has never been a level playing field""?

column1: In the joint autobiography of Milton Friedman and his wife Rose

column2: Professor Friedman left behind a foundation dedicated to promoting school choice
column3: so that disadvantaged children could get a better education for a better chance in life.

column1: What is it that the political left is saying that they think is so new
column2: such a breakthrough and such a necessity for progress? More important
column3: what test of evidence ‚Äî if any ‚Äî have they ever subjected their notions to?

column1: No one has presented the social vision of the left more often than Nicholas Kristof of the New York Times ‚Äî and no one has been more certain that those who do not happen to share his vision ""just don't get it
column2: as he has repeatedly declared.

column1: Mr. Kristof's essay ""Growing Up Poor in America"" in the October 30th New York Times is a classic example of the mindset of the left.
It begins with the story of a poor black teenager in Arkansas
column2: being raised by a single mom. Sometimes he goes hungry and his home does not have even one book. But it does have television sets with huge screens
column3: and apparently there is money enough to buy marijuana.

column1: Surely we can all agree that this young fellow has very unpromising future prospects ahead of him
column2: and that this is a human tragedy. The circumstances of his life are unfair to him and none of us would want to be born into such circumstances. Moreover
column3: he is just one of many who are brought up in a setting that is full of dangers and with a low probability of improvement.

column1: But that is not enough for Mr. Kristof or for the political left in general. Of such youngsters he says
column2: ""as a society
column3: we fail them long before they fail us.""

column1: Whoa! Just when did ""society"" make the decisions and engage in the actions that have led to this teenager being in the bad situation he is in? And just when did ""society"" acquire either the omniscience or the omnipotence to prevent it?
When the left says ""society"" they usually mean government. That is apparently what ""society"" means in this case
column2: for Kristof laments that this teenager is ""the kind of person whom America's presidential candidates just don't talk about.""

column1: If the left chooses to believe that government intervention is the answer to such tragedies
column2: that is their right. But
column3: if they expect the rest of us to share that belief
column4: surely they could subject that belief to some empirical test. But we can
column5: however.

column1: The 1960s were the triumphant decade of those who wanted government intervention to ""solve"" what they called ""social problems."" How did that work out? What were things like before this social vision triumphed? And what were things like afterwards?
Homicide victimization rates among black males were going down substantially in the 1940s and the 1950s. But homicide victimization rates reversed and skyrocketed in the 1960s
column2: wiping out all the progress of the two previous decades.

column1: When the 1960s began
column2: most black children were born into families with both a mother and a father. After the great welfare state expansion during the 1960s
column3: most black children were born to a single mother
column4: like the youngster in Arkansas today.

column1: Kristof's essay also mentions a teenage girl who is a single mother
column2: and suggests that ""sex education"" could have prevented her from getting pregnant. Teenage pregnancy was going down ‚Äî repeat
column3: DOWN ‚Äî during the 1950s. It reversed and shot up after the 1960s began bringing the ""sex education"" vision into schools across the country.

column1: Very similar trends occurred in England
column2: after very similar visions and policies also triumphed there in the 1960s. Perhaps it is the left that just doesn't get it ‚Äî or cannot face the hard fact that its own vision and policies worsened the very things they claimed would be made better.";english;2016-11-01T07:32:55.748+02:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;The Left's Vision;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/10/ap_967030594535-e1456947216338-936x625.jpg?itok=cku4Kfnm;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3753;67fb84f3c5748f33ecb0beaf2fd9a868c838bb61;0;Ari Lieberman;2016-11-02T06:45:43.046+02:00;From Bad to Worse: Obama‚Äôs Ransom Payment to Iran is Just the Tip of the Iceberg;"Search form Search From Bad to Worse : Obama‚Äôs Ransom Payment to Iran is Just the Tip of the Iceberg In his bid to pursue a legacy
column2: Obama charts disastrous course with reckless abandon. November 2
column3: 2016 Ari Lieberman

column1: Most of us
column2: including several democratic lawmakers
column3: cringed when Obama inked the Iran deal but those of us who are familiar with the malevolent nature of the Iranian regime
column4: recoiled in horror when we learned that Obama transferred $400 million to the Iranians in exchange for four American citizens held captive by the mullahs on trumped up charges. The $400 million was part of a larger installment totaling $1.7 billion
column5: ostensibly to settle claims Iran had against the United States stemming from aborted Iranian arms purchases dating back to the Shah. Obama claimed that this was money that was ‚Äúowed‚Äù to Iran and the settlement
column6: which included $1.3 billion in interest
column7: saved the U.S. taxpayer ‚Äúbillions‚Äù because the Iranians were demanding even more at the Hague tribunal
column8: where the claim was being adjudicated.

column1: The timing and method of the cash transfers were disquieting to say the least and raised serious questions of legality as well as broader geo-political concerns. The Americans were freed only after Iran received its $400 million. The payment
column2: which was airlifted in the dead of night in an unmarked cargo plane
column3: was made in untraceable cash
column4: stacked on wooden pallets. The Iranians demanded Swiss Francs and Euros rather than Dollars and a pliant Obama agreed to the Islamic Republic‚Äôs dictates. Gleeful Iranian leaders were quick to announce victory and claimed that the payment was indeed a ransom
column5: contradicting the administration‚Äôs adamant denials.

column1: Even within the administration there was confusion about whether the payment was in fact a ransom. State Department spokesman Mark Toner came very close to acknowledging this fact when he noted that the $400 million was used as ‚Äúleverage‚Äù to ensure the Americans‚Äô safe return. The White House however
column2: quickly repudiated the State Department‚Äôs characterization.

column1: Even if one were to believe the story peddled by the administration
column2: the mere appearance of a quid pro quo payment potentially exposes the U.S. to extortion and hostage-taking. The Iranians certainly believed it was a ransom payment and more likely than not
column3: every two-bit dictator on the planet saw it that way as well.

column1: But there are deeper more troubling aspects to this convoluted story. In his January 17
column2: 2016 address to the American people
column3: Obama tried to put a positive spin on his dealings with the Islamic Republic but as noted by Rick Richman in an excellent article featured in Mosaic
column4: the deal struck with the Iranians was rotten to its core and the administration deliberately kept the American people in the dark about various aspects of the shady arrangement.

column1: The $400 million that the U.S. transferred to Iran came from Iran‚Äôs Foreign Military Sales (FMS) account with the Pentagon. The balance of 1.3 billion ostensibly represented interest accrued since 1979. But Obama neglected to note that when Iran filed its lawsuit
column2: the U.S. filed counterclaim against Iran for $817 million for Iranian breaches of its obligations under the FMS program. The U.S. could have conceivably won that counterclaim which would have meant wooden pallets of cash for the American treasury
column3: courtesy of the Islamic Republic.

column1: Moreover
column2: American plaintiffs maintained sixteen U.S. court judgments against the Islamic Republic stemming from that regime‚Äôs involvement in terrorist activities. Those judgments totaled $3.9 billion in compensatory and punitive damages.

column1: Some plaintiffs sought to recover their Judgments directly from Iran‚Äôs FMS account but their efforts were stymied by the Clinton administration. Instead
column2: under a convoluted deal struck between Congress and the Clinton administration in 2
column4: the U.S. treasury was to pay the holders of the judgments against Iran for the amount of their compensatory damages and 10 percent of their punitive damages up to the amount in the FMS fund. The judgments would then be subrogated to the United States
column5: which meant that judgments became direct U.S claims against the Iranian government.

column1: Iran ignored the Judgments and never paid any of the plaintiffs. Under U.S. law
column2: the $400 million sitting in the FMS account should have gone back to the U.S. treasury
column3: which had already paid the judgment holders. But the U.S. treasury never collected a dime on the subrogated claims since Obama shipped the money off on wooden pallets to Iran. Essentially
column4: the U.S. taxpayer ended up footing the bill for Iran‚Äôs terrorism while the Iranians were never held accountable for their maleficence.

column1: Obama‚Äôs actions represented blatant disregard for the law
column2: for the victims of terrorism and for the American taxpayer. His claim of saving the taxpayer ‚Äúbillions‚Äù represents the zenith of mendacity.

column1: Obama claimed that the payments had to be made in cash because existing sanctions prohibited normal banking procedures. But as noted by Richman
column2: the sanctions regimen expressly permits payments made to settle Iranian claims instituted at The Hague
column3: exposing yet another lie by the Obama administration.

column1: There was one
column2: and only one reason why the Iranians requested cash and all but the most disingenuous know what that reason is. The Iranians are the world‚Äôs foremost state-sponsors of international terrorism. They finance terrorist groups and proxy militias throughout the region and internationally but can only do so through illicit means that circumvent normal methods of financing. Hence
column3: they demanded untraceable cash. The misery that we are currently witnessing in Syria
column4: Yemen and elsewhere is due in no small part to the Obama administration which provided the Iranians with the cash necessary to keep operations flowing.

column1: In addition to the $1.7 billion in cash
column2: Obama also authorized the release of seven convicted Iranian felons and expunged warrants on 14 others. But this aspect of the transaction seems almost trivial when considering the sheer mendacity and illegality of nearly every other aspect of the deal.

column1: Lastly
column2: the transfer of such a large sum to Iran in ‚Äúsettlement‚Äù of an alleged legal claim required the attorney general‚Äôs approval but the administration has yet to produce any document bearing Loretta Lynch‚Äôs signature authorizing such payment. On October 7
column3: Sen. Marco Rubio (R.
column4: Fla.) and Rep. Mike Pompeo (R.
column5: Kan.) presented Lynch with a series of questions seeking clarification of various aspects of the deal. Lynch
column6: whose tenure as attorney general is proving to be as corrupt and partisan as her predecessor
column7: has inexplicably refused to answer the lawmakers‚Äô queries.

column1: In a desperate attempt to establish a legacy
column2: Obama pursued the Iran deal with reckless abandon
column3: forfeiting positions previously regarded as red lines and signing the worst deal in U.S. diplomatic history. The ancillary deal struck with the Iranians concerning American hostages was laced with outright lies and enabled the Iranians to continue their reign or regional terror. More importantly

column1: 3754;51fc3555481d97e475f3591b41ff1625bdbd3937;0;Caroline Glick;2016-11-02T06:45:43.651+02:00;Netanyahu‚Äôs Critical Foreign Tour;"Netanyahu‚Äôs Critical Foreign Tour Israel's strategic repositioning.
Originally published by the Jerusalem Post .
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu‚Äôs upcoming trips to Australia
column2: Singapore
column3: Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan might be the most significant diplomatic visits he makes in his tenure in office. The trips will take place against the backdrop of two major international shifts that cast Israel into uncharted waters as a small state with a dizzying array of strategic threats arrayed against it. The states that he will visit are all well-positioned to help Israel navigate its next moves. The first shift is the US‚Äôs political crackup.

column1: Next week American voters will choose their next president. The major candidates
column2: Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and Republican nominee Donald Trump
column3: are the weakest candidates to have ever stood for the highest office in the land. Their rise is a testament to the weakening
column4: if not the unraveling of the glue that has held America together since the Civil War. The unraveling of the US electorate comes against the backdrop of the diminution of US military power. The US‚Äôs multi-trillion dollar investment in inconclusive if not failed wars in the Middle East over the past 15 years has come at the expense of military modernization. The F-35 program has sucked up the majority of the remaining research and development funds. And it has yet to produce a reliable airplane. Worse
column5: the F-35‚Äôs long and problematic gestation period has given Russia and China the time and opportunity to develop air defense systems capable of neutralizing the F-35‚Äôs stealth systems. Those systems were supposed to be its chief advantage as the next generation fighter for the US and its allies. The deterioration of the US‚Äôs military capabilities has gone hand in hand with the US‚Äôs apparent loss of strategic rationality. This is apparent worldwide
column6: but is nowhere more obvious than in the Middle East. President Barack Obama‚Äôs decision to effectively abandon the US‚Äôs major allies in the Middle East in favor of cultivating ties with Iran has made the region far more dangerous to the US and its spurned allies than it was eight years ago. True
column7: in theory
column8: Obama‚Äôs decision to prefer the Shi‚Äôites to the Sunnis makes sense given the totalitarian and imperial nature of Sunni jihadism. But in light of the genocidal
column9: totalitarian and imperial nature of the current Iranian regime
column10: his move made no sense and its impact has been massively destructive. Moreover
column11: Obama‚Äôs willingness to rack up the US‚Äôs national debt in an unprecedented manner and repress economic growth through overregulation has left a large question mark over the possibility of a military buildup. In other words
column12: even under the best circumstances
column13: it is hard to imagine that the US will be capable of reestablishing its global primacy over the next four years or even over the next decade. The implications for Israel are far reaching. For decades
column14: Israel‚Äôs strategic posture has been predicated on its ability to depend on US power. This strategic posture is no longer tenable. The second major international shift is Russia‚Äôs sudden rise as the primary global power in the Middle East. As Channel 2 reported Sunday night
column15: Russia has deployed sophisticated naval and air systems in the region that can detect all of Israel‚Äôs air and naval operations. In a matter of months
column16: Israel has lost the air and naval supremacy it has enjoyed for the past four decades. The air force reportedly is convinced that the F-35‚Äôs stealth systems will be able to neutralize Russia‚Äôs detection capabilities. But given the well-documented current problems with the F-35‚Äôs stealth systems
column17: this conviction is unwise. And even under the best circumstances
column18: in which Israel has the opportunity to develop its own electronic warfare systems and apply them to its F-35 without American interference
column19: it will take Israel years to surmount the challenge that rapidly improving Russian systems present to our air force. According to Channel 2‚Äôs report
column20: air force and naval commanders are in a panic over the sudden turn of events. Rather than panicking though
column21: Israel needs to roll with the punches and figure out how best to cope with this new situation. The obvious answer is that we need to quickly expand our capabilities in areas that Russia‚Äôs military primacy does not reach. Specifically
column22: Israel needs to expand massively its capacity for under-the-radar operations. The first area that needs to be massively strengthened is our intelligence capabilities
column23: particularly human intelligence capabilities. Israel should be investing massively in developing and expanding our cultivation and direction of proxies on the ground throughout the region. Second
column24: Israel needs to adapt its cyber technology capabilities in a manner that diminishes our enemies‚Äô ability to strike us. Israel needs to be able to disrupt and disable command and control and other systems. Israel‚Äôs reach needs to extend as low down the line of its enemies‚Äô military chain of command as possible. If our offensive capabilities are being checked
column25: so must the capabilities of our enemies. Indeed
column26: our enemies need to be subverted. Part of the intelligence and cyber capabilities that Israel must develop and deploy must be geared toward destabilizing with the goal of overthrowing the regime in Iran. At the same time
column27: Israel should be empowering anti-regime sectors in Iran in a manner that expands the prospect of developing close ties with a successor regime along the lines of the strategic alliance Israel built with the regime of the shah in the decades which preceded the 1979 Islamic revolution. Third
column28: Israel needs to expand and diversify the capabilities of our ground forces. Israel needs to be capable of using new means to deploy its fighters at home and on distant shores. It needs to align its both its special and regular forces with the new threat environment. And it needs to be able to utilize its ground forces in manners that can extend the reach and diminish the compromised positions of its air and naval assets in the era of Russian regional primacy. Fourth
column29: Israel needs to expand its economic growth and diversify its economic ties in a manner that positions it as a regional economic power. It needs to use it natural gas resources specifically as a means to expand and deepen its ties with Asia. Such economic growth and power will positively influence Russia‚Äôs willingness to allow Israel to carry out air and naval operations against its enemies ‚Äì and Russia‚Äôs allies in Lebanon
column30: Syria and beyond. In other words
column31: the more economically powerful Israel is
column32: the more Russia will be willing to side with Israel against Hezbollah and others that are currently operating under the Russian umbrella. This then brings us to Netanyahu‚Äôs upcoming trips. Each state that he will visit has something to offer Israel in expanding its intelligence
column33: cyberwarfare and economic capabilities. Australia
column34: a major Western economy
column35: is moving toward China as America has become less engaged in the Pacific. Israel has an acute interest in using Australia as a platform for expanding its ties to China and other Asian countries
column36: both because of the economic advantages such ties convey and due to China‚Äôs strategic importance to Russia. As for Singapore
column37: Israel effectively built the Singaporean military in the 1960s and 1970s. The country remains extremely supportive of Israel. Like Australia
column38: Singapore has close ties to China. It has technological and other capabilities that can be extremely advantageous for Israel today. Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan are critically important to Israel today. Their strategic proximity to Iran
column39: and their ties to Russia
column40: along with their ethnic composition and their natural resources make securing good relations with both critical to Israel‚Äôs ability to advance and security its strategic interests in every sphere. Israel has tremendous assets to offer each of the four countries that Netanyahu will visit. These assets must be deployed wisely to ensure that Israel gains as much as possible from his trip and from its future ties with all of them. Given the dramatic changes in the global power balance
column41: and their implications for Israel
column42: Netanyahu‚Äôs decision to fly to visit these four countries just after the US elections tells us that he gets it. At a time of regional and global turbulence and uncertainty
column43: in the context of swiftly multiplying threats
column44: this is no small matter.";english;2016-11-02T06:45:43.651+02:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;Netanyahu‚Äôs Critical Foreign Tour;0.0;http://www.frontpagemag.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_full/public/uploads/2016/11/defense.gov_photo_essay_110325-d-xh843-010.jpg?itok=B0EiswGj;0;1;0;0;0;hate

The biggest mystery about Hillary Clinton isn't any of her scandals. Those are obvious. It's her lies. Not the usual kind of lies. The lies about corruption and greed. So why tell it?

Suffolk University‚Äôs interim president said Tuesday that the college will hold mandatory microaggression training for all faculty in response to an outcry last week after a Latina student wrote a viral blog post saying she was the victim of a professor‚Äôs racial bias.

column1: Privilege. This is what it looks like.
Scholars and Rogues fights a last stand against the decline and fall of journalism by stating the obvious .
In short
column2: what we have here isn‚Äôt merely iffy reporting on an academic dustup. It‚Äôs a microcosm of what has happened to journalism in modern America. These headlines are certain to entice Web surfers to click

column1: 3764;df84a54fa862fdcc14f6026de58d2970f840ef50;0;EdJenner;2016-11-03T07:22:47.661+02:00;The Factless Fact-Checkers;"Go to Article
Daniel Greenfield
column2: a Shillman Journalism Fellow at the Freedom Center
column3: is a New York writer focusing on radical Islam.

column1: Once upon a time
column2: fact-checking meant that newspapers
column3: radio stations and television news broadcasts were obligated to check their facts before broadcasting or publishing them. Some newspapers and magazines boasted renowned departments filled with intellectuals whose restless minds roved over each line to ensure that the fewest possible errors would appear under that publication‚Äôs masthead.

column1: But fact-checking of the media by itself has declined almost as badly as the Roman Empire. Errors routinely appear under storied mastheads followed by corrections that are published as a janitorial duty. There is very little concern for the facts even among the great names of publishing and broadcasting.

The media has stopped fact-checking itself and it now uses fact-checking largely to refer to a type of opinion journalism in which it ‚Äúchecks the facts‚Äù of public figures. The fall of fact-checking within the media has paralleled the rise of fact checking by the media of its political opponents. The media has become factless even as it deploys a term that once meant self-correction to instead correct others.
Fact checks once meant that reporters were expected to be accurate. These days they‚Äôre only expected to be politically correct. The media deploys fact checks to check political correctness
column2: not facts. Its fact checks routinely venture into areas that are not only partisan
column3: but subjective matters of opinion.

column1: Consider Politico‚Äôs often mocked ‚Äúfact check‚Äù of Donald Trump as to whether ISIS was indeed unbelievably evil. Under a banner headline
column2: ‚ÄúDonald Trump‚Äôs Week of Misrepresentations
column3: Exaggerations and Half-Truths‚Äù
column4: it zoomed in on a quote from his Florida rally.

column1: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre presiding over something that the world has not seen. The level of evil is unbelievable
column2: ‚Äù Trump had said.

column1: Politico swooped in to correct the candidate with its fact check. ‚ÄúJudging one ‚Äòlevel of evil‚Äô against another is subjective
column2: but other groups in recent history have without any question engaged in as widespread killing of civilians as ISIS.‚Äù

column1: There were no facts being checked here because Politico doesn‚Äôt seem to know what a fact even is.
The only information conveyed by this ‚Äúfact check‚Äù is that Politico
column2: like the rest of the media
column3: does not like Donald Trump and would find a way to argue with him if he said that the sky was blue.

column1: In the Daily Show media culture where overt bias and trolling are virtues
column2: fact-checking is just another snotty variety of editorializing that attempts to compensate for perceptions of bias not with higher ethical and factual standards
column3: but by rebranding its editorials as fact checks to gain credibility.

column1: The ISIS evil ‚Äúfact check‚Äù of Trump came from the same media outlet whose White House reporter decided that the Wisconsin flag
column2: which carries the date 1848 to mark the state‚Äôs admission to the Union
column3: was ‚Äúa flag for the local union
column4: Wisconsin 1848‚Äù. Politico ran an entire story asserting that Obama was flying a labor flag to oppose Governor Walker because its reporter couldn‚Äôt process basic history.

column1: This is what happens when media outlets think that fact-checking is something that they do to Republicans rather than to themselves.
Fact-checking was one of those dinosaurs of journalism
column2: like objectivity
column3: which is viewed as largely irrelevant in a media culture whose Edward R. Murrow is Jon Stewart. Today‚Äôs millennial journalists spend most of their time exchanging sarcastic quips with their peers on Twitter
column4: aspire to found their own Vox sites and write viral blog posts that seek a new angle on a trending left-wing narrative.

column1: Fact checks often function as narrative defenses and meme attacks. That‚Äôs why the Washington Post decided to ‚Äúfact check‚Äù a Saturday Night Live gag about Obama‚Äôs illegal alien amnesty. It‚Äôs not that anyone imagines that Saturday Night Live is in the business of producing facts that need checking. The Post was just worried that one of its jokes would go viral and hurt Obama and his agenda.

It‚Äôs the same reason that the paper ‚Äúfact checked‚Äù a 13-year-old boy who claimed he was blocked by Obama on Twitter. This isn‚Äôt about the facts. It‚Äôs paranoia about social media narratives going viral.
This is more understandable if you stop thinking of the media in the old-fashioned sense as a series of papers
column2: radio and television stations and start thinking of it as a massive machine that advocates for left-wing policies using its massive infrastructure and wealth to monopolize internet narratives.

column1: Media outlets trade on their history
column2: but they don‚Äôt resemble their past selves in any meaningful way.

column1: The New Yorker once boasted a fact-checking department that was famous for its range
column2: its depth and its resourcefulness in running down even the most obscure facts. But what use is such a thing at David Remnick‚Äôs New Yorker whose big draw comes from Andy Borowitz‚Äôs insipid near parodies? The New Republic went from respected liberal publication to another snarky and shrill social justice blog. CBS News cited a psychic site to explain that a fly landed on Hillary‚Äôs face to help her cope with stress.

column1: This isn‚Äôt material that exists in the same realm as facts. It‚Äôs snarky contempt alternating with lowest common denominator propaganda. Left-wing journalism
column2: like most left-wing culture
column3: is totalitarian anti-intellectualism masquerading as enlightened intellectualism. The Soviet Union was quite fond of culture. It just hated the creative process that produced it because it was independent of Communist ideology. The left loves journalism; it just hates the objectivity that validates journalism as more than propaganda.

column1: It‚Äôs this perverse anti-intellectualism that turned fact-checking from self-discipline to attack ad. Once journalism became pure left-wing advocacy
column2: it also became inherently correct by virtue of being left-wing and was not in need of having its facts checked. When fact checks stopped being something that journalists did to themselves
column3: first facts and then fact checks became meaningless. Unable to even recognize a fact
column4: media fact checkers just wrote editorials which spiced their left-wing attacks on Republicans liberally with cargo cult invocations to ‚Äúfact‚Äù as if it were some deity.

column1: The average media fact check is a masterpiece of unintentional comedy for thinking adults.
At the Washington Post
column2: Michelle Yee ‚Äúfact checks‚Äù Donald Trump‚Äôs comment that Hillary‚Äôs email scandal is bigger than Watergate and concludes that since Watergate led to Nixon‚Äôs resignation and Hillary‚Äôs email scandal has yet to lead to any convictions
column3: it can‚Äôt be bigger than Watergate. Since the scandal has yet to be resolved
column4: a fact check of it could only take place in the future.

column1: CNN featured Toronto Star ‚Äúfact checker‚Äù Daniel Dale who claimed that Trump said 35 lies in one day.
The list of ‚Äúlies‚Äù included deeming Trump‚Äôs statement that Hillary would raise taxes false because her plan only taxes the rich
column2: asserting that there is no such thing as a ‚Äúphony poll‚Äù and denying that Hillary Clinton had received debate questions. Some of these ‚Äúlies‚Äù are themselves lies. Others
column3: like Yee
column4: show an inability to even understand what a fact is and what can and can‚Äôt be deemed false.

column1: Just how degraded fact checking had become was made manifest when Hillary Clinton pleaded at the debate
column2: ‚ÄúPlease
column3: fact checkers
column4: get to work.‚Äù Her campaign site touted its own ‚Äúfact checking‚Äù which was mostly indistinguishable from the media‚Äôs fact checking. That was a commentary on the transformation of the media into a left-wing politician‚Äôs spin center.

column1: Nearly every media outlet now boasts a fact check blog or headlines touting fact checks. But the biggest fact checking department of the media
column2: rather than by the media
column3: isn‚Äôt in the United States
column4: but in Germany. In America
column5: fact checking has become a type of partisan attack launched by media outlets at their political opponents. It‚Äôs bigger than ever and also more worthless than ever because it is factless.

column1: And those who do it often not only don‚Äôt know the facts
column2: but don‚Äôt even know what a fact is.  ";english;2016-11-03T07:22:47.661+02:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;The Factless Fact-Checkers;0.0;http://conservativeangle.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Conservative-Angle-Logo.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 3765;46e429bef6ae81d991fde7267ce0887c4404490e;0;EdJenner;2016-11-03T07:22:47.669+02:00;Obama DOJ: Handmaiden of Clinton Corruption;"Go to Article
The Obama Department of Justice has been corruptly aiding and abetting the Democratic Party‚Äôs presidential nominee

column4: the Department has blocked the FBI from searching for the truth and following the evidence of potential criminality to its logical conclusion. column1: Lynch and President Obama were reportedly furious with FBI Director James Comey for sending a letter to Congress on October 28 th indicating that new evidence potentially pertinent to the e-mail case had come to light
column2: which required further investigation. This evidence consisted of a batch of e-mails FBI investigators had found on one or more computers belonging to Anthony Weiner
column3: Clinton confidante Huma Abedin‚Äôs estranged husband

Comey sent his letter after months of agonizing over his previous decision to let Hillary off the hook in the e-mail case last July. He was said by a source close to him to have been particularly disturbed by the mounting number of resignation letters from FBI agents who felt betrayed by that decision.

column1: Department of Justice officials had leaned on Comey not to send the letter to Congress
column2: claiming that it would violate Department protocols and procedures against taking any action that could be perceived as interfering with the upcoming presidential election. To his credit
column3: Comey ignored the Department officials‚Äô objections
column4: claiming he had an obligation to keep the Congress and the public informed of any potentially significant new developments in the case.

column1: Democrats
column2: who had lavished praise on Comey for his July decision
column3: lashed out at Comey for sending his letter updating Congress. Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid went so far as to make the baseless charge that Comey may have violated the law by informing Congress
column4: because
column5: Reid argued
column6: he appeared to be taking sides in an election. The disgraced former Attorney General Eric Holder
column7: held in contempt of Congress for withholding information relating to the Fast and Furious scandal
column8: said about Comey‚Äôs action
column9: ‚ÄúI fear he has unintentionally and negatively affected public trust in both the Justice Department and the FBI. It is up to the director to correct his mistake ‚Äî not for the sake of a political candidate or campaign but in order to protect our system of justice and best serve the American people.‚Äù

column1: Since when has Holder been genuinely concerned about protecting our system of justice and best serving the American people? Holder had already contributed to the erosion of public trust
column2: with his blatant politicization of the Obama Department of Justice. As evidenced by the Obama Department of Justice‚Äôs handling of the multiple FBI investigations involving Hillary Clinton
column3: the Department has continued its slide into the muck of corruption. It interfered with both the normal course of criminal investigations and the election by stacking the deck in Hillary‚Äôs favor
column4: ensuring that no indictment would occur to derail her path to succeed Obama and preserve his legacy.

column1: First
column2: the Department of Justice reportedly refused to empanel a grand jury in either the e-mail case or in connection with the FBI‚Äôs investigation of the Clinton Foundation pay-for-play allegations. ‚ÄúThe problem here is this investigation was never a real investigation
column3: ‚Äù former assistant FBI director James Kallstrom said . ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem. They never had a grand jury empanelled
column4: and the reason they never had a grand jury empanelled
column5: I‚Äôm sure
column6: is Loretta Lynch would not go along with that.‚Äù

column1: Kallstrom‚Äôs belief that Lynch acted to influence the results of the FBI probes in Hillary‚Äôs favor is buttressed by Lynch‚Äôs 30 minute private tarmac meeting with Bill Clinton shortly before FBI Director Comey faced the cameras on July 5 th with his exculpatory announcement.
Second
column2: at least five immunity agreements were handed out in the e-mail case
column3: including to Hillary‚Äôs lawyer and confidante Cheryl Mills and to Platte River Networks‚Äô Paul Combetta. It appears that Combetta had previously lied to government investigators ‚Äì a crime in itself ‚Äì while trying to cover up the fact that he had evidently Bleachbited e-mails to delete them
column4: even though they had been subject to a previously issued Congressional subpoena. The immunity agreements garnered nothing in return
column5: but had the effect of blocking access to the computer devices of the immunity beneficiaries in the FBI‚Äôs separate Clinton Foundation investigation. Apparently
column6: the Department decided against the alternative option of subpoenaing the computer devices or seeking a search warrant
column7: rather than granting useless immunities
column8: in order to obtain any evidence relevant to the e-mail investigation that might have been contained in those devices.

column1: Third
column2: the Department and FBI did not conduct their last minute interview of Hillary Clinton under oath and allowed Cheryl Mills ‚Äì herself a material witness ‚Äì to sit in during Hillary‚Äôs interview. They did not ask pertinent follow-up questions. There was no verbatim transcript of the interview to use in checking the veracity of Hillary‚Äôs statements during the interview against her sworn Congressional testimony or her many public statements.

column1: Fourth
column2: the Department of Justice reportedly refused to allow the FBI to issue subpoenas to gather more evidence in connection with its investigation of the Clinton Foundation pay-for-play allegations. In fact
column3: senior Department officials reportedly would not authorize a more thorough FBI investigation because they claimed there was not sufficient evidence gathered thus far to justify going further. Such a circular argument was a mere cover to prevent seasoned career investigators from learning the full extent of foreign government donations while Hillary was Secretary of State
column4: their true motivations and any favors extended by the State Department in return.

column1: Finally
column2: the cross-connections between the Clintons and some high level Department of Justice and FBI officials cry out for recusal. But not so in this administration. For example
column3: the wife of the deputy FBI director who was involved in the laggard Clinton Foundation investigation
column4: Andrew McCabe
column5: just happened to have received a large donation from close Clinton ally Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe to her 2015 run for the State Senate.

column1: To make matters worse

column3: a close friend of Hillary Clinton‚Äôs campaign manager John Podesta
column4: to communicate with Congress about what Kadzik promised would be a ‚Äúthorough‚Äù review of the newly discovered e-mails from Anthony Weiner‚Äôs online account.

column2: ‚Äù and said about his pal
column3: ‚ÄúKept me out of jail.‚Äù Their history together goes further back than that. During the waning days of Bill Clinton‚Äôs presidency

column5: then representing the infamous billionaire fugitive Marc Rich

column10: paid off. Bill Clinton delivered the requested pardon on his last day in office.

column1: Kadzik joined the Department of Justice in April 2013

column3: and then as the Principal Deputy. With the Podesta connection intact

column1: Exploiting his coordinating role in the re-opened e-mail investigation and contacts with FBI investigators
column2: Kadzik will now be in a position to relay inside information to his pal Podesta and to provide inside information to the Clinton campaign‚Äôs supporters in Congress as well.

column1: After the referendum made Brexit possible
column2: I warned that the establishment would do everything possible to stop it. That should not come as a surprise to anyone. Brexit was very much a popular rebellion whose centers were well outside the centers of power. The establishment is culturally and politically hostile to it. And one of the most basic ways that the system has of sabotaging policies it doesn't like is to swamp them in procedural red tape and as much politicking as possible so as to make them unviable. Doing that to a Brexit is trickier
column3: but it's still happening. The same old game plan is to just bog it down as much as possible until its motive energy runs down. It's worked in the past. It may not work this time. But that won't stop them from trying.

In Iran? In Russia? I'll skip over the ""outright defy legality altogether"" argument. Though it's certainly sad that this is now considered some sort of high water mark.
But can Hillary govern herself? Is the compulsive liar who can't help shouting

column1: Why does everyone love Hillary Clinton? It's hard to say. Her unfavorable ratings have hit 60%. That makes her more popular than
1. The Bubonic Plague
2. ObamaCare
3. Osama bin Laden's corpse
It's not much to go on. But the Atlantic decided to run a piece by Chimamanda Adichie titled
column2: Why Is Hillary Clinton So Widely Loved?""

column1: Your response to seeing the name Chimamanda Adichie was probably huh. Unless you're a gender studies student at an Ivy. In which case you know exactly who she is and love her. Chimamanda Adichie is a Nigerian novelist whose ""We should all be feminists"" is big in those circles.
The Clinton campaign is unbearably awkward and this panegyric by Adichie was an obvious attempt to channel some of that canned Obama poetry. And like most Hillary branding
column2: it fails badly.

column1: There are howlers like
column2: ""There are millions who admire the tapestry of Hillary Clinton‚Äôs past"" and ""There are people who
column3: when Hillary Clinton becomes the first woman to be president of the United States
column4: will weep from joy"". It's not quite a hymn to Comrade Stalin. Nor is it getting there by any means except a tow truck.

column1: And then there's the phrasing. Oh the phrasing. ""Hillary Clinton was guilty immediately when she stepped into the view of the American public as the first lady of Arkansas.""
This is an awkward attempt to channel that Obama poetry
column2: but instead it reads like a DVD manual badly translated from the Japanese.

column1: The Atlantic piece is full of lines that straddle the border between tin-eared propagandistic cliche and just bad writing.
She was a lawyer full of dreams:
She was guilty of not being a traditional first lady. She offended the old patriarchal order.""
Then there's the theme of the article
column2: which is to just deny reality.

column1: A conservative writer labeled her a congenital liar when she was first lady
column2: and the label stuck because it was repeated over and over‚Äîand it was a convenient label to harness misogyny. If she was a liar

column2: with no context

The people who love Hillary Clinton know that the IT system at the State Department is old and stodgy

3774;85d9b6d3d52b18cce23f4b8cedea7ee5c02b168e;0;EdJenner;2016-11-04T07:17:16.422+02:00;You Can Smell Hillary‚Äôs Fear;"Daniel Greenfield
column2: a Shillman Journalism Fellow at the Freedom Center
column3: is a New York writer focusing on radical Islam.

column1: In the final stretch of the election
column2: Hillary Rodham Clinton has gone to war with the FBI.

column1: The word ‚Äúunprecedented‚Äù has been thrown around so often this election that it ought to be retired. But it‚Äôs still unprecedented for the nominee of a major political party to go war with the FBI.

But that‚Äôs exactly what Hillary and her people have done. Coma patients just waking up now and watching an hour of CNN from their hospital beds would assume that FBI Director James Comey is Hillary‚Äôs opponent in this election.

The FBI is under attack by everyone from Obama to CNN. Hillary‚Äôs people have circulated a letter attacking Comey. There are currently more media hit pieces lambasting him than targeting Trump. It wouldn‚Äôt be too surprising if the Clintons or their allies were to start running attack ads against the FBI.

The FBI‚Äôs leadership is being warned that the entire left-wing establishment will form a lynch mob if they continue going after Hillary. And the FBI‚Äôs credibility is being attacked by the media and the Democrats to preemptively head off the results of the investigation of the Clinton Foundation and Hillary Clinton.
The covert struggle between FBI agents and Obama‚Äôs DOJ people has gone explosively public.
The New York Times has compared Comey to J. Edgar Hoover. Its bizarre headline
column2: ‚ÄúJames Comey Role Recalls Hoover‚Äôs FBI
column3: Fairly or Not‚Äù practically admits up front that it‚Äôs spouting nonsense. The Boston Globe has published a column calling for Comey‚Äôs resignation. Not to be outdone
column4: Time has an editorial claiming that the scandal is really an attack on all women.

column1: James Carville appeared on MSNBC to remind everyone that he was still alive and insane. He accused Comey of coordinating with House Republicans and the KGB. And you thought the ‚Äúvast right wing conspiracy‚Äù was a stretch.
Countless media stories charge Comey with violating procedure. Do you know what‚Äôs a procedural violation? Emailing classified information stored on your bathroom server.

Senator Harry Reid has sent Comey a letter accusing him of violating the Hatch Act. The Hatch Act is a nice idea that has as much relevance in the age of Obama as the Tenth Amendment. But the cable news spectrum quickly filled with media hacks glancing at the Wikipedia article on the Hatch Act under the table while accusing the FBI director of one of the most awkward conspiracies against Hillary ever.
If James Comey is really out to hurt Hillary
column2: he picked one hell of a strange way to do it.

column1: Not too long ago Democrats were breathing a sigh of relief when he gave Hillary Clinton a pass in a prominent public statement. If he really were out to elect Trump by keeping the email scandal going
column2: why did he trash the investigation? Was he on the payroll of House Republicans and the KGB back then and playing it coy or was it a sudden development where Vladimir Putin and Paul Ryan talked him into taking a look at Anthony Weiner‚Äôs computer?

column1: Either Comey is the most cunning FBI director that ever lived or he‚Äôs just awkwardly trying to navigate a political mess that has trapped him between a DOJ leadership whose political futures are tied to Hillary‚Äôs victory and his own bureau whose apolitical agents just want to be allowed to do their jobs.

The only truly mysterious thing is why Hillary and her associates decided to go to war with a respected Federal agency. Most Americans like the FBI while Hillary Clinton enjoys a 60% unfavorable rating.
And it‚Äôs an interesting question.

Hillary‚Äôs old strategy was to lie and deny that the FBI even had a criminal investigation underway. Instead her associates insisted that it was a security review. The FBI corrected her and she shrugged it off. But the old breezy denial approach has given way to a savage assault on the FBI.
Pretending that nothing was wrong was a bad strategy
column2: but it was a better one that picking a fight with the FBI while lunatic Clinton associates try to claim that the FBI is really the KGB.

column1: There are two possible explanations.

Hillary Clinton might be arrogant enough to lash out at the FBI now that she believes that victory is near. The same kind of hubris that led her to plan her victory fireworks display could lead her to declare a war on the FBI for irritating her during the final miles of her campaign.
But the other explanation is that her people panicked.

Going to war with the FBI is not the behavior of a smart and focused presidential campaign. It‚Äôs an act of desperation. When a presidential candidate decides that her only option is to try and destroy the credibility of the FBI
column2: that‚Äôs not hubris
column3: it‚Äôs fear of what the FBI might be about to reveal about her.

column1: During the original FBI investigation
column2: Hillary Clinton was confident that she could ride it out. And she had good reason for believing that. But that Hillary Clinton is gone. In her place is a paranoid wreck. Within a short space of time the ‚Äúpositive‚Äù Clinton campaign promising to unite the country has been replaced by a desperate and flailing operation that has focused all its energy on fighting the FBI.

column1: There‚Äôs only one reason for such bizarre behavior.

The Clinton campaign has decided that an FBI investigation of the latest batch of emails poses a threat to its survival. And so it‚Äôs gone all in on fighting the FBI. It‚Äôs an unprecedented step born of fear. It‚Äôs hard to know whether that fear is justified. But the existence of that fear already tells us a whole lot.
Clinton loyalists rigged the old investigation. They knew the outcome ahead of time as well as they knew the debate questions. Now suddenly they are no longer in control. And they are afraid.
You can smell the fear.

The FBI has wiretaps from the investigation of the Clinton Foundation. It‚Äôs finding new emails all the time. And Clintonworld panicked. The spinmeisters of Clintonworld have claimed that the email scandal is just so much smoke without fire. All that‚Äôs here is the appearance of impropriety without any of the substance. But this isn‚Äôt how you react to smoke. It‚Äôs how you respond to a fire.

The misguided assault on the FBI tells us that Hillary Clinton and her allies are afraid of a revelation bigger than the fundamental illegality of her email setup. The email setup was a preemptive cover up. The Clinton campaign has panicked badly out of the belief
column2: right or wrong
column3: that whatever crime the illegal setup was meant to cover up is at risk of being exposed.

column1: The Clintons have weathered countless scandals over the years. Whatever they are protecting this time around is bigger than the usual corruption
column2: bribery
column3: sexual assaults and abuses of power that have followed them around throughout the years. This is bigger and more damaging than any of the allegations that have already come out. And they don‚Äôt want FBI investigators anywhere near it.

column1: The campaign against Comey is pure intimidation. It‚Äôs also a warning. Any senior FBI people who value their careers are being warned to stay away. The Democrats are closing ranks around their nominee against the FBI. It‚Äôs an ugly and unprecedented scene. It may also be their last stand.
Hillary Clinton has awkwardly wound her way through numerous scandals in just this election cycle. But she‚Äôs never shown fear or desperation before. Now that has changed. Whatever she is afraid of
column2: it lies buried in her emails with Huma Abedin. And it can bring her down like nothing else has.  ";english;2016-11-04T07:17:16.422+02:00;frontpagemag.com;US;34811.0;You Can Smell Hillary‚Äôs Fear;0.0;http://conservativeangle.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Conservative-Angle-Logo.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column3: ‚Äù to make sure that if any of them are foolish enough to find themselves agreeing with me

column2: Obama seeks to undermine America‚Äôs closest ally. November 4

column1: Israelis and the pro-Israel community at large will breathe a collective sigh of relief when Obama leaves office. During Obama‚Äôs tenure
column2: relations with Israel were caustic at best. Barely five months after taking office
column3: he publicly launched a scathing attack against Israel ‚Äì where he perversely insinuated a moral equivalence between Israeli and Palestinian actions ‚Äì and did so in one of the most virulently anti-Semitic countries on the planet. He later skipped over Israel despite the fact that Israel was a mere 20-minute plane ride away. That was Obama‚Äôs opening salvo against America‚Äôs closest ally. It was only downhill from there.

column1: Obama utilized high-level administration sources to leak negative information about Israel to sympathetic members of the press. In one such instance
column2: an administration official ‚Äìprobably Ben Rhodes ‚Äì referred to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as a ‚Äú chicken-Sh*t .‚Äù In another instance

column4: Nicholas Sarkozy
column5: when Sarkozy characterized Netanyahu as a ‚Äú liar .‚Äù

column1: Often

column3: Moshe Yaalon
column4: was shamefully transformed into a persona non grata. In the most notorious incident
column5: Obama left Netanyahu out in the cold while having dinner with Michelle and his daughters. One commentator dryly noted that Obama treated Netanyahu as though he was the president of Equatorial Guinea.

column1: Ultimately
column2: Obama crossed the line and received significant pushback from Democratic lawmakers and donors. Obama got the message and toned down the rhetoric but his deep-seeded animus against Israel never dissipated and relations with Israel‚Äôs prime minister remained toxic.

column1: Tensions surfaced again during Israel‚Äôs counter insurgency campaign against the Gaza-based terror group Hamas. Obama held up a shipment of Hellfire missiles to Israel and then tried to strong-arm Israel into accepting a suicidal ceasefire agreement brokered by Turkey and Qatar
column2: two despotic nations that support Hamas and gave aid and comfort to Islamic State terrorists.

column1: Obama saw Netanyahu‚Äôs opposition to the JCPOA
column2: the so-called Iran deal
column3: as a personal attack and allowed his petulant nature to further sour relations. The so-called ‚Äúsettlements‚Äù were another point of contention. Obama disregarded a letter of assurance to Israel provided by the Bush administration specifying that ‚ÄúIn light of new realities on the ground
column4: including already existing major Israeli population[s] centers

column1: Bush gave implicit recognition to existing settlement blocs and the right of Israel to build within those blocs. It is also important to note that no new settlement was created during Obama‚Äôs term of office and Netanyahu had even agreed to an unprecedented 10-month moratorium on construction within the disputed territories. But nothing was ever enough for Obama who never wasted an opportunity to excoriate Israel at every turn. His parting shot was at the United Nations General Assembly. During a recent address to that contemptible body
column2: he explicitly singled out Israel for criticism but heaped praise on the xenophobic nation of Indonesia. Obama‚Äôs moral compass had gone completely awry.

column1: Despite the fact that Obama is in his twilight months
column2: he can still inflict immeasurable harm on Israel. According to a report featured in the Wall Street Journal
column3: Obama is contemplating several options
column4: each with significant negative implications for Israel. The report noted that he will only implement those options during the transitional period after November 8
column5: so as not to harm Clinton‚Äôs presidential prospects.

column1: He may seek to remove tax exempt status for organizations supportive of Israeli communities living in East Jerusalem
column2: Judea and Samaria. Perhaps more ominously
column3: he may seek to impose dictates on Israel utilizing the U.N. Security Council.

column1: In one such scenario
column2: Obama may seek to pass a resolution condemning settlement construction and declaring Israeli communities situated in Judea and Samaria to be illegal. Alternatively
column3: the administration may seek formal recognition of the ‚ÄúState of Palestine‚Äù even though such a state has no formal boundaries and rejects Israel‚Äôs existence as a Jewish state. Lastly
column4: he is said to be considering the possibility of setting up the parameters of a future peace agreement that would entail significant Israeli territorial concessions.

column1: The United States does not have to actively support any UNSC resolution to see the successful passage of anti-Israeli measures. It merely has to fail to exercise its veto powers. France
column2: facing significant problems of its own in connection with its growing radicalized Muslim population
column3: has historically been the fiercest advocate for the Palestinian Arabs. It is likely that the administration would seek to have the French submit a draft resolution and the United States would simply abstain while the permanent and non-permanent members voted

column2: would be an act of extreme betrayal. It would also represent bad policy and would significantly complicate efforts to broker a future peace agreement.

column1: But Israel is not without recourse. There is strong bipartisan support for Israel in Congress and lawmakers from both sides of the political divide have already expressed to the White House their strong opposition to U.N. involvement.
Some
column2: like the Jerusalem Post‚Äôs Caroline Glick
column3: have suggested that the Israelis can reach out to the Russians with carrots in an effort to counter Obama‚Äôs nefarious plans but this option seems to be a stretch. column4: serves to reinforce this view. Moreover

column1: ‚ÄúThere is one part of Trump that is indisputably real: his ego

column7: as Hillary did.

column2: anyone who thinks that Hillary‚Äôs proven record of recklessness
column3: mendacity
column4: and indifference is not more troubling by several orders of magnitude than Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúdepravities‚Äù is ‚Äúdelusional.‚Äù

column7: ‚Äù ‚Äúracist

Is she right when she leaps to conclusions about police ‚Äúbrutality‚Äù aimed against African-Americans before the evidence in specific cases is carefully examined? I don‚Äôt think so.

column1: 4906;6944c2ef200cd5730cb3f579eb2b63e28294f2dc;0;Jonathan Lee;2016-10-26T21:54:52.366+03:00;The War Against Payday Lending;"The War Against Payday Lending Apple uses similar tactics with iPhone Jonathan Lee | Mises.org - October 26
column2: 2016 Comments Image Credits: flickr
column3: khrawlings .

column1: In June of 2016
column2: the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) put forward a proposal to regulate the short-term loan industry.

column1: The Small Dollar Lending Rule seeks to ‚Äúalleviate and solve‚Äù for the ‚Äúapparent weaknesses‚Äù of the current rates and short-term lenders by requiring ‚Äúlenders to assess and verify a borrower‚Äôs income
column2: housing costs
column3: and credit and legal obligations.‚Äù

column1: The intention of the proposal is to protect low-income families from being caught in an endless cycle where many are ‚Äúforced to take out another loan to make ends meet.‚Äù At first glance
column2: it seems that the rule would solve problems in an industry known for its ‚Äúdirtiness.‚Äù Except policymakers are thinking with their hearts while sitting in their air-conditioned offices
column3: away from the facts and any form of interaction with the real world of short-term loans. Just the fact that they see the short-term loan industry as ‚Äúdirty‚Äù supplies sufficient reason to believe that either these policymakers are ignorantly prejudiced or plainly manipulative.

column1: Instead of pointing fingers and name calling at the short-term lending industry
column2: they should be applying simple economics to their proposals to see if they hold water.

column1: In ‚ÄúUnderstanding the CFPB Proposal for Payday and Other Small Loans
column2: ‚Äù a paper released by the CFPB and PEW Charitable Trusts
column3: the Bureau aimed to make several arguments in favor of new legislation.

column1: The first of its arguments is that
column2: ‚Äúwith payday and vehicle title loan markets
column3: lenders‚Äô and borrowers‚Äô interests are not aligned because profitability for lenders depends on loans being unaffordable for customers.‚Äù But doesn‚Äôt this argument stand for any industry that sells a product?

column1: For example
column2: are the interests of iPhone sellers and buyers ‚Äúaligned‚Äù in the manner acceptable to the CFPB? Each additional iPhone 6 is said to cost $200.10 to produce and is sold for $699 dollars. That is 3 times its cost to make. To borrow a phrase from the left
column3: that‚Äôs ‚Äúprice-gouging‚Äù to the tune of 300 percent. Yet there is no noise from policymakers claiming to call Apple a company that cheats its customers.

column1: So why should short-term lenders be held accountable in any way that is different than Apple? Shouldn‚Äôt short-term lenders be able to charge interest rates that make-up for the huge risk they incur in lending money out to low-income borrowers?
Studies show these lenders charge on average 15 percent
column2: or $15 for every $100 loaned ‚Äî a profit margin that is significantly less than the price percentage difference of products in other markets.

column1: The second of the CFPB‚Äôs arguments is that to solve for ‚Äúballoon payments
column2: ‚Äù or the cycle of continued borrowing to pay off loans
column3: the CFPB would ‚Äúrequire that most products become installment loans with smaller
column4: manageable payments.‚Äù

column1: The problem with this statement is that the Bureau completely ignores the reason why short-term loans are so available to borrowers ‚Äî it‚Äôs because short-term loan companies can offset risk by requiring borrowers to weigh their own risk against their need to borrow.
Simply put
column2: the short payment periods are put in place to deter those who definitely should not borrow. Additionally
column3: making the periods longer and the payments smaller defeats the business model
column4: making short-term lenders irrelevant because their models are defined by their expediency.

column1: The third of the CFPB‚Äôs arguments is that their proposal would solve the ‚Äúproblems‚Äù related to ‚Äúprice gouge lending‚Äù by requiring ‚Äúlenders to evaluate borrowers‚Äô financial condition
column2: ‚Äù by forcing borrowers to submit written statements on income
column3: housing expenses
column4: all outstanding debt
column5: and child support. Meanwhile
column6: the lender is required to obtain a national credit report
column7: and then deliver that data to all proposed credit tracking agencies.

column1: Remember: all of these government-imposed requirements cost the short-term lenders money. The cost of finding out this data would eliminate any ability that firms have to loan small amounts of cash at current interest rates. The result would either lead short-term loan companies to shut down or further hurt borrowers by requiring that they borrow larger sums of money to qualify for loans.
Lastly
column2: the CFPB heralds that their redesign is prompted by a study by The Pew Charitable Trusts‚Äô survey research that the ‚Äúvast majority of borrowers want ‚Ä¶ most products [to] become installment loans with smaller
column3: manageable payments.‚Äù

column1: At first glance
column2: it seems that borrowers in need are hurting and want to find a way out of a difficult situation. Although there are those who are caught in the inability to pay back loans because they got caught in bad finance (due to the risk of short-term loans)
column3: many of those ‚Äúsurveyed‚Äù actually sent in raving reviews in support of short-term loans.

column1: In fact
column2: more than 98 percent of the 12
column3: 308 submissions to the Bureau‚Äôs ‚Äú Tell Your Story ‚Äù program ‚Äî where people sent in their experiences regarding short-term loans ‚Äî were positive and excessively thankful for these loans.

column1: These responses ranged from
column2: ‚Äúthere are no other avenues out there that can lend money like [this]
column3: ‚Äù to a simple ‚Äúthank you.‚Äù This study was personally conducted by the CFPB. Unsatisfied with the results
column4: they hid it from the public‚Äôs view until a Freedom of Information Act request forced them to release it.

column1: This holding back of information demonstrates that the Bureau is not truly searching to help the people it says it wants to help. Rather
column2: they have a keen eye for policy symbolism
column3: and the flash of ‚Äúfighting for the underdog‚Äù when in fact they are irreversibly harming them while sticking a knife in their back.

column1: Policymakers continue the belief that short-term loans are as bad as they seem comes either because they did not attend their economics classes in college
column2: or they simply want to be perceived as ‚Äúsomeone who cares.‚Äù But we cannot let policymakers make decisions because their hearts lead them to make uneducated proposals. We cannot let legislators sway our hearts because we hear about the extreme situations where people are hurt. Instead
column3: we need to look at the cold-hard facts: the numbers that the CFPB uses to defend their arguments are manipulative and outright false.

column1: The Small Dollar Lending Rule must not be allowed to pass and the proposal must be removed and taken back ‚Äî it will only hurt the people it claims it will help. Let Americans make decisions for themselves ‚Äî they‚Äôre smarter and more risk-averse than Washington insiders give them credit for.

Jonathan Lee is a filmmaker and freelance economics journalist. He is an alumnus of Chapman University.
