column1: Establishment politicians and press are outraged that Trump would question the integrity of their system.
They say it undermines public trust in political institutions.
Yet to see who is truly undermining public trust we need look no further than the people running the elections
column2: who are shutting down election audit procedures
column3: who stonewall and eject certified election monitors and who make any recording of malfunctioning voting machines a felony.

column1: One such person is Texas Director of Elections
column2: Keith Ingram.

column1: This story is specific to Texas
column2: but the same tactics are used nationwide by both parties to exploit vulnerabilities inherent in electronic voting.

column1: I went to the Texas Secretary of State offices to ask Mr. Ingram about specific procedural changes he has made in his 4 year tenure and the changes he attempted to make in August that would have gone into effect this November.
With camera & mic in hand
column2: we told the reception desk that we were with the press and would like to talk to the Director about the election.

column1: We were told to wait in the lobby and Mr. Ingram would be down.
You can see for yourself what happened when he saw the mic flag showing we were with Infowars.
The man running the election bureaucracy runs from questions.
So much for transparency and candor.
This unelected bureaucrat is tasked with ensuring that counties adhere to election law.
What follows are the specific actions taken by his office that waive requirements and undermine election integrity in Texas.
But before we get to specifics about his actions & his connection to the Rose Law firm in Arkansas
column2: there are some general questions that should concern voters nationwide:

column1: ‚Ä¢ Why would standards required by our elected lawmakers for election integrity be bent to the capabilities of vendors rather than require vendors to perform to the standard?
‚Ä¢ Why would election procedures be waived and honesty and transparency sacrificed for the convenience of election workers & officials?
Burning The Paper Trail
In August 2016
column2: Ingram
column3: Texas Director of Elections
column4: attempted to make last minute rule changes for the upcoming November 8 election that would eliminate crucial paper backup records for electronic voting. His office issued new rules that would:

column1: Eliminate printing of paper audit logs that poll watchers are entitled to monitor at main tabulation computers.
Eliminate printing of Early Voting Results tapes.
Eliminate printing of ballot images for recounts.
Fortunately activists and some elected representatives got the proposed rule changes postponed
column2: with a formal public hearing scheduled after the November election.

column1: State Senator Don Huffines said ‚ÄúThe state‚Äôs chief election officers must reconsider and redraft their proposed election rules to pursue more real-time paper records and backups
column2: not fewer‚Ä¶The comfort & convenience of election administrators should not take priority over voters‚Äô confidence and election integrity.‚Äù

column1: But even though these procedures have been postponed
column2: Ingram‚Äôs previous rule changes are still a cause for concern in the November election and have caused repercussions in two election cases currently being litigated. Here are some of the problems‚Ä¶

column1: 1) Waiver of laws requiring a Partial Manual Recount audit
Ingram waived the requirement to conduct a manual count in 1% of the election precincts or 3 election precincts
column2: whichever is greater. This was waived in all 254 counties the day after the March 2016 Primary. The timing is significant because during the primary there were 1
column3: 743 move votes than voters in Hill County in the Republican Primary. The margin of victory was 225 in Texas House District 8 that contains Hill County. In calling for a criminal investigation
column4: Ingram noted that it appears ‚Äú6 or 7 voters voted more than once in the election and one voter voted as many as four times.‚Äù Yet he waived the partial manual recount audit requirement statewide and he has waived other audit and monitoring procedures.

column1: 2) Waiver of laws requiring printing of paper backup results tapes
Ingram‚Äôs waivers issued in 2014
column3: and 2016
column4: appear to be in direct contradiction of state election laws 65.004
column8: 66.024 and the Judges Handbook. These rules require ‚Äì ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúThree original tally lists shall be maintained at the polling place to record the number of votes received for the candidates‚Äù ‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúOn completion of the vote count
column9: the presiding judge shall prepare the returns of the election for the precinct‚Äù with ‚Äútotal number of voters‚Äù
column10: ‚Äútotal number of votes‚Äù with the presiding judge signing each of the 3 copies to certify.

column1: Ingram also issued waivers for requirements that a ‚Äúzero tape‚Äù be printed from the machines at the beginning of election day and a ‚Äútally tape‚Äù printed at the close of election. His letter states that ‚Äúthe process of printing of the zero tape and tally tape at each countywide precinct location could take hours in both the morning and the evening of election day.‚Äù
So expediency for election workers takes precedent over requirements enacted by the legislature for integrity of elections. And if a favored vendor can‚Äôt perform to the law
column2: the law is waived.

column1: If proper procedures had been followed to ensure that the machine was at a zero state
column2: instead of waived by Ingram
column3: the Hill County issue of 1
column4: 743 more voters than votes would not have happened. The vendor in Hill County
column5: ES&S eventually identified the source of the extra votes saying ‚ÄúAn audit of the log report from the central paper ballot scanner showed that the hard drive had not been properly cleared of all ballots cast before scanning Early Voting or Election Day ballots‚Ä¶There are established election protocols which should be followed to prevent this type of reporting error.‚Äù

column1: But the Director of Elections is waiving those ‚Äúestablished election protocols‚Äù. Ingram‚Äôs waver of legal requirements & his improvised solution of ‚Äúprinting a zero tape at the county warehouse prior to election day‚Äù opens the door for error and fraud.
3) Ignoring laws requiring printing of legally sufficient ballot images for recounts
The Secretary of State Election Division claims that ‚Äúcast vote records‚Äù are equivalent to ‚Äúballot images‚Äù. As you can see
column2: the cast vote records are very different from ballots and are not uniquely numbered.

column1: The Texas Constitution
column2: Article 6 ‚Äì Suffrage
column3: Section 4 says ‚ÄúIn all elections by the people
column4: the vote shall be by ballot
column5: and the Legislature shall provide for the numbering of tickets and make such other regulations as may be necessary to detect and punish fraud and preserve the purity of the ballot box.‚Äù

column1: Yet the machines by vendors Hart InterCivic and ES&S
column2: certified by Ingram
column3: do not provide uniquely numbered ballots per state recount laws and don‚Äôt provide other components of a legal Texas ballot.

column1: 4) Ignoring laws that allow poll watchers to monitor all election activities such as the printing of paper audit logs for computerized result tabultion
Texas Election Code
column2: Sec 33.056 says a ‚Äúwatcher is entitled to observe any activity conducted at the location at which the watcher is serving.‚Äù

column1: Affidavits from two official poll watchers for a candidate in Dallas County (with official Poll Watcher signed forms) detail how they were ‚Äúrepeatedly obstructed from monitoring multiple election activities at the Dallas County Central Counting Station such as ballot scanning
column2: vote transfer
column3: ballot transfer
column4: computer activities
column5: ballot tabulation
column6: and viewing the elections computer line printer.‚Äù They state that they were ‚Äúrepeatedly treated disrespectfully
column7: obstructed and blatantly ignored‚Äù by the election officials
column8: and voting machine vendor before being thrown out after the officials spoke with the Texas Secretary of State Elections office.

column1: Hostility to election monitors
column2: like Ingram‚Äôs refusal to answer our questions
column3: destroy the public‚Äôs confidence in the honesty of the process ‚Äî and rightfully so.

column1: Ingram‚Äôs Connections To Arkansas
column2: Kutak Rock

column2: Ingram left private practice and moved to Little Rock Arkansas

column4: Kutak Rock

column8: Vince Foster and Webster Hubbell at the Rose Law Firm in Arkansas in the 1990‚Äôs. The Wilbourn family is a large donor to the Clinton Foundation and the Hillary Clinton campaign.

column2: boards & commissions.

column2: his journey from private practice in Texas through Arkansas Clinton-cronies and back to Texas government resulted in pay cuts with each move and his salary being cut in half. In 2012
column3: Ingram
column4: was promoted to Director of the Election Division in the Texas Secretary of State‚Äôs Office where his salary was still 40% less than private practice.

column1: Ingram‚Äôs determination to remove paper trails and auditing procedures for electronic voting is even more troubling when we look at his connections to big Clinton donors.
Establishment Of Both Parties Don‚Äôt Appear To Want Election Integrity
In one lawsuit contesting election results for Austin City Council
column2: the County could not produce ANY ballot images as required by law to conduct a recount. Computer logs had multiple ‚Äúcorruption/invalid‚Äù errors. During discovery it was learned that the computer counted more votes than registered voters in 10 of the 12 precincts forming the district. One precinct had 100% voter turnout
column3: another was just 2 registered voters shy of 100% in spite of only 32% and 17% county-wide turnout in the general and runoff elections.

column1: The County Democrat Party has financed legal opposition to the lawsuit and a Republican judge claimed there was no evidence for election irregularities.
There are some positive developments
column2: however. The Republican judge has now been voted off the bench of the solidly Republican County and state legislators have taken up the question of election integrity that has so far been ignored by Governor Abbott‚Äôs office.

column1: State Senator Bob Hall said
column2: ‚ÄúDue to an increasing number of complaints
column3: it is time for the Texas Elections Division Office to take immediate and decisive action to rescind all waivers issued by that office‚Ä¶and instruct all Texas counties using electronic voting systems to consistently adhere to all election laws‚Ä¶‚Äù

column1: Voters
column2: regardless of political affiliation
column3: should reject policies and personnel that compromise honest
column4: transparent elections. For example

Two months after being purged from the border town of Jarablus in northern Syria by a Turkish-led force ‚Äî and just days after being targeted by Turkish airstrikes near al-Bab ‚Äî Syrian Kurds now fear a ‚Äústab in the back‚Äù from Turkey‚Äôs military as plans for a U.S.-led push to clear ISIS fighters from Raqqa are carried out.
‚ÄúIt is very important Raqqa is liberated

column3: the PYD

column1: At the end of August
column2: Turkish forces took part in a U.S.-led operation to eject ISIS from the northern border of Syria. Once inside Syria
column3: however
column4: Turkish forces ‚Äî leading Free Syrian Army (FSA) rebels ‚Äî took aim at Kurdish fighters in the town of Jarablus
column5: which sent them scurrying across the Euphrates River in retreat.

column1: The issue here is that the U.S. claims to find the Kurds useful in the fight against ISIS. The Kurds
column2: in fact
column3: make up a significant portion of one of the primary U.S.-supplied rebel forces in the region. As Reuters explains :

column1: ‚ÄúKurdish militia have played a big role in the past year in the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF)
column2: a U.S.-backed umbrella group
column3: as it has seized large areas of territory from Islamic State

column1: ‚ÄúHowever
column2: Turkey‚Äôs intervention in Syria in August in support of rebel groups fighting under the Free Syrian Army (FSA) banner has complicated that equation
column3: leading to clashes between them and Kurdish groups allied to the SDF.‚Äù

column1: The problem is one of trust. Turkey believes the Kurdish militants are aligned with the Kurdish PYD party
column2: which the Turks believe is allied with Kurds within Turkey who‚Äôve been waging a religious insurgency for over three decades.

column1: So regardless of whether the U.S. finds the Kurds useful
column2: Turkey has made it clear it intends to sleep with one eye open for the foreseeable future. In fact
column3: it‚Äôs taking a much more proactive stance than that.

column1: Last Thursday
column2: in a campaign of airstrikes that were ‚Äúthe heaviest against the YPG since Turkey launched a military incursion into Syria
column3: ‚Äù Turkey targeted three Kurdish-controlled villages along the northern Syrian border. The Turkish military later confirmed it had carried out ‚Äú26 strikes on areas recently taken by the Kurdish YPG militia‚Äù and ‚Äúhad killed between 160 and 200 combatants.‚Äù

column1: Turkey‚Äôs major concern is that Kurdish-controlled enclaves will physically unite
column2: ‚Äúthereby creating a de facto Kurdish mini-state along the Turkish border.‚Äù As such
column3: Turkey has warned Kurds to keep out of towns like Manjib
column4: which is just northeast of the heaviest fighting in Aleppo.

column1: This tangled web of strained alliances and old feuds will likely only grow more confusing as the U.S.-led operation to purge ISIS from Raqqa draws nearer. In any case

column3: and the days of him obediently ‚Äî even if somewhat grudgingly ‚Äî bending to the U.S. will appear to be fading
column4: as well.

column1: Daniel Fernandez suggested this in his article ‚Äú Has China Reached Its Debt Limit? ‚Äù in Mises Wire . In response to the government‚Äôs monetary expansion stimulus plan after the 2008 financial crisis
column2: China‚Äôs corporate sector did indeed leverage up quickly
column3: followed by an equally fast pace of leveraging in the household sector. However
column4: in order to avoid comparing apples with oranges
column5: we need to take a closer look by putting these numbers into perspective. Using the same data source as used by Fernandez
column6: we find that China‚Äôs total debt as a percentage of GDP was 254 percent by the end of 2015. Debt-to-GDP ratio of corporate
column7: government
column8: and household sectors stood at 170 percent
column9: 44 percent
column10: and 40 percent respectively.

column1: For government and household sectors
column2: both started from considerably low levels until the last administration kicked in a four-trillion yuan (RMB) stimulus plan in 2009. Government debt-to-GDP ratio
column3: which was kept in the mid 30s in the first decade of this millennium
column4: now stood at 44 percent by the end of 2015. Household‚Äôs debt-to-GDP ratio was at 11 percent in 2006 and almost doubled to 19 percent in 2007 and then doubled again to 40 percent by the end of 2015. The leveraging up of households happened exactly as the Chinese society was undergoing rapid urbanization as well as when the government launched its 2009 stimulus.

column1: Apart from the demand for urban housing
column2: Chinese households
column3: with their high savings rate and extra cash in hands
column4: invested in in real estate as a hedge against future inflation. Furthermore
column5: as the stimulus package allowed for easier lending
column6: household debt increased dramatically. However
column7: we must note that although the debt growth rate was high
column8: the absolute debt level of household is still considerably low versus global peers.

column1: The most disturbing trend is found in the corporate sector
column2: with the debt-to-GDP ratio increased from approximately 110 percent prior to 2009 to 170 percent by the end of 2015. First of all
column3: the level of corporate debt (mostly in the form of bank loans) was high to start with
column4: but is by no means out of the norm for a financial system dominated by the banking sector
column5: whose funding source is mostly deposits. Two figures from Jonathan Anderson‚Äôs How To Think About China series provide some insights: 1

Breakdown of assets of China‚Äôs financial system:
This point can be further demonstrated by comparing financial asset structures

column3: between the US and China. Obviously bank loans are the dominant funding source of the corporate sector in China
column4: whereas in the US the role of bank loans is far from prominent in comparison with its enormous capital markets
column5: where the corporates can raise both equities and bond financing easily.

column1: The large role of the banks can also be seen in China‚Äôs bond market yields
column2: and one manifestation of this is a flat yield curve . The reason for this is simple: deposits. When banks have more deposits to manage than they can lend out
column3: they invest these deposits into the bond market and usually on the long end to boost yields. This investment strategy (or asset-liability management scheme) bids up the bond prices on the long end
column4: hence pushing down the long-term yields.

column1: In addition
column2: between allocating deposits to these two types of assets (bonds vs. loans)
column3: banks sometimes have incentives to invest in bonds
column4: rather than lending
column5: due to the balancing considerations of corporate demand
column6: credit risks
column7: market liquidity
column8: and yields (that are also subject to interest rate controls that are at final stage of liberalization and the lending rate was completely liberalized only in early 2016). So the yield spread
column9: at current stage
column10: reflects more of the combination of China‚Äôs financial structure and capital flows rather than being a good indicator of economic fundamentals. As the government flooded the market with four trillion RMB from the stimulus plan in 2009
column11: bond yields faced downward pressure
column12: more so at the long-term end. Please see the yields of Chinese government treasury bonds at maturity (10 years vs. 1 year) and the spread thereof in the below figure. Wealth management products channel a considerable amount of deposits out of the banking system to capture higher yields outside of banking-sector supervision (in form of trusts
column13: for example)
column14: but the amount is still not pivotal enough to change the above explained pattern in a fundamental manner.

column1: China didn‚Äôt open up to the outside world until the very late 1970s. Now China provides half of the manufacturing goods and close to half of electronic products in the world and the economy is still growing at around 6 percent. Obviously a good part of China‚Äôs production structure has been configured to export
column2: mostly to the developed economies
column3: which are dominated by the service sector. As the global demand in the developed economies lost its momentum
column4: China faces the necessity of reconfiguring its economic structure to better serve its domestic consumers (which stands at 4 times the number of US consumers). This reconfiguration process is surely painful as demonstrated by the empty factories in the traditional export production oriented cities. But to me
column5: this is more of a textbook case of Austrian economics at work. Capital and labor have to be freed up for those productions currently being demanded by the market. And this takes time. Moreover
column6: quick capital formation in the past three decades lifted labor productivity
column7: with which the manufacturing sector needs to be upgraded and the tertiary sector needs to be expanded to serve a more affluent society comparing with more than 30 years ago
column8: so that Chinese consumers don‚Äôt have to go to Japan to buy hi-tech toilet lids . A Healthier Skepticism of ‚ÄúStimulus‚Äù

column1: Needless to say
column2: the current debt level causes concern and the deeper concern is whether debt growth trajectory will continue. Ultimately
column3: whether or not the debt will grow at the rate of post 2008 stimulus phase is a function of how fast the Chinese government runs the money printing press. A recent article on the People‚Äôs Daily ‚Äî the mouthpiece of China Communist Party (CCP) ‚Äî quoted the diagnosis from an ‚Äúauthoritative figure‚Äù on the Chinese economy and its cure. This ‚Äúauthoritative figure‚Äù suggested there should be no more money printing to stimulate the economy and that the Chinese should be prepared for a lower growth rate (comparing with its own historical average of 10 percent). Anyone with an understanding of China‚Äôs political messaging system would not be mistake it for anything but an opinion handed down from the very top of Chinese leadership. This can be considered a concluding remark on the policy swings for the past several years.

column1: The Xinhua News Agency
column2: the mainstream media group
column3: recently followed with a commentary suggesting resistance to the use of stimulus plans in the face of slowing growth. Xinhua also warned of a disastrous result if its advice is not followed. Messages like these are refreshing to hear nowadays among the mantra of the stimulus chorus around the world. How China‚Äôs policy direction is to be implemented remains to be seen
column4: but at least the insidious effects of stimulus is well recognized by those at the top of the regime and openly represented by mainstream media. In addition
column5: a series of measures to lower tax burdens for corporate and households alike are also being introduced
column6: and the central government is pushing hard for business-friendly deregulations and increasing economic freedom.

column1: China has its problems; tons of them. China may or may not be the first to blow up in the coming wave of crises
column2: as many people say. No matter whichever the case
column3: I am more convinced that China will be among the first ones to revive ‚Äî because it has high savings to invest
column4: it has a well-trained labor force with one of the most vibrant
column5: if not the most complete
column6: manufacturing chain
column7: and the manufacturing sector still contributes to over 40 percent of its GDP. It is still in the middle of a rapid urbanization process. It is not yet a welfare state. Chinese people are fully aware of the fact that their safety net is the result of their own frugality rather than government promises. China has the biggest potential market of 1.3 billion people with a rising middle-class that is still increasing in numbers and share in population. Serving them well is one of the biggest business opportunities in the 21st century.

As Infowars has highlighted

column1: While election officials have dismissed the reports

column1: Larry Norden
column2: a voting technology expert
column3: told NPR that the reports usually arise where outdated technology is being employed.

column1: ‚ÄúOver time

column1: During elections over the past decade and more there have been reports of voting machines ‚Äòflipping‚Äô. Indeed

column1: Meanwhile

column1: Callum Borchers

column1: 4931;7aa5f6ad807d08e7deeb13628ef3ed5e211e6f4d;0;National Geographic;2016-10-27T18:42:16.263+03:00;Exclusive: Christ‚Äôs Burial Place Exposed for First Time in Centuries;"Store Exclusive: Christ‚Äôs Burial Place Exposed for First Time in Centuries Restorers working in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Israel uncover stone slab venerated as the resting place of Jesus Christ Image Credits: Wiki Commons .
For the first time in centuries
column2: scientists have exposed the original surface of what is traditionally considered the tomb of Jesus Christ. Located in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in the Old City of Jerusalem
column3: the tomb has been covered by marble cladding since at least 1555 A.D.
column4: and most likely centuries earlier.

column1: ‚ÄúThe marble covering of the tomb has been pulled back
column2: and we were surprised by the amount of fill material beneath it
column3: ‚Äù said Fredrik Hiebert
column4: archaeologist-in-residence at the National Geographic Society
column5: a partner in the restoration project. ‚ÄúIt will be a long scientific analysis
column6: but we will finally be able to see the original rock surface on which
column7: according to tradition
column8: the body of Christ was laid.‚Äù

column1: According to Christian tradition
column2: the body of Jesus Christ was laid on a shelf or ‚Äúburial bed‚Äù hewn from the side of a limestone cave following his crucifixion by the Romans in A.D. 30 or possibly 33. Christian belief says Christ was resurrected after death
column3: and women who came to anoint his body three days after the burial reported that no remains were present.";english;2016-10-27T18:42:16.263+03:00;infowars.com;US;2774.0;Exclusive: Christ‚Äôs Burial Place Exposed for First Time in Centuries;0.0;http://hw.infowars.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/church-sepulchre1.jpg;0;1;37;0;37;conspiracy

column1: 4932;13655e7c6796282de15ad88405f9548d9dd893dd;0;Steve Watson;2016-10-27T18:42:19.708+03:00;Three Quarters Of Americans Oppose Gun Control;"Three Quarters Of Americans Oppose Gun Control Record numbers say no to proposed handgun ban Steve Watson | Infowars.com - October 27
column2: 2016 Comments

column1: A new poll released by Gallup has found that a record amount of Americans are opposed to gun control measures .
The survey found that 76 percent of respondents
column2: over three quarters
column3: believe that a ban on civilian ownership of handguns should not be made law.

column1: The findings represent a four-point increase on the same survey from last year
column2: in addition to an all-time high for the past three decades.

column1: The poll also found that almost two thirds
column2: 61 percent
column3: are ‚Äúagainst‚Äù a ban on semi-automatic rifles
column4: or ‚Äúassault weapons‚Äùas the corporate media refers to them.

column1: That figure represents a full ten-point increase on previous findings
column2: and is an all time record high since polling began on the issue 20 years ago.

column1: Just 27 percent
column2: less than a third
column3: say they support a ban on handgun ownership
column4: while only 36 percent
column5: support a semi-automatic ban. an eight-point decline on previous findings.

column1: In addition
column2: gun sales have been hitting record highs for months on end.

column1: In a summary of the new poll
column2: Gallup seemed surprised
column3: by the findings
column4: describing waning support for a gun ban as a ‚Äúparadox‚Äù:

column1: Perhaps paradoxically
column2: opposition toward a ban has increased against a backdrop of multiple mass shootings and terrorist attacks in which the perpetrators used assault rifles. These guns were used in high-profile incidents
column3: including the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino
column4: California
column5: and Orlando
column6: and the mass shootings in Aurora
column7: Colorado
column8: and Newtown
column9: Connecticut.

column1: The findings reveal just how out of step Hillary Clinton‚Äôs position on gun control is with the majority of Americans.
Hillary is a staunch gun control proponent. Wikileaks releases have revealed that Hillary plans to implement strict gun control measures by executive order.
Clinton purportedly plans to open gun manufacturers to lawsuits by crime victims
column2: a move that critics say would do nothing to reduce crime

column1: 4934;04c3711676b7b727f8420cf175ad994827e81600;0;Fiona Miller;2016-10-27T18:54:58.827+03:00;Chinese University Sells HIV Testing Kits in Vending Machine;"Chinese University Sells HIV Testing Kits in Vending Machine China has a 43% year-over-year increase of the disease Image Credits: David Pursehouse/Flickr .

China has experienced such a growth rate of HIV in the past several years that one university has taken steps to allow students to test themselves: by placing an HIV testing kit in a vending machine next to regular fare like snacks.
China has seen a 43% year-over-year increase in infection rates
column2: which likely prompted Southwest Petroleum University in Nanchong City in Sichuan Province to install the test kits .

column1: Sichuan Province is one of the top three provinces in China with a disproportionately high rate of HIV/AIDS. Together
column2: with the other two provinces that have high rates of the disease
column3: the three account for over half of the cases of HIV/AIDS in the entire country.

column1: 80% of new HIV cases occur due to homosexual activity.

The kits retail for $4.40 and can be taken as a urine test to determine whether or not students need to seek medical attention. Those who purchase the test will collect their urine and send it to a laboratory
column2: and then access the results online. This can all be done completely anonymously.

column1: Similar kits can be purchased online
column2: but they retail for around $45. The cheaper vending machine tests are just as accurate and are partially subsidized by a charity to allow the test to be more accessible.

column1: Reports state that the Chinese have limited sex education and very little is discussed about HIV or AIDS. Many students who suspect they may have the disease do not seek medical help because of its link to homosexuality. Those who do have HIV are often thought to be pariahs by their families and friends because of its connection with same-sex encounters.
The disease is mostly spreading amongst young homosexual men
column2: but as with anywhere else
column3: women who do not use proper protection are also susceptible to becoming infected.

column1: Doctors have stated that most young people who have become infected with HIV/AIDS in China lacked proper education and did not take appropriate precautions for prevention.
The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) states that there are currently about half a million people in China living with HIV or AIDS
column2: however this figure may be inaccurate due to underreporting.  ";english;2016-10-27T18:54:58.827+03:00;infowars.com;US;2774.0;Chinese University Sells HIV Testing Kits in Vending Machine;0.0;http://hw.infowars.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/vendingmachine-2.jpg;0;1;375;0;375;conspiracy

column1: 4938;1540dd28ba8f7036335d1966730d1456e0146479;0;Kit Daniels;2016-10-28T00:15:48.481+03:00;Public Faith in Elections Falls as the State Grows;"Public Faith in Elections Falls as the State Grows Out-of-control state power Ryan McMaken | Mises.org - October 27
column2: 2016 Comments

column1: In the wake of the final presidential election debate last week
column2: the mainstream media was appalled that Donald Trump would not pre-emptively agree to not contest the outcome of the election .

column1: Trump‚Äôs position reflects a growing faction of Americans who doubt the integrity and honesty of the American electoral system. In response
column2: mainstream media sources have responded by vehemently insisting that ‚Äúrigged‚Äù elections are ‚Äú a myth .‚Äù

column1: While rarely stated explicitly
column2: the way American electoral politics is supposed to work is this: the population spends several months listening to the candidates accuse each other of terrible crimes
column3: horrible ideas
column4: and gross incompetence. Each candidate lists the ways he or she will use the power of government to force the winner‚Äôs policy preferences on the losers. Then
column5: once the votes are cast
column6: everyone is supposed to quickly accept the results
column7: ignore everything that was said during the campaign
column8: and immediately accept the winner as having an indisputable mandate to rule over everyone
column9: including the sizable minority ‚Äî or even the majority
column10: in many cases ‚Äî who either voted against the winner
column11: or abstained. If there appears to be any ‚Äúirregularities‚Äù in the vote
column12: well
column13: those should just be ignored because it would ‚Äútear the country apart‚Äù to ‚Äúdrag out‚Äù the election. If half the country feels it‚Äôs been cheated
column14: well
column15: tough luck and better luck next time. Democracy Breaks Down As (Perceived) Interventionism Increases

column1: This model can only work indefinitely under certain specific conditions. It can be workable when there is a perception that government is limited in its power
column2: and extensive or abrupt change to government institutions are thought to be rare. It can also work in a small
column3: culturally uniform society where there is a relatively small divide between socio-economic and ethnic groups.

column1: In the case of the United States
column2: however
column3: it appears that neither of these conditions apply.

column1: In the age of presidential executive orders
column2: militarized police
column3: uncountable federal laws
column4: and a myriad of spy agencies empowered to watch Americans‚Äô every move
column5: gone is the perception that a loss in an electoral contest should simply be accepted without question. The president says he can issue laws with ‚Äú a pen and ‚Ä¶ a phone ‚Äù without any need to consult Congress. The Libya war proved presidents can invade any country without so much as a debate in Congress. Meanwhile
column6: the untouchable Supreme Court hands down decisions that are equivalent to Constitutional amendments
column7: some of which can have enormous effects on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.

column1: In other words
column2: the stakes are now reaching the point where an attitude of ‚Äúbetter luck next time‚Äù doesn‚Äôt cut it. Whether or not these fears are at times overstated is irrelevant. The fact is the perception of democratic lawlessness is growing.

column1: This situation is further complicated by the fact that the United States is an enormous conglomeration of different cultural and socio-economic groups spread out over a vast and varied geography. Many of these different groups distrust each other
column2: and in a country where the president and the judiciary now rule largely by proclamation
column3: there is reason to be fearful when ‚Äúthe other guy‚Äôs‚Äù candidate wins and yours loses. Democracy Can Work When the Stakes Are Low

column1: Contrary to the naive musings of some nostalgic conservatives
column2: the United States was never united into a single cultural
column3: linguistic
column4: or socio-economic group. Those differences may have reached a low point during the twentieth century
column5: but they were far larger in the 19th century than they are today.

column1: When you have a diverse population
column2: however
column3: the problem of who controls the government becomes far more important
column4: and this concern grows as the state becomes more powerful. Writing on the topic of immigration and nationalism in Australia
column5: Ludwig von Mises noted how powerful states exacerbate the problem of cultural divides. Could a laissez-faire regime be guaranteed to all residents of Australia
column6: Mises notes
column7: it would not matter at all if there were cultural mistrust between English-descended Australians and Asian newcomers. However
column8: since laissez-faire liberalism has not been embraced
column9: a familiar problem presented itself:

column1: The present inhabitants of [Australia] fear that some day they could be reduced to a minority in their own country and that they would then have to suffer all the horrors of national persecution to which
column2: for instance
column3: the Germans are today [i.e.
column4: the early 1920s] exposed in Czechoslovakia
column5: Italy
column6: and Poland.

column1: It cannot be denied that these fears are justified. Because of the enormous power that today stands at the command of the state
column2: a national minority must expect the worst from a majority of a different nationality. As long as the state is granted the vast powers which it has today and which public opinion considers to be its right
column3: the thought of having to live in a state whose government is in the hands of members of a foreign nationality is positively terrifying. It is frightful to live in a state in which at every turn one is exposed to persecution ‚Äî masquerading under the guise of justice ‚Äî by a ruling majority. It is dreadful to be handicapped even as a child in school on account of one‚Äôs nationality and to be in the wrong before every judicial and administrative authority because one belongs to a national minority‚Ä¶

column1: It is clear that no solution of the problem of immigration is possible if one adheres to the ideal of the interventionist state
column2: which meddles in every field of human activity
column3: or to that of the socialist state. Only the adoption of the liberal program could make the problem of immigration
column4: which today seems insoluble
column5: completely disappear. In an Australia governed according to liberal principles
column6: what difficulties could arise from the fact that in some parts of the continent Japanese and in other parts Englishmen were in the majority?

column1: These same principles can be applied outside the subject of immigration as well. The existence of an interventionist state means any country composed of diverse ethnic and socioeconomic groups faces the same problem of one group being exploited by another group
column2: with the help of state power. Change the term ‚Äúnationality‚Äù to ‚Äúpolitical party‚Äù or ‚Äúinterest groups
column3: ‚Äù and one has a fair approximation of the problem of democracy in any interventionist state.

column1: In the presence of a relatively weak government
column2: however
column3: these concerns are often overstated. At the turn of the 20th century in the US
column4: for example
column5: the fact that Spanish-speakers were in the majority in New Mexico and many areas of the American West was irrelevant to the lives of the vast majority of Americans. The fact that Japanese immigrants and their descendant were out-competing white businessmen in California was simply not a matter of national importance. The fact that Oregon attempted to outlaw Catholic Schools was not a matter for presidential executive orders. Thanks to widespread suspicion of federal power at the time
column6: the lack of a strong federal judiciary and a relatively weak presidency meant these issues remained largely local while public policy was haphazard.

column1: Voters have always feared losses in elections
column2: but now more than ever
column3: the voters may be justified in refusing to simply accept the outcomes of elections under ‚Äúan interventionist state
column4: which meddles in every field of human activity.‚Äù When that is the case
column5: elections are not something to be taken lightly. Trump‚Äôs remarks about rigged elections ‚Äî and public fears over the outcome ‚Äî are to be expected from voters with an immense fear of out-of-control state power.

column1: In response to all of this
column2: the pundits and government class will tell us that everyone must double down on democracy
column3: and that elections ‚Äî specifically federal ones ‚Äîare sacred rituals never to be questioned. There will be a double standard
column4: of course. A Trump victory will be questioned by the media and powerful politicians. But
column5: in that case it will be the fault of the Russians
column6: and not anything wrong with the system itself. The solution for the feds
column7: of course
column8: will be a federal takeover of the election system. If Clinton wins
column9: then no questioning of the system will be tolerated at all. To question the outcome or the wisdom of these presidential contests will be denounced as scarcely less than sacrilege.

column1: The true solution to the problem remains far more practical
column2: however. To paraphrase Mises
column3: it is clear that no solution of the problem of elections is possible if one adheres to the ideal of the interventionist state. So long as elections are increasingly perceived to be referenda on which side shall use the power of the state to crush the other side
column4: faith in the electoral system will erode
column5: and the potential for real violence will increase. NEWSLETTER SIGN UP Get the latest breaking news & specials from Alex Jones and the Infowars Crew. column1: 4940;4c0fffe790c6238951625fc6bf278e3d48dd58f1;0;Adan Salazar;2016-10-28T00:15:48.955+03:00;WHO Cancer Agency Under Fire for withholding ‚Äòcarcinogenic glyphosate‚Äô Documents;"WHO Cancer Agency Under Fire for withholding ‚Äòcarcinogenic glyphosate‚Äô Documents IARC urged its scientists not to publish research documents on its 2015 weedkiller glyphosate review RT.com - October 27
column2: 2016 Comments

column1: The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC)
column2: facing criticism over its classification of carcinogens
column3: has reportedly been advising its scientific experts not to publish internal research data on its 2015 report on ‚Äúprobably carcinogenic‚Äù glyphosate.

column1: The IARC urged its scientists not to publish research documents on its 2015 weedkiller glyphosate review
column2: according to Reuters. The agency told Reuters on Tuesday that it tried to protect the study from ‚Äúexternal interference
column3: ‚Äù as well as protect its intellectual rights
column4: since it was ‚Äúthe sole owner of such materials.‚Äù

column1: The scientists had been asked earlier to release all the documentation on the 2015 report under US freedom of information laws.
The groundbreaking review
column2: published in March 2015 by the IARC ‚Äì a semi-autonomous agency of the World Health Organization (WHO) ‚Äì labeled the glyphosate herbicide as ‚Äúprobably carcinogenic to humans.‚Äù Glyphosate is a key ingredient of Monsanto‚Äôs flagship weedkiller well-known under the trade name ‚ÄòRoundup.‚Äô It is one of the most heavily used herbicides in the world and is designed to go along with genetically-modified ‚ÄúRoundup Ready‚Äù crops
column3: also produced by Monsanto.

column1: The IARC‚Äôs report caused problems for both the notorious agrochemical giant and the agency itself.
The report sparked a heated debate around the use of Roundup
column2: and caused several EU countries ‚Äì including France
column3: Sweden
column4: and the Netherlands ‚Äì to object to the renewal of the glyphosate‚Äôs EU license. The vote on prolonging the glyphosate license for 15 years failed several times in June 2016
column5: but the license was temporarily extended for 18 months during last hours before its expiration.

column1: The controversial report has seemingly made the IARC a target for attacks from multiple directions
column2: and raised scientific
column3: legal
column4: and financial questions.

column1: Various critics
column2: including those in the chemical industry
column3: said the IARC‚Äôs evaluations are fuel for ‚Äúunnecessary health scares
column4: ‚Äù since the IARC allegedly studies the potentially harmful substance itself
column5: and not a ‚Äútypical human‚Äù exposure to it. It remained unclear whether the critics urged a WHO body to test the potentially carcinogenic chemical on humans.

column1: The critics also brought up other controversial statements from the IARC
column2: over whether such things as mobile phones
column3: coffee
column4: red meat
column5: and processed meat could cause cancer.

column1: The agency defended its methods as scientifically sound and ‚Äúwidely respected for their scientific rigor
column2: standardized and transparent process and‚Ä¶freedom from conflicts of interest.‚Äù Numerous freedom of information requests by the Energy & Environment Legal Institute (E&E Legal)
column3: a US conservative advocacy group
column4: have since been turned down with this reasoning.

column1: E&E Legal told Reuters that it is pushing a legal challenge over whether the documents in question belong to the IARC or to the US federal and state institutions where some of the experts work. Basically
column2: it‚Äôs being decided whether the IARC
column3: as part of the WHO
column4: is truly independent and free from ‚Äúconflicts of interest.‚Äù

column1: According to Reuters
column2: officials from the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) will be questioned by a congressional committee about why American taxpayers fund the cancer agency
column3: which faces much criticism over its allegedly faulty classification of carcinogens.

column1: ‚ÄúIARC‚Äôs standards and determinations for classifying substances as carcinogenic
column2: and therefore cancer-causing
column3: appear inconsistent with other scientific research
column4: and have generated much controversy and alarm
column5: ‚Äù a letter from US Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz to NIH director Francis Collins states
column6: as quoted by Reuters.

column1: The Oversight Committee demanded a full disclosure of NIH funding of the IARC
column2: and even money spent in relation to the cancer agency‚Äôs activities.

column1: IARC opponents from scientific circles vowed to provide their data on the matter. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA)
column2: which believes glyphosate is ‚Äúunlikely pose a carcinogenic hazard to humans
column3: ‚Äù promised to release its raw data on the subject as part of its ‚Äúcommitment to open risk assessment.‚Äù The food safety watchdog made this statement in late September
column4: and still has to deliver the promised information. NEWSLETTER SIGN UP Get the latest breaking news & specials from Alex Jones and the Infowars Crew. column1: DO THE COMMITTEES that oversee the vast U.S. spying apparatus take intelligence community whistleblowers seriously? Do they earnestly investigate reports of waste
column2: fraud
column3: abuse
column4: professional negligence
column5: or crimes against the Constitution reported by employees or contractors working for agencies like the CIA or NSA? For the last 20 years
column6: the answer has been a resounding ‚Äúno.‚Äù

column1: My own experience in 1995-96 is illustrative. Over a two-year period working with my wife
column2: Robin (who was a CIA detailee to a Senate committee at the time)
column3: we discovered that
column4: contrary to the public statements by then-Chairman of the Joint Chiefs Colin Powell and other senior George H. W. Bush administration officials (including CIA Director John Deutch)
column5: American troops had in fact been exposed to chemical agents during and after the 1991 war with Saddam Hussein. While the Senate Banking Committee under then-Chairman Don Riegle
column6: D-Mich.
column7: was trying to uncover the truth of this
column8: officials at the Pentagon and CIA were working to bury it.

column1: At the CIA
column2: I objected internally ‚Äî and was immediately placed under investigation by the CIA‚Äôs Office of Security. That became clear just days after we delivered the first of our several internal briefings to increasingly senior officials at the CIA and other intelligence agencies. In February 1995
column3: I received a phone call from CIA Security asking whether I‚Äôd had any contacts with the media. I had not
column4: but I had mentioned to CIA officials we‚Äôd met with that I knew that the CBS newsmagazine ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù was working on a piece about the Gulf War chemical cover-up. This call would not be the last I‚Äôd receive from CIA Security about the matter
column5: nor the only action the agency would take against us.

column1: In the spring of 1995
column2: a former manager of Robin‚Äôs discreetly pulled her aside and said that CIA Security agents were asking questions about us
column3: talking to every single person with or for whom either of us had worked. I seemed to be the special focus of their attention
column4: and the last question they asked our friends
column5: colleagues
column6: and former managers was
column7: ‚ÄúDo you believe Pat Eddington would allow his conscience to override the secrecy agreement he signed?‚Äù";english;2016-10-28T05:10:09.820+03:00;infowars.com;US;2774.0;When CIA and NSA Workers Blow the Whistle

column12: Trump supporters continue to point to the reports as evidence that vote fraud may be taking place.

4988;ad93b7b697556f388bd7f34bd57331a895fb8848;0;Fiona Miller;2016-10-28T21:12:37.671+03:00;Big Pharma Targets Profits in Rare Diseases;"Big Pharma Targets Profits in Rare Diseases All of the world's most expensive drugs are used to treat uncommon conditions Image Credits: StockSnap/Pixabay .
One might think Big Pharma garners most of its profit peddling pills for more well-known diseases
column2: but new research shows that pharmaceutical companies are instead searching for the next ‚Äúbig thing‚Äù in rare diseases.

column1: Big Pharma‚Äôs profit margins continue to rise considerably with rarer diseases
column2: simply because they can charge more for the pills than they do for medication for more common ailments.

column1: The search for the next money-maker within rare diseases has actually halted some of the advancements for more common ailments
column2: which may explain why they still haven‚Äôt discovered a cure for some of the most common diseases affecting the world‚Äôs population.

the Orphan Drug Act started to incentivize the creation of drugs for rarer diseases to ensure that those suffering from uncommon conditions were not neglected in new scientific research simply because the drugs weren‚Äôt as profitable.

column1: Because of the incentives
column2: which include reduced taxes and reduced or waived regulatory fees
column3: over 500 new drugs for uncommon diseases have hit the market since the law was introduced.

column1: For common illnesses
column2: Big Pharma can get still turnover big profits while not charging a fortune for the drug. For example
column3: Liptior (atorvastatin)
column4: which is used to regulate cholesterol
column5: generates a sales profit of $131 billion with the prescription only costing patients around $2 per day.

column1: But with rare diseases
column2: prices must be kept high in order to keep Big Pharma in business. This means that while those with uncommon illnesses may benefit healthwise from the new measures
column3: their pocketbooks are in for a hit.

column1: For example
column2: the cystic fibrosis drug Kalydeco by Vertex costs individual patients $311

column1: Gilead‚Äôs Sovaldi
column2: used to treat Hepatitis C
column3: cashes in at $84
column4: 000 for a paltry 12-week course of medication.

column1: And Soliris
column2: used to treat rare blood conditions
column3: costs the patient a whopping $400
column4: 000 per year.

column1: The list of the 10 most expensive drugs that are currently manufactured are all created to treat ‚Äúorphan‚Äù or uncommon illnesses.
Thanks to these laws that allow Big Pharma to charge these insane amounts of money
column2: they can use those who suffer from rare diseases as their cash cows.

column1: Drugs for rare diseases will account for 19% of pharmaceutical branded drug profits by the year 2020. 4991;27ce554642b5e188f594dcdb1d9ffe6b98975120;0;J√∂rg Guido H√ºlsmann;2016-10-28T22:36:55.909+03:00;Is De-industrialization a ‚ÄúNatural Phenomenon‚Äù of Developed Economies?;"Is De-industrialization a ‚ÄúNatural Phenomenon‚Äù of Developed Economies? Increasing real revenues affect people‚Äôs lifestyle choices J√∂rg Guido H√ºlsmann | Mises.org
Let me first state my position and then add a few arguments to back it up.
Economic growth typically entails a re-allocation of labor away from industrial production
column2: but it does not all by itself lead to falling industrial output. The decline of industrial production in the US and France in the past thirty years is to some extent due to capital exports
column3: but especially to government interventionism in the form of mushrooming labor
column4: business and financial regulations
column5: education policies
column6: social security funding
column7: and taxation. This decline cannot be stopped through more interventions
column8: even if they are designed with the good intention to reindustrialize the country.

column1: Now let me offer a few considerations in support of these contentions.

The reallocation of labor in a growing economy results most notably from capital accumulation and from changing preferences of the working-age population. Further investments and extensions of the existing structure of production make it necessary to spend more time devising new methods
column2: preparing industrial activity
column3: coordinating and monitoring supply chains. Low-quality blue-collar labor diminishes
column4: whereas there is some increase in high-quality blue-collars
column5: but especially an increase in white-collars working in and around the supply chains.

column1: Increasing real revenues affect people‚Äôs lifestyle choices. Rather than laboring long hours that provide essentially a monetary reward
column2: they increasingly prefer enjoyable activities that provide immediate psychological and emotional rewards. Thus the blossoming of artistic
column3: intellectual
column4: and scientific activities in developed countries
column5: at the expense of traditional industrial pursuits.

column1: As a natural consequence of economic growth
column2: therefore
column3: industrial production declines relative to what it could be if it attracted even more people. But this does neither imply a shrinking physical industrial output
column4: nor does it imply shrinking industrial revenues. Capital accumulation and technological progress make it possible that industry thrives even when less people have industrial employment. Germany provides an example.

column1: In the past thirty years
column2: western capitalists have invested large amounts of capital in formerly communist countries of the East and Far East. This reallocation of capital
column3: though beneficial from the overall point of view of the world economy
column4: has been detrimental in the short-run to the industrial development of those western countries where the capital would otherwise have been used.

column1: But capital investments in countries such as France and the US have declined even more as a result of mushrooming government interventions. Welfare checks diminish the incentive to accept low-paying and non-gratifying industrial jobs. Massive subsidies for secondary and higher education artificially prolong schooling; reduce the supply of qualified manual labor; and create an artificial bias among the working-age population for scientific
column2: intellectual
column3: and artistic activities. Panoply of regulations have
column4: on the one hand
column5: increased the costs of doing business and
column6: on the other hand
column7: stimulated rent-seeking and manifold forms of evasion and regulatory arbitrage. Today they are feeding entire armies of lawyers
column8: accountants
column9: auditors
column10: and financial advisors
column11: all at the expense of ordinary business.

column1: These tendencies cannot be stopped through so-called reindustrialization policies
column2: which boil down to even more government spending
column3: premised on the spurious notion that irresponsible (and often also inexperienced) politicians know best how to use the available scarce resources. Such policies have utterly failed in the past (Airbus included)
column4: and will fail in the future. Genuine reindustrialization requires more oxygen for industry. It requires nothing less than a rollback of the artificial obstacles for industrial development that government interventions have created in past generations.  ";english;2016-10-28T22:36:55.909+03:00;infowars.com;US;2774.0;Is De-industrialization a ‚ÄúNatural Phenomenon‚Äù of Developed Economies?;0.0;http://hw.infowars.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/hillary-factory.jpg;0;1;24;0;24;conspiracy

column1: 4993;ffe41839ac12beddddf7cf4a59e799103ad30f9d;0;Mikael Thalen;2016-10-29T00:54:59.074+03:00;The Email That Got John Podesta Hacked;"The Email That Got John Podesta Hacked Latest WikiLeaks dump reveals phishing email that compromised Podesta Mikael Thalen - October 28
column2: 2016 Comments

column1: The email that lead to the hack of Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta‚Äôs Gmail account was published online Friday by WikiLeaks.
The malicious March 2016 email
column2: which claims to be from Google
column3: asked Podesta to change his password due to unauthorized access from an IP address in the Ukraine.

column1: Clinton campaign staff members who viewed the email were convinced it was genuine. Clinton insider Sara Latham argued ‚ÄúThe gmail one is REAL‚Äù while even Clinton campaign IT specialist Charles Delavan said ‚ÄúThis is a legitimate email.‚Äù
The first suspicious aspect of the email
column2: unnoticed by the Clinton camp
column3: was the ‚Äúbit.ly‚Äù password reset link. Bitly
column4: a website that shortens long web addresses
column5: would not be found in an official email from Google.

column1: As first reported by Motherboard earlier this month
column2: examination of the Bitly link that redirected Podesta to a fake Google webpage also contained several red flags.

column1: The Bitly link helped hide not only the fact that the landing page ended in ‚Äú.tk‚Äù instead of ‚Äú.com‚Äù but that the web page itself failed to use HTTPS encryption. Such links were also likely used to fool Google‚Äôs spam filters.

Prior analysis of the phishing link by cybersecurity group SecureWorks revealed the hackers also made a significant operation security mistake ‚Äì they failed to make their two Bitly accounts private.
The public accounts revealed the hackers had created 8
column2: 909 similar links to use against 3
column3: 907 Gmail accounts between October 2015 and May 2016.

column1: SecureWorks notes that the targets included ‚Äúindividuals in Russia and the former Soviet states
column2: current and former military and government personnel in the U.S. and Europe
column3: individuals working in the defense and government supply chain
column4: and authors and journalists.‚Äù

column1: Accounts linked to the 2016 election were also in the hackers‚Äô sights.
‚ÄúSpecific targets include staff working for or associated with Hillary Clinton‚Äôs presidential campaign and the Democratic National Committee (DNC)
column2: including individuals managing Clinton‚Äôs communications
column3: travel
column4: campaign finances
column5: and advising her on policy.‚Äù

column1: Thomas Rid
column2: a professor at King‚Äôs college
column3: displayed on Twitter how decoding the phishing links could reveal the specific emails being targeted.

column1: Click to enlarge Interestingly
column2: former Secretary of State Colin Powell
column3: whose emails were released by the website DCLeaks in September
column4: was also targeted by the same hackers.

column1: Click to enlarge This connection suggests the hackers who provided WikiLeaks with the Podesta emails and DCLeaks with the Powell emails are likely one in the same. The Bitly accounts are also behind the malicious email sent to retired four-star General Philip Mark Breedlove ‚Äì whose emails appeared on DCLeaks in April.

Numerous cybersecurity groups have accused the Russian government of being responsible not only for the above election season hacks but for creating DCLeaks and Guccifer 2.0. to disseminate the data. The U.S. government also publicly blamed Russia on October 7 just one week before the CIA was tasked with preparing a possible retaliatory ‚Äú cyber strike .‚Äù
Russian President Vladimir Putin has denied involvement
column2: arguing that the contents of the hacks are far more important than who is responsible.

column1: ‚ÄúListen
column2: does it even matter who hacked this data?‚Äô‚Äô Putin said on September 1. ‚ÄúThe important thing is the content that was given to the public.‚Äô‚Äô

column1: Putin again dismissed US ‚Äúhysteria‚Äù concerning the hacks on Thursday during an annual speech at the Valdai Discussion Club in Sochi.
‚ÄúHysteria has been whipped up in the United States about the influence of Russia over the U.S. presidential election
column2: ‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs much simpler to distract people with so-called Russian hackers
column3: spies
column4: and agents of influence. Does anyone really think that Russia could influence the American people‚Äôs choice in any way? Is America a banana republic or what? America is a great power.‚Äù NEWSLETTER SIGN UP Get the latest breaking news & specials from Alex Jones and the Infowars Crew.
