4995;d49cbde2bf4a4586fe87ab0d32a6807cce12bb14;0;Kit Daniels;2016-10-29T01:07:07.767+03:00;Britain Should Embrace Unilateral Free Trade Right Now;"Britain Should Embrace Unilateral Free Trade Right Now Unilateralism is not simply a utopian libertarian ideal Louis Rouanet | Mises.org   Image Credits: Iker Merodio / Flickr .
If we read the newspapers or listen to the experts
column2: Britain faces two ways to negotiate its way out of the European Union without succumbing to the protectionists‚Äô sirens.

column1: The first is a deal √† la Norway not only with full access to the common market
column2: but also with full implementation of EU law and a contribution to the EU budget as is the case for every member State. The second option would be a trade treaty such as the one negotiated between the EU and Canada. However
column3: a viable third opportunity exists: unilateral free-trade.

column1: Contrary to what is often assumed
column2: unilateralism is not simply a utopian libertarian ideal which cannot be reached in today‚Äôs world. Unilateral free trade is genuine free-trade. It is also the most pragmatic and efficient strategy to foster commerce and peace. Theresa May seems ready to conduct an interventionist industrial and economic policy which oddly resembles French planning as it existed in the 50s and 60s. But
column3: the free-market policy paradigm is more likely to transform post-Brexit Britain into a flourishing economy.

column1: Unilateral Free Trade: The British Tradition
The tradition of unilateral free trade is tightly linked to the UK. With the victory of the liberals in the 1840s
column2: Britain became strongly committed to unilateral free trade and from 1845 to at least 1914
column3: free trade was politically unassailable. Trade treaties
column4: however
column5: were seen as inherently suspicious. Sir Robert Peel
column6: when announcing the repeal of the Corn Laws in the House of Commons in 1846
column7: brilliantly warned:

column1: I trust the government ‚Ä¶ will not resume the policy which they and we have found most inconvenient
column2: namely the haggling with foreign countries about reciprocal concessions
column3: instead of taking that independent course which we believe to be conducive to our own interests. ‚Ä¶ [L]et us trust that our example
column4: with the proof of practical benefits we derive from it
column5: will at no remote period insure the adoption of the principles on which we have acted. ‚Ä¶ Let
column6: therefore
column7: our commerce be as free as our institutions. Let us proclaim commerce free
column8: and nation after nation will follow our example. This repeal of the Corn Laws was the result of an intense political effort
column9: especially by Cobden and the Anti-Corn Law League
column10: who made the case for unilateral free trade. Cobden in his later years explained:

column1: We came to the conclusion that the less we attempted to persuade foreigners to adopt our trade principles
column2: the better
column3: for we discovered so much suspicion of the motives of England
column4: that it was lending an argument to the protectionists abroad to incite the popular feeling against the free-traders. ‚Ä¶ To take away this pretense
column5: we avowed our total indifference whether other nations became free-traders or not; but we should abolish Protection for our own selves
column6: and leave other countries to take whatever course they liked best. Some will argue that the UK soon departed from unilateral free trade with the Cobden-Chevalier treaty of 1860 which Cobden himself supported and negotiated. It is less known however that this treaty was primarily a way to avoid conflict. After Orsini‚Äôs attempt to murder Napol√©on III in 1858
column7: the emperor was convinced
column8: by this same Orsini
column9: to support the cause of Italian independence. This Italian question brought England to the edge of war with France. Being strongly anti-militarists
column10: both Cobden and Chevalier looked at a trade treaty not primarily as a way to adopt free trade
column11: but as a way to establish friendship between France and England. Gladstone
column12: himself an ardent unilateralist
column13: in retrospect held that ‚Äúthere were only two alternatives
column14: one of them the French treaty & the other war with France.‚Äù And Cobden felt that the treaty was ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs own method to produce an entente cordiale.‚Äù

column1: Commercially
column2: the treaty was an incredible success mainly because it was not supervised by bureaucrats ‚Äî as is the case today with trade treaties ‚Äî but by two prominent free traders. As Cobden was aware of all the dangers for real free trade contained in the negotiations of trade treaties
column3: he proceeded very carefully. Cobden wrote in a letter to the great British free trader John Bright
column4: ‚ÄúI will undertake that there is not a syllable on our side of the Treaty that is inconsistent with the soundest principles of Free Trade.‚Äù Nonetheless
column5: Bright remained a skeptic and remarked:

column1: Governments seem as a rule to be standing conspiracies to rob and bamboozle people
column2: and why should that of Louis Napoleon be an exception? The more I see of the rulers of the world
column3: the less of wisdom or greatness do I find necessary for the government of mankind. To convince Cobden of the benefits brought about by a treaty
column4: Michel Chevalier showed that the unilateral reductions of tariffs that Bright asked for could constitute the British side of the bargain and could be extended to all other nations
column5: thus avoiding a clear violation of British unilateralism.

column1: Free Trade With or Without You
The unilateral free trade program is very simple: the British Parliament declares the abolition of all tariffs. To avoid a race in non-tariff barriers
column2: the Parliament can pass a law declaring that every product which conforms to the EU norms and regulations can be sold freely in the UK. This should not be a problem since the UK still is a member of the EU. By Parliament‚Äôs act
column3: most of the ‚Äúnon-tariff barrier‚Äù problem withers away without any need for regulatory harmonization. If the EU legislator considers it necessary to regulate the curvature of vegetables
column4: so be it! But
column5: although EU producers will be free to sell their product in the UK
column6: the British legislator may deem it unnecessary to regulate its producers in the same absurd way.

column1: The advantages of this approach are many. First
column2: the UK can have free trade now instead of waiting through years of negotiations. No need to wait for bureaucrats to agree on which laws we burden consumers and producers with.

column1: The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA)
column2: for example
column3: between the EU and Canada contrasts the expediency of unilateralism with endless negotiations. Negotiations about CETA were started in October 2008 and finished in August 2014. But for the treaty to be effective
column4: each EU member State still has to ratify it. Worse
column5: in some European federal member States
column6: the treaty must be agreed upon by the local federated States. This is why Wallonia recently vetoed CETA
column7: thus threatening the work of a six-year-long negotiation. In the case of the UK ‚Äî and whether or not trade treaties are actually advancing free trade ‚Äî the British economy cannot afford to wait that long for free trade.

column1: The second major advantage of unilateralism is the message you send to Brussels. You are signifying to the EU apparatus that ‚Äúwith or without you
column2: we will have free trade!‚Äù At this point
column3: the EU will have no leverage left with the UK. The negotiation of a trade treaty
column4: on the other hand is a hopelessly utopian solution
column5: not only because of the obvious coordination problem between the 28 EU member States
column6: but also because the EU has a vested interest in making sure Brexit fails. Eurocrats
column7: starting from the contestable assumption that the UK has much more to lose than the EU
column8: will try to concoct a deal as bad as possible for their fellow Anglo-Saxon neighbors.

column1: Free Trade First
column2: Negotiations Later

column1: Still
column2: it is possible that after having declared free trade unilaterally
column3: the EU will decide to restrict the access of British corporations to the single market. This is a particularly valid concern in the financial sector were banks and other financial institutions need licenses to operate in the EU member States. The concern with unilateral free trade is that by respecting it
column4: it will remove any leverage the British government has to negotiate a favorable access to other actual and potential commercial partners. Without a treaty
column5: commercial partners
column6: it is thought
column7: will soon erect protectionist barriers.

column1: Unilateral free trade
column2: however
column3: does not mean the UK producers will be bullied without their government being able to respond. First
column4: by declaring unilateral free trade
column5: the maintained strength of commercial links made will make it much easier to negotiate with the EU. To antagonize a good client would be foolish. Let‚Äôs not forget that this past decade
column6: British exports to the EU grew much slower than exports to the rest of the world. At the same time
column7: the UK is a major consumer of EU products and its balance of commerce with the EU was negative by about ¬£62 billion in 2014.

column1: But how can a country committed to unilateralism make sure other countries will not close their markets? Let us first remark that maintaining trade barriers to negotiate later with other nations is a self-defeating strategy. Sir Robert Peel
column2: whom we mentioned earlier
column3: said in 1842 that in the case of wine and brandy he did not reduce the duty
column4: because he hoped that they might employ these duties ‚Äúas instruments of negotiation
column5: with a view of effecting a reduction in the duties imposed by other countries on the produce of our own country.‚Äù Such a strategy was self-defeating. Tariffs in view of a negotiation
column6: by reducing the capacity of foreigners to produce for the British market
column7: were destroying the very interests that wanted free trade. Peel finally admitted
column9: during a debate in the House of Commons
column10: ‚ÄúI am bound to say that it is our interest to buy cheap
column11: whether other countries will buy cheap or no.‚Äù

column1: There certainly is a more efficient policy than maintaining trade barriers or threatening to raise some in order to force trade ‚Äúpartners‚Äù to keep their markets open. Indeed
column2: the British government can make it clear that if the EU unfairly penalizes British interests in some sectors
column3: e.g.
column4: finance
column5: then the British government will work to maintain the competitiveness of the industry in question by aggressively lowering their taxes. Imagine that the EU wants to damage Britain‚Äôs car manufacturers. Then the British government should not be afraid to create a loophole and to lower manufacturers‚Äô corporate taxes ‚Äî even to zero. In an economy which was never as globalized and competitive as today
column6: the UK would have good chances of prevailing over the EU interests.

column1: Perhaps the EU will consider making trading conditions with the UK harder
column2: but they would have way too much to lose if doing so means creating a fiscally ultra-attractive market just next door. In the short run
column3: unilateralism in trade can achieve what multilateralism cannot
column4: a quick and radical liberalization of exchanges. In the long run
column5: unilateralism can achieve what multilateralism cannot
column6: genuine free trade.  ";english;2016-10-29T01:07:07.767+03:00;infowars.com;US;2774.0;Britain Should Embrace Unilateral Free Trade Right Now;0.0;http://hw.infowars.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/UKflag.jpg;0;1;21;0;21;conspiracy

column1: 4996;ae36a033bcf20052b33a5288e1d6b4328decd7a6;0;Allen Mendenhall;2016-10-29T02:08:58.551+03:00;Ideas Make Us Rich;"Image Credits: flickr
The following excerpt is adapted from Mendenhall‚Äôs review of Deirdre McCloskey‚Äôs book Bourgeois Equality; the original review
column2: which appeared in the Quarterly Journal of Austrian Economics
column3: is available here.

column1: If it‚Äôs true that Wayne Booth inspired Deirdre McCloskey‚Äôs interest in the study of rhetoric
column2: then it‚Äôs also true ‚Äî happily
column3: in my view ‚Äî that McCloskey has refused to mimic Booth‚Äôs programmatic
column4: formulaic methods and boorish insistence on prosaic succinctness. Bourgeois Equality is McCloskey‚Äôs third volume in a monumental trilogy that began with The Bourgeois Virtues (2006) and Bourgeois Dignity (2010)
column5: each published by the University of Chicago Press. This latest volume is a Big Book
column6: alike in kind but not in theme to Jacques Barzun‚Äôs From Dawn to Decadence (2000)
column7: Camille Paglia‚Äôs Sexual Personae (1990)
column8: or Herald Berman‚Äôs Law and Revolution (1983) and Law and Revolution II (2006). It‚Äôs meandering and personal
column9: blending scholarship with an essayistic style that recalls Montaigne or Emerson.

column1: McCloskey‚Äôs elastic arguments are shaped by informal narrative and enlivened by her plain and playful voice. At times humorous
column2: rambling
column3: and deliberately erratic
column4: she gives the distinct impression that she‚Äôs simply telling a story
column5: one that happens to validate a thesis. She‚Äôs having fun. Imagine Phillip Lopate articulating economic history. McCloskey is
column6: in this regard
column7: a latter-day Edward Gibbon
column8: adopting a mode and persona that‚Äôs currently unfashionable among mainstream historians
column9: except that she‚Äôs more lighthearted than Gibbon
column10: and unashamedly optimistic.

column1: McCloskey‚Äôs elastic arguments are shaped by informal narrative and enlivened by her plain and playful voice. At times humorous
column2: rambling
column3: and deliberately erratic
column4: she gives the distinct impression that she‚Äôs simply telling a story
column5: one that happens to validate a thesis. She‚Äôs having fun. Imagine Phillip Lopate articulating economic history. McCloskey is
column6: in this regard
column7: a latter-day Edward Gibbon
column8: adopting a mode and persona that‚Äôs currently unfashionable among mainstream historians
column9: except that she‚Äôs more lighthearted than Gibbon
column10: and unashamedly optimistic.

column1: Writing with an air of confidence
column2: McCloskey submits
column3: contra Thomas Piketty
column4: that ideas and ideology ‚Äî not capital accumulation or material resources ‚Äî have caused widespread economic development. Since 1800
column5: worldwide material wealth has increased and proliferated; the quality of life in poor countries has risen ‚Äî even if it remains unequal to that of more prosperous countries ‚Äîand the typical human being now enjoys access to the food
column6: goods
column7: services
column8: medicine
column9: and healthcare that
column10: in earlier centuries
column11: were available to only a select few in the richest parts of the globe. The transition from poverty to wealth was occasioned by shifting rhetoric that reflected an emerging ethical consensus. The rhetorical-ethical change involved people‚Äôs ‚Äúattitudes toward other humans‚Äù (p. xxiii)
column12: namely
column13: the recognition of shared experience and ‚Äúsympathy
column14: ‚Äù as Adam Smith stated in The Theory of Moral Sentiments. Attributing human progress to ideas enables McCloskey to advocate the norms and principles that facilitated economic growth and social improvement (e.g.
column15: class mobility and fluidity) while generating extensive prosperity. Thus
column16: her project is at once scholarly and tendentious: a study of the conditions and principles that
column17: in turn
column18: she promotes.

column1: She argues that commercialism flourished in the eighteenth century under the influence of ideas ‚Äî such as ‚Äúhuman equality of liberty in law and of dignity and esteem‚Äù (p. xxix) ‚Äî that were packaged in memorable rhetoric and aesthetics. ‚ÄúNot matter
column2: mainly
column3: but ideas‚Äù caused the Great Enrichment (p. 643). In other words
column4: ‚Äú[t]he original and sustaining causes of the modern world [‚Ä¶] were ethical
column5: not material
column6: ‚Äù and they included ‚Äúthe new and liberal economic idea of liberty for ordinary people and the new and democratic social idea of dignity for them‚Äù (p. xxxi). This thesis about liberty and dignity is clear and unmistakable if only because it is repetitive. McCloskey has a habit of reminding readers‚Äîin case you missed her point the first
column7: second
column8: or fifty-seventh time around‚Äîthat the causes of the Industrial Revolution and the Great Enrichment were ideas
column9: not ‚Äúnarrowly economic or political or legal changes‚Äù (p. 470). She maintains
column10: to this end
column11: that the Scottish Enlightenment succeeded in combining the concepts of liberty and dignity into a desirable form of equality‚Äînot equality of outcomes
column12: of course
column13: but of opportunity and treatment under the law. And the Scottish model
column14: to her mind
column15: stands in contradistinction to the French example of centralized
column16: top-down codification
column17: command
column18: planning
column19: and design.

column1: A perennial villain lurks in the pages of her history: the ‚Äúclerisy
column2: ‚Äù which is an ‚Äúappendage of the bourgeoisie‚Äù (p. 597) and often dubbed ‚Äúthe elite‚Äù in regular parlance. McCloskey calls the clerisy ‚Äúthe sons of bourgeois fathers‚Äù (p. xvii) and ‚Äúneo-aristocratic‚Äù (p. 440). The clerisy includes those ‚Äúartists
column3: intellectuals
column4: journalists
column5: professionals
column6: and bureaucrats‚Äù who resent ‚Äúthe commercial and bettering bourgeoisie‚Äù (p. xvi). The clerisy seeks
column7: in different ways at different times
column8: to extinguish unfettered competition with exclusive
column9: illiberal
column10: irrevocable grants and privileges that are odious to free society and offensive to the rights of average consumers. ‚ÄúEarly on
column11: ‚Äù says McCloskey
column12: referring to the period in Europe after the revolutionary year 1848
column13: ‚Äúthe clerisy began to declare that ordinary people are misled in trading
column14: and so require expert protection and supervision‚Äù (p. 609). The clerisy since then has been characterized by paternalism and a sense of superiority.

column1: Because the clerisy is shape-shifting
column2: assuming various forms from time to time and place to place
column3: it‚Äôs a tough concept to pin down. The word ‚Äúclerisy‚Äù does not appear in the book‚Äôs index to permit further scrutiny. By contrast
column4: McCloskey‚Äôs general arguments are easy to follow because the book is separated into parts with questions as their titles; subparts consisting of onesentence headings answer those questions.

column1: In a massive tour de force such as this
column2: readers are bound to take issue with certain interpretive claims. Historians will find McCloskey‚Äôs summaries to be too breezy. Even libertarians will accuse her of overlooking manifest wrongs that occurred during the periods she surveys. My complaints are few but severe. For instance
column3: McCloskey is
column4: I believe
column5: either careless or mistaken to announce that
column6: during the nineteenth and early twentieth century
column7: ‚Äúunder the influence of a version of science
column8: ‚Äù in a territory that‚Äôs never specifically identified
column9: ‚Äúthe right seized upon social Darwinism and eugenics to devalue the liberty and dignity of ordinary people
column10: and to elevate the nation‚Äôs mission above the mere individual person
column11: recommending
column12: for example
column13: colonialism and compulsory sterilization and the cleansing power of war‚Äù (p. xviii).

column1: Let‚Äôs hope that it‚Äôs innocent negligence rather than willful distortion that underlies this odd
column2: unqualified
column3: categorical assertion. Adam Cohen‚Äôs Imbeciles (2016) and Thomas C. Leonard‚Äôs Illiberal Reformers (2016) describe how
column4: in the United States
column5: social Darwinism and eugenics were adopted primarily
column6: though not exclusively
column7: by the Left
column8: not the Right. These recent books come on the heels of several scholarly treatments of this subject: Thomas M. Shapiro‚Äôs Population Control Politics (1985)
column9: Philip R. Reilly‚Äôs The Surgical Solution (1991)
column10: Joel Braslow‚Äôs Mental Ills and Bodily Cures (1997)
column11: Wendy Kline‚Äôs Building a Better Race (2001)
column12: Stefan Kuhl‚Äôs The Nazi Connection (2002)
column13: Nancy Ordover‚Äôs American Eugenics (2003)
column14: Christine Rosen‚Äôs Preaching Eugenics (2004)

column18: and Alexander Minna Stern‚Äôs Eugenic Nation (2016). These represent only a small sampling.

column9: Lester Ward

column1: Other undefined terms only make matters worse

column4: as a class

She throws around the term ‚ÄúRomanticism‚Äù as if its referent were eminently clear and uncontested: ‚Äúa conservative and Romantic vision‚Äù (p. xviii); ‚Äúscience fiction and horror fiction [are] ‚Ä¶ offshoots of Romanticism‚Äù (p. 30); ‚Äú[Jane Austen] is not a Romantic novelist ‚Ä¶ [because] [s]he does not take Art as a model for life
column6: and does not elevate the Artist to a lonely pinnacle of heroism
column7: or worship of the Middle Ages

column11: Sir Walter Scott
column12: and later Romantics‚Äù (p. 170); ‚ÄúRomanticism around 1800 revived talk of hope and faith and a love for Art or Nature or the Revolution as a necessary transcendent in people‚Äôs lives‚Äù (p. 171); ‚ÄúRomantic candor‚Äù (p. 242); ‚Äúthe late eighteenth-century Romantic literary critics in England had no idea what John Milton was on about [sic]
column13: because they had set aside the rigorously Calvinist theology that structured his poetry‚Äù (p. 334); ‚Äúthe nationalist tradition of Romantic writing of history‚Äù (p. 353); ‚ÄúRomantic ‚Ä¶ hostilities to ‚Ä¶ democratic rhetoric‚Äù (p. 510); ‚Äú[i]n the eighteenth century ‚Ä¶ the idea of autonomy triumphed
column14: at any rate among the progressive clerisy
column15: and then became a leading Romantic idea

column1: To allege that the clerisy was ‚Äúthrilled by the Romantic radicalism of books like Mein Kampf or What Is to Be Done‚Äù (p. xviii) is also recklessly to associate the philosophies of
column2: say
column3: Keats or Coleridge or Wordsworth with the exterminatory fantasies of Hitler and Lenin. McCloskey might have guarded against this misleading conflation by distinguishing German idealism or contextualizing Hegel or by being more vigilant with diction and definition. Her loose language will leave some experts (I do not profess to be one) scratching or shaking their heads and
column4: more problematic
column5: some non-experts with misconceptions and misplaced targets of enmity. One imagines the overeager and well-meaning undergraduate
column6: having read Bourgeois Equality

column8: about whom Paul Cantor has written judiciously.2 Wouldn‚Äôt originality
column9: imagination

column11: and individualism‚Äîwidely accepted markers of Romanticism‚Äîappeal to McCloskey? Yet her unconditionally derogatory treatment of Romanticism‚Äîwhich she portrays as a fixed
column12: monolithic

column14: period

column17: and attitude that are
column18: or seem to be

column1: But I protest too much. These complaints should not diminish what McCloskey has accomplished. Would that we had more grand studies that mapped ideas and traced influences across cultures
column2: communities
column3: and eras. McCloskey takes the long view
column4: as we all should. Her focus on rhetoric is crucial to the future of liberty if
column5: given the technological advances we have made
column6: the ‚Äúwork we do will be more and more about decisions and persuading others to agree
column7: changing minds
column8: and less and less about implementation by hand‚Äù (p. 498). Equally significant is her embrace of humanomics‚Äîdefined as ‚Äúthe story [of] a complete human being
column9: with her ethics and language and upbringing‚Äù (p. xx)‚Äîwhich materializes in casual references to Henrik Ibsen‚Äôs plays
column10: challenges to the depiction of John Milton ‚Äúas a lonely poet in a garret writing merely to the starry heavens‚Äù (p. 393)
column11: analyses of Jane Austen‚Äôs novels
column12: and portrayals of Elizabethan England. Her historical and narrative arc enables us to contextualize our own moment
column13: with all of its troubles and possibilities.

column1: Best of all
column2: her book is inspiring and exhilarating and brimming with rousing imperatives and moving calls to action. ‚ÄúLet us
column3: then
column4: ‚Äù she says at one point
column5: ‚Äúnot reject the blessings of economic growth on account of planning or pessimism
column6: the busybody if wellintentioned rationalism of some voices of the French Enlightenment or the adolescent if charming doubts of some voices of the German Romantic movement
column7: fashionable though both attitudes have long been among the clerisy. As rational optimists
column8: let us celebrate the Great Enrichment
column9: and the rhetorical changes in freer societies that caused it‚Äù (p. 146). At another point she encourages her audience to guard against ‚Äúboth cynicism and utopianism‚Äù (p. 540)
column10: and elsewhere to heed ‚Äútrade-tested cooperation

column12: and conservation in the right mix‚Äù (p. 523). These little nudges lend her credibility insofar as they reveal her true colors
column13: as it were
column14: and demonstrate that she is not attempting‚Äîas is the academic wont‚Äîto hide her prejudices and conceal her beliefs behind pretended objectivities.

column1: Poverty is relative and
column2: hence
column3: permanent and ineradicable
column4: despite McCloskey‚Äôs claim that we can ‚Äúend poverty‚Äù (p. 8). If
column5: tomorrow
column6: we woke up and the wealth of each living person were magically to multiply twentyfold‚Äîeven fiftyfold‚Äîthere would still be people at the bottom. The quality of life at the bottom
column7: however
column8: would be vastly improved. The current manifestation of global poverty shows how far we as a species have advanced in the last few centuries. McCloskey is right: We should pursue the ideas that accelerated and achieved human flourishing
column9: that demonstrably brought people out of distress and destitution. Hard sciences and mathematical models are insufficient in themselves to convey the magnitude and splendor of these ideas and their accomplishments. Hence we should welcome and produce more books like McCloskey‚Äôs that undertake a ‚Äúrhetorical-ethical Revaluation‚Äù to both examine and celebrate ‚Äúa society of open inquiry
column10: ‚Äù one which not only ‚Äúdepends on rhetoric in its politics and in its science and in its economy
column11: ‚Äù but which also yields intellectual creativity and political freedom (p. 650). In McCloskey‚Äôs approach
column12: economics and the humanities are not mutually exclusive; rather
column13: they are mutually illuminating and
column14: in fact
column15: indispensably and inextricably tied. An economics that forsakes the dignity of the human person and his capacity for creativity and aesthetics does so at its own peril and to its own disgrace. All economics is
column16: at its core
column17: humanomics. We could do without the latter term if we understood the former. NEWSLETTER SIGN UP Get the latest breaking news & specials from Alex Jones and the Infowars Crew. column1: 4999;eb9d438af435cbb586bf0c4621b8200c04ee16b3;0;Steve Watson;2016-10-29T13:10:16.575+03:00;3 Competing Theories On Why The FBI Re-opened The Hillary Email Server Investigation;"3 Competing Theories On Why The FBI Re-opened The Hillary Email Server Investigation The FBI normally avoids acting just before an election in order to avoid charges of political manipulation American Thinker

There is no question that re-opening the FBI Investigation into Hillary Clinton‚Äôs email server is a big deal. The FBI normally avoids acting just before an election in order to avoid charges of political manipulation. NBC reports:
The FBI is reviewing a new batch of Hillary Clinton emails
column2: bureau director James Comey said in a letter to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Friday.

column1: ‚ÄúIn connection with an unrelated case
column2: the FBI has learned of the existence of emails that appear to be pertinent to the investigation ‚Ä¶ I agreed that the FBI should take appropriate investigative steps designed to allow investigators to review these emails to determine whether they contain classified information
column3: as well as to assess their importance to our investigation
column4: ‚Äù he wrote.

column1: The very first thing to note is that Comey made no mention of a grand jury. The emails whose existence he learned of may have been the result of a subpoena in another investigation. If that is the case
column2: further subpoenas are quite possible
column3: a tool that was left unused in the investigation to date.

column1: There are 3 competing theories as to why he might be doing this now that come to mind. He might be seeking to restore his badly damaged reputation
column2: recognizing that the damage he has inflicted on the FBI is substantial. Three days ago
column3: American Thinker published an open letter from a retired FBI Agent
column4: Hugh Galyean
column5: that laid out some of the damage Comey has inflicted on the institution he leads. There is little doubt that this reached many in the FBI family
column6: putting in print what people have only whispered about. If those silenced voices start speaking out
column7: Comey could face a serious loss of face. In this scenario
column8: he is heading off a staff rebellion
column9: possibly including mass resignations. Rush Limbaugh today discussed an alternative theory
column10: that by announcing an FBI Investigation resuming
column11: Comey is putting a lid on further attention to Wikileaks. I guess this means that Clinton forces will argue we must wait for the investigation to be complete (after the election) before speaking about what the evil Russians are planting into our politics. It is possible that something so dramatic came up in the pertinent emails that postponing a public reaction by not announcing the reopening of the investigation would
column12: be regarded as political interference by covering up a smoking gun until after the election. In this scenario
column13: Comey is assuming the evidence cannot be suppressed
column14: and that he would be held accountable after it comes out. This scenario also indicates that we could be headed for a constitutional crisis
column15: involving the possible indictment of a president-elect before an election. Or the evidence being turned over to the House of Representatives for impeachment hearings.

column1: We‚Äôll know more in the coming days
column2: and I am sure there are other possible theories and motives. It is shame that we have to speculate
column3: and that the once-respected FBI director is now subject to analysis of his political gamesmanship. 6422;4dda50a11aeb0611c20c00f6cd2b8960aeb35eb5;0;Ethan A. Huff
column2: staff writer;2016-10-27T09:09:32.971+03:00;California becomes second state to raise legal smoking age to 21;"California becomes second state to raise legal smoking age to 21

column1: Ethan A. Huff
column2: staff writer Tags: smoking age
column3: California
column4: prohibition (NaturalNews) If you're between the ages of 18 and 21
column5: live in California and are a smoker
column6: expect to be denied your favorite pack at the convenience store. Beginning in June
column7: the new minimum age for officially jumped from 18 to 21
column8: a prohibition move that lawmakers claim will curb the number of smokers in the Golden State
column9: and ultimately help save lives.Joining both Hawaii and the city of Needham in Massachusetts
column10: California is the third locale in the U.S. to raise the legal smoking age to 21. Officials there hope that
column11: like in these other places
column12: age restrictions on smoking will help reduce the number of smokers and minimize the number of individuals who develop smoking-related health conditions like emphysema and lung cancer.Citing statistics from Needham that show a nearly 50 percent reduction in the number of smokers in the five-year period following the change that was made in 2005
column13: April Roeseler
column14: head of the California public health department's Tobacco Control Program
column15: told the Los Angeles Times that she expects similar reductions in her state.In Needham
column16: the number of high schoolers smoking cigarettes fell by nearly half
column17: according to a study published last year. And adult smoking rates in the town also fell from about 18.1 percent to a mere 8 percent ‚Äì statistics that experts say can be replicated all across the country.""If we can push that age up where fewer and fewer people start smoking as a teen
column18: it's likely that we will start to have some tobacco-free generations
column19: the Times quotes her as saying. Prohibition never works; people who want 'contraband' will find a way At this point
column20: though
column21: very little
column22: if any
column23: evidence exists to show that the rule change is working as intended. University of California
column24: San Francisco (UCSF) professor Dr. Stanton Glantz
column25: for instance
column26: admitted to the Times that the policy still needs time to ""settle in."" The California Smokers' Helpline also says it hasn't noticed any increases in the number of callers in the prohibited age range trying to quit
column27: which suggests that not much has changed.There's also the contraband factor ‚Äì older kids still buying cigarettes for younger kids
column28: for example
column29: including those younger than the former threshold age of 18. Illegal buying has always been an issue
column30: law or no law
column31: which is something that the government never really seems to understand when it comes to issues of prohibition .""They're hanging out and partying together
column32: so they'll just get someone else to buy
column33: says Leonard Charles
column34: the owner of a liquor store in Oakland. Charles says he strictly enforces the new cigarette age law
column35: but believes that if somebody wants cigarettes
column36: he or she is going to find a way
column37: regardless of the law.In the internet age
column38: cigarettes are also freely available to anybody with a WiFi connection. People can order cigarettes off the web and have them delivered right to their doorstep
column39: which means that state-level restrictions are basically moot.And what about e-cigarettes? The State of California classifies e-cigs as a ""tobacco product"" just like cigarettes
column40: and they are subject to the same laws. However
column41: everybody has them these days
column42: they're very discreet
column43: and they don't produce that typical tobacco smell that's so hard to get out of a room
column44: so trying to enforce restrictions against their use is next to impossible
column45: say experts familiar with the reality of how easy it is to obtain tobacco
column46: regardless of what the law says.When asked how the new law will realistically work in light of the fact that smoking laws often aren't effective
column47: Glantz responded
column48: ""The short answer is I don't know."" Sources for this article include:";english;2016-10-27T09:09:32.971+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;California becomes second state to raise legal smoking age to 21;0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/Women/Asian-Woman-Tattoos-Smoking-Haircut.jpg;0;1;415;0;415;junksci

column1: 6424;09efc9b916d8588c77a7cb1272521ad0a9b5e2fb;0;Vicki Batts;2016-10-27T11:36:10.703+03:00;Nestle to launch new non-GMO products ... How shocked will Monsanto be?;"Nestle to launch new non-GMO products ... How shocked will Monsanto be?
Thursday
column2: October 27
column3: 2016 by: Vicki Batts Tags: GMOs
column4: Nestle
column5: Monsanto (NaturalNews) One of the food industry's most prominent players recently announced that they will be expanding their line of non-GMO products
column6: due to the ever-increasing customer demand for clean food. Nestle may have wowed consumers with their choice
column7: but it may make some waves with their good friend
column8: Monsanto .""The company is broadening its product offerings to give consumers more options with no GMO ingredients and identifying these products with the SGS-verified 'no GMO ingredients' claim
column9: the food giant stated on Tuesday.""Nestle USA understands that consumers are seeking choice and many prefer to select products with no GMO ingredients
column10: they declared.Of course
column11: this is not Nestle's first move towards GMO-free products. In April
column12: Nestle announced that they would be removing GMO ingredients from six of their top-selling ice cream products
column13: as well. The company states it is trying to evolve along with consumer demands. It is great to see that companies are beginning to realize that consumers want options; no one wants to be forced to buy GMO products.It is easy to want to applaud Nestle for their decision to continue to expand their line of non-GMO products. However
column14: it is also clear that this company is doing so out of their own financial interests ‚Äì not because they care about what people are eating. Organic
column15: GMO-free foods are the newest trend
column16: and smart manufacturers are beginning to see that they will not win anyone over by insisting that GM
column17: pesticide-laden food products are safe. ""If you can't beat 'em
column18: join 'em
column19: is a philosophy Nestle has clearly taken to heart.Nestle is not an angelic company
column20: even if they have decided to start serving up ""GMO-free"" options. Just three years ago
column21: they donated millions of dollars to prevent and oppose GMO labeling in Washington state
column22: along with Monsanto and other biotech firms. Truth Out reports that on October 18
column24: the Grocery Manufacturers of America disclosed that several of their largest
column25: most powerful players silently donated large sums of money to oppose Initiative 522. This bill would have required grocery items containing GMO ingredients to be labeled as such. The group chose to voluntarily release the names of the silent donors
column26: after Washington state Attorney General Bob Ferguson filed a lawsuit against their concealment of corporate donors.Nestle was among the top three highest contributors
column27: and donated a cool $1.5 million to keep GMO ingredients under wraps and off product labels. Nestle also made a large donation to oppose similar legislation in California the year before
column28: in 2012. The bill ultimately failed
column29: after Big Food and Big Biotech joined forces and together raised a staggering $46 million to prevent its passing. And we're supposed to believe they care?The controversial history of Nestle doesn't end with their consistent financial support of GMO labeling opposition efforts. It is a corporation that is wrought with wrongdoings and corrupt practices. Look no further than their outright theft of water in California.Given that the coastal state is currently being plagued by a devastating drought
column30: you might be shocked to learn that just last year Nestle pumped a disturbing 36 million gallons of water out of one of the state's water sources
column31: known as Strawberry Creek. Peter Gleick
column32: president of the Pacific Institute and author of Bottled and Sold: The Story Behind Our Obsession with Bottled Water
column33: estimates that Nestle is making millions of dollars in this way.""They're converting a public resource into private profit
column34: he told Los Angeles Magazine .The most shocking thing is that their permit to pump water from the creek expired in 1988. The forest service has allowed Nestle to gouge the creek for water at will
column35: so long as they continue to pay a minuscule access fee. While bottled water accounts for only a small fraction of California's water use
column36: the overall environmental impact of what their practices are doing to a drought-stricken state have yet to be examined.Nestle has been subject to countless other controversies
column37: including human rights violations
column38: and has been host to many environmental and product safety issues.To put it simply: Nestle may be trying to win over customers with their non-GMO products
column39: but they don't deserve to. Monsanto may be shocked
column40: but only because Nestle is still one of their own. Sources:";english;2016-10-27T11:36:10.703+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Nestle to launch new non-GMO products ... column5: criminal journalism (NaturalNews) Are North Dakota authorities waging a war against the public's right to know about the ongoing Standing Rock pipeline protests? We are joined by documentary filmmaker Deia Schlosberg
column6: who was charged earlier this month with three felonies for filming an act of civil disobedience in which climate activists manually turned off the safety valves to stop the flow of tar sands oil through pipelines spanning the U.S. and Canada.The actions took place in Minnesota

column10: North Dakota. She was arrested along with the activists
column11: and her footage was confiscated. Then she was charged with a Class A felony and two Class C felonies‚Äîwhich combined carry a 45-year maximum sentence.(Article republished from DemocracyNow.org ) TRANSCRIPT AMY GOODMAN: But we're joined right now in Los Angeles by Democracy Now! video stream by Deia Schlosberg

column13: producer

column35: outside of Walhalla
column36: as you said. I was‚ÄîI was filming the action. I was on public land. I was on a public road and at no point trespassed
column37: at no point
column38: you know
column39: broke in or destroyed any property. I had nothing to do with the planning of the event. I was there to document it. I think it's essential for journalists to‚Äîjournalists and filmmakers to go where the mainstream media is not. And there's a major hole in the coverage of climate change and people that are already dealing with the consequences of climate change and people that are fighting climate change. So
column40: I take that responsibility very seriously. AMY GOODMAN: So when did the police come? DEIA SCHLOSBERG: The police came after‚Äîwell

column42: Michael
column43: had called the company ahead of time to say that he was‚Äîhe was going to shut off the valve
column44: so they could‚Äîto give them ample time to take any emergency precautions. And then he turned the valve. And meanwhile
column45: the company notified the local police. So
column46: after the valve was closed
column47: they came in probably about 15 minutes. I had my camera set up on a tripod on the public road. And they told me I was arrested for being an accessory to a crime
column48: at which point I was brought to the local jail . I figured it would‚Äîthings would just have to clear up once they realized what was‚Äî AMY GOODMAN: So
column49: they charged you with three felonies? DEIA SCHLOSBERG: ‚Äîthat I was just
column50: you know
column51: exercising my First Amendment‚Äî AMY GOODMAN: What were the felonies? DEIA SCHLOSBERG: Conspiracy‚Äîthey were all conspiracy charges: conspiracy to theft of public‚Äîtheft of property
column52: conspiracy to theft of service and conspiracy of interfering with a public‚Äîa critical public infrastructure. AMY GOODMAN: And you face 45 years in jail? What is your comment on this? DEIA SCHLOSBERG: What is my what? Sorry
column53: the connection is‚Äî AMY GOODMAN: What do say about this? DEIA SCHLOSBERG: It's absolutely outrageous. Yeah
column55: this is what I‚Äîthis is what I do for my living. This is what I've done for years and years. There's absolutely no grounds for these charges.Read more at: DemocracyNow.org";english;2016-10-27T11:36:11.079+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Meet the journalist facing 45 years in jail for filming the tar sands pipeline protest in North Dakota;0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/VideoClips/Pipeline-Protest-Dog-Handlers.jpg;0;1;18;0;18;junksci

column1: 6427;dffbdb5829b54396cc372e28b788f4c59e8923d7;0;David Gutierrez
column2: staff writer;2016-10-27T11:36:20.197+03:00;Tasmanian Devil Milk is capable of killing the most deadly superbugs;"Tasmanian Devil Milk is capable of killing the most deadly superbugs

column1: Thursday
column2: October 27
column3: 2016 by: David Gutierrez
column4: staff writer Tags: superbugs
column5: drug resistance
column6: Tasmanian Devils (NaturalNews) Milk from Tasmanian devils and other marsupials may be a natural cure for antibiotic-resistant infections
column7: suggests a study conducted by researchers from the University of Sydney and published in the journal Scientific Reports. The researchers found that the milk contains no fewer than six compounds capable of killing some of the world's worst superbugs .Unlike placental mammals (including humans)
column8: which gestate their young within the mother's body
column9: marsupials give birth after just a few weeks to highly immature offspring -- mobile fetuses
column10: essentially -- that still need to complete significant development in their mother's pouch.In particular
column11: the immune systems of newborn marsupials are highly underdeveloped. Because a marsupial's pouch is a significantly less controlled environment than a placental mammal's uterus
column12: researchers wondered if newborn marsupials might need -- and get -- an extra immune boost. Six times as potent as human milk? A previous study
column13: conducted in 2015
column14: cataloged many of the microbes that naturally make up the microbiome of the Tasmanian devil's pouch. These included several disease-causing organisms.""There are potential pathogens present in the devil microbiome
column15: so the fact that the under-developed young in the pouch don't get sick was a clue something interesting was going on
column16: co-author Emma Peel said. ""That's what inspired our most recent study.""For the new study
column17: the researchers analyzed the Tasmanian devil's genome for genes coding for antimicrobial peptides called cathelicidins. They found that Tasmanian devil milk contains six different types of cathelicidin.For comparison
column18: human milk
column19: with all its antimicrobial and immune-boosting properties
column20: contains just a single cathelicidin.The researchers artificially synthesized the peptides
column21: then tested them against several known superbugs
column22: including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Enterococci. The peptides killed every type of microbe they were tested against. Although the researchers had expected to find some antimicrobial effect
column23: the potency of the peptides surprised them.""We showed that these devil peptides kill multi-drug resistant bacteria
column24: Peel said
column25: ""which is really cool.""Many marsupials have even more cathelicidins in their milk than Tasmanian devils. Wallabies have eight
column26: for instance
column27: while opossums (a Western hemisphere species) have 12.Preliminary results have also shown that similar antimicrobial peptides are found in koala milk. The global threat of superbugs Although MRSA has gotten most of the media attention
column28: other superbugs such as Enterococci can also be highly dangerous. These bacteria -- which
column29: like MRSA
column30: often naturally occur on or in the human body -- can cause infections at several different sites. While such infections are minor if treated
column31: Enterococci are growing increasingly antibiotic resistant.Health experts were alarmed recently when more strains of Enterococcus started turning up resistant to the antibiotic vancomycin.""Vancomycin is a pretty potent antibiotic and if a bug is resistant to that
column32: then there aren't a lot of drug options available to you
column33: Peel said.Margaret Chan
column34: director-general of the World Health Organization
column35: recently called antibiotic resistance ""a fundamental threat to human health
column36: development and security"".And the United Kingdom's Review on Antimicrobial Resistance recently concluded that unless urgent action is taken to stem the spread of drug resistance
column37: superbugs will kill 10 million people annually by 2050. That's more than the combined death toll of cancer and diabetes.Shockingly
column38: that review estimated deaths from only six varieties of superbug: Klebsiella pneumoniae
column39: E. coli
column40: MRSA
column41: HIV
column42: TB and malaria.Researchers estimate that today
column43: superbugs kill ""only"" 700
column44: 000 people a year. The number is expected to rise so dramatically due to the spread of drug-resistance genes through microbial populations
column45: combined with the ongoing evolution of resistance to new drugs.The Review on Antimicrobial Resistance also failed to estimate the deaths that would come from people being unable to gain medical care
column46: such as surgery or cancer treatment
column47: that would be lethal without the use of reliable antibiotics. Sources for this article include:";english;2016-10-27T11:36:20.197+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Tasmanian Devil Milk is capable of killing the most deadly superbugs;0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/Medical/Superbug-Virus-Sick-Hospital.jpg;0;1;253;0;253;junksci

column1: 6428;6a92fae115c08e68dc79b3d6f243f1b585d47490;0;Vicki Batts;2016-10-27T11:36:23.054+03:00;Top doctors: Chemotherapy one of dozens of procedures shown to 'give no benefit';"Top doctors: Chemotherapy one of dozens of procedures shown to 'give no benefit'
Thursday
column2: October 27
column3: 2016 by: Vicki Batts Tags: cancer
column4: chemotherapy
column5: ineffective medicine (NaturalNews) Chemotherapy is arguably one of the medical industry's biggest frauds . Perhaps that's why it recently landed on a list of ineffectual treatments drawn up by the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges (AMRC).The list was created by 11 top specialists
column6: who were each asked to think of five treatments they felt provided little to no patient benefits. And surprise
column7: surprise ‚Äì chemotherapy was one of them. Doctors from the AMRC said that chemotherapy cannot cure terminal cancer
column8: and may bring unneeded distress in the final months of life. The Guardian reported:""The treatment is 'by its very nature toxic'
column9: the college said. ""Therefore
column10: the combination of failing to achieve a response and causing toxicity can 'do more harm than good.'""Do more harm than good? You don't say.Research has shown that in some hospitals
column11: up to 50 percent of cancer patients are dying
column12: not from their disease
column13: but from chemotherapy drugs. For the first time ever
column14: researchers actually looked at the numbers of patients who were dying within 30 days of chemotherapy administration
column15: which could indicate that the treatment was the cause of death rather than the cancer. What they found was horrifying.The study
column16: which was conducted by Public Health England and Cancer Research UK
column17: found that the average 30-day mortality rate across England was about 8.4 percent for lung cancer and 2.5 percent for breast cancer. But
column18: in some hospitals
column19: those numbers were much higher. For example
column20: at Lancashire Teaching Hospitals
column21: the 30 day mortality rate for palliative chemotherapy for lung cancer was 28 percent. In Milton Keynes
column22: the death rate for lung cancer treatment soared up to 50.9 percent.The research revealed that the death rate for lung cancer patients was higher than average in several areas
column23: including Blackpool
column24: Coventry
column25: Derby
column26: South Tyneside
column27: Surrey and Sussex.The data also revealed that about 1-in-5 people who underwent palliative care for breast cancer at Cambridge University Hospitals died because of chemotherapy treatment.Of course
column28: the industry was quick to defend their practices
column29: with doctors suggesting that these occurrences could simply be the outcome of data problems
column30: noting that even a few deaths could skew statistics.However
column31: no one really argued with the fact that chemotherapy is indeed a toxin. It doesn't discriminate; it kills cancerous cells and healthy cells ‚Äì and therein lies the rub. It may kill the cancer
column32: but not without increasing your risks of getting cancer again in the future.A 2004 study also found that cytotoxic chemotherapy does very little towards enhancing cancer survivors' 5-year survival rates. The research
column33: which was led by scientists from the Department of Radiation Oncology at the Northern Sydney Cancer Centre of the Royal North Shore Hospital
column34: located in Sydney
column35: Australia
column36: raised serious questions about the actual efficacy of curative and adjuvant chemotherapies.What they found was that in Australia chemo only contributed 2.3 percent to the 5-year survival rate in adults
column37: and in the U.S.
column38: that number dropped to 2.1 percent. These findings suggest that overall
column39: chemotherapy truly provides very little benefit to any patient's survival. In their conclusion
column40: the study authors wrote
column41: ""As the 5-year relative survival rate for cancer in Australia is now over 60%
column42: it is clear that cytotoxic chemotherapy only makes a minor contribution to cancer survival. To justify the continued funding and availability of drugs used in cytotoxic chemotherapy
column43: a rigorous evaluation of the cost-effectiveness and impact on quality of life is urgently required.""The AMRC urges doctors and patients to question whether or not particular treatments are necessary. After all
column44: unwarranted and harmful treatments are truly anything but medicine . Sources:";english;2016-10-27T11:36:23.054+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Top doctors: Chemotherapy one of dozens of procedures shown to 'give no benefit';0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/Cancer/Man-Upset-Cry-Cancer-Patient-Chemotherapy.jpg;0;1;33;0;33;junksci

column26: to start fights and engage in physical violence against Trump supporters (acts that the establishment media then blames on Trump ).But aren't electors legally obligated to cast a ballot for the presidential candidate who won the majority vote in that elector's district? No
column27: they're not. Nine-nine percent of electors have done what they're supposed to do throughout our history

column29: there is no constitutional provision or federal law requiring electors to vote according to the results of the popular vote. Rather

column1: 6430;5cdf3cf97480e607be40f5250620ae8912ab9b10;0;Ethan A. Huff
column2: staff writer;2016-10-27T11:36:27.861+03:00;Hospitals raise their prices despite public outcry from over-burdened patients;"Hospitals raise their prices despite public outcry from over-burdened patients

column1: Thursday
column2: October 27
column3: 2016 by: Ethan A. Huff
column4: staff writer Tags: hospital visits
column5: rising prices
column6: healthcare costs (NaturalNews) When word got out last year that a handful of hospitals throughout Florida were massively price-gouging their patients
column7: experts predicted that the outrageous bills for services at these care facilities would quickly drop in response. But the exact opposite occurred
column8: a new investigation has found
column9: with many of these same hospitals not only charging the same ridiculous prices
column10: but in some cases drastically more .Researchers from the University of Miami looked at hospital prices both before and after the media picked up on the issue
column11: evaluating the billing schemes at some 50 of the priciest Florida hospitals to see how they may have changed. They looked at these hospitals' total billing charges in the quarter of a year before news of the gouging first broke headlines
column12: as well as in the quarter post-headlines.In a five-year period spanning from 2010‚Äì2015
column13: Bayfront Health Dade City topped the list of Florida's most expensive hospitals
column14: with price increases nearly doubling. Following were Kendall Regional Medical Center
column15: Heart of Florida Regional Medical Center
column16: North Okaloosa Medical Center and Sebastian River Medical Center.All of these facilities
column17: and many others
column18: despite having their names tarnished for taking advantage of patients
column19: were found to still be charging the same or even higher prices in 2016
column20: the researchers learned. Other than a minor setback of temporarily decreased share prices
column21: these exploitative care facilities are continuing to get away with jacking their prices
column22: and with no end in sight.""We were thinking we would see a drop or lowering of some charges
column23: Karoline Mortensen
column24: co-author of a study published in the Journal of Health Care Finance that looked at hospital prices both before and after the publicity
column25: told The Washington Post (WP) . ""There's nothing stopping them. They're not being held accountable to anyone."" The insurance system is utterly broken

column1: 6432;2a6da42f10efe3efc4771b734b10b97427586e0f;0;Isabelle Z.;2016-10-27T11:36:41.278+03:00;Beware: You could be poisoning yourself by reheating these five foods;"Beware: You could be poisoning yourself by reheating these five foods
Thursday
column2: October 27
column3: 2016 by: Isabelle Z. Tags: reheating
column4: toxic food
column5: foodborne illness (NaturalNews) Nothing beats a home-cooked meal. Not only does food taste better when you prepare it yourself
column6: but it's also a lot healthier. Unfortunately
column7: this can also be very time-consuming depending on the dish in question
column8: and today's hectic lifestyle means that a lot of us can't cook something special from scratch every day. If you don't want your family to have to resort to toxic fast food on your busy days
column9: what can you do?Making enough home-cooked food to last a few days sounds like a great idea on the surface because you can quickly microwave it
column10: but the truth is that reheating certain foods can actually make you and your family quite ill . Here is a look at some of the foods that you need to be really careful about reheating. Rice According to the NHS
column11: eating reheated rice can cause food poisoning. They explain that the reheating itself is not the culprit; it actually has to do with how the rice was stored prior to reheating. Rice can sometimes contain spores of bacteria known as Bacillus cereus
column12: which can cause food poisoning
column13: and these spores can survive cooking. If rice is then left to sit at room temperature
column14: the spores can grow into bacteria
column15: which will multiply and could produce toxins that can cause vomiting and diarrhea.The NHS says that the likelihood of this happening increases with the amount of time the rice sat outside at room temperature. They advise serving rice right away after it has been cooked or else cooling it as quickly as possible ‚Äì within no more than an hour. They also suggest reheating rice to the point where it is steaming
column16: and avoiding storing it in the refrigerator for longer than one day. Potatoes Potatoes that have sat out at room temperature for several hours can not only lose their nutritional value
column17: but they could also create the perfect conditions for botulism to grow. Uneaten potatoes should go directly to the fridge after cooking to help reduce the chances of this occurring. Chicken When you reheat cold chicken
column18: the structure of its proteins is changed
column19: which can cause digestive upset. If you have leftovers you can't bear to toss
column20: reheat them slowly at a lower temperature on the stove or in the oven to help keep the chicken's proteins intact. It must be steaming all the way through before you can serve it
column21: so be sure to stir it every once in a while. Spinach Spinach is best eaten raw
column22: but it's okay to cook it if you plan to eat all of it immediately afterward. However
column23: when cooked spinach is reheated
column24: the nitrates in it break down into nitrites
column25: turning one of the healthiest foods into something that is potentially toxic and can negatively impact the uptake of oxygen in the blood. Eggs It is not a good idea to repeatedly expose eggs to heat. Reheating them after they've been fried or boiled using high temperatures can cause them to become toxic and upset your digestive tract. Moreover
column26: their protein is destroyed when they are repeatedly exposed to heat. According to the FDA
column27: cooked egg dishes should never be left outside of the fridge for more than two hours; this drops to just one hour if the temperature is higher than 90 degrees F. Warm temperatures between 40 and 140 degrees provide the perfect environment for bacteria to grow.While most of us have reheated these foods and have not noticed any adverse effects
column28: it is important to exercise caution if you plan to continue doing so in order to avoid poisoning yourself and your family or causing digestive issues. Tina Hanes of the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline suggests making sure your leftovers reach 165 degrees Fahrenheit when you reheat them
column29: and you should use a food thermometer to verify this. Covering the food helps it retain moisture and boosts its chances of heating all the way through
column30: which is vital for avoiding cooler pockets where bacteria can thrive. Finally
column31: keep in mind that microwaves are particularly risky because they do not heat food evenly. Sources include:";english;2016-10-27T11:36:41.278+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Beware: You could be poisoning yourself by reheating these five foods;0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/Technology/Microwave-Oven-Appliance-Cook.jpg;0;1;891;0;891;junksci

column1: 6435;082b0b5f6a263130fde8edc33a73c5fee8bdf822;0;Maia M;2016-10-27T23:18:00.000+03:00;How Correct Breathing Can Prevent Cancer and Depression?;"Keywords: Body Detox
column2: breath

column4: Breathing Techniques

column1: Breathing ‚Äì a process that goes almost unnoticed and happens on such a deep subconscious level
column2: yet it is vital for our being. Nowadays
column3: there are more and more cases of people breathing incorrectly.

column1: Living in a big city surrounded by constant stress
column2: pollution and technology can sometimes bring the body out of sync with the nature‚Äôs flow. Young children know how to breathe correctly on an intuitive level. Their body follows the rhythm of nature.

column1: With time
column2: as the stress increases and obstacles come into our lives we quickly forget our calm manner of breathing and switch to a frantic one instead
column3: without even realizing it. Cancer Prevention

column2: Dr. Otto Warburg received a Nobel Prize when he proved that cancer cells are anaerobic . This means that they cannot survive in high levels of oxygen. When a body is low on oxygen some cells start to replace it by fermenting sugar. A normal cell gets its energy through a process of respiration of oxygen
column3: whereas a cancer cell does it through fermentation. Cardiovascular Health

column1: Hypertension is all too common
column2: quite often as a result of stress. In order to lower the blood pressure
column3: it‚Äôs important to decrease the stress levels . One of the oldest and most natural ways to do that is through deep
column4: slow breathing. Not only does it calm your heart beat
column5: but it allows the blood to flow at a more even pace.

column1: Research was conducted over a 30 year period that showed how proper breathing can prolong the lifespan
column2: as well as increase general health. The Framingham study found a correlation between the vital capacity
column3: meaning the largest amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after a deep breath

column1: Brain needs oxygen to work

column3: but looking on a smaller scale there is a connection between improper breathing and depression. Long periods of even a slightly limited air supply to the body caused by improper breathing
column4: can lead to a decrease in cognitive functions. Symptoms such brain fog
column5: forgetfulness
column6: lack of concentration and in the end depression are all interconnected. Increased Energy Levels

column1: Have you ever told someone you‚Äôre tired and in return you were told to go for a walk or do a light exercise? This is because the body converts oxygen into energy through a process called cellular respiration . When you inhale the air correctly
column2: more of it gets to your body
column3: thus increasing the energy levels through conversion. It is also one of the reasons why people who exercise on a regular basis are generally more energetic than those with sedentary lifestyles. Different Breathing Techniques

column1: There is a countless number of breathing techniques for different purposes and each one of them has its own benefits. Breathing exercises can lower or raise blood pressure
column2: improve sleep
column3: help with anxiety and much more.

column1: Yoga is one of the practices that incorporates breathing exercises called Pranayama as an essential part of the process. Coming from the East
column2: it‚Äôs uncertain when exactly yoga originated
column3: but there is evidence that it has been around for at least 5
column4: 000 years . Yogic breathing techniques have been applied for thousands of years
column5: making them timeproof. I will share with you a couple of my favorite breathing techniques that I personally use in different situations. Best Body Detoxifier

column1: Kapalbhati is a breathing technique that detoxifies your body
column2: opens up your nasal passages and allows your mind to concentrate. After doing the exercise you will feel a rush of energy that will immediately wake you up.

column1: Instructions: Sit comfortably with a straight spine. Place your left hand on the knee with the palm facing upwards and your right hand on the stomach. Take a deep breath. Quickly exhale. While exhaling
column2: pull the stomach in as if you‚Äôre trying to touch the back and do it to an extent that feels comfortable. However
column3: do not apply strength or pressure beyond the level of comfort. 20 repetitions per set. Come back to normal breathing after each set and observe your body‚Äôs sensations. It‚Äôs advised to do 100-200 repetitions daily. Sleeping and Stress Reducing Technique

column1: It‚Äôs a simple slow breathing 4-7-8 exercise that helps you fall asleep faster or calm down during an anxiety attack. All you have to do is: Fully exhale through your mouth with a sound whoosh With a closed mouth
column2: slowly inhale with your nose on a count of four Hold your breath for seven seconds Exhale fully through your mouth on a count of eight
column3: making a whoosh sound Repeat until you feel sleepy or calm";english;2016-10-28T01:28:08.396+03:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;How Correct Breathing Can Prevent Cancer and Depression?;0.0;http://10667-presscdn-0-56.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Woman-Free-Freedom-Happy.jpg;0;1;8;0;8;junksci

column1: After a Gallop poll was done

6439;3d74fd888a84df7f1abeb71f4d66bb8e61df3345;0;Andy Green;2016-10-27T23:05:00.000+03:00;The Sugar Industry: Funding Research to Sugarcoat the Truth;"Keywords: Cardiovascular
column2: diabetes
column3: dietary fat
column4: heart disease
column5: sugar
column6: sugar industry

column1: Sugar ‚Äúdoes not have a unique role in heart disease.‚Äù When it comes to dietary claims made by the sugar industry
column2: we need to take them with a grain of salt.

column1: Researchers at the University of California
column2: San Francisco have uncovered documents and communications dating back as far as the 1960s
column3: revealing that the SRF (Sugar Research Foundation
column4: now known as the Sugar Association) funded research to serve its own interest: to create a sweet image of sugar.

column1: At the time
column2: heart disease was on the rise as was the consumption of dietary fat and sugar. Instead of trying to determine the true cause for the higher occurrence of the disease
column3: the biased research focused everyone‚Äôs attention on fat.

column1: UCSF‚Äôs finding
column2: published in JAMA Internal Medicine
column3: shows researchers at leading universities
column4: including Harvard
column5: were paid by the SRF in an effort to portray dietary fat as the major cause of heart disease. In the process
column6: sugar‚Äôs role in the fatal disease has been ignored. Singing the Praises of Low-Fat Foods

column1: As a result of the biased research published in many esteemed publications
column2: life in the second half of the 20th century was filled with misleading dietary recommendations and scary headlines.

column1: Warnings regarding the dangers of dietary fat ran rampant. Eating fat
column2: especially the saturated variety
column3: was equivalent to clogging your arteries. Even eating an egg
column4: containing 5 grams of the forbidden macro-nutrient
column5: was considered a luxury not to be indulged in more than once per week.

column1: Low-fat diets became the craze. In fact
column2: ‚Äúlow-fat‚Äù labels decorated food packaging throughout groceries stores
column3: from yoghurt aisles to frozen sections. Consumers felt good whenever they chose low-fat varieties over standard options.

column1: Yet this sense of well-being generated by the low-fat fad was unfounded. To add flavour to low-fat foods
column2: sugar was the usual substitute. And the truth that has been uncovered is that sugar is a secret killer. It contributes not only to obesity and diabetes
column3: but also to the leading cause of death worldwide: cardiovascular disease (CVD). A Time for Change

column1: Recently the sugar industry‚Äôs funded research has been challenged by unbiased studies which reveal sugar to possess the unwelcome property previously
column2: and falsely
column3: attributed to fat: it leads to atherosclerosis.

column1: JAMA Internal Medicine has published a study by a team of UCSF researchers showing that sugar
column2: aside from causing diabetes and tooth decay
column3: sets into motion several changes that bring on heart disease. In this study
column4: the diets of 43 children were changed to replace added sugar with starch while maintaining the same amounts of protein
column5: fat
column6: complex carbohydrates
column7: and total caloric intake. The results showed beneficial effects on LDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels as well as diastolic blood pressure.

column1: Another study
column2: undertaken by researchers from Saint Luke‚Äôs Mid America Heart Institute and Albert Einstein College of Medicine and published in Progress in Cardiovascular Diseases
column3: showed that consuming diets high in added sugar caused an increase in LDL (bad) cholesterol
column4: total cholesterol
column5: and triglycerides while lowering HDL (good) cholesterol.

column1: The new research results have brought about a change in worldwide dietary guidelines. From governmental associations to medical organisations and private practitioners are warning consumers and patients about sugar‚Äôs toxicity.

The U.S. Dietary Guidelines for 2015 to 2020 recommend that added sugars make up less than 10 percent of a person‚Äôs daily calorie consumption. While the main reason for this recommendation is that added sugar constitutes empty calories and leads to a nutrient-deficient diet
column2: the Guidelines also acknowledge that there is ‚Äústrong evidence‚Ä¶lower intake of sources of added sugars are associated with reduced risk of CVD in adults.‚Äù

column1: The American Heart Association warns that ‚Äútoo much added sugar in your diet could significantly increase your risk of dying from cardiovascular disease.‚Äù It recommends lowering dietary sugar intake even further to a maximum of 6 teaspoons and 9 teaspoons for women and men
column2: respectively. How Can Something Sweet Be So Bad?

column1: According to one cardiologist
column2: Dr Stephen Sinatra
column3: sugar delivers its damage to the cardiovascular system via a surge in insulin. High levels of insulin wreak havoc on blood vessels‚Äô endothelial linings. An inflammatory response ensues
column4: causing the walls of the blood vessels to become clogged. In this way
column5: the stage is set for heart disease.

column1: Add to that the well-known fact that sugar leads to diabetes
column2: which raises the risk of heart disease
column3: and the overall danger is compounded. Addictive Properties Exacerbate the Problem

column1: It seems that the sugar industry pushed us toward a secret killer just like the tobacco industry did. This notion seems even more valid in light of medical claims that sugar
column2: like nicotine
column3: is an addictive substance.

column1: In medical circles
column2: addiction is an altered state of the brain which causes repetitive behaviour despite negative consequences. Experts state that studies on rats prove sugar to be more addictive than cocaine.

column1: When our bodies digest sugar
column2: they release dopamine and opioids. These neurotransmitters play a key role in the brain‚Äôs reward centre
column3: which in turn causes addiction to the same substance that set off too much activity in this pleasure circuit. So What Do We Do Now?

column1: We need to gather public funding to carry out unbiased research on consumer goods
column2: including foods.

column1: Food labels should allow consumers to identify easily how much added sugar is present in every food item.
Every processed food item should not be allowed to contain more than 10 percent of its total calories from added sugars.
Widespread education regarding sugar‚Äôs toxicity should reach from the classroom to our doctors‚Äô offices.
Everyone deserves the chance to break the cycle of sugar addiction.
