But malnutrition during the ""great economic recovery"" of the Obama years is rising at an alarming rate in the U.S. That's because in real terms
column21: workers' wages are falling

column2: staff writer;2016-11-02T07:13:16.134+02:00;Woman awarded $70M after contracting cancer from Johnson & Johnson talcum powder;"Woman awarded $70M after contracting cancer from Johnson & Johnson talcum powder

column1: Wednesday
column2: November 02
column3: 2016 by: David Gutierrez
column4: staff writer Tags: talc
column5: ovarian cancer
column6: jury award (NaturalNews) Once again
column7: a St. Louis jury has ruled that Johnson & Johnson damaged women's health by engaging in a decades-long coverup about the potential risks of talcum powder (""baby powder"") as a feminine hygiene product. On October 27
column8: Johnson & Johnson was ordered to pay $70.1 million to Deborah Giannecchini of Modesto
column9: California
column10: who received an ovarian cancer diagnosis in 2012.For 40 years
column11: Giannecchini had used Johnson & Johnson's Baby Powder to keep her genital area dry
column12: a use promoted by the company.The main ingredient in talcum powder is talc
column13: a mineral widely used in paints and plastics as well as cosmetics
column14: where it is used to absorb moisture. Some evidence suggests that regular exposure to talc
column15: particularly in the genital area
column16: can increase the risk of ovarian cancer.The jury found Johnson & Johnson guilty of negligence for failing to warn customers of this fact. Conspiracy to conceal risks Ovarian cancer is a rare but highly lethal disease. Well-established risk factors include obesity
column17: not having children
column18: estrogen therapy after menopause
column19: and a family history of ovarian or breast cancer.The evidence linking talc to ovarian cancer is compelling but not yet conclusive. The International Agency for Research on Cancer lists talc as a ""possible"" carcinogen.Among the robust studies suggesting a connection are two meta-analyses that found a roughly one-third increase in ovarian cancer risk among women who were regularly exposed to talc . The first
column20: published in 2003
column21: found the connection in all cases. The second
column22: published in 2013
column23: found it only in women who applied talc directly to the genital area.The case marks the third guilty verdict against Johnson & Johnson over this issue. St. Louis juries have previously slapped the company with $55 million and $72 million judgments.The first case was filed by the family of Jackie Fox of Birmingham
column24: Alabama
column25: who had died of ovarian cancer after long-term use of talcum powder. In that case
column26: the jury found the company guilty not just of negligence
column27: but also of ""failure to warn and conspiracy to conceal the risks of its products.""Another 2
column28: 000 lawsuits are pending. Thirty years of deception Even after the recent verdict
column29: Johnson & Johnson continues to insist on the safety of its product
column30: including for genital use. In its home state of New Jersey
column31: the company has successfully gotten two lawsuits over the issue dismissed. It is appealing all three guilty verdicts from Missouri.Investors seem to believe the company will prevail. Its stock price seemed unaffected by the recent guilty verdict.Alexandra Scranton
column32: director of science and research at Women's Voices for the Earth
column33: has characterized Johnson and Johnson's behavior as typical of Big Pharma and other companies that go to extreme lengths to keep selling products even as evidence mounts of their dangers.Scranton said that documents uncovered during the Fox trial show that for decades
column34: Johnson & Johnson sought to take advantage of the scientific uncertainty over the talc-ovarian cancer link
column35: downplaying the potential risk rather than pursing a ""clearly more ethical role
column36: to take a precautionary approach."" Indeed
column37: Scranton notes
column38: the company ""poured money over years into defending talc.""Among the documents revealed during the Fox case are internal memos showing that Johnson & Johnson had been preparing to be sued over the health risks of talc for 30 years. In one 1997 memo
column39: a medical consultant warned that anyone who continued to deny a connection between ovarian cancer and genital talc use would eventually be seen as on par with tobacco companies denying a cancer link: ""denying the obvious in the face of all evidence to the contrary.""Another memo laid out a strategy to counter falling talc sales caused by health concerns by more aggressive marketing to minority communities. Sources for this article include: http://www.naturalnews.com/053112_Johnson_&_talc_ovarian_cancer.html Health Ranger Approved AquaTru Water Filter Back in Stock

column2: staff writer;2016-11-02T07:13:24.317+02:00;Americans' health deteriorating under Obamacare as life expectancies plunge;"Americans' health deteriorating under Obamacare as life expectancies plunge

column1: Wednesday
column2: November 02
column3: 2016 by: Ethan A. Huff
column4: staff writer Tags: Americans
column5: life expectancy
column6: plummeting health (NaturalNews) For many years
column7: the assumption has been that the United States leads the world as an advanced civilization
column8: dominating in categories like education
column9: quality of life
column10: and life expectancy. But a new study released this year by the Society of Actuaries (SOA) paints a much different picture
column11: suggesting that Americans are less healthy and will more than likely live much shorter lives compared to those in previous generations.The 36-page report reveals that the average 65-year-old American man today will most likely die just short of his 86th birthday
column12: while the average 65-year-old American woman only has about two years longer until she dies
column13: on average
column14: around age 88. This might not sound like anything out of the ordinary
column15: except that these figures are actually down compared to last year's report using the same criteria.Over the past several years
column16: the report explains
column17: American health has taken a major downturn. Life expectancy amongst 65-year-olds is down by about six months
column18: on average. It's also down for younger Americans
column19: who are likewise expected to live about six months less than in previous generations. In nearly every generational category
column20: including ""Baby Boomers
column21: ""Generation X
column22: and ""Millennials
column23: life expectancy is down
column24: and will likely continue to go down.This is especially the case among middle-aged
column25: non-Hispanic whites
column26: who a recent study by Princeton University found are increasingly succumbing to the detrimental effects of bad habits like alcohol and drug abuse
column27: unhealthy diet
column28: and lack of exercise. This report also highlights increasing rates of suicide within younger populations
column29: a sad state of affairs that says even more about the current state of our society.Mortality rates are still rising
column30: the data suggests
column31: but at an increasingly lower rate. And if things continue on the current trajectory
column32: eventually overall life expectancy will be on the downturn ‚Äì that is
column33: unless the factors contributing to this decline are addressed and brought to bear. If they aren't
column34: the average American life will likely continue to decline into the future. Pension payers
column35: insurance companies see dollar signs as people die earlier While the study's findings have many applications in terms of social science research
column36: the one area where they're making the biggest ripples involves employee pensions. By looking at this new life expectancy data through the lens of post-retirement disbursements
column37: employers can determine whether or not their liabilities will increase or decrease ‚Äì and based on the most current data
column38: it appears that a decrease is on the way.""The updated scale provides the latest information to help accurately measure pension obligations
column39: says Dale Hall
column40: managing director of research at the SOA. ""However
column41: it is up to pension plan sponsors
column42: working with their plan actuaries
column43: to determine how to incorporate emerging mortality improvement data into their plan valuations.""With the growing popularity of 401k accounts as opposed to pensions
column44: the new data can also help employees who handle their own retirement affairs better ascertain how much they need to make
column45: and how much they need to save
column46: to live comfortably until their deaths. All of this information makes a difference when determining the price of annuities and insurance contracts whereby insurance companies are obligated to pay out until the time a person dies.Year-over-year changes in mortality are very volatile
column47: Hall adds
column48: noting that something as simple as a bad flu season can disrupt the death rate averages.At the same time
column49: some experts claim that longevity rates in the long-term are still on an upward trajectory
column50: and that soon-to-be retirees and younger folks alike need to take into account the fact that they could live much longer than the latest figures suggest
column51: and to plan accordingly. Sources:";english;2016-11-02T07:13:24.317+02:00;naturalnews.com;US;6416.0;Americans' health deteriorating under Obamacare as life expectancies plunge;0.0;http://www.naturalnews.com/gallery/640/Seniors/Senior-Couple-Love-Sunlight-Beach-Picnic.jpg;0;1;311;0;311;junksci

column40: the patent says. ""In addition to being largely ineffective and difficult and costly to apply

column43: he wrote

column1: 7196;3346885f1c3226312c3e92e5a59bee8d3bcfa967;0;Rmuse;2016-10-27T17:45:32.062+03:00;The Media Ignores the Good News On Climate Change;"By Rmuse on Thu
column2: Oct 27th
column3: 2016 at 10:36 am To avoid climate-ending global temperature rise
column4: it is critical for the world to transition off fossil fuels and embrace renewable
column5: clean energy sources. Share on Twitter Print This Post *The following is an opinion column by R Muse*

column1: Over the past few months
column2: there has been a dearth of good news
column3: and if there did happen to be anything good to report it was overshadowed by the national clown show that is a typical American election. Where there has not been one iota of good news is on climate change. Even dismissing the horrible flooding
column4: wildfires
column5: droughts
column6: sea level rise
column7: melting ice caps
column8: hurricanes and worldwide food shortages
column9: there have only been dire reports on the level of CO2 permeating the atmosphere and the subsequent yearly record-setting rise in global temperatures.

column1: This week
column2: while most Americans were living
column3: breathing and bleeding over Donald Trump and the tortuously-long presidential campaign
column4: the International Energy Agency offered up some good news; for the climate
column5: the Earth‚Äôs population
column6: and even for America.

column1: The good news for the planet came in the form of an announcement on Tuesday by the International Energy Agency (IEA) that stated according to new data
column2: for the first time ‚ÄúRenewable energy sources have passed coal as the largest new source of electricity in the world.‚Äù

column1: It may not seem like such fantastic news
column2: but climate scientists the world over have warned that if human beings are going to avoid that climate-ending 2-degree C rise in global temperatures
column3: it is critical for the world to transition off of carbon-producing fossil fuels and embrace renewable
column4: clean energy generating sources. This is particularly true for getting off dirty coal-fired electrical generation plants that are responsible for a quarter of America‚Äôs C02 emissions. Carbon dioxide emissions are one of the main culprits contributing to climate change driven by global warming.

column1: The IEA report revealed that solar and wind account for nearly two-thirds of current renewable energy growth and interestingly those increases are occurring in
column2: and coming from
column3: developing and industrialized nations alike. For a developing nation
column4: it makes perfect sense to embrace cheaper renewable energy as opposed to any fossil fuel-generated power sources whether they are dirty coal-fired plants or not-quite-as-dirty natural gas-burning generating plants.

column1: The IEA also revised its earlier projections for renewable energy‚Äôs continued expansion and growth and ‚Äú significantly increased‚Äù the amount of ‚Äú green energy ‚Äù it expects to ‚Äú come on line ‚Äù over the next five years. Renewable energy includes so-called ‚Äúgreen‚Äù sources such as biomass
column2: biogas
column3: eligible biomass and small hydroelectric sources
column4: according to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Both terms
column5: ‚Äúrenewable and green energy
column6: ‚Äù include solar and wind generating sources and depending on the context they can be interchangeable.

column1: In addition to pro-renewable policies (such as the Paris climate agreement and to a lesser extent the America-China deal to roll back coal-generated emissions
column2: there has been a significant price decline that is helping drive the growth in renewables; particularly in solar. And
column3: the IEA projected that the worldwide costs for solar-generated power will continue declining by an additional 25 percent over the next five years. Onshore wind generated electricity costs will drop by at least another 15 percent during that same five-year period.

column1: Although the IEA report was incredibly good news for the entire planet
column2: there was some extra good news in the report about America‚Äôs transition to renewable energy. According to the IEA‚Äôs Medium-Term Renewable Market Report
column3: the United States is adding renewables at a faster rate than demand is growing. What that means for the climate is that renewables are not only covering the ever-increasing demand for electricity but are now supplanting some fossil fuel electricity. Still
column4: America has a long way to go because wind and solar generating sources make up a small portion of America‚Äôs electricity.

column1: In time and if the Koch brothers allow it
column2: America may catch up to still-developing nations where renewable energy accounts for about half of new electric power sources. Industrialization is fueling a rapid increase in demand for electricity that is best generated with cheaper renewable energy.

column1: Although there appears to be no down-side in this bit of good news
column2: the growth of renewable energy does have economic implications. The dirty coal industry is facing some struggles‚Ääin part due to the glut of oil and lower national gas prices
column3: financial mismanagement
column4: and new clean-air regulations
column5: but the amount of CO2 driving climate change is a testament that they have had a good long reign in providing dirty fuel to generate electricity. It is noteworthy that as coal jobs may be declining the solar industry is growing and thriving to more than take up the slack in any lost coal jobs.

column1: The IEA couldn‚Äôt pass up the chance to note one ‚Äústicking point‚Äù in their otherwise encouraging report; ‚Äú persistent challenges of heating and transportation energy ‚Äù that renewables are not affecting. However
column2: since the IEA only monitored and tracked the world‚Äôs transistor from oil and gas to biofuels
column3: they note that as electric and hybrid vehicles continue to increase around the world
column4: they will be connected to the same electrical grid that is steadily getting a little greener
column5: significantly cheaper
column6: and one Hell of a lot more friendly for the climate and the people.

column1: It is a mystery how Republicans beholden to the Koch brothers and dirty fossil fuel industry
column2: particularly the dirty coal industry
column3: will absorb this good news. In the past eight years
column4: Republicans
column5: the Kochs
column6: their lobbyists at the Heritage Foundation
column7: Americans for Prosperity
column8: and the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC) have made killing renewable energy one of their primary goals. It is likely that the IEA‚Äôs report will signal they are not winning the war on renewable energy and in the past that may have been worrisome. But now that more Americans are benefitting from renewable energy
column9: particularly solar
column10: Republicans will have a difficult time convincing them to stop getting free electricity from the Sun and saving the climate for their children‚Äôs future; something the IEA‚Äôs report never mentions.

column3: the campaign must have a credible messenger. Donald Trump is not a credible messenger to any of the voters that he is trying to deter
column4: and he has no effective surrogates that are capable of delivering his message.

People on all sides of the political spectrum who care about basic democratic institutions should be alarmed by Trump‚Äôs public attack on democracy.
The good news for all Americans is that Democrats are already fighting back
column2: and the Trump campaign‚Äôs dark efforts to steal an election appear to be failing.";english;2016-10-27T18:37:48.144+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Trump Campaign Admits They Are Trying To Steal The Election With Voter Suppression;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/african-american-voters-trump.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column3: 2016 at 9:02 pm It's amazing how often a microphone can be the root of a presidential candidate's troubles. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: In an interview with Bill O‚ÄôReilly on Thursday
column2: Donald Trump was again asked about the ‚ÄòAccess Hollywood‚Äô tape in which the Republican nominee was caught bragging about sexually assaulting women. This time
column3: though
column4: he put up a new defense strategy
column5: at least when it comes to this particular issue ‚Äì blame the microphone.

column1: When asked by O‚ÄôReilly if he thinks he would be winning the election if not for the release of the video

‚ÄúIt was locker room talk. The microphone was not supposed to be on ‚Ä¶ it was an illegal act that was NBC. It was not supposed to be on‚Ä¶ that was a private dressing room.‚Äù
It‚Äôs amazing how often a microphone can be the root of a presidential candidate‚Äôs troubles.

It should also be noted that Trump‚Äôs complaint about his dressing room privacy being breached is particularly rich given his history of storming into the dressing rooms of teenage pageant contestants
column2: some as young as 15 years old.

column1: All of this comes after Trump recently promised to sue the growing number of women who have come forward saying that they were sexually assaulted by him.
Trump also spent an absurd amount of time in the interview complaining that the media is rigged (not true)
column2: voter fraud is widespread (false)
column3: and the polls are dirty (they‚Äôre not).

column1: On the Electoral College front
column2: RealClearPolitics shows that Clinton is ahead in states that total 333 electoral votes. One of the states she leads in is Arizona ‚Äì a red state before Republicans nominated Trump.

column1: To put things in perspective
column2: Barack Obama was leading Mitt Romney by just a single percentage point on this day in 2012. That is what you call a close presidential contest
column3: and Obama still went on to easily win.

column1: 7214;1695c9321fd46dd5d50c192bcee28c28f28deab7;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-28T18:10:27.176+03:00;The Banishment Of Trump Has Begun As The American People Are Tuning Him Out;"By Jason Easley on Fri
column2: Oct 28th
column3: 2016 at 10:57 am It is a cruel reality of American electoral politics that the losers of presidential campaigns get banished from national discourse
column4: and that process has already begun for Donald Trump. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: It is a cruel reality of American electoral politics that the losers of presidential campaigns get banished from national discourse
column2: and that process has already begun for Donald Trump.

column1: Despite the fact that Trump has been claiming that the presidential election is going to be rigged
column2: stolen
column3: or unfair
column4: his cries are beginning to fall on deaf ears. The latest Washington Post tracking poll found that confidence that votes will be counted correctly grew by 12 points from 31%-43%. The number of respondents who believed that voter fraud occurs somewhat often has dropped from 47%-37%
column5: and those expressing concerns that all votes will be counted accurately dropped from 34% to 28%. Even Trump supporters are split 50%-49% on whether or not votes will be counted accurately.

column1: Part of the shift is likely due to the effective job that President Obama did in addressing these concerns
column2: but it is most likely that voters are treating Trump like the candidate who is going to lose the election.

column1: One of the best indicators of a presidential election‚Äôs outcome as election day draws near is the question of who voters think will win.
Hillary Clinton is dominant on the question of who voters believe will win the election
column2: which is a hint of the way that people are voting.

column1: The process of tuning out the losing candidate has a long history in the US two party system. Losing candidates who refuse to go away
column2: like Sarah Palin
column3: are viewed as annoying relics who refuse to acknowledge that their time is up.

column1: Trump‚Äôs fifteen minutes of fame on the national stage appear to be coming to an end. His words can still poison and damage our country at a cultural level
column2: which is why he still needs to be discussed
column3: but as far as changing minds and winning an election
column4: it looks voters are in the process of banishing Trump from the political island.";english;2016-10-28T18:10:27.176+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;The Banishment Of Trump Has Begun As The American People Are Tuning Him Out;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Trump-rejected.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7215;c01e0b28c7077998468044b50ed570b23a8f88e7;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-28T18:10:28.433+03:00;‚ÄúBillionaire‚Äù Donald Trump‚Äôs Presidential Campaign Is Flat Out Broke;"The Washington Post reported :
Donald Trump raised just $29 million for his presidential campaign committee in the first 19 days of October
column2: about half as much as his Democratic rival
column3: putting him at a severe financial disadvantage in the crucial final days of the White House contest
column4: new campaign finance reports filed Thursday night showed.

column1: The GOP presidential nominee had just $16 million left in his campaign coffers on Oct. 19
column2: compared to Hillary Clinton‚Äôs $62 million. When the cash reserves of their joint fundraising committees are included
column3: Clinton‚Äôs war chest grew to $153 million
column4: while Trump‚Äôs totaled $68 million.

column1: Trump‚Äôs total fundraising dropped 39% in the first 19 days of October. $29 million is close to nothing for a national presidential campaign in the closing weeks of the race. At a time when Trump needs boots on the ground to get out the Republican vote
column2: his presidential campaign is broke
column3: and in debt to the tune of $2 million. There isn‚Äôt going to be a last-minute ad blitz for Trump
column4: or a reservation of television time so that the Republican nominee can speak directly to voters before election day.

column1: The plan for Trump is for the campaign to continue to limp along with lots of rallies
column2: which are good for Trump‚Äôs ego
column3: but not effective in getting voters to the polls. Trump promised to donate $100 million to his campaign but has only given $56 million . The billionaire who promised to self-finance has run his presidential campaign into the ground. Trump took ten times more money out of his campaign in reimbursements to his own businesses than he gave in October.

column1: Fundraising is an indicator of expected election outcomes. The money tends to go towards the winner at the end of an election. Hillary Clinton is having no trouble raising money
column2: which suggests that enthusiasm is high among her supporters. Trump‚Äôs cash crush points to a depressed base that doesn‚Äôt expect him to win.

column1: Trump has done what he does best. He talked a big game while bankrupting the Republican Party for his own personal gain. Convincing Republicans to give him their nomination may go down in history as Trump‚Äôs biggest con of all.";english;2016-10-28T18:10:28.433+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;‚ÄúBillionaire‚Äù Donald Trump‚Äôs Presidential Campaign Is Flat Out Broke;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/trump-freak-out.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

As Republicans cheer because they think that they have been thrown an election lifeline
column2: read the whole letter and look at what it says. The letter does not say that Hillary Clinton did anything wrong. The letter states that emails were found that were pertinent to the email investigation while looking into an unrelated matter.

column1: The letter FBI Director Comey reads like what it is
column2: an update on an investigation. The FBI is dotting the Is and crossing the Ts. Comey‚Äôs letter destroys the Republican claim that there was a conspiracy to cover up Clinton‚Äôs emails. Republicans
column3: including Donald Trump
column4: have spent months criticizing Comey‚Äôs investigation
column5: but it turns out that they were wrong.

column1: It would take something unprecedented and dramatic to change the FBI‚Äôs original findings. Director Comey made it clear that the agency‚Äôs work might not be completed before the election.
The email story that Republicans and the media love
column2: but voters have never cared about is back in the news
column3: but it remains an empty scandal.

column1: The FBI‚Äôs reopened investigation does open the door for Republicans to continue their bogus witch hunt if Hillary Clinton wins the White House. Unless voters want two more years of conspiracy investigations instead of action
column2: today‚Äôs developments have made voting for Democrats in House and Senate contests more vital than ever.";english;2016-10-28T20:53:13.796+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;The Reopening Of The Clinton Email Investigation Is More GOP Hype Over Nothing;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/clinton.png;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: If Donald Trump wants to keep Arizona in the Republican column
column2: he will have to spend some of his very limited time
column3: money
column4: and resources there
column5: because Hillary Clinton is campaigning in the red state next week.

column1: The Clinton announced that the Democratic nominee would be spending part of the last week of the campaign in Arizona
column2: ‚ÄúOn Wednesday
column3: November 2
column4: ‚Äé Hillary Clinton will campaign in Phoenix
column5: Arizona
column6: days before Election Day. Clinton will lay out what is at stake in the election. With more people voting in this election than any in history
column7: Clinton will urge Arizona voters to take advantage of in-person early voting. Voters can check their registration status and early vote location at iwillvote.com.‚Äù

column1: The fact that Clinton will be in usually reliably red Arizona in November during the final week of the presidential campaign tells voters all they need to know about the state of the presidential race.
Hillary Clinton is in such a good position that she can afford to spend some time during the last week of the campaign trying to turn red states blue.
The Trump campaign already deployed VP nominee Mike Pence to Utah in a bid to save that dark red state from falling
column2: and it looks like they will have to devote resources to saving Arizona to prevent Clinton from winning a state that has been a given for Republicans in previous elections.

column1: The Trump campaign is broke. The nominee had to give his campaign $10 million so that they could afford to buy air time in battleground states for their ads.

The Clinton campaign is trying to stretch Trump past his breaking point by making a serious play for Arizona. It is a brilliant move from a campaign that has outwitted its Republican opponent at every turn.";english;2016-10-28T20:53:16.992+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Hillary Clinton Is Brilliantly Forcing Broke Trump To Spend Money Defending Arizona;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/clinton-victory-speech.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

Candidates who have been vocal in their support for gun violence prevention perform well in Florida. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton leads Republican Donald Trump by four points (48/44)
column2: and Democratic U.S. Senate candidate Patrick Murphy is tied with Republican incumbent Sen. Marco Rubio
column3: 46/46. By an almost two to-one margin
column5: Florida voters would be more likely to vote for a candidate for U.S. Senate who supports strengthening gun laws
column6: suggesting ample room for growth for gun safety candidates before the election next month.

column1: The poll was conducted by PPP the Americans for Responsible Solutions PAC
column2: and it illustrates the dilemma that the Florida Senate race has created for Democrats. Democratic leadership is divided on spending more money on expensive Florida media
column3: but there are polls that suggest that Sen. Marco Rubio‚Äôs Democratic challenger
column4: Rep. Patrick Murphy
column5: has a chance of winning the seat.

column1: If Rep. Murphy can beat Sen. Rubio
column2: the defeat would likely put an end to Rubio‚Äôs national political career or at least force the Florida Republican to put the brakes on his plan to run for president in 2020
column3: and instead focus on a run for governor.

column1: Democrats have a real chance to send Marco Rubio to the unemployment line. Rubio has been a disinterested Senator
column2: who just like Ted Cruz
column3: seems only interest in his Senate seat as a platform from which to launch his presidential ambitions. Rubio has provided poor service to his constituents
column4: and doesn‚Äôt deserve to return to the US Senate.

column1: Sen. Rubio has refused to commit to serving his full Senate term
column2: which should tell voters all they need to know about his commitment to them.

column1: Democrats have a chance to solidify their potential Senate majority by sending Marco Rubio home. With cash to spend and less than two weeks left in the campaign
column2: they‚Äôd be foolish not to take it.

column1: ‚Äî Ken Gude (@KenGude) October 29

The problem with Comey‚Äôs actions isn‚Äôt that he is investigating Hillary Clinton; the problem is he is violating long standing rules that prohibit federal employees from doing anything that could be seen as political near an election. It is an established rule that ongoing investigations aren‚Äôt commented on for obvious reasons.
This is quite simply not done. Comey‚Äôs reasons for doing this are unclear
column2: and perhaps when he provides more information his decision will make more sense. But it‚Äôs troubling that we are seeing such a consistent breakdown of tradition and rules/agreements of law surrounding the Trump campaign
column3: which seems to have lowered the bar all around.

column1: Democracy is a fragile thing. It is to Goodlatte‚Äôs credit that he declined the call to draw up articles of impeachment in 2014 and that he cautioned Megyn Kelly that a special prosecutor is appointed not by the House but by the Attorney General. However
column2: the GOP-led House has been far too engaged already in undermining our democracy.

column2: short on facts. Podesta said the more information that comes out
column3: the more this seems overblown. Podesta went off on Rep. Jason Chaffetz for distorting the facts and undermining his own legitimacy by claiming that the investigation was reopened. Podesta said that Comey had provided selective information that allowed partisans to distort the facts.

column1: Hillary Clinton‚Äôs campaign chair called on Comey to provide answers to be public.
Clinton campaign manager Robbie Mook said that the Comey letter is motivating Clinton volunteers and supporters:
Based on the anecdotes I am hearing from out team on the ground
column2: this situation has created an urgency and intensity among our volunteers and activists that was already high because we are so close to the election. Our volunteers are rallying around Hillary They know what a fighter she is.

column1: They are turning out
column2: not only to have her back but to rally our supporters to turn out and vote
column3: as early voting goes into full swing. We‚Äôre not just seeing this in our offices
column4: on the ground
column5: but also in our online
column6: in the online space as well. I think this is; we already had momentum and wind behind our back going into yesterday. I think that this has only increased the momentum that we‚Äôre feeling among our activists on the ground.

column1: Later Mook suggested that the Comey letter is helping the Clinton campaign by adding fuel to their early voting fire. It is likely that the Comey letter will backfire on Republicans and motivate Democrats to get out and support their nominee.

An early report from a pollster in two swing states saw no impact from the letter on voters. Hillary Clinton may end up benefiting from Comey‚Äôs actions because the FBI Director might have gotten rid of the one thing that could have beaten her.

column3: 2016 at 12:03 pm Donald Trump uses sexual shaming and humiliation of women as simplistic revenge for the slightest felt spurn. A newly surfaced video via Ryan Grim shows the Trump Humiliation game in action
column4: which I walk everyone through from the POV of the woman. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: If you‚Äôre a woman who‚Äôs worked in any business where you‚Äôre forced to try to appease the massively sensitive ego of a sexually aggressive
column2: vulgar man in power
column3: you will know exactly what‚Äôs about to happen in this video.

column1: Donald Trump uses sexual shaming and humiliation of women as simplistic revenge for the slightest felt spurn. And there‚Äôs a newly surfaced video via Ryan Grim at Huffington Post that shows the Trump Humiliation game in action.
In the video
column2: Trump publicly sexualizes and shames the 2004 Miss Universe winner from Australia
column3: Jennifer Hawkins as revenge. Before he does it
column4: Trump tells the audience
column5: ‚ÄúGet even with people. If they screw you
column6: screw them back 10 times as hard. I really believe that.‚Äù

column1: Watch this newly surfaced 2011 corporate speech here via Huffington Post (major trigger warning if you‚Äôve been there):
Watching this you see the Trump modus operandi in action. This is the sting felt by numerous women who report spurning Trump‚Äôs advances. The harassment as revenge. The sexual shaming.

Trump sets the audience up for the Roman Gladiator moment of public sexual offering by priming them with his belief that you should ‚Äúscrew‚Äù people back if they ‚Äúscrew‚Äù you. The sexually angry verb foreshadows what‚Äôs to come
column2: because he is going to ‚Äúscrew‚Äù Jennifer Hawkins in public
column3: when she realizes that because it‚Äôs public
column4: she can‚Äôt further humiliate him by saying no or objecting without facing huge repercussions.

column1: Trump says he‚Äôs going to give them an example of his revenge theory
column2: ‚ÄúJennifer Hawkins.‚Äù

column1: Trump orders Hawkins to the stage. The audience cheers and jeers
column2: delighting in the upcoming shaming of the beautiful girl. It‚Äôs to be a public spanking. So much fun.

column1: ‚ÄúFirst of all
column2: how beautiful is Jennifer
column3: ‚Äù Trump asks
column4: claiming ownership of Jennifer as an object while playing magnanimous daddy who dishes out praise and approval before the spanking. The message: He can make or break her. She better play nice.

column1: Warning shot
column2: ‚ÄúThis is about getting even.‚Äù

column1: Trump tells the audience that he was mad at Hawkins because she allegedly dissed him by declining to introduce him at the event in Sydney. He tells the audience how mad he was
column2: and then says
column3: as she‚Äôs crossing the stage
column4: ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs my favorite Miss Universe.‚Äù So she thinks maybe this isn‚Äôt going to be as bad as she fears.

column1: But then he stabs her publicly for the first time
column2: ‚ÄúBut I think I like the new one better.‚Äù

column1: The audience loves it. He is going to feed them the sexual humiliation of a beautiful woman because she wasn‚Äôt a good girl. She reaches him and they clasp hands while she smiles through the shame knowing she has no choice and wanting to be a good sport.
Hawkins tries to make light of the situation while appeasing Trump
column2: playing along with his game because she has to
column3: but there will be no easy way out of this one. It won‚Äôt be enough to fawn over him in front of the audience. She will have to pay.

column1: ‚ÄúI was actually going to get up and tell you that Jennifer is a beautiful girl on the outside
column2: but she‚Äôs not very bright
column3: ‚Äù Trump tells the audience
column4: signaling that Hawkins is a piece of meat to be dissected by him publicly for her refusal to give him anything he asks for.

column1: ‚ÄúThat wouldn‚Äôt have been true
column2: but I would have said it anyway
column3: ‚Äù Trump proudly tells the audience. This is his alpha male routine
column4: except in real life
column5: the alpha male doesn‚Äôt have to abuse money and power he inherited in order to win the girl. But in the mind of little men like Trump
column6: this makes him a winner.

column1: Trump points out that Hawkins is a big star now
column2: but he helped her make it and then dissed him. He owns her. She must comply or face his wrath. Hawkins tries to say that she did introduce him
column3: but Trump pushes her away from the microphone. This public shaming will be done from Trump‚Äôs POV only. No need for Hawkins to assert her personhood.There will be no defense allowed
column4: because she‚Äôs already guilty.

column1: ‚ÄúAnd you know what? She came tonight
column2: she came ‚Äî came
column3: she came
column4: she came
column5: ‚Äù Trump says gleefully like the drunk pervy uncle everyone tries to avoid at Christmas. He waits for the audience to join him in his sexual shaming
column6: and they do. They get it. Hee heee. So clever. Came. Knuckles dragging on the floor clever.

column1: ‚ÄúSee
column2: so they have the same filthy minds in Australia
column3: ‚Äù Trump says.

column1: Trump grabs Hawkins around the waist and forces a kiss on her
column2: just like he bragged about doing on the Bush tape.

column1: Hawkins reflexively turns away and puts her arm between them. The kiss misses its mark and lands on her cheek. She is hoping this is good enough humiliation for him
column2: but putting her foot down on actual mouth contact. She‚Äôs allowed herself to be publicly humiliated to appease him
column3: and pretended to fawn over him as required
column4: but she will not
column5: cannot
column6: allow the kiss. The repulsive kiss.

column1: I‚Äôm telling this story as I imagine it to be from her point of view
column2: although she has refused to comment. Of course she refused to comment
column3: women are told they will be blackballed if they comment. The world is full of men like Trump
column4: and they stick together. See Roger Ailes. Women have to play along and appease and if that doesn‚Äôt work
column5: they have to allow themselves to be sexually assaulted and humiliated just a little bit in public
column6: especially if they said no in private.

column1: I can only do this because I have lived it
column2: somewhat like this
column3: in public. And I have tried to appease the ego of the assaulter in order to keep my job
column4: while denying him his assumed entitlement to my body.

column1: From talking to so many women during this election
column2: I know that I‚Äôm not alone. I know that many other women will watch this and know. They will feel the creep of fear and revulsion
column3: the deer in the headlights cringe that takes over when you know that you are about to be humiliated as a sexual object because you refused him or refused to appease the ego of the powerful man in charge by behaving like a sexual conquest. How dare Hawkins have her own life and be unwilling to change all of her plans in order to introduce Trump.

column1: And other people will watch this humiliation and enjoy it
column2: setting you up to be humiliated even more. They will laugh about it and gossip about it
column3: which is the social punishment women face when they reject a man like Trump. Ironically
column4: if you give in you‚Äôre not humiliated. It‚Äôs only if you say no that you are set up to be publicly flogged as a sex object.

column1: It‚Äôs not just the unwanted kiss
column2: although that is disgusting and assault
column3: much like Donald Trump bragged about doing on the Billy Bush bus tape. It‚Äôs the public humiliation and denigration.

column1: It‚Äôs the way the woman is forced
column2: in front of thousands of people
column3: to try to smile her way through his ambush of verbal and physical assaults as he takes revenge.

column1: It‚Äôs the way she tries to make it okay
column2: to sweet-smooth his ego in order to get out of the line of fire
column3: and in return he shames her by suggesting he made her ‚Äúcome‚Äù and then grabs her for an unwanted kiss.

column1: If there is any good to come out of the total crapfest of the Trump candidacy
column2: perhaps it is a raised awareness that women are people
column3: and that this kind of thing is horrific but it‚Äôs not all Trump‚Äôs fault. It‚Äôs the culture‚Äôs fault because it takes a willing audience to successfully publicly sexually shame a woman.

column1: In fact
column2: this is shades of what Trump did to Hillary Clinton in the stalking debate
column3: after which he announced that looking at her from behind he was not impressed.

column1: Neither are we by you
column2: Mr. Trump. Neither are we.";english;2016-10-29T21:05:47.777+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Women Everywhere Cringe in Horror Watching Donald Trump Sexually Humiliate a Woman for Revenge;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/TrumpHawkins.png;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7236;efcfd1510d71df71233c85eea13d9ddba7dbc3df;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-29T21:05:48.090+03:00;Pollster Sees No Early Impact From Comey Clinton FBI Email Letter In Swing States;"A pollster who is in the field in two swing states is reporting that he is seeing no early impact from the FBI reviewing new emails in the Hillary Clinton investigation in two swing states.
Geoff Garin of Hart Research tweeted from the field: Still early
column2: but I was in the field in two states last night and saw absolutely no impact from the reporting on the Comey letter.

column1: ‚Äî Geoff Garin (@geoffgarin) October 29
It is still early
column2: but if this were the election shifting news that Republicans were hoping for the impact would have been immediate. The reality is that if the public opinion polls tighten in the final days of the campaign
column3: it will be because Republicans are coming back to Trump.

column1: There are few undecided voters in this election
column2: and even if all the Republican base come home to Trump
column3: it won‚Äôt be enough for Trump to win
column4: because he is losing where the presidential election is really held. Trump is getting crushed at the state level.

column1: Republicans have been trying to build Hillary Clinton‚Äôs emails into a story for years
column2: and they have failed at every turn.

column1: Hillary Clinton led the election while under Congressional investigation. Hillary Clinton led the election while under FBI investigation. Hillary Clinton is leading the election today. The message that Republicans and the media don‚Äôt want to hear is that voters are sick of the emails
column2: and they don‚Äôt care.

column1: Voters are smarter than Republicans and the press give them credit for. The Hillary Clinton email scandal has never broken out of the right wing bubble because there is no evidence that Clinton did anything wrong.
If the polls tighten a little
column2: this will be the best news in the world for Hillary Clinton and Democrats
column3: because it will destroy any potential for Democratic complacency and get their voters out and to the polls.

column1: What Geoff Garin witnessed is probably going to end up being very accurate. James Comey‚Äôs letter to Congress is unlikely to move swing states and change the outcome of the presidential election.";english;2016-10-29T21:05:48.090+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Pollster Sees No Early Impact From Comey Clinton FBI Email Letter In Swing States;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/hillary_clinton_donald_trump.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

7237;b054ceb84bde5b92f2ace65ac1fe231a64b8528d;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-29T21:05:49.223+03:00;Bombshell New Details Destroy Republican Hopes In FBI Clinton Email Investigation;"Share on Twitter Print This Post
The FBI is examining how a Hillary Clinton aide handled emails. The examination has nothing to do with the Democratic nominee
column2: her emails
column3: or her email server.

column1: According to Newsweek‚Äôs Kurt Eichenwald
column2: the ‚Äúscandal‚Äù is related to the process Clinton aide Huma Abedin used to print out emails for the then secretary of state to read.

column1: Eichenwald reported: Because Clinton preferred to read documents on paper rather than on a screen
column2: emails and other files were often printed out and provided to her either at her office or home
column3: where they were delivered in a diplomatic pouch by a security agent. Abedin
column4: like many State Department officials
column5: found the government network technology to be cumbersome
column6: and she had great trouble printing documents there
column7: investigative records show. As a result
column8: she sometimes transferred emails from her unclassified State Department account to either her Yahoo account or her account on Clinton‚Äôs server
column9: and printed the emails from there. It is not clear whether she ever transferred official emails to the account she used for her husband‚Äôs campaign.

column1: Abedin would use this procedure for printing documents when she received emails she believed Clinton needed to see and when the Secretary forwarded emails to her for printing. Abedin told the FBI she would often print these emails without reading them. Abedin printed a large number of emails this way
column2: in part because
column3: investigative records show
column4: other staff members considered her Clinton‚Äôs ‚Äúgatekeeper‚Äù and often sent Abedin electronic communications they wanted the Secretary to see.

column1: The entire scandal is about how emails were printed. It has nothing to do with how Hillary Clinton handled emails or classified information. The investigation is related to how an aide printed emails for Hillary Clinton to read. No wonder Comey didn‚Äôt provide more details in his letter to Congress. The details of what is being examined are an embarrassment to the FBI.
There is no evidence that Clinton‚Äôs aide committed a crime. For the printing of the emails to be deemed criminal
column2: there must be evidence that Abedin intended to leak classified information. There remains zero evidence of criminal activity.

column1: The FBI examination of new emails is turning out to be one of the most overblown red herrings of the 2016 election
column2: and Comey‚Äôs behavior is a disgrace to the US intelligence community.

column1: The new information destroys Republican hopes that the new emails were the game changer that could save them from defeat . Republicans may spend the remaining days pushing the emails
column2: but their behavior will be the hallmark of a desperate party that is facing a crushing defeat.

column1: The emails won‚Äôt change anything in 2016
column2: but they will give Congressional Republicans a reason to keep investigating Hillary Clinton in 2017 and beyond. In other words
column3: James Comey is already delegitimizing Hillary Clinton‚Äôs potential presidency.";english;2016-10-29T21:05:49.223+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Bombshell New Details Destroy Republican Hopes In FBI Clinton Email Investigation;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/Clinton-Trump-coward.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7238;623c13fe3e7df70a5731097139ad7e8ea10d02b9;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-29T22:04:29.785+03:00;Trump Melts Down And Accuses The US Postal Service Of Stealing The Election For Clinton;"Trump warned his supporters that the US Postal Service is trying to steal the election for Hillary Clinton in Colorado.
Video:
At a rally in Golden
column2: CO
column3: Trump said:

column1: I have real problems with ballots being sent. Does that make sense?
Like people saying
column2: ‚ÄúOh
column3: here‚Äôs a ballot. Here‚Äôs another ballot. Throw it away. Oh
column4: here‚Äôs one I like. We‚Äôll keep that one.‚Äù

column1: I have real problems
column2: so get your ballots in.

column1: Trump also accused election officials of throwing away ballots
column2: as his rally was a mixture of claims of voter fraud and baseless speculation about Hillary Clinton‚Äôs emails.

column1: Donald Trump appears to be losing his mind. He also seems to think that accusing the US Postal Service and election officials of stealing the election for Hillary Clinton is going to motivate Republicans to vote.
Consider the contradiction in Trump‚Äôs message. The Republican nominee tells his supporters that the US Postal Service is throwing away ballots
column2: while at the same time he is urging them to mail in their ballots.

column1: If their ballots are going to be thrown away by USPS
column2: why should Republicans bother mailing their ballots in?

column1: It is this sort of incoherent gibberish that makes no sense. Trump‚Äôs inability to stay disciplined and on message is also one of the biggest reasons why Republicans on pace to lose this election.
Donald Trump‚Äôs descent into paranoid senior citizen continues to play out in front of the entire nation
column2: as the Republican nominee for president believes that his letter carrier is out to get him

7239;644db362a08d83d3518d2769095d10aad0d40d2b;0;Rmuse;2016-10-29T22:54:59.504+03:00;President Obama Gets Real, Not Revenge, On Republicans;By Rmuse on Sat
column4: Oct 29th
column5: 2016 at 3:23 pm He is taking the conspiracy theories and obstruction that dogged his presidency from day one and throwing them back in Republicans' faces.   *The following is an opinion column by R Muse*

column1: Although this campaign season has been interesting
column2: to say the least
column3: there is something happening one never thought would occur. After spending nearly eight years demonizing
column4: obstructing
column5: and criticizing every and anything about the President of the United States
column6: Republicans desperate to save their jobs are beginning to tout their ‚Äú imagined ‚Äù close ties to the Democratic President whose approval rating and popularity are growing.

column1: It is hypocritical
column2: to say the least
column3: and at some point a result of a toxic Republican candidate for the presidency
column4: but for some GOP candidates it is a very dangerous strategy. If any Republican believed President Obama would allow them to take advantage of him after spending eight years assailing him as illegitimate and corrupt
column5: they were sadly mistaken and underestimated the commander in chief‚Äôs tolerance during an election.

column1: The President is using the final two weeks before the election to decimate Republicans for either ‚Äú belated rejection ‚Äù or continued support of Donald Trump. President Obama is also reminding Republicans that ‚Äú Donald Trump is the endpoint of eight years of [GOP] toxic hostility .‚Äù It may be a tad of an exaggeration to claim that ‚Äú Obama seems determined to spend the last two weeks of the election laying waste to every Republican who ever crossed him
column2: ‚Äù but he is getting some well-placed and well-warranted shots at Republicans.

column1: Two Republican hypocrites hoping to take advantage of the President‚Äôs approval ratings have been some of his harshest critics; so it likely stunned the President that they are boasting working closely with the man they obstructed
column2: opposed
column3: and attempted to get rid of.

column1: Ohio Senator Rob Portman had the temerity to run a campaign ad boasting about working closely with the President ‚Äúto break the grip of heroin addiction.‚Äù President Obama took the time to excoriate Portman for
‚Äú Finally withdrawing his support from Donald Trump
column2: ‚Äù but only ‚Äú After looking at the polling. Now that it‚Äôs politically expedient. But he has supported him up until last week? So I guess it was OK when Trump was attacking minorities
column3: and suggesting that Mexicans were rapists ‚Ä¶ and insulting Gold Star moms
column4: making fun of disabled Americans. I guess that didn‚Äôt quite tip it over the edge. Why was that OK? And now he says he will vote for the vice-presidential nominee instead
column5: except that guy still supports Donald Trump. ‚Äù

column1: The President was a little more exercised after learning that the man who called the President ‚Äú one of the most corrupt presidents in modern times
column2: ‚Äù California Republican Representative Daryl Issa
column3: is sending out campaign mailers with the President‚Äôs face on them and boasting about his close work with President Obama ‚Äú to protect victims of sexual assault .‚Äù

column1: Daryl Issa is in a fairly competitive race compared to past elections and he certainly has earned the President‚Äôs wrath after obstructing progress and wasting taxpayer money on Issa-created scandals. During a fundraiser in La Jolla California Sunday last
column2: the President assailed Issa for having the audacity to use a campaign mailer with the President‚Äôs image on it. The President said

column1: ‚Äú Issa‚Äôs primary contribution to the United States Congress has been to obstruct and to waste taxpayer dollars on trumped-up investigations that have led nowhere. This is now a guy who
column2: because poll numbers are bad
column3: has sent out brochures with my picture on them touting his cooperation on issues with me. Now that is the definition of chutzpah.‚Äù

column1: As remarked by Tim Murphy at Mother Jones
column2: President Obama is not just evening up the score with Republicans who made his tenure miserable
column3: ‚Äú He is attempting to have the last word on the personal and political fights of the last eight years‚Äîto take the conspiracy theories and obstruction that dogged his presidency from day one and throw them back in Republicans‚Äô faces .‚Äù

column1: The President clearly has a lot of ‚Äú words ‚Äù to harangue Republicans with. He said
‚Äú Here‚Äôs the thing. For years
column2: Republican politicians and the far-right media outlets have pumped up all kinds of crazy stuff about me. About Hillary. About Harry. They said I wasn‚Äôt born here. They said climate change is a hoax. They said that I was going to take everybody‚Äôs guns away! They said that while we were doing military exercises that we‚Äôve been doing forever
column3: suddenly this was a plot to impose martial law. This is what they‚Äôve been saying for years now! So people have been hearing it they start thinking well maybe it‚Äôs true! And if the world they‚Äôve been seeing is I‚Äôm powerful enough to cause hurricanes on my own and to steal everybody‚Äôs guns in the middle of the night and impose martial law‚Äîeven though I can‚Äôt talk without a ‚Äòprompter‚Äîthen is it any wonder that they end up nominating somebody like Donald Trump?

column1: And the fact is that there are a lot of politicians who knew better. There are a lot of senators who knew better but they went along with these stories because they figured you know what this‚Äôll help rile up the base
column2: it‚Äôll give us an excuse to obstruct what we‚Äôre trying to do
column3: we won‚Äôt be able to appoint judges
column4: we‚Äôll gum up the works
column5: we‚Äôll create gridlock
column6: it‚Äôll give us a political advantage. So they just stood by and said nothing and their base began to actually believe this stuff. So Donald Trump did not start this. Donald Trump didn‚Äôt start it
column7: he just did what he always did which is slap his name on it
column8: take credit for it
column9: and promote it. That‚Äôs what he always does. And so now
column10: when suddenly it‚Äôs not working and people are saying wow this guy‚Äôs kind of out of line
column11: all of a sudden these Republican politicians who were okay with all this crazy stuff up to a point suddenly they‚Äôre all walking away. Oh
column12: this is too much. So when you finally get him on tape bragging about actions that qualify as sexual assault and his poll numbers go down
column13: suddenly that‚Äôs a deal-breaker. Well what took you so long! What the heck! What took you so long! All these years!‚Äù

column1: The Mother Jones piece made out like President Obama is seeking retribution
column2: or ‚Äú revenge ‚Äù against Republicans for their impropriety as legislators over the past eight years. Without knowing what goes on in the President‚Äôs head to motivate his campaign rhetoric; that is a hard call to make with any surety. Barack Obama does not strike one as being vindictive.

column1: The President is
column2: though
column3: an accomplished campaigner and as his tenure in the White House is winding down and Republicans are struggling to find an identity apart from Donald Trump
column4: it is prudent of the President to remind voters exactly what Republicans are about and what they are about is precisely why Donald Trump is their standard bearer; and why Republicans are hypocrites for both abandoning Trump and embracing the man they obstructed and tried to remove from the White House.";english;2016-10-29T22:54:59.504+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;President Obama Gets Real
column5: Not Revenge
column6: On Republicans;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/obama-rigged-election.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7240;b4c8763f22bb0752b233553348783ca025791bac;0;Hrafnkell Haraldsson;2016-10-29T23:17:00.600+03:00;When Trump Attacked the Khans
column2: He Didn‚Äôt Know What a Gold Star Family Was;"By Hrafnkell Haraldsson on Sat
column3: Oct 29th
column4: 2016 at 4:05 pm ‚ÄúYou do know you just attacked a Gold Star family?‚Äù one adviser warned Trump. ""What's that?"" he asked. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: Gabriel Sherman writes at New York Mag that when Donald Trump attacked the Khan family over Khizr Khan‚Äôs speech at the Democratic National Convention
column2: he had no idea what a Gold Star family was.

column1: You will remember that Khizr Khan stood up in front of the entire world and said to Donald Trump
column2: ‚ÄúLet me ask you
column3: ‚ÄòHave you even read the United States Consitution?‚Äô I will gladly lend you my copy. In this document
column4: look for the words ‚Äòliberty‚Äô and ‚Äòequal protection of the law.‚Äô‚Äù

column1: The fallout was predictable. Donald Trump
column2: openly criticized
column3: lost it. He attacked the Khan‚Äôs religious beliefs
column4: saying ‚ÄúIf you look at his wife
column5: she was standing there. She had nothing to say. She probably
column6: maybe she wasn‚Äôt allowed to have anything to say.‚Äù

column1: Now it turns out that he had no idea what he was doing. Because he is ignorant
column2: and because
column3: as Mark Cuban has observed
column4: he isn‚Äôt interested in learning anything. Gabriel Sherman explains:

column1: ‚ÄúYou do know you just attacked a Gold Star family?‚Äù one adviser warned Trump. Trump didn‚Äôt know what a Gold Star family was: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs that?‚Äù he asked. To Trump
column2: Khizr Khan and his wife
column3: Ghazala
column4: were enemies who had said something mean about him
column5: just like Rosie O‚ÄôDonnell and any number of people who had gotten under his skin over the years. Wasn‚Äôt it his right to respond? ‚Äú‚ÄÖ‚ÄòThe election is about the American people
column6: it‚Äôs not about you
column7: ‚Äô‚ÄÖ‚Äù Manafort told Trump
column8: according to a person briefed on the conversation. Trump countered with Breitbart‚Äôs report on Khan‚Äôs purported belief in Sharia. ‚Äú‚ÄÖ‚ÄòHe‚Äôs not running for president
column9: ‚Äô‚ÄÖ‚Äù Manafort shot back. ‚Äú‚ÄÖ‚ÄòThe Clintons did this to us to waste our time getting off message.‚Äô‚ÄÖ‚Äù

column1: Of course
column2: Trump could not and would not admit his own ignorance and he certainly wasn‚Äôt prepared to take the blame. Instead
column3: as Sherman reveals
column4: he ‚Äútook it out on Manafort in front of his senior advisors
column5: including Ailes.‚Äù According to Trump
column6: Manafort wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúable to get the media to focus on the right stuff.‚Äù

column1: No wonder
column2: when Trump refuses to take Manafort‚Äôs advice and focus on the right stuff. This is not to defend Manafort
column3: who is at least as despicable as his boss
column4: but it serves as an example of how Trump‚Äôs first reaction each and every time is to get back at his critic.

column1: It was one of Donald Trump‚Äôs most visible Joe McCarthy moments
column2: and his response to Khizr Khan actually reinforced the point Khan was trying to make.

column1: Stopping and thinking are foreign to him. And if you are not astonished by the appalling ignorance on display here
column2: you should not be. This is all in keeping with a party that prides itself on ignorance rather than facts.";english;2016-10-29T23:17:00.600+03:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;When Trump Attacked the Khans
column3: He Didn‚Äôt Know What a Gold Star Family Was;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/khizr-khan-dnc.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7241;07272632351c0de9953fa0bd42d550321f808454;0;Rmuse;2016-10-30T02:03:36.590+02:00;Koch Brothers Helped Incite the Impending Bloodbath Among Republicans;"By Rmuse   7:57 pm ""If the party doesn‚Äôt learn lessons and change based on what‚Äôs gone on for the last year and a half
column2: I think it‚Äôs going to be just catastroph[ic].""   *The following is an opinion column by R Muse*

column1: It may be the understatement of the year to say the Republican Party is on the verge of a full-on civil war
column2: and it may be obvious to many Americans that the blame for the inter-party discord is its standard bearer Donald J. Trump. However much Trump‚Äôs candidacy has contributed to the tensions between establishment types terrified of Trump‚Äôs reckless disregard for the longevity of the party and rebellion-minded Trump supporters
column3: the real instigators are the Koch brothers.

column1: Although the oil magnates were never on the Trump bandwagon
column2: they are responsible for the Trump loyalists within the GOP who were part of the teabagger movement intent on disrupting the nation‚Äôs political system and indeed
column3: the workings of government itself. The tea party caucus
column4: an extremist sect that succeeded in chasing former House Speaker John A. Boehner out of Congress
column5: morphed into the inaptly- named Freedom caucus that has embraced Trump are set to set fire to the party establishment and it isn‚Äôt solely to put current Speaker Paul Ryan out of a job
column6: although that is high on the Trump supporters‚Äô to-do list.

column1: As noted in Wednesday‚Äôs New York Times
column2: ‚Äú Mr. Trump‚Äôs supporters said they were determined to harness the anti-establishment energy that Mr. Trump had catalyzed and to refocus it on the Republican leadership in Congress ‚Äî a target many of them seem‚Ä¶eager to take down .‚Äù

column1: The right-wing extremist that actually ‚Äú took down ‚Äù former House Majority Leader Eric Cantor
column2: conservative extremist and House Freedom Caucus member David Brat
column3: issued a warning to establishment Republicans:

column1: ‚Äú There‚Äôs a huge chunk of people who want to see a fight taken to D.C. Leadership comes and smacks our guy? That‚Äôs where you‚Äôre going to put down a marker? Really? And the American people are just scratching their head saying
column2: ‚ÄòReally? That‚Äôs rich .‚Äô‚Äù

column1: Brat has been a thorn in the establishment‚Äôs side since Paul Ryan became Speaker and he joins a dangerous number of ‚Äú real conservatives ‚Äù who cannot understand or comport with Ryan and establishment leaders who dared criticize Trump instead of using their majority advantage to go after Hillary Clinton.
Donald Trump and a few of his ‚Äú senior aides ‚Äù are prodding extremist conservatives to revolt against the establishment leadership after the election for not defending Trump. In fact
column2: besides assailing Ryan for not sticking by Trump
column3: it is reported that Trump said privately that Ryan should be made to pay a heavy price for disloyalty to the Trump candidacy. And
column4: during an interview with Reuters he complained that ‚Äú The people are very angry with the leadership of this party
column5: because this is an election that we will win
column6: 100 percent
column7: if we had support from the top .‚Äù Win or lose
column8: there is going to be a major blood-letting after the election and the establishment
column9: although powerful
column10: may face a Herculean task to save the party.

column1: This impending conflict within the GOP has been brewing longer than Donald Trump has been a candidate and it may be why he brought on an experienced anti-establishment devotee to run his campaign. The chairman of Breitbart News
column2: Stephen Bannon
column3: had made it one of his primary goals to get Paul Ryan out as House Speaker because he is not a ‚Äútrue conservative‚Äù intent on tearing government down to restructure it into an uber-conservative paradise. And ‚Äúuber-conservative‚Äù is just a different way of saying a ‚Äú non-government ‚Äù according to the Koch brothers‚Äô vision of American libertarianism. Don‚Äôt believe it?

column1: Two groups closely aligned with the Koch brothers
column2: Heritage Action for America and FreedomWorks
column3: have been pushing Republicans as a Party to adopt more extremist positions and see the civil war as a stellar opportunity to have greater influence over the party‚Äôs decisions; something establishment types are resisting.

column1: Over the past few days
column2: leaders of both Koch groups joined extremist conservatives in calling to delay a vote on selecting a candidate to be the next
column3: or new
column4: speaker of the House; something typically occurring directly after the general election in November regardless the outcome.

column1: According to the chief executive of Heritage Action
column2: Michael Needham
column3: there is going to be Hell to pay for establishment Republicans if they don‚Äôt bend to the will of the extremist wing created by the Kochs and heavily courted by Donald Trump. Mr. Needham said

column1: ‚Äú If the party doesn‚Äôt learn lessons and change based on what‚Äôs gone on for the last year and a half
column2: I think it‚Äôs going to be just catastrophe .‚Äù

column1: Another conservative extremist
column2: House Freedom Caucus member and ardent Donald Trump supporter echoed Needham‚Äôs sentiment and said
column3: ‚Äú You can‚Äôt ignore what millions and millions of people have expressed in this election cycle. ‚Äù

column1: The dilemma for Republicans after the election
column2: no matter the outcome
column3: is maintaining a semblance of stability as a political party. That doesn‚Äôt seem likely because if Trump loses
column4: big or small
column5: the extremists will unleash whatever level of Hell they can muster on the establishment for daring to criticize any of Trump‚Äôs more outrageous and dangerous comments on the stump. If Trump wins
column6: the extremists will be emboldened to purge the party of any disloyal establishment types and it appears that no matter what happens on November 8
column7: it will not be the end of hostilities among Republicans.

column1: The Republican Party establishment is in for a reckoning with an extremist wing that was once content threatening the full faith and credit of the United States or shutting down the government as a show of anger. After four years of internal bickering over what it means to be a true conservative
column2: and the past year-and-a-half of incitement by Donald Trump
column3: the Republican Party faces a serious threat to its long-term survival. It is a threat that began about six years ago when the Koch brothers ushered in an age of extremist conservatives that Donald Trump took advantage of to seize control of the Republican Party.";english;2016-10-30T02:03:36.590+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Koch Brothers Helped Incite the Impending Bloodbath Among Republicans;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/elephant-broken.jpg;0;1;699;0;699;bias

column1: 7243;7a9ffd4f7332a7671a46dbd5ce95ace264ff8eca;0;Reuters;2016-10-30T02:03:36.775+02:00;Clinton campaign urges FBI to detail new developments in email case;"By Reuters   6:34 pm Democrat Hillary Clinton's top aides on Saturday lashed out at FBI Director James Comey for igniting a new controversy over a long-running private email investigation less than two weeks before the presidential election
column2: saying there was no evidence of wrongdoing and accusing him of spreading ""innuendo.""

column1: By Roberta Rampton and Steve Holland
DAYTONA BEACH
column2: Fla./GOLDEN
column3: Colo. (Reuters) ‚Äì Democrat Hillary Clinton‚Äôs top aides on Saturday lashed out at FBI Director James Comey for igniting a new controversy over a long-running private email investigation less than two weeks before the presidential election
column4: saying there was no evidence of wrongdoing and accusing him of spreading ‚Äúinnuendo.‚Äù

column1: Comey
column2: who has headed the Federal Bureau of Investigation since 2013
column3: notified the U.S. Congress on Friday that the agency is again reviewing emails
column4: even though in July it decided not to seek prosecution of Clinton for her handling of classified materials on a private email server while she was secretary of state.

column1: John Podesta
column2: who heads Clinton‚Äôs presidential campaign
column3: told reporters that Comey‚Äôs letter to Congress was ‚Äúlight on facts
column4: heavy on innuendo
column5: ‚Äù and he urged Comey to ‚Äúcome forward and give those answers to the American public‚Äù about the exact nature of the FBI‚Äôs latest review of emails.

column1: Sources close to the investigation on Friday said the latest emails were discovered as part of a separate probe into Anthony Weiner
column2: the estranged husband of top Clinton aide Huma Abedin.

column1: Weiner
column2: a former U.S. congressman from New York
column3: is the target of an FBI investigation into illicit text messages he is alleged to have sent to a 15-year-old girl in North Carolina.

column1: With the Nov. 8 elections quickly approaching
column2: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump pounded away at the new FBI development
column3: devoting a large part of a campaign speech in Golden
column4: Colorado
column5: to attacking Clinton and arguing that she is not to be trusted with the presidency.

column1: ‚ÄúHer criminal action was willful
column2: deliberate
column3: intentional and purposeful
column4: ‚Äù Trump said
column5: standing in front of hay bales stacked in a horse barn. ‚ÄúHillary set up an illegal server for the obvious purpose of shielding her illegal actions from public disclosure and exposure.‚Äù

column1: Comey
column2: however
column3: has not provided any details on whether the emails now under review are being seen for the first time by the FBI or the nature of their contents.

column1: Clinton‚Äôs campaign tried to play down the new review. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no evidence of wrongdoing
column2: no charge of wrongdoing
column3: ‚Äù Podesta said
column4: in the FBI‚Äôs latest announcement that it was taking ‚Äúappropriate investigative steps‚Äù after learning of emails ‚Äúthat appear to be pertinent‚Äù to the earlier probe.

column1: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook
column2: trying to tamp down speculation of a voter backlash this late in the campaign
column3: said Americans had already ‚Äúfactored‚Äù what they knew about the email investigation into how they would cast their ballots.

column1: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt see it changing the landscape‚Äù for undecided voters
column2: Mook said.

column1: Clinton aides also said this latest controversy has further energized her supporters.
Clinton was campaigning in Florida on Saturday
column2: a battleground state that many analysts say Trump must win in order to have any chance of being elected.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: Trump has been running behind Clinton in most public opinion polls.

column1: Justice Department officials
column2: according to a source who asked not to be identified
column3: were opposed to the FBI director‚Äôs letter being sent to Congress and believe his actions conflict with a Justice Department memo outlining instructions that agencies should not to act in ways that could influence elections.

column1: While Attorney General Loretta Lynch did not discuss the matter directly with Comey

column1: Comey let it be known he felt he had to send the letter as a follow-up to his congressional testimony earlier this year regarding the FBI‚Äôs probe of Clinton‚Äôs emails
column2: the source said.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Clinton supporters rallied to her defense following Friday‚Äôs FBI disclosure.

column1: The Congressional Black Caucus

column3: nearly all Democrats

column5: Ohio
