column1: 7244;f8f6493540f664f0fafd7dcf8a12e76e609273b3;0;Reuters;2016-10-30T02:03:36.786+02:00;Hillary Clinton enjoys solid lead in early voting: Reuters/Ipsos poll;"By Reuters   5:51 pm Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton leads Republican Donald Trump by 15 percentage points among early voters surveyed in the past two weeks
column2: according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project.

column1: By Maurice Tamman
NEW YORK (Reuters) ‚Äì With 11 days to go before the U.S. presidential election
column2: Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton leads Republican Donald Trump by 15 percentage points among early voters surveyed in the past two weeks
column3: according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project.

column1: Though data is not available for all early voting states
column2: Clinton enjoys an edge in swing states such as Ohio and Arizona and in Republican Party strongholds such as Georgia and Texas.

column1: An estimated 19 million Americans have voted so far in the election
column2: according to the University of Florida‚Äôs United States Election Project
column3: accounting for as much as 20 percent of the electorate.

column1: Overall
column2: Clinton remained on track to win a majority of votes in the Electoral College
column3: the Reuters/Ipsos survey showed.

column1: Having so many ballots locked down before the Nov. 8 election is good news for the Clinton campaign. On Friday
column2: the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced that it is examining newly discovered emails belonging to Clinton‚Äôs close aide
column3: Huma Abedin. Those emails were found on a computer belonging to Anthony Weiner
column4: Abedin‚Äôs estranged husband
column5: during an unrelated investigation into illicit messages he is alleged to have sent to a teenage girl. The Reuters/Ipsos survey was conducted before the news emerged Friday afternoon.

column1: It remains unclear whether the FBI inquiry will upset the balance in the race. The bureau disclosed nothing about the Abedin emails
column2: including whether any of the messages were sent by or to Clinton. Over the summer
column3: the FBI said it was closing its investigation into Clinton‚Äôs use of a private email system while secretary of state. Until Friday
column4: her campaign seemed to have weathered the initial FBI email probe.

column1: Clinton has held a lead averaging four to seven percentage points in polls in recent weeks as the Trump campaign wrestled with accusations by women of groping and other sexual advances. Trump has said none of the accusations are true. He also struggled in the recent presidential debates and faced questions about his taxes.
As of Thursday
column2: Clinton‚Äôs odds of receiving the 270 Electoral College votes needed to win the presidency remained at greater than 95 percent
column3: according to State of the Nation polling results released Saturday. The project estimated she would win by 320 votes to 218
column4: with 278 votes solidly for the Democrat.

column1: Clinton‚Äôs lead among early voters is similar to the lead enjoyed by President Barack Obama over Republican Mitt Romney at this point of the 2012 race
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll taken at the time. Obama won the election by 332 electoral votes to Romney‚Äôs 206.

column1: But even before the latest email news
column2: it had been a difficult week for Clinton. News coverage of Trump‚Äôs accusers had diminished
column3: while Clinton confronted the almost daily release by WikiLeaks of emails purportedly hacked from her campaign manager‚Äôs account. This week‚Äôs leaked messages raised questions about former President Bill Clinton‚Äôs finances.

column1: And her lead in the States of the Nation project fell slightly from last week. Though the projected Electoral College votes hardly moved
column2: the number of states solidly for Clinton slid from 25 to 20 this week. Trump didn‚Äôt see any additional states tilt solidly to him
column3: but he did see some gains: The swing states of Pennsylvania
column4: Colorado
column5: Iowa and Nevada all moved from leaning to Clinton to being too close to call.

column1: Still
column2: Trump‚Äôs path to a victory is narrow
column3: and any realistic chance rests on his winning Ohio
column4: North Carolina and Florida. As of Thursday
column5: Ohio remained a toss-up. Florida and North Carolina were still tilting toward Clinton
column6: according to the States of the Nation results.

column1: Early voting data for Florida and North Carolina was not yet available this week. In Ohio
column2: Clinton led Trump by double digits among early voters. The project‚Äôs broader polling suggests the state is deadlocked between the two candidates.

column1: In Arizona
column2: Clinton also was solidly ahead among early voters. In the past month
column3: Arizona has gradually moved from a solid Trump state to a marginal Clinton state
column4: although it is still too close to call
column5: according to the project results.

column1: In Georgia
column2: she enjoyed a similar lead among early voters. Overall
column3: Georgia leans to Trump
column4: but his lead narrowed to five percentage points this week
column5: down from eights points last week and 13 points a month ago.

column1: Even in Texas
column2: where Trump enjoys a sizable lead
column3: Clinton has a double-digit edge among early voters
column4: according to project results.

column1: The States of the Nation project is a survey of about 15
column2: 000 people every week in all 50 states plus Washington D.C. State by state results are available by visiting http://www.reuters.com/statesofthenation/

column1: Coming from people who believe in something called ‚Äúspiritual warfare‚Äù‚Äì a nebulous spiritual struggle taking place over and above all the talk about issues and policy positions ‚Äì it is perhaps no surprise that the Religious Right should declare that their messiah ‚Äì Donald Trump ‚Äì is being threatened with witchcraft.

Oh sweet baby Jesus

Not only do they deal in a conspiracy-laden world

column1: Video:
Chuck Todd asked Mook if he believed the email story could cost Clinton the election.
He answered:
I don‚Äôt think so. Look
column2: as I said
column3: we have over 50
column4: 000 volunteers out there. We‚Äôre seeing record early voting numbers in North Carolina
column5: Florida. Look
column6: I would wager in Nevada turnout is so strong among Democrats there Hillary could build an insurmountable lead in the coming days in Nevada. We‚Äôre feeling really good about this record turnout. Over 200 million people in our country now registered to vote. Fifty million of those are young people. We‚Äôre just nose to the grindstone
column7: and we‚Äôre going to finish this out. But people should not take anything for granted
column8: and we‚Äôre going to have to work hard to earn this.‚Äù

column1: Hillary Clinton could put Nevada out of reach for Trump this week
column2: but whether or not that happens is up to the voters. If Democrats continue to vote in overwhelming numbers in swing states
column3: the email story won‚Äôt matter. If Democrats don‚Äôt show up
column4: that is Trump‚Äôs only chance of winning.

column1: The early voting numbers that Hillary Clinton is running up in Florida
column2: North Carolina
column3: and Nevada are no accident. Clinton and the Democratic Party have invested heavily in an extensive get out the vote operation in early voting states.

column1: Democrats already had a strategic advantage in early voting before the 2016 election
column2: but Donal Trump‚Äôs refusal to invest in a substantial get out the vote operation has widened the gap between the two parties in this area.

column1: The final week before the election could be just as vital to Democrats in swing states as election day. If Hillary Clinton piles up big margins in early voting
column2: it could leave minimal drama for election night.

column1: The Democratic early voting plan is working to perfection
column2: now as Mook said
column3: all that is left is for Democrats to put their heads down

column1: 7248;eead7e3d81b9f5a358edd3cf5f903513843e69f7;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-30T18:24:32.286+02:00;Hillary Clinton Maintains Swing State Leads As Comey Email Letter Flops;"By Jason Easley on Sun
column2: Oct 30th
column3: 2016 at 10:52 am Republicans hoped that FBI Director James Comey's letter about new Clinton related emails would swing the election for them
column4: but a new series of CBS News Battleground polls shows Clinton keeping her lead and within 2 points of Trump in Arizona. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: The CBS News Republicans hoped that FBI Director James Comey‚Äôs letter about new Clinton related emails would swing the election for them
column2: but a new series of CBS News Battleground polls shows Clinton keeping her lead and within 2 points of Trump in Arizona.

column1: Battleground tracker found that by a small margin Comey‚Äôs letter made Democrats more likely (net +7) to support Clinton.
In the individual battleground states
column2: Clinton leads by eight points in Pennsylvania 48%-40%
column3: North Carolina (48%-45%)
column4: and in Colorado (42%-39%). The only state of the four polled where Trump has a small two point lead in Arizona (44%-42%).

column1: According to CBS News
column2: ‚ÄúAnd the larger demographic difference defining the race between Clinton and Donald Trump has been a gender gap ‚Äì slightly larger now than the last time in these states ‚Äì that offsets a smaller movement of Republicans to Trump.‚Äù

column1: To put it another way
column2: Hillary Clinton‚Äôs support with women is going up at a larger rate than Republican movement towards Trump.

column1: These are the first swing state polls to be taken since FBI Director Comey released his now infamous letter on Friday. The email story isn‚Äôt moving voters. It is reinforcing the partisanship of the election. Democrats are going to vote Clinton. Republicans are going to vote for Trump
column2: and there aren‚Äôt enough undecided voters to swing the election to Trump.

column1: Republicans were hoping for a Hail Mary touchdown to save Trump
column2: but Clinton continues to lead in critical states with a little more than a week to go before election day. If the Comey letter is the big October surprise
column3: it isn‚Äôt working on voters.

column1: Hillary Clinton Maintains Swing State Leads As Comey Email Letter Flops added by Jason Easley on Sun

column1: 7250;e9b73a19d48d5684e917a700ac63dc7cdf35550e;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-30T09:09:00.000+02:00;Comey‚Äôs October Surprise Blows Up In His Face As Democrats Drop The Hammer On FBI Boss;"Senate Democrats aren‚Äôt playing around with FBI Director James Comey. Four top Democrats sent Comey and Attorney General Loretta Lynch a letter demanding details on the emails that the FBI is investigating by Monday. In the letter
column2: Sens. Carper
column3: Leahy
column4: Feinstein
column5: and Cardin wrote:

column1: Senate Democrats aren‚Äôt fooling around. They want answers
column2: and they want them right now. As more details become known
column3: FBI Director Comey‚Äôs motives have come under criticism. Comey was advised by Attorney General Lynch not to send his letter until after the election
column4: but he sent it anyway.

column1: Comey worried to FBI employees that his letter would be misunderstood
column2: but he could have easily avoided any misunderstanding by either being specific in his letter or not sending the letter at all. It is becoming difficult to look at Comey‚Äôs actions in an objective manner and not see partisan political motivations.

column1: The FBI Director has interfered in a presidential election with new emails that have nothing to do with the Democratic nominee
column2: but can be used by her opponents for political purposes.

column1: Democrats are demanding answers
column2: and if James Comey doesn‚Äôt answer their questions by Monday
column3: he will be forced to under oath if the Democratic Party wins a majority of seats in the Senate.

column1: Either way
column2: Comey‚Äôs October surprise has blown up in his own face.";english;2016-10-30T18:24:32.571+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;Comey‚Äôs October Surprise Blows Up In His Face As Democrats Drop The Hammer On FBI Boss;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/2016-07-07T163623Z_1_LYNXNPEC6616G_RTROPTP_4_USA-ELECTION-CLINTON-COMEY.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7251;5fe76ede82363337a089c485c00df641106907af;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-30T23:43:27.358+02:00;George W. Bush‚Äôs Ethics Lawyer Files Complaint Against FBI Director James Comey;"Richard W. Painter wrote in a New York Times an op-ed: The F.B.I.‚Äôs job is to investigate
column2: not to influence the outcome of an election.

column1: Such acts could also be prohibited under the Hatch Act
column2: which bars the use of an official position to influence an election. That is why the F.B.I. presumably would keep those aspects of an investigation confidential until after the election. The usual penalty for a violation is termination of federal employment.

column1: And that is why
column2: on Saturday
column3: I filed a complaint against the F.B.I. with the Office of Special Counsel
column4: which investigates Hatch Act violations
column5: and with the Office of Government Ethics. I have spent much of my career working on government ethics and lawyers‚Äô ethics
column6: including two and a half years as the chief White House ethics lawyer for President George W. Bush
column7: and I never thought that the F.B.I. could be dragged into a political circus surrounding one of its investigations. Until this week.

column1: This is the second complaint to be filed against FBI Director Comey. The Democratic Coalition Against Trump has also filed a complaint against Comey for interfering in a presidential election as a federal employee.

Suspicion around Comey‚Äôs actions has grown as the FBI Director is not expected to make any additional statements on this matter before the presidential election. Director Comey appears to have set himself for problems after the election as Senate Democrats are making it known that they are open to holding hearings to investigate the FBI investigation if they win back the Senate majority.
Unless Trump wins and Republicans take control of Congress
column2: Director Comey is going to have to answer for his decisions.

column1: As the complaints pile up
column2: it looks like Congressional testimony may be the least of James Comey‚Äôs future problems.";english;2016-10-30T23:43:27.358+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;George W. Bush‚Äôs Ethics Lawyer Files Complaint Against FBI Director James Comey;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/Screen-Shot-2016-07-05-at-11.09.14-AM.png;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7254;d848d98c0a1204020668ed3a9fdb576946dbb95c;0;Jason Easley;2016-10-31T01:27:53.964+02:00;The Top Democrat In The Senate Just Accused FBI Director James Comey Of Breaking The Law;"Here is the full text of Sen. Reid‚Äôs letter to Director Comey: Dear Director Comey:
Your actions in recent months have demonstrated a disturbing double standard for the treatment of sensitive information
column2: with what appears to be a clear intent to aid one political party over another. I am writing to inform you that my office has determined that these actions may violate the Hatch Act
column3: which bars FBI officials from using their official authority to influence an election. Through your partisan actions
column4: you may have broken the law.

column1: The double standard established by your actions is clear.
In my communications with you and other top officials in the national security community
column2: it has become clear that you possess explosive information about close ties and coordination between Donald Trump
column3: his top advisors
column4: and the Russian government ‚Äì a foreign interest openly hostile to the United States
column5: which Trump praises at every opportunity. The public has a right to know this information. I wrote to you months ago calling for this information to be released to the public. There is no danger to American interests from releasing it. And yet
column6: you continue to resist calls to inform the public of this critical information.

column1: By contrast
column2: as soon as you came into possession of the slightest innuendo related to Secretary Clinton
column3: you rushed to publicize it in the most negative light possible.

column1: Moreover
column2: in tarring Secretary Clinton with thin innuendo
column3: you overruled longstanding tradition and the explicit guidance of your own Department. You rushed to take this step eleven days before a presidential election
column4: despite the fact that for all you know
column5: the information you possess could be entirely duplicative of the information you already examined which exonerated Secretary Clinton.

column1: As you know
column2: a memo authored by Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates on March 10
column4: makes clear that all Justice Department employees
column5: including you
column6: are subject to the Hatch Act. The memo defines the political activity prohibited under the Hatch Act as ‚Äúactivity directed towards the success or failure of a political party
column7: candidate for partisan political office
column8: or partisan political group.‚Äù

column1: The clear double-standard established by your actions strongly suggests that your highly selective approach to publicizing information
column2: along with your timing
column3: was intended for the success or failure of a partisan candidate or political group.

column1: Please keep in mind that I have been a supporter of yours in the past. When Republicans filibustered your nomination and delayed your confirmation longer than any previous nominee to your position
column2: I led the fight to get you confirmed because I believed you to be a principled public servant.

column1: With the deepest regret
column2: I now see that I was wrong.

column1: Sincerely
Senator Harry Reid
Reid basically accused Comey of violating the Hatch Act by releasing his letter so close to a presidential election. Even though Harry Reid is retiring

column1: 7255;f0a355c588c85dc1a559be96baf8ee2064ae1f4e;0;Sarah Jones;2016-10-31T03:32:38.003+02:00;October Shocker: FBI Has Explosive Information on Trump Conspiring With Putin;"By Sarah Jones on Sun
column2: Oct 30th
column3: 2016 at 8:59 pm Senator Harry Reid dropped the bomb that the FBI and national security experts possess ""explosive information"" about ties and coordination between Russia and Donald Trump and his campaign. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: Talk about burying the lede.
In Senator Harry Reid‚Äôs letter in which he suggests that FBI Director James Comey may have broken the law (the Hatch Law)
column2: he also drops the bomb that the FBI and national security experts possess ‚Äúexplosive information‚Äù about ties and coordination between Russia and Donald Trump and his campaign.

column1: Reid writes
column2: ‚ÄúIn my communications with you and other top officials in the national security community
column3: it has become clear that you possess explosive information about close ties and coordination between Donald Trump
column4: his top advisors
column5: and the Russian government ‚Äì a foreign interest openly hostile to the United States
column6: which Trump praises at every opportunity.‚Äù

column1: Reid points out the ‚Äúdisturbing double standard‚Äù in Comey‚Äôs treatment of sensitive information between the two parties with a ‚Äúclear intent‚Äù to aid one over the other.

If the FBI and national security experts have information that Donald Trump and or his campaign are colluding or collaborating to bring about a particular result regarding the U.S. election or our foreign policy stances
column2: this is an emergency.

column1: Which issue is so much of an emergency that a federal official might consider dropping the bomb just 11 days before an election: Electing someone who is conspiring with Russia or electing someone whose aide may have sent an email she forget to tell everyone about.
The double standard is not only troubling at this point
column2: but dangerous.

column1: Bomb dropped.
Everyone already suspected Trump‚Äôs ties to Russia and his campaign has been full of ties to the Kremlin
column2: but now Reid has confirmed information about coordination between Trump and Russia.

column1: Now that
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: is an October shocker.

column1: Reid‚Äôs full letter follows:
Dear Director Comey:
Your actions in recent months have demonstrated a disturbing double standard for the treatment of sensitive information
column2: with what appears to be a clear intent to aid one political party over another. I am writing to inform you that my office has determined that these actions may violate the Hatch Act
column3: which bars FBI officials from using their official authority to influence an election. Through your partisan actions
column4: you may have broken the law.

column1: The double standard established by your actions is clear.
In my communications with you and other top officials in the national security community
column2: it has become clear that you possess explosive information about close ties and coordination between Donald Trump
column3: his top advisors
column4: and the Russian government ‚Äì a foreign interest openly hostile to the United States
column5: which Trump praises at every opportunity. The public has a right to know this information. I wrote to you months ago calling for this information to be released to the public. There is no danger to American interests from releasing it. And yet
column6: you continue to resist calls to inform the public of this critical information.

column1: By contrast
column2: as soon as you came into possession of the slightest innuendo related to Secretary Clinton
column3: you rushed to publicize it in the most negative light possible.

column1: Moreover
column2: in tarring Secretary Clinton with thin innuendo
column3: you overruled longstanding tradition and the explicit guidance of your own Department. You rushed to take this step eleven days before a presidential election
column4: despite the fact that for all you know
column5: the information you possess could be entirely duplicative of the information you already examined which exonerated Secretary Clinton.

column1: As you know
column2: a memo authored by Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates on March 10
column4: makes clear that all Justice Department employees
column5: including you
column6: are subject to the Hatch Act. The memo defines the political activity prohibited under the Hatch Act as ‚Äúactivity directed towards the success or failure of a political party
column7: candidate for partisan political office
column8: or partisan political group.‚Äù

column1: The clear double-standard established by your actions strongly suggests that your highly selective approach to publicizing information
column2: along with your timing
column3: was intended for the success or failure of a partisan candidate or political group.

column1: Please keep in mind that I have been a supporter of yours in the past. When Republicans filibustered your nomination and delayed your confirmation longer than any previous nominee to your position
column2: I led the fight to get you confirmed because I believed you to be a principled public servant.

column1: With the deepest regret
column2: I now see that I was wrong.

column1: Sincerely

column2: the Supreme Court decided to weigh in on transgender rights in the case of Gloucester County School Board vs. G.G . This gives the right wing another chance to take civil rights away from people they don‚Äôt like. Plain and simple.

column1: At issue is whether a transgender student who identifies as a boy has a right to use the bathroom that corresponds with the gender he identifies with.
Last summer
column2: the court granted the school board‚Äôs request to put a lower court ruling in the student‚Äôs favor on hold until the board filed its petition for review by the Supreme Court. Justice Breyer joined the conservative justices in that ruling as a courtesy.

column1: The Virginia school board established a policy mirroring ‚Äúbathroom police‚Äù laws in red states like North Carolina that required students to use rest rooms and locker rooms to correspond with the gender they were assigned at birth.
In this case
column2: the district court ruled against G.G. by relying on a 1975 regulation allowing schools to provide ‚Äúseparate toilet
column3: locker room and shower facilities based on sex‚Äù provided those facilities are comparable to those provided to the opposite sex.

column1: In January 2015
column2: the Department of Education‚Äôs Office of Civil Rights issued a letter opining that if schools separate students in restroom and locker rooms based on their sex a ‚Äúschool must treat transgender students‚Äù in a manner consistent ‚Äúwith their gender identity.‚Äù

column1: Because of that letter
column2: the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit reversed the lower court ruling in favor of G.G. It relied on a 1997 Supreme Court decision that courts generally should defer to an agency‚Äôs interpretation of its own regulation.

column1: 7269;998bab06aaf9ffa34b3feefe39182bc3dcc977af;0;Sean Colarossi;2016-11-01T02:56:53.827+02:00;New Report Uncovers Secret Trump Server That Repeatedly Communicated With Russia;"By Sean Colarossi on Mon
column2: Oct 31st
column3: 2016 at 8:47 pm While the media continues to focus on the Clinton email non-story
column4: news about Donald Trump's ties to Russia continues to gain steam. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: While the media continues to focus on what is increasingly becoming a non-story ‚Äì FBI Director James Comey‚Äôs vague letter regarding more emails related to Hillary Clinton ‚Äì news about Donald Trump‚Äôs ties to Russia continues to gain steam.
Not only did NBC just report that the FBI is now in the preliminary stages of investigating Trump‚Äôs ex-campaign manager‚Äôs connection to Russia
column2: but Slate also reported on Monday that a Trump server may have repeatedly been communicating with a Russian bank.

column1: Slate claims that while a group of computer scientists was looking into the Russian cyber attack of the DNC
column2: they stumbled onto something unexpectedly.

column1: The report:
In late July
column2: one of these scientists‚Äîwho asked to be referred to as Tea Leaves
column3: a pseudonym that would protect his relationship with the networks and banks that employ him to sift their data‚Äîfound what looked like malware emanating from Russia. The destination domain had Trump in its name
column4: which of course attracted Tea Leaves‚Äô attention. But his discovery of the data was pure happenstance‚Äîa surprising needle in a large haystack of DNS lookups on his screen. ‚ÄúI have an outlier here that connects to Russia in a strange way
column5: ‚Äù he wrote in his notes. He couldn‚Äôt quite figure it out at first. But what he saw was a bank in Moscow that kept irregularly pinging a server registered to the Trump Organization on Fifth Avenue.

column1: More data was needed
column2: so he began carefully keeping logs of the Trump server‚Äôs DNS activity. As he collected the logs
column3: he would circulate them in periodic batches to colleagues in the cybersecurity world. Six of them began scrutinizing them for clues.

column1: The researchers quickly dismissed their initial fear that the logs represented a malware attack. The communication wasn‚Äôt the work of bots. The irregular pattern of server lookups actually resembled the pattern of human conversation‚Äîconversations that began during office hours in New York and continued during office hours in Moscow. It dawned on the researchers that this wasn‚Äôt an attack
column2: but a sustained relationship between a server registered to the Trump Organization and two servers registered to an entity called Alfa Bank.

column1: This news doesn‚Äôt come out of nowhere. Trump has repeatedly praised Vladimir Putin as a strong leader
column2: all while taking pro-Russia positions throughout the campaign that come straight off a Kremlin wishlist.

column1: The Clinton campaign was quick to jump on the report in a statement by Clinton Senior Policy Adviser Jake Sullivan:
This secret hotline may be the key to unlocking the mystery of Trump‚Äôs ties to Russia. It certainly seems the Trump Organization felt it had something to hide
column2: given that it apparently took steps to conceal the link when it was discovered by journalists.

column1: This line of communication may help explain Trump‚Äôs bizarre adoration of Vladimir Putin and endorsement of so many pro-Kremlin positions throughout this campaign. It raises even more troubling questions in light of Russia‚Äôs masterminding of hacking efforts that are clearly intended to hurt Hillary Clinton‚Äôs campaign. We can only assume that federal authorities will now explore this direct connection between Trump and Russia as part of their existing probe into Russia‚Äôs meddling in our elections.
Trump‚Äôs pro-Russia rhetoric and policy positions are not a coincidence. The more information that comes out
column2: the clearer it is that the Republican nominee has connections to Russia that he is hiding from voters.

column1: With just a week until Election Day
column2: this is the explosive story the media should be focusing on. It‚Äôs critical that the American people know what kind of financial ties a potential president has with an American adversary
column3: especially when that adversary is Russia.";english;2016-11-01T02:56:53.827+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;New Report Uncovers Secret Trump Server That Repeatedly Communicated With Russia;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/24877259689_02fabb19c9_b.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7273;44225bfcf0b8acdae9a647db9f88af2909175e1e;0;Rmuse;2016-11-01T16:06:37.902+02:00;North Carolina Republicans Sued For Rigging the Election For Trump;"By Rmuse   10:00 am The voter suppression tactic is right out of the GOP [election rigging] playbook to suppress the Black vote in North Carolina.‚Äù   *The following is an opinion column by R Muse*

Some Americans are likely aware of the psychological term ‚Äúprojecting‚Äù that roughly means a person attributes their own faults and actions onto someone else; as an ‚Äòunconscious‚Äô form of transferring guilt for one‚Äôs own actions. As soon as the Republican primaries concluded
column2: Donald Trump projected Republicans‚Äô guilt for election rigging
column3: either through vote obstruction or suppression
column4: onto Democrats and his opponent Hillary Clinton. Republicans have been actively suppressing votes since the election of Barack Obama in 2008
column5: and they have only ramped up their ‚Äò election rigging‚Äô activities over the past eight years; and yet Trump accuses Democrats of election rigging as frequently as most human beings draw breath.

column1: Yesterday
column2: the North Carolina conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) filed a lawsuit against North Carolina Republicans and demanded they put an immediate stop to the ‚Äú coordinated effort to suppress the Black vote in the state .‚Äù What the NAACP rightly said was that the voter suppression tactic was ‚Äú right out of the GOP [election rigging] playbook to suppress the Black vote in the state. ‚Äù

column1: The election rigging amounts to three counties in North Carolina canceling voter registration of thousands of
column2: mostly African American
column3: Democratic residents a week before the presidential election. The lawsuit charged election officials in Beaufort
column4: Moore
column5: and Cumberland counties of denying primarily African American voters‚Äô eligibility to participate in democracy because their voter registration documents mysteriously were ‚Äú bounced back as undeliverable. ‚Äù

column1: Most of the voters whose eligibility to vote was denied and flagged for purging
column2: such as James Edward Arthur Sr. had moved within the same county and were still legally allowed to cast ballots. Many of the purged voters lived at their ‚Äú original registration address ‚Äù and were victims of a ‚Äú simple postal service error. ‚Äù

column1: Mr. Arthur is an African American who lives in a nursing home and has voted in at least the last 14 elections in the same county he was born and raised in without issue. Arthur testified that he
column2: like thousands of other African American Democratic voters
column3: never received any state or county election documents informing him that his eligibility was denied
column4: or that if he didn‚Äôt attend an appeal hearing to maintain his right to vote he would be denied the right to participate in democracy. Mr. Arthur said

column1: ‚Äú If I knew my right to vote was in jeopardy
column2: I would do whatever I could to protect it. I want and plan to vote in the upcoming election
column3: but I am concerned that since my registration has been canceled I will not be able to cast a ballot or it will not be counted .‚Äù

column1: It is what any sane human being would consider ‚Äú election rigging ‚Äù simply because the tri-county ploy targeted primarily African Americans who typically vote for Democrats. It is also something North Carolina Republicans have been guilty of for the past six years.
According to the NAACP lawsuit
column2: North Carolina Republicans are in violation of the National Voter Registration Act which ‚Äú bans the systemic removal of voters from the rolls in the final 90 days before an election .‚Äù Republican election officials State officials defended their ‚Äú election rigging ‚Äù and said they were justified in ‚Äú purging tens-of-thousands ‚Äù of mainly African American Democratic voters‚Äô eligibility
column3: the definition of systemic
column4: on an individual basis.

column1: However
column2: the NAACP also accused Republicans of conducting a coordinated mailing campaign for the sole purpose of challenging the eligibility of thousands of mainly African American voters‚Äô eligibility who did not receive the mailing. One Republican who ran for a local office last year
column3: Shane Hubers
column4: challenged the registration of voters
column5: ‚Ääthe majority who are them Democrats
column6: ‚Ääin Beaufort County.

column1: In one of the other counties charged in the lawsuit
column2: Cumberland County
column3: one ‚Äú individual used returned mail to challenge the registrations of 3
column4: 951 mostly Democratic voters .‚Äù In Moore County
column5: the secretary of the local Republican Party
column6: N. Carol Wheeldon
column7: challenged approximately 400 mainly African American registered voters; likely because they do not vote for Republicans.

column1: The lead attorney for the NAACP‚Äôs lawsuit
column2: Penda Hair
column3: said that although she cannot yet prove there is a concerted Republican ‚Äú election rigging ‚Äù conspiracy;

column1: ‚Äú We know that in two of the counties
column2: the people who brought the challenges had connections to the local Republican Party. We also know that the pattern of these challenges is very similar across the counties .‚Äù Ms. Hair also noted that
column3: ‚Äú in Moore County the return address of a right-wing group called the Voter Integrity Project appeared on the mail that was used to challenge voters. This is a very pernicious treatment of voters
column4: ‚Äù she said. It is also a deliberate act of ‚Äú election rigging ‚Äù by Republicans.

column1: The president of the North Carolina NAACP
column2: Reverend Dr. William Barber said

column1: ‚Äú We are seeing the worst attempts of voter suppression here in North Carolina that we‚Äôve seen since the days of Jim Crow. The Tar Heel state is ground zero in the intentional
column2: surgical efforts to suppress the voice of voters. These attempts are a direct affront to our Constitution .‚Äù

column1: The NAACP lawsuit is demanding the state reinstate all voters challenged since 2012 using this ‚Äúelection rigging ‚Äù process back on the rolls immediately. The organization also demands that the state notifies the voters that they have been reinstated as eligible voters
column2: and allow them to cast regular ballots early or on Election Day. They have already put in a request for an emergency hearing this week to decide the case.

column1: It might be the case that the NAACP‚Äôs request for a hearing may be granted; especially in light of these new charges arising just days after a federal court ruled that North Carolina Republicans violated the National Voter Registration Act in yet another manner; failing to add tens of thousands of voters to the rolls who registered at a DMV office over the past few years.

Last Thursday U.S. District Court Judge Loretta Biggs ordered North Carolina Republicans to permit those tens-of-thousands of voters to cast provisional ballots. It is highly doubtful that North Carolina Republicans will obey the Federal Judge‚Äôs orders because they have been the recipients of several court orders over their ‚Äúelection rigging‚Äù actions that have had no effect whatsoever or the Republicans would not continue disenfranchising voters.
Republicans have been on a tear to rig elections since the American people first elected Barack Obama as President
column2: and the conservatives on the Supreme Court are ultimately guilty of conspiring with Republicans to suppress
column3: or obstruct
column4: the voting rights of primarily people of color because they don‚Äôt support Republicans. To be perfectly clear
column5: it is irrelevant if it is called voter suppression
column6: obstruction
column7: or disenfranchisement; it is a deliberate attempt to rig elections. And it is only Republicans and the Koch brothers‚Äô outfit the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC)
column8: who are behind each and every attempt in Republican-controlled states to kill democracy by doing what the Republican Party standard bearer Donald Trump is guilty of projecting; rig elections.";english;2016-11-01T16:06:37.902+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;North Carolina Republicans Sued For Rigging the Election For Trump;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/women-voting.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 7275;52fc8f910ed2a40681c9e4574a9751e45ef8c94c;0;Jason Easley;2016-11-01T17:24:02.359+02:00;Trump Kills The GOP With The Lowest Score In History Of Presidential Leadership Poll;"In a major omen of potential election disaster for Republicans
column2: Donald Trump has scored the lowest rating in the history of Gallup‚Äôs presidential leadership poll.

column1: Gallup released their presidential leadership survey
column2: and the results were historically bad for Donald Trump:

column1: Voters rate Trump worse than any other presidential candidate in Gallup‚Äôs records on having the personality and leadership qualities a president should have. Previous readings were taken in late October in the 2000
column2: 2004 and 2008 campaigns. In those years
column3: between 52% and 61% of registered voters said the two major-party candidates had the right personality and leadership qualities ‚Äî a sharp contrast to Trump‚Äôs current 32%. Clinton‚Äôs rating of 51% is one percentage point below the previous low score.

column1: Clinton‚Äôs score
column2: while low
column3: was one point of the range for previous presidential cycles going back to 2000. Trump‚Äôs score was twenty percent below the lowest score in the history of the poll.

column1: Voters aren‚Äôt going to elect a man to be the next president who they view as lacking the basic qualities of presidential leadership. The popular vote total in 2016 may reflect the nation‚Äôs political polarization
column2: but there is a reason why electoral map projections continue to look very good for the Democratic candidate.

column1: Donald Trump has failed the most elemental test for any presidential candidate. He doesn‚Äôt look
column2: act
column3: or behave like a person who has the qualities needed to occupy the Oval Office and lead the United States of America.

column1: The last week before election day tension that is in the air is normal
column2: but the fundamental motivating factors of this contest haven‚Äôt changed. Democrats are holding on to their electoral map advantage
column3: while Donald Trump has become the central issue and question on the ballot.

column1: A ‚Äúveteran‚Äù spy is alleging that Russia is cultivating
column2: supporting and assisting Donald Trump and has been for at least five years. The spy said the response from the FBI was ‚Äúshock and horror.‚Äù

column1: The report alleges that Trump and his ‚Äúinner circle‚Äù have accepted a regular ‚Äúflow of intelligence from the Kremlin and that Russian intelligence claims to have ‚Äúcompromised‚Äù Trump on his visits and could ‚Äúblackmail him‚Äù.
David Corn at Mother Jones reported:
Mother Jones has reviewed that report and other memos this former spy wrote. The first memo
column2: based on the former intelligence officer‚Äôs conversations with Russian sources
column3: noted
column4: ‚ÄúRussian regime has been cultivating
column5: supporting and assisting TRUMP for at least 5 years. Aim
column6: endorsed by PUTIN
column7: has been to encourage splits and divisions in western alliance.‚Äù It maintained that Trump ‚Äúand his inner circle have accepted a regular flow of intelligence from the Kremlin
column8: including on his Democratic and other political rivals.‚Äù It claimed that Russian intelligence had ‚Äúcompromised‚Äù Trump during his visits to Moscow and could ‚Äúblackmail him.‚Äù It also reported that Russian intelligence had compiled a dossier on Hillary Clinton based on ‚Äúbugged conversations she had on various visits to Russia and intercepted phone calls.‚Äù

column1: The former intelligence officer says the response from the FBI was ‚Äúshock and horror.‚Äù The FBI
column2: after receiving the first memo
column3: did not immediately request additional material
column4: according to the former intelligence officer and his American associates. Yet in August
column5: they say
column6: the FBI asked him for all information in his possession and for him to explain how the material had been gathered and to identify his sources. The former spy forwarded to the bureau several memos‚Äîsome of which referred to members of Trump‚Äôs inner circle. After that point
column7: he continued to share information with the FBI. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite clear there was or is a pretty substantial inquiry going on
column8: ‚Äù he says.

column1: In August
column2: Corn reports
column3: the FBI asked the spy for all information related to his findings and he ‚Äúcontinued to share information with the FBI‚Äù which he says made it clear there was a ‚Äúpretty substantial inquiry going on.‚Äù

column1: If this report is accurate
column2: the spy‚Äôs information confirms what Senator Harry Reid says intelligence experts and FBI Director James Comey already shared with him regarding ‚Äúexplosive information‚Äù regarding ties and coordination between Donald Trump and Russia.

column1: This report also rings true given report about the Trump server repeatedly being connected to Russia
column2: including Trump‚Äôs server possibly communicating with a Russian bank.

column1: It also makes sense given the many ties to Russia within Trump‚Äôs own campaign and indeed Trump‚Äôs own rhetoric regarding NATO and Russia. Trump changed the Republican Party platform‚Äôs pro-Ukraine proposals and talked about weakening NATO
column2: both of which mirrored Putin‚Äôs wish list. NBC reported Monday evening that the FBI is in the preliminary stages of investigating Trump‚Äôs ex-campaign manager‚Äôs connection to Russia.

column1: Donald Trump has already been busted for reading Russian propaganda at his rallies
column2: as Newsweek‚Äôs Kurt Eichenwald uncovered an instance of Trump reading propaganda directly from Putin at a rally in Pennsylvania.

column1: Eichenwald pointed out something vital and that is that the Russians have been hacking into American emails and then falsifying them in hopes of impacting the presidential election
column2: ‚ÄúThe Russians have been obtaining American emails and now are presenting complete misrepresentations of them‚Äîfalsifying them‚Äîin hopes of setting off a cascade of events that might change the outcome of the presidential election. The big question

column5: in the process

column1: The answer to why Putin is trying so hard to defeat Clinton might be in multiple reports that he fears her. Unlike Donald Trump

column3: Putin sees Clinton as a ‚Äúforceful proponent of ‚Äòregime change‚Äô policies that the Russian leader considers a grave threat to his own survival.‚Äù

column1: Trump has been acting like someone already groomed by the Kremlin. He‚Äôs been a willing puppet for their dangerous goal of destroying western democracy
column2: he is easily flattered and easily manipulated. It‚Äôs also easy to see how they could have gotten something on him with which to blackmail him ‚Äì see the Billy Bush bus tape of Trump bragging about sexual assault. Trump is easy bait.

column1: The fact that the FBI Director felt compelled to announce something about Hillary‚Äôs emails that turned out to not be about her emails but about her aide‚Äôs emails and even then he wasn‚Äôt sure what they said or even if they were duplicates
column2: but he chose to keep this explosive information about Donald Trump‚Äôs ties to Russia under wraps is very disturbing.

column1: This isn‚Äôt a matter of partisan disagreement about the rules the FBI follows about ongoing investigations. This is a matter of national security at this point if all of these reports from different sources are accurate. But the fact that they come from different sources and that Trump willingly staffed his own campaign with Russian ties and he is advocating for their dream positions and he reads their propaganda straight from the vault so to speak ‚Äî these facts add up to what looks like a terrifying fire of epic proportions.";english;2016-11-01T17:55:04.779+02:00;politicususa.com;US;4617.0;FBI Horrified As Spy Says Russia Has Been Supporting And Cultivating Trump For Years;0.0;http://15130-presscdn-0-89.pagely.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/2016-10-15T180331Z_2_LYNXMPEC9E0FO_RTROPTP_3_USA-ELECTION-TRUMP.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: Russia did hack the Democrats. So all of that email information that the media has been reporting came from a foreign entity that seeks to alter the outcome of the U.S. election.

column1: 7495;799ce12a7a1d189c641b5807621b4718e55170df;0;;2016-11-04T07:00:00.000+02:00;PressTV-US troops could be prosecuted for war crimes;"Military An American soldier talks with Saudi troops. (File photo by the US Army)

column1: 7503;fba8d3da11e05c0f88d8764ad4f610643f46824e;0;Mike Rivero;2016-11-12T23:14:42.938+02:00;Clinton campaign blames FBI director for loss to Trump;"Politics FBI Director James Comey (AFP file photo)

column2: the head of the Clinton campaign‚Äôs opinion research division

column4: outlining ‚Äúearly signals‚Äù as to why the candidate lost the November 8 presidential election

column1: 7508;420411d86ab48c28483cc19a48a29875e63aafff;0;;2016-11-14T07:00:00.000+02:00;PressTV-Catch a glimpse of spectacular Supermoon Monday;"Society Naza says the upcoming full moon will appear up to 14 percent bigger and 30 percent brighter than usual.
The brightest moon in almost 69 years will be lighting up the night sky this week in a treat for star watchers around the globe.
The phenomenon
column2: known as the supermoon
column3: will reach its zenith in Asia and the South Pacific on Monday night.

column1: It will then reach its most brightest mode in North America before dawn on Monday.
Across the international dateline in New Zealand
column2: it will reach its brightest after midnight on Tuesday local time.

column1: If skies are clear
column2: the upcoming full moon will appear up to 14 percent bigger and 30 percent brighter than usual
column3: according to NASA. This image shows a near full moon in Aravica
column4: Arizona
column5: on October 13
column6: 2016. (Photo by AFP)

column1: The moon‚Äôs distance from Earth varies because it is in an egg-shaped
column2: not circular
column3: orbit around the planet.

column1: Since the moon‚Äôs orbit is elliptical
column2: one side (perigee) is about 50
column3: 000 kilometers closer to Earth than the other (apogee).

column1: The word syzygy is the scientific term used for when the Earth
column2: sun
column3: and moon line up as the moon orbits Earth.

column1: When perigee-syzygy of the Earth-moon-sun system occurs and the moon is on the opposite side of the Earth from the sun
column2: we get a perigee moon
column3: which is more commonly known as supermoon.

column1: This coincidence already happened one time on October 16.
On November 14 and December 14
column2: it happens again
column3: as the moon becomes full on the same day as perigee. On November 14
column4: it becomes full within about two hours of perigee‚Äîarguably making it an extra -supermoon.

column1: The full moon of November 14 is not only the closest full moon of 2016 but also the closest full moon to date in the 21st century.
The next time a full moon comes this close to Earth will be November 25
column2: 2034. Loading ... ";english;2016-11-15T23:10:43.492+02:00;presstv.com;CA;38347.0;PressTV-Catch a glimpse of spectacular Supermoon Monday;0.009000000000000001;http://media.presstv.com/photo/20161114/ea0a8574-26ca-4ea0-9a67-c91a95bf83c5.jpg;0;0;0;0;0;state

column2: protest against 'land grab' turns violent;"Sudan This file photo shows people in the Jreif district of the Sudanese capital Khartoum protesting against the government's land policies.

column1: Clashes involving police have erupted in the Sudanese capital Khartoum as hundreds of people demonstrated in protest against the government's land policies.
The peaceful protest turned violent after riot police fired tear gas canisters at the demonstrators in East Jreif district.
‚ÄúOur land belongs to our ancestors and the government wants to give it to investors. We are protesting to save our land
column2: ‚Äù a protester said
column3: regretting that the government had shown no intention of compensating the land owners in case their property was seized.

column1: Some protesters pelted police officers and members of security forces with rocks. Others burned tires and tried to close off all the streets in East Jreif.
Police had a heavy presence with reports saying that 15 trucks of riot policemen armed with batons were deployed in the area.
People stage routine protests in Sudan
column2: complaining about local grievances
column3: but most of the demonstrations are crushed by security forces. A similar demonstration in East Jreif last year led to the death of a protester. Anti-government rallies in April also left two students dead.

column1: There was no immediate report of possible casualties during the Wednesday rally in Khartoum.
A government decision to slash fuel subsidies in September 2013 sparked mass protests in Sudan. Thousands of people took to the streets in the capital and some other towns
column2: calling for President Omar al-Bashir to step down. Human rights groups say about 200 people were killed
column3: hundreds were wounded and more than 800 were arrested in the protests. The government challenges the figures. Loading ...";english;2016-10-26T23:00:24.363+03:00;presstv.ir;FR;18495.0;In Khartoum

column1: 7519;e5fa645ad9b3e57ae3d26f544e7ae3c578df2176;0;;2016-10-26T23:00:28.297+03:00;Secret talks between Mozambique opposition

column1: Secret peace negotiations between Mozambique's opposition leader Afonso Dhlakama and EU mediators were annulled at the weekend after fighting erupted between the country's army and former rebel fighters
column2: local media say.

column1: The meeting aimed to contribute to talks that began in May to find a solution to the conflict between the government and Dhlakama‚Äôs rebel group turned political party Renamo.
We had agreed (with President Filipe Nyusi) that two mediators would come ... to meet me
column2: the independent weekly Canal de Mocambique quoted Dhlakama as saying.

column1: Dhlakama said he had cancelled the meeting after the army increased its presence near the place of the meeting.
There was a violent shootout. I even heard explosions from here
column2: said Dhlakama
column3: who has been in hiding in the central Gorongosa mountains since October 2015.

column1: So I called (chief mediator Mario) Raffaelli to tell him that armed forces had come to ambush me
column2: he added.

column1: Dhlakama quoted the mediator as saying that he was ""convinced"" that the ruling Frelimo party ""wanted to capture me during the meeting.""
It is obvious they have a plan to kill me
column2: he added.

column1: Raffaelli declined to comment on the matter but an EU diplomat
column2: who spoke on condition of anonymity
column3: confirmed that two mediators had gone to Gorongosa for a meeting with the opposition leader.

column1: The diplomat said Dhlakama had told the mediators to ""turn back at the very last moment.""
The political situation in Mozambique has been tense for months with Dhlakama refusing to recognize the results of the 2014 elections
column2: where the Frelimo party was declared the winner. The party has been in power since the southern African country‚Äôs independence from Portugal in 1975. Dhlakama also threatened to seize power by force in the northern half of the country.

column1: Renamo and the Frelimo-led government had been engaged in a civil war for 16 years that was brought to an end in 1992.
Renamo's armed wing has conducted a string of fatal assaults in central Mozambique in recent years as it seeks to increase its share of power.
On October 19
column2: the warring sides resumed a new round of peace talks despite the killing of an opposition negotiator on October 9.

column1: 7520;4c5b264f5c3bfb863c8e2e9d579e1fc86d76b343;0;;2016-10-26T23:00:32.990+03:00;UNESCO passes anti-Israel resolution despite Tel Aviv brickbats;"Palestine The file photo shows a view of al-Aqsa Mosque in East Jerusalem al-Quds.
The United Nations Educational
column2: Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has approved a motion that endorses the right of the Palestinians to the al-Aqsa Mosque compound and slams Israeli provocations around the holy site.

column1: UNESCO's 21-member World Heritage Committee adopted the resolution in Wednesday's secret ballot at the agency‚Äôs headquarters in Paris.

British Defense Minister Michael Fallon says the UK is set to deploy hundreds of troops to the Baltic region in Europe to support its NATO allies in the face of a ‚Äúmore assertive Russia.‚Äù

column1: 7558;917155f8f1de7f051117e7a336ac8bc058166a1f;0;;2016-10-27T12:30:05.535+03:00;The Syria conundrum - Press TV;"On The News Line ¬©AFP
These are some of the headlines we are tracking for you in this episode of On the News Line:
The Syria conundrum

The crisis in Syria is getting more complicated. Many parties are participating in the war. The administration of US President Barack Obama has been talking about sending more sophisticated weapons to the so-called moderate rebels in Syria. But the White House is hesitant and the plan seems to have stalled. The Turks are after for their own agenda in Syria. It‚Äôs been almost two months since Turkey launched its offensive in northern Syria. According to Ankara
column2: the mission is aimed at clearing its border area of ISIL militants and anti-Turkey Kurdish militants. And that has put Turkey on a collision course with the US
column3: which has invested heavily on the Kurdish fighters.

column1: EU threat of disintegration

Things seem to be falling apart in Europe which many believe is under strain from many factors ranging from the Brexit to the rise of the far-right across the European political spectrum to the refugee crisis
column2: which is the worst to hit the continent. The prospect of the European Union seems so bleak that it has rung the alarm in Germany. German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier has warned: ""The financial crisis
column3: the refugee influx into Europe and the shock from the Brexit referendum in Great Britain have brought the European Union into violent turmoil.‚Äù Steinmeier warned that this might lead to the collapse of the EU.

column1: Saudis aim to starve Yemenis

Reports have surfaced that Saudi Arabia is ""deliberately targeting impoverished Yemen‚Äôs farms and agricultural industry."" Increasing evidence suggests that the kingdom is not merely bombing civilians
column2: but it is systematically targeting infrastructure survivors will need to avoid starvation when the war is over. That includes water infrastructures
column3: and even farms. Loading ...";english;2016-10-27T12:30:05.535+03:00;presstv.ir;US;18495.0;The Syria conundrum - Press TV;0.0;http://media.presstv.com/photo/20161027/2befdb13-8836-4aa1-83ff-469cf4051429.jpg;0;0;0;0;0;state

column1: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is pushing for its biggest military buildup near Russian borders
column2: as the Western military alliance continues to harbor perceptions of a Russian ‚Äúthreat‚Äù since the days of the Cold War.

column1: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg will discuss the plan for military deployments to the Baltic states and eastern Poland at a two-day meeting of NATO ministers in Brussels on Wednesday.
The military alliance aims to send ‚Äúbattle groups‚Äù to the Baltic states and Poland early next year. The groups will consist of 40
column2: 000 forces. It will be the biggest military buildup near Russia since the Second World War. More forces would also be deployed if necessary.

column1: ‚ÄúThis is credible deterrence. Not to provoke a conflict
column2: but to prevent conflict
column3: ‚Äù Stoltenberg claimed contradictorily on Tuesday
column4: referring to the planned deployments near Russia. ‚ÄúConcrete proof that NATO can and will deploy thousands of forces to support our allies. And a clear demonstration of our transatlantic bond.‚Äù

column1: The United States
column2: Germany
column3: Britain
column4: and Canada have already agreed to contribute forces to the ‚Äúbattle groups
column5: ‚Äù which are to be deployed to Poland
column6: Lithuania
column7: Estonia and Latvia. Norwegian and Italian fighter jets patrol over the Baltics during a NATO air policing mission from an airbase in Lithuania
column8: May 20
column9: 2015. (Photo by Reuters)

column1: France
column2: Denmark
column3: Italy and other NATO members are expected to contribute forces of their own but have been reluctant so far.

column1: Anti-Russia by default
Russia had previously warned that it would take unspecified measures to respond to the increased activities by the Western military bloc.
It also moved nuclear-capable missiles to its westernmost region of Kaliningrad
column2: near its border with the Baltic countries and NATO member states earlier this month. The Iskander-M cruise missiles are capable of hitting targets across Poland and the Baltics.

column1: NATO was formed during the Cold War as a means of countering the former Soviet Union.
The military alliance suspended all ties with Moscow in April 2014
column2: after the then-Ukrainian Crimea Peninsula voted in a referendum to join Russian territory.

column1: Shortly afterwards
column2: an armed conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine

column2: among the recent batch of hacked emails released by Wikileaks

column1: Kadzik‚Äôs role at the DOJ
column2: where he started in 2013

column1: A Long
column2: Friendly History

column1: Podesta and Kadzik have a long history
column2: one which has surprisingly gone mostly unnoticed during the ongoing Clinton email scandal. As DC helps summarize
column3: Kadzik represented Podesta during the Monica Lewinsky investigation. And in the waning days of the Bill Clinton administration
column4: Kadzik lobbied Podesta on behalf of Marc Rich
column5: the fugitive who Bill Clinton controversially pardoned on his last day in office.

column1: That history is cited by Podesta in another email hacked from his Gmail account. In a Sept. 2008 email
column2: which the Washington Free Beacon flagged last week
column3: Podesta emailed an Obama campaign official to recommend Kadzik for a supportive role in the campaign. Podesta
column4: who would later head up the Obama White House transition effort
column5: wrote that Kadzik was a ‚Äúfantastic lawyer‚Äù who ‚Äú kept me out of jail.‚Äù

column1: As the DC Chuck Ross notes
column2: it is unclear to which case Podesta was referring and whether he was joking about prison. But Podesta was caught in a sticky situation in both the Lewinsky affair and the Rich pardon scandal. As deputy chief of staff to Clinton in 1996
column3: Podesta asked then-United Nations ambassador Bill Richardson to hire the 23-year-old Lewinsky . In April 1996
column4: the White House transferred Lewinsky from her job as a White House intern to the Pentagon in order to keep her and Bill Clinton separate. But the Clinton team also wanted to keep Lewinsky happy so that she would not spill the beans about her sexual relationship with Clinton.

column1: Richardson later recounted in his autobiography that he offered Lewinsky the position but that she declined it.
Podesta made false statements to a grand jury impaneled by Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr for the investigation. But he defended the falsehoods
column2: saying later that he was merely relaying false information from Clinton that he did not know was inaccurate at the time. ‚ÄúHe did lie to me
column3: ‚Äù Podesta said about Clinton in a National Public Radio interview in 1998. Clinton was acquitted by the Senate in Feb. 1999 of perjury and obstruction of justice charges related to the Lewinsky probe. Kadzik
column4: then a lawyer with the firm Dickstein Shapiro Morin & Oshinsky
column5: represented Podesta through the fiasco.

column1: Podesta had been promoted to Clinton‚Äôs chief of staff when he and Kadzik became embroiled in another scandal.
Kadzik was then representing Marc Rich
column2: a billionaire financier who was wanted by the U.S. government for evading a $48 million tax bill. The fugitive
column3: who was also implicated in illegal trading activity with nations that sponsored terrorism
column4: had been living in Switzerland for 17 years when he sought the pardon. To help Rich
column5: Kadzik lobbied Podesta heavily in the weeks before Clinton left office on Jan. 20
column6: 2001. A House Oversight Committee report released in May 2002 stated that ‚ÄúKadzik was recruited into Marc Rich‚Äôs lobbying campaign because he was a long-time friend of White House Chief of Staff John Podesta.‚Äù

column1: The report noted that Kadzik contacted Podesta at least seven times regarding Rich‚Äôs pardon.
On top of the all-hands-on-deck lobbying effort
column2: Rich‚Äôs ex-wife
column3: Denise Rich

column5: 000 to Hillary Clinton‚Äôs New York Senate campaign and another $450
column6: 000 to the Clinton presidential library.

column1: Kadzik‚Äôs current role
In his current role as head of the Office of Legislative Affairs
column2: Kadzik handles inquiries from Congress on a variety of issues. In that role he was not in the direct chain of command on the Clinton investigation. The Justice Department and FBI have insisted that career investigators oversaw the investigation
column3: which concluded in July with no charges filed against Clinton.

column1: But Kadzik worked on other Clinton email issues in his dealings with Congress. Last November
column2: he denied a request from Republican lawmakers to appoint a special counsel to lead the investigation .

column1: In a Feb. 1
column2: 2016 letter in response to Kadzik
column3: Florida Rep. Ron DeSantis noted that Kadzik had explained ‚Äúthat special counsel may be appointed at the discretion of the Attorney General when an investigation or prosecution by the Department of Justice would create a potential conflict of interest.‚Äù

column2: a Republican
column3: suggested that Lynch‚Äôs appointment by Bill Clinton in 1999 as U.S. Attorney in New York may be considered a conflict of interest. He also asserted that Obama‚Äôs political appointees ‚Äî a list which includes Kadzik ‚Äî ‚Äúare being asked to impartially execute their respective duties as Department of Justice officials that may involve an investigation into the activities of the forerunner for the Democratic nomination for President of the United States. ‚Äù

column1: It is unknown if Kadzik responded to DeSantis‚Äô questions.
Kadzik‚Äôs first involvement in the Clinton email brouhaha came in a Sept. 24
column2: 2015 response letter to Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Chuck Grassley in which he declined to confirm or deny whether the DOJ was investigating Clinton. Last month

column4: in a classified briefing

column1: Scientists have heard hugely unusual messages from deep in space that they think are coming from aliens.
A new analysis of strange modulations in a tiny set of stars appears to indicate that it could be coming from extraterrestrial intelligence that is looking to alert us to their existence.

The new study reports the finding of specific modulations in just 234 out of the 2.5 million stars that have been observed during a survey of the sky. The work found that a tiny fraction of them seemed to be behaving strangely.

column1: 7624;ef1267e70faa01155528a460db096f551c37a35e;0;admin;2016-10-26T19:20:00.000+03:00;US-led coalition killed 300 Syrian civilians in 11 probed strikes ‚Äì Amnesty;"RT October 26
Around 300 civilians were killed in eleven airstrikes conducted by the US-led coalition in Syria
column2: which Amnesty International investigated for its latest report. Amnesty says the US must come clean about the civilian toll of its fight against Islamic State.

column1: Amnesty suspects that US Central Command (CENTCOM)
column2: which directs coalition airstrikes in Syria
column3: ‚Äúmay have‚Ä¶ carried out unlawful attacks‚Äù in Syria
column4: failing to take necessary measures to prevent civilian killings.

column1: ‚ÄúWe fear the US-led coalition is significantly underestimating the harm caused to civilians in its operations in Syria
column2: ‚Äù said Lynn Maalouf
column3: Deputy Director for Research at Amnesty International‚Äôs Beirut regional office.

column1: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs high time the US authorities came clean about the full extent of the civilian damage caused by coalition attacks in Syria. Independent and impartial investigations must be carried out into any potential violations of international humanitarian law and the findings should be made public.‚Äù
Amnesty investigated evidence
column2: including eyewitness accounts
column3: reports by human rights organizations and the media
column4: photographs and video footage as well as satellite imagery
column5: related to 11 suspected coalition attacks in Syria. The group estimates that the attacks have claimed as many as 300 civilian lives. So far none of these deaths has been acknowledged by CENTCOM.

column1: The report published on Wednesday added that the total civilian death toll from coalition action ‚Äúcould be as high as 600 or more than 1
column2: 000‚Äù since the operation against Islamic State (IS
column3: formerly ISIS
column4: ISIL) started in Syria in 2014.

column1: One of the strikes investigated by Amnesty took place in the early hours of December 7
column2: 2015. The attacks hit two houses in the village of Ayn al-Khan
column3: near al-Hawl in al-Hasakah governorate in northern Syria
column4: killing 40 civilians
column5: including 19 children
column6: and injuring at least 30 others
column7: the report said. A d v e r t i s e m e n t

column1: According to an eyewitness account
column2: an initial night strike was followed by a second attack from a helicopter gunship
column3: which hit first responders trying to dig out survivors.

column1: ‚ÄúAt this point I had a two-month-old baby boy in my arms whom I had rescued. The hit caused me to fall and drop him‚Ä¶ I fell into the hole made by the air strike. That was what saved me‚Ä¶ My mother
column2: aunt
column3: wife and children ‚Äì a daughter who was four years old and a son who was two and a half were all killed. The woman and her son who I‚Äôd rescued were killed. Everyone but me was killed
column4: ‚Äù the survivor said.

column1: The strike is believed to have targeted IS fighters. But local Kurdish militia reportedly warned the coalition that there were civilians in the area.
Amnesty said CENTCOM‚Äôs failure to acknowledge civilian deaths in Syria
column2: as well as the poor record of investigating such incidents in Afghanistan and Iraq
column3: poses grave concerns over the toll which the civilian population of Mosul
column4: Iraq is likely to face from the ongoing operation to take the city from IS. The US-led coalition is providing air support for the offensive.

column1: ‚ÄúGiven the likely increase in air strikes by the US-led Coalition as part of the Iraqi offensive to recapture Mosul
column2: it is even more pressing that CENTCOM be fully transparent about the impact of their military actions on civilians. And it is crucial that they adhere scrupulously to international humanitarian law
column3: including by taking all feasible precautions to spare civilians and to minimize harm to civilian homes and infrastructure
column4: ‚Äù said Maalouf.

column1: A similar operation to capture Manbij
column2: Syria
column3: which is far smaller than Mosul
column4: killed more than 200 civilians
column5: Amnesty estimated.

column1: 7635;f764f6f041d15f3d155e190c9faa2af65f436810;0;admin;2016-10-26T19:18:00.000+03:00;Nuclear Reactor in Norway Leaks Radioactive Iodine;"Prison Planet.com October 26
One of Norway‚Äôs nuclear reactors was discovered to be leaking radioactive iodine Monday morning
column2: according to the Norwegian Radiation Protection Authority (NRPA). [1]

column1: In a statement released today
column2: the NRPA said:

column1: ‚ÄúThe radioactive leak was due to a technical failure during treatment of the fuel in the reactor hall. Emissions are low.‚Äù
Experts say contamination levels around the Institute for Energy Technology
column2: in the southern town of Halden
column3: were well within legal limits and posed no risk to the public.

column1: Said Per Strand
column2: deputy director-general at the NRPA
column3: a government regulator:

column1: ‚ÄúOf course it‚Äôs an unfortunate situation but there is a low environmental risk. This is not the sort of leak we want.‚Äù [2]
The radioactive iodine was a byproduct of the uranium which powers the facility.
Staff were evacuated from the institute
column2: but later returned
column3: donning protective gear
column4: to assess the cause and extent of the leak
column5: and halt it.

column1: A senior NRPA official said the incident would ‚Äúmaybe‚Äù be rated a 1 on the International Nuclear Event Scale
column2: which rates nuclear incidents from 1 to 7. By comparison
column3: the incidents at Fukishima and Chernobyl were ranked 7. [3] Source: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

column1: Regulatory officials were frustrated that they were not notified about the leak until today . Atle Valseth
column2: a research director at the Institute for Energy Technology
column3: agreed. He said:

column1: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt sit so close to those decisions but I think we should have informed the authority yesterday. We will have to go through why it wasn‚Äôt reported ‚Äî it wasn‚Äôt good enough that we didn‚Äôt report it yesterday.‚Äù [2]
Strand
column2: the head of safety
column3: preparedness and environment at the NRPA
column4: expressed the regulator‚Äôs frustration.

column1: ‚ÄúWe need to gather more information ‚Ä¶ But we are not happy with the situation
column2: that we were not warned immediately. We will investigate further.‚Äù [3]

column1: The Swiss Radiation Safety Authority (SRSA) said i t has not detected any radiation emanating from the facility
column2: which sits close to the Swiss border.

column1: Mark Foreman
column2: a nuclear expert at the Chalmers University of Technology in Sweden
column3: stressed that the vast majority of the radioactive iodine is trapped inside the fuel
column4: which is contained within a ceramic material. The ceramic-wrapped material is stored inside a metal tube that is welded shut. The tube is inside the reactor.

column1: The iodine would have to leak out of the reactor to enter the reactor hall.

column4: 15:28 CHIP DESIGNER Nvidia has revealed that it crippled its Linux driver to ensure parity with Windows.According to a forum poster at the Nvidia Developer Zone
column5: the v310 version of the drivers for Basemosaic has reduced the number of monitors a user can connect simultaneously to three.The firm's reply to the post was the type of dismissive response that the Linux community has come to expect in its dealings with Nvidia.Nvidia said
column6: ""For feature parity between Windows and Linux we set Basemosaic to [three] screens.""So let's be clear about this. Nvidia has chosen to remove functionality from a Linux driver to ensure that it isn't more capable than the Windows version. This really doesn't sound like the action of a company that wants to get along well with Linux developers and users. So far
column7: Nvidia hasn't indicated whether this is a temporary situation

column10: or the continuing acrimony between the graphics firm and Linux is not over yet.While for most users three monitors are ample
column11: making this a fairly niche problem
column12: it's an example of a company manipulating the marketplace. Of course controlling the flow of progress in order to sell another product is nothing new - video games makers have been doing that since the 1980s.But to control the flow of progress to favour one platform over another is playing ""technology god"" and sets a disturbing precedent. column3: 07:16:45 PM ¬ª Fukushima disaster caused at least 1
column4: 232 fatalities last year as radiation death rate accelerates 7 April 2015
column5: by David Gutierrez (Natural News)According to the most recent report
column6: deaths in Japan attributable to the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster have continued to increase. Last year
column7: the number of deaths increased by 18% over the year before.A March 2011 earthquake and tsunami triggered multiple meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Japan's northeast coast
column8: in what has become the worst nuclear disaster in history. A massive radioactive plume was released by the meltdowns
column9: and the crippled plant has continued to leak radiation into the surrounding environment
column10: including into the Pacific Ocean.A total of about 160
column11: 000 people were evacuated as a result of the Fukushima disaster. More fatalities on the horizon? According to data collected by the Fukushima Prefecture
column13: 232 nuclear-related deaths. The two towns with the greatest number of deaths were both near the Fukushima plant: Namie
column14: with 359 dead; and Tomioka
column15: with 291 dead.The term ""nuclear-related"" means a death that does not result directly from radiation exposure but is caused by a disease later caused by that exposure. Indeed
column16: it is radiation-related diseases -- including cancer
column17: tumors and genetic damage -- that often cause the bulk of health problems and fatalities in cases of radiation exposure.One of the diseases particularly expected to show an uptick after the Fukushima disaster is thyroid cancer
column18: because radioactive iodine from nuclear disasters tends to concentrate in the thyroid gland. An estimated 6
column19: 000 children contracted thyroid cancer following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. It typically takes four to five years for most nuclear-related thyroid cancers to manifest
column20: and as that window approaches many Fukushima parents believe that their children are already showing symptoms. Fukushima officials have tested approximately 300
column21: 000 children and have turned up 100 cases of the disease
column22: in contrast to the pre-disaster rate of one or two per million children.One parent concerned about her child's thyroid cancer risk is Megumi Muto. Muto's daughter
column23: Nana
column24: has been diagnosed with lumps in her thyroid gland
column25: and the lumps are growing. Muto is certain that the tumors were caused by Nana's exposure to Fukushima radiation.""I feel angry
column26: Muto said. ""I think the authorities hide the real dangers and now many more children are being diagnosed.""The health of both of Muto's children has deteriorated after being exposed to the radioactive fallout
column27: she said.""They had rashes on their bodies then nose bleeds. My son's white cells have decreased and they both have incredible fatigue
column28: she said. ""They may not have cancer now but they both have multiple nodules around their thyroids. I'm really worried."" Residents suing government Muto and about 100 other Fukushima residents are currently suing the local and national governments
column29: alleging that the governments failed to protect their children during the nuclear disaster.This sentiment was echoed in a recent report
column30: released by a parliamentary panel
column31: which said that the Fukushima incident was
column32: in part
