7983;f1f3709c0526dd5686b2c1f610e567e619a34e71;0;Quintus Curtius;2016-11-07T22:01:07.903+02:00;What Fran√ßois De La Rochefoucauld Has To Teach Us About Cynicism;Is there any merit in taking a cynical view of life? Are the observations of cynicism realistic
column2: brave observations on human nature
column3: freed from sentimentality
column4: or are they only the somber commentary offered by one who is a loser at the game of life
column5: taking solace in his weakness and failure? There are compelling arguments either way. What is not disputed
column6: however
column7: is that Fran√ßois de La Rouchefoucauld was one of the most brilliantly cynical epigrammers who ever lived.

column1: It probably did not help that he came from a long line of noblemen
column2: for nothing so enfeebles the soul as much as inherited wealth and titles. He was born in 1613 and inherited the title of duke on the death of his father in 1650. Receiving the usual education of his class
column3: he dabbled in military matters in his teens. Various itinerant love affairs followed with well-placed women
column4: but some of these ended badly; we find him imprisoned in Bastille for a week in 1636 for political intrigue.

column1: Although married
column2: he continued to pursue other women
column3: as was the custom of the time and his station. Marriages in those days were business affairs to be ignored at each party‚Äôs pleasure or necessity; one such dalliance resulted in an illegitimate child
column4: but the woman eventually rejected him for a more appealing competitor. In 1652 he found himself mixed up with a quasi-revolt called the Fronde
column5: an adventure that left him with impaired sight when he was struck with a musket ball in the head. Health problems also intervened to add to his misery in the form of gout and melancholy.

column1: In late seventeenth century France
column2: the Paris salons were centers of debate
column3: discussion
column4: and the flowering of controversial ideas. By now La Rochefoucauld had acquired an acrid talent for stinging prose
column5: and he knew how to use it. His failures in love and war had primed his spirit for a cynical view of life
column6: and this predilection meshed well with the taste of the salons for savage wit. Nothing is so shallow as sophistication.

column1: From his frequent visits to the salon of Mme. de Sable in Paris
column2: he had begun to piece together a body of epigrams that represented his worldview. One of his peers had more commercial goals in mind
column3: for a bootleg collection of 189 of his sayings was first published without his permission (and with no attribution) in 1663. Two years later he finally put out a proper edition; this contained 317 maxims. The volume was titled Sentences et maximes morales
column4: but this is usually shortened to Maxims.

column1: There is a philosophy here. It centers around the idea that all men are self-seeking egoists to a fault; any ‚Äúvirtue‚Äù a man displays is only a smokescreen concealing his self-love: ‚ÄúOur virtues are only vices in disguise.‚Äù Human vanity takes precedence over nearly all else: ‚ÄúVirtues are lost in self-interest
column2: as rivers are in the sea.‚Äù Even the nobler emotions like love and altruism
column3: according to La Rochefoucauld
column4: are only a ‚Äúkind of traffic in which self-love ever proposes to be the gainer.‚Äù He took a dim view of women
column5: finding them fit only for love (for men such as himself
column6: of course) and procreation. One of his crueler maxims was ‚Äúfew women‚Äôs worth lasts longer than their beauty.‚Äù

column1: But life‚Äôs realities eventually caught up with him
column2: softening his rougher edges. His wife
column3: who had cared for him in his infirmities for eighteen years
column4: died in 1670; his mother‚Äôs death followed two years later. Two of his sons would eventually die of injuries received in France‚Äôs ruinous wars of the period.

column1: This gloomy picture was brightened by the entry into his life of the Mme. de La Fayette
column2: who was twenty years his junior. She invited him to stay with her in Paris
column3: and he was carried there with difficulty. She seems to have viewed him as a reform project; she would later say that ‚ÄúHe gave me understanding
column4: but I reformed his heart.‚Äù Perhaps his fame made him an interesting captive. The union worked
column5: and seemed to alleviate his dark picture of humanity; and when his final hours came
column6: he asked for
column7: and received
column8: the last rites of the Church in 1680.

column1: A fair assessment of La Rochefoucauld must take into account his undeniable wit
column2: his probing sensitivity
column3: and his ability to strip away the pretenses behind many human actions. Yet all in all
column4: his maxims are meager in result. Many of them are superficial and shallow
column5: the product of a personality still nursing the wounds of an early disillusionment. We weary of his aphorisms after two or three pages
column6: and hesitate to reopen his book later.

column1: Worse still
column2: he was wrong to say that virtue and altruism are shams. Nothing is more vital to life
column3: and we can see them around us every day
column4: if only we know where to look
column5: and as long as our senses are not blinded by fear. Timor animi auribus officit
column6: as Sallust says: fear blocks out the ears.

column1: Any bitter weakling can be a cynic
column2: but it takes depth of character to accept the world‚Äôs‚Äîand man‚Äôs‚Äîfaults and foibles
column3: and to balance those against man‚Äôs unquestioned capacity for greatness of soul. Broader life experiences might have corrected La Rochefoucauld‚Äôs errors
column4: but he preferred to remain in a state of arrested development while receiving the applause and notoriety of Paris society. His maxims can bring smiles to our faces
column5: as it is easy to find amusement in the flaws of others; yet we forget that his barbs were directed at us as well.

column1: Montaigne was far wiser
column2: for he took a balanced view of life
column3: accepting the world‚Äôs absurdities and joys with the equanimity and calm resolution of a Greek or Roman sage. He was also a better man. La Rochefoucauld was intelligent without being wise
column4: and never found the confidence in himself to submit his ego to the consolatory power of a higher philosophical authority in any form. Cynicism
column5: in the end
column6: strips a man of his most important protective armor
column7: and leaves him naked to face the cruelties of life. No cynic ever died a happy man.

column1: Read More: 7 Tips On How To Get Into The Best Shape Of Your Life

column2: what gets grabbed in a panic? What should you get? What should you count on still being available? We‚Äôve got three categories: guns
column3: ammo
column4: and components/accessories.

column1: Guns Anything that‚Äôs big on the liberal hit list is a first target for a ban
column2: so it‚Äôs a first target for a panic. Look for things that are popular with the right
column3: and scary to the left. Also look for things that are modern; no one is going to ban the M1 Garand anytime soon.

column1: Evil features matter more than destructive power. Anyone who knows anything about guns knows that the AK-47 and the AR-15 fire intermediate cartridges that are puny enough to be considered inhumane in several states with which to hunt deer as they lack the power to kill the animal with marginal shots. However
column2: they‚Äôre black and have mean things attached to them
column3: so they‚Äôre on the shit list
column4: while a nice blued with wooden stock scoped bolt action rifle in a magnum cartridge capable of wrecking your world from twice the distance that an AR can pull is safe as it looks ‚Äútraditional.‚Äù

column1: They have to be popular to the left to get noticed; rifles like the FAL and anything based of the G3/HK91 action simply don‚Äôt have enough exposure to get targeted
column2: unless they pull something sweeping like the USC 18 922r rules again. The Mini 30 and the M1A might be safe; maybe.

column1: For pistols
column2: pretty much any semi-automatic of the polymer age is fair game to want banned. Oftentimes
column3: stupid rules like restrictive magazine sizes get pushed. 1911s
column4: Hi Powers
column5: other old domestic semi-autos
column6: and revolvers should be safe. Expect the libtards to go after Glocks and the like.

column1: Shotguns seem to be immune these days as there‚Äôs not a whole lot of difference between a hunting gun and a combat gun other than paint and mag tube length. I think the Saigas are still not being imported
column2: and it‚Äôs about the only box mag fed one out there
column3: but anything else makes a good home defense gun that should also be immune to the ammo panic portion as well.

column1: Ammunition Range (full metal jacket) and defense/hunting (hollow or soft point) cartridges in popular centerfire calibers and 22 Long Rifle will almost literally evaporate from your local store and online
column2: and it‚Äôs probably beginning as I write this.

column1: Oddly enough
column2: only certain rounds will suffer panic buying. For rifles
column3: it‚Äôs limited to .223/5.56
column5: and .308/7.62√ó51. Traditional hunting rounds like 30-30
column7: and .270 do not seem to be impacted. Why doesn‚Äôt 30-06 get bought in a panic? As the old joke goes
column8: men with 30-06‚Äôs don‚Äôt panic
column9: but it really has to do with the feedback cycle I mentioned at the start. If there‚Äôs little demand
column10: it cannot exceed the in-store supply
column11: so the perception of it being gone for good cannot occur.

column1: Everything but the shotgun shell and the howitzer round to the far right will sell fast in a panic.
Panic bought pistol ammo is the big 3: 9mm Luger
column2: 40 S&W
column3: and .45 ACP. .380 will round out the affected semi-automatic rounds
column4: and there usually is a bit of a run on .357 Magnum and .38 Special as well. 10mm
column5: .357 SIG
column6: .45 GAP and other magnums like the .44 do not seem to be affected.

column1: For rimfires
column2: .22 Long Rifle just goes poof
column3: while its Magnum brother and smaller
column4: 17 caliber
column5: cousins do not seem to be as affected. Rimfires are not reloadable
column6: and this contributes to their over-stockpiling.

column1: Components and Accessories Most centerfire ammo is reloadable
column2: and the serious amongst shooters will roll their own for economy
column3: self-reliance
column4: and performance
column5: so the consumable components will also get some panics. Although I‚Äôve held off on reloading articles until I get my press set back up
column6: we can hit up the components that will get panic bought briefly.

column1: Biggest thing is primers
column2: even bigger than the bullets
column3: oddly enough. The primer is the little metal cup that gets smacked by the firing pin and sets off the powder in modern cartridges
column4: and they come in two sizes for pistols
column5: two for rifles
column6: and of varying hardness to satisfy military specifications.

column1: The second is gunpowder itself. Fortunately
column2: there‚Äôs a wide variety of smokeless powder
column3: and everyone tends to have the brands and formulas they prefer
column4: so it takes a little less of a hit than the primers. The third is the bullets
column5: and since there are so many types and manufacturers
column6: they also take a little less of a hit than primers. While you obviously need all three to reload
column7: bear that in mind. Always save your brass
column8: and anyone else‚Äôs you can pick up.

column1: Even though the little ones are easier to use
column2: the higher capacity ones disappear first. Get both.

column1: While it is always a good idea to have spare springs and small parts like firing pins and extractors that are prone to breakage
column2: the number one accessory or part to take a hit in panics is the box magazine
column3: especially ‚Äúhigh capacity‚Äù ones. I don‚Äôt mean the 200 round drum mags
column4: although those do take a dive
column5: nor do I really mean the 100 round coffin mags
column6: but I mean the full capacity full sized pistol mags
column7: like a 15 round mag for a full sized pistol
column8: or a 30 round AR-15 mag. Expect to see P-mags and surplus style aluminum AR mags just vanish. The Gabby Giffords Special
column9: the extended Glock 17 30 round mag
column10: is also a contender for vanishing fast in a panic.

column1: Holsters
column2: slings
column3: cleaning accessories
column4: optics
column5: and ammo cans seem to be immune from panics.

column1: What to do? If you already own a carbine and/or a semi-auto pistol
column2: make sure you have enough ammo
column3: magazines
column4: and spare parts. It‚Äôs a lot better to have one gun with multiple mags and a lot of ammo than many guns with the one or two mags with which they came from the factory and a couple boxes of ammo.

column1: I try to have at least six mags for my semi-auto pistols
column2: and at least ten mags for my semi-auto rifles. Get some rifle mags of different sizes
column3: the 30 and 40 AR mags are fun for shooting standing up
column4: but they get in the way of prone firing and the 10 and 20 rounders are preferable.

column1: Your ultimate ammo goal
column2: I maintain
column3: should be a thousand practice rounds and 500 defense rounds for each gun you have
column4: but
column5: in a pre-panic or panic situation
column6: just get what you can at a normal price; some is better than none. If you‚Äôre into reloading
column7: you know what to get already.

column1: If you don‚Äôt own anything
column2: and want to soon
column3: refer to some pistol articles
column4: a rifle article
column5: a shotgun article
column6: and a buying guide here. Consider buying some stripped AR lowers to build on a rainy day later on.

column1: Build an AR and meet girls at the range?
Conclusion No matter who got elected
column2: I think this country is in for rough times. It‚Äôs always better to have firearms and not need them
column3: then not have them and need them. Store yours safely
column4: but accessible and ready in times of need.

Andr√© is a young European who left his decaying country in 2012 for greener pastures. He enjoys exploring subterranean places
column2: reading about a host of interconnected topics
column3: and yearns for Tradition. November 11

column1: The existence of intellectuals is more ubiquitous today than ever. Many are those who contend for public attention
column2: credibility
column3: and money as a reward for their wits
column4: not to mention the very status of intellectual. Yet the existence of such people is far from self-evident. For centuries
column5: traditional societies barely had anything or anybody that looked like modern intellectuals
column6: and this did not prevent them from lasting hundreds or even thousands of years.

column1: So
column2: as we elaborate projects and ideas for reforming the depraved societies of the Empire of Nothing‚Äîa necessary step if we want a lasting victory‚Äîan important question must be confronted: do we need at all what has been called ‚Äúintellectuals‚Äù during last centuries? And if we do not
column3: what should we have instead? The origin of modern intellectuals

column1: At the heart of modernity lies a deep crisis. Before it
column2: Western Europe was united by the same Christian faith and a basic agreement on the place of economy‚Äîsubordinated to guilds and the rights of the average producer.

column1: When modernity reared its philosophical head through Ren√© Descartes
column2: a prominent thinker of the seventeenth century
column3: the Old Continent was in a much more problematic state: Christianity had splintered into various opposing faiths whose intellectual opposition was shaking everything to the core. We have been told that the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries were a glorious new flourishing of intelligence. But
column4: in fact
column5: thinkers who actually lived at this time had quite a different impression.

column1: The Irish bishop George Berkeley (1685-1753) criticized how the practice of philosophy had become
column2: on his age
column3: synonymous with getting embroiled into ‚Äúthousand scruples‚Ä¶ prejudices and errors of sense
column4: ‚Äù a situation he attributed to ‚Äúthe wrong use we make of our faculties.‚Äù Likewise
column5: the Scottish philosopher David Hume (1711-1776) scolded his contemporaries for being too eager to criticize the ‚Äúsystems‚Äù of others for the sake of pushing their own on the scene
column6: that is
column7: a mutual hypercriticism that led to a general lack of certitude about everything:

column1: There is nothing which is not the subject of debate
column2: and in which men of learning are not of contrary opinions. The most trivial question escapes not our controversy
column3: and in the most momentous we are not able to give any certain decision. Disputes are multiplied
column4: as if everything was uncertain; and these disputes are managed with the greatest warmth
column5: as if everything was certain. Amidst all this bustle it is not reason
column6: which carries the prize
column7: but eloquence‚Ä¶ From hence in my opinion arises that common prejudice against metaphysical reasonings of all kinds.

column1: The first precursors were honest in their endeavour to solve the crisis. Descartes
column2: Berkeley
column3: Hume and many others genuinely sought a grand encompassing theory that could resume with all controversies. But soon the very controversy became an institution. A whole market of ideas was growing
column4: in which more and more lettr√©s started to see an opportunity to make a name
column5: thus earning fame
column6: social standing and sometimes money. Hume could not help himself: soon after criticizing those who fed the crisis by attacking the others‚Äô ‚Äúsystems‚Äù while promoting their own
column7: he was doing the same.

column1: Such was the so-called Enlightenment: the further undermining of any spiritual
column2: philosophical or cultural unity by ambitious individuals ready to hustle for notoriety. They would be experts at flattering the powerful
column3: mocking the Catholic church
column4: fiddle fashionable themes and ‚Äúwitty‚Äù prose
column5: and more than everything else rationalizing their activity as a ‚Äúprogress.‚Äù The very expression ‚ÄúEnlightenment‚Äù stems from their willingness to market themselves to the posterity. The intellectuals‚Äô bread and butter

column1: It can be noted that
column2: from the amateur gentlemen of the eighteenth century
column3: generations of scientists have sprang up. Some of these characters were mathematicians
column4: engineers
column5: doctors
column6: or dedicated observers of nature
column7: and they all contributed to improving general human power over matter . But make no mistake: even science needs problems and unknown stuff to justify careers and research
column8: thus following a headlong rush dynamic. At its side
column9: the literary intellectuals need more problems so they can have the opportunity to sell themselves through claiming they want to solve them.

column1: The momentous crisis turned into a crisis structure and the structure turned into a mark of the modern West. Where God ceased to speak
column2: the modern talking head took more and more territory and wrote dozens of books trying to prove he was the embodiment of progress. It doesn‚Äôt matter if problems are genuine or artificial. Intellectuals need them like a blacksmith needs iron.

column1: Two typical intellectual characters are Voltaire and √âmile Zola. Both were gifted writers
column2: both were charming and witty
column3: both managed to write about matters that were actually relevant to their times
column4: and both have used a trial with political overtones to make a show of themselves. (Not so incidentally
column5: both were French and participated to the furthering of a twisted literary chauvinism.)

column1: Voltaire took advantage of various trials to claim that the defendants were accused because they were Protestants inside a Catholic country. The infamous affaire Calas
column2: from the name of a father who was accused of having murdered his own son
column3: was used by the shrewd philosophe to sending pathetic letters to the upper crust of the society
column4: stirring the public opinion
column5: pressuring magistrates
column6: until the father‚Äîwho had been convicted and executed after a thorough investigation‚Äîwas rehabilitated. Two centuries and a half later
column7: young Frenchmen are still taught Voltaire was a champion of truth
column8: justice
column9: and reason
column10: whereas he was more like a playwright who peddled influence.

column1: Zola
column2: more than a century later
column3: did the same. A Jewish-French captain
column4: Alfred Dreyfus
column5: was convicted for high treason after he allegedly communicated secret documents to Prussia. Years later
column6: some new evidence seemed to indicate that Dreyfus was innocent and that another officer had leaked the documents: at this very moment
column7: Zola published an incendiary article
column8: J‚Äôaccuse
column9: where he spat on the judges and cried about the injustice of the affaire . Eventually
column10: Dreyfus was rehabilitated‚Äîand the army
column11: the patriots and the Catholics were shamed through a never-ending media discourse that casted them as villains of the whole story.

column1: Voltaire and Zola played the same role in a narrative of the exact same kind. We are taught about a situation of injustice
column2: where the majority of the population is oppressing an innocent group through an innocent individual and crooked institutions. Fortunately
column3: a heroic talking head rises
column4: miraculously converts the opinion to recognize the poor innocent victim as such
column5: the talking head is crowned as an awesome thinker beyond boundaries whereas some are fairly vilified as ‚Äúoppressors
column6: ‚Äù and the poor victim‚Äôs rehabilitation is also the victory of reason
column7: justice
column8: and progress.

column1: Thus
column2: the intellectuel in the most typical sense is a highly paradoxical creature who becomes taught in classes after having seemingly rebelled against dominant institutions. Teenagers are led to think that heroic and highly intelligent individuals can turn the tide of unfavourable opinion‚Ä¶ provided they follow a mysterious sense of history. There have been a lot more intellectuals than the mere classics
column3: and often those rejected by the official narrative are more interesting than those inside. Who‚Äôs gonna pay?

column1: Even if you are gifted with words and language
column2: being a talking head does not pay much. Would anyone be ready to pay you for giving an opinion
column3: no matter how elaborate
column4: on anything? The problem of money is a good starting point to connect the dots: Voltaire was close from wealthy Protestants bankers
column5: one of whom even helped him to obtain a house in Geneva
column6: and Zola was a Rotschild prot√©g√© . Both of them contributed to tarnish Catholicism and most of their own people. In other words
column7: they served interests that could pay them‚Äîthey were sellouts.

column1: Today
column2: some bloggers happen to earn money as independents
column3: especially when they found themselves a niche. Yet independence is scarce. Way too many people would like to live from their wits
column4: and
column5: even more
column6: obtain recognition as intellectuals. More than often
column7: intellectual types turn into teachers
column8: journalists
column9: or even marketers‚Äîthus depending upon an institution that pays them.

column1: In North America
column2: the war against whites and masculinity is massively subsidized
column3: whether in the academic or in the media. You won‚Äôt easily find a job there if you take a critical stance on cultural Marxism. And in case you wouldn‚Äôt be self-hating enough
column4: they are already replacing you with ‚Äúminority‚Äù individuals who are rewarded for spewing wordy venom daily.

column1: Old Marxism was well-aligned with the interests of intellectuals as a class
column2: not as individuals. It handed them an official status and flattered their ego by casting them as the vanguard of ‚Äúprogress.‚Äù Keynesianism triumphed for the exact same reason as it justified the creation of a bloated State where model-obsessed nerds enjoy a tremendous power over those who produce actual wealth. Intellectual types historically joined the left because it gave them a status
column3: money
column4: and moral recognition.

column1: But the whole Marxist vocabulary of ‚Äúprogress‚Äù and ‚Äúemancipation‚Äù dissimulated what seems glaring today. Namely
column2: that intellectuals were recognized and paid
column3: not because they were enlightened or bright
column4: but because they were an efficient tool of destruction.

column1: The conservative right has often lacked a milieu for intellectual types. The average conservative was reluctant to pay someone he saw as a parasite. Such a lack pushed a number of high IQs to the arms of the left
column2: who made an establishment out of them and paid them to enforce globalism
column3: anti-whiteness

column5: pathological altruism
column6: transgender madness
column7: ‚Äúpolitically correct‚Äù repression and so on. Intellectuals were never paid to say the truth: they were paid as tools who performed a primarily destructive social function.

column1: If we happen to beat cultural Marxism

column3: we have to think about what we will replace the bobo -leftist establishment. The intellectual mediocrity and spinelessness of the average conservative is no solution. A truly traditional society would likely have initiates
column4: something akin to high priests and knights
column5: in lieu of vacuous and coward talkers. How exactly we go there or how exactly this could look today is another question. Conclusion

column1: The French essayist Alain Soral once famously said
column2: ‚Äúa journalist is either a whore or without a job.‚Äù This is even truer for most intellectuals
column3: sold as they are to a destructive left or (more seldomly) to the inefficient right.

column1: Culture is overrated. What the mainstream refers to under that name is a giant matrix
column2: full of lies
column3: taboos
column4: and the snobbery of talking heads who end up lying to everyone or believing into their own bullshit. No wonder why the shrewd Robert Greene advised to be an ‚Äúintense realist‚Äù: one must cultivate inner intuition and situational awareness not to fall prey to some of the claptrap that constitutes at least eighty per cent of current mainstream ‚Äúculture.‚Äù

column1: The previous generations could join the cultural Marxist establishment and pretend their destructive
column2: ego-laden works were progress. To our generation
column3: this is impossible. Either we stand up for our very existence
column4: even if we must go against more than two centuries of manipulations and lies
column5: or we resign ourselves to an ignominious death. Before we take the power back
column6: a shared awareness must be stimulated
column7: and this is where we enter in direct conflict with the well-funded anti-white
column8: anti-masculine establishment types
column9: whom we must beat on their own field once and for all. Bonus: 6 quotes about the intellectuels

column1: Some of the problems that modern philosophical thinking puts forward appear void of any importance and meaning. [Modern philosophy] features a range of issues that merely stem from an equivocal stance and the confusion of different viewpoints. These issues only exist because they are poorly framed. They have no fundamental reason to exist. In many cases

column8: 2016 Masculinity

column1: Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong are household names because they were the first men to land on the moon. And while Neil is perhaps the more-remembered of the two because he was technically the ‚Äúfirst‚Äù to land on the moon
column2: Buzz is just as remembered because of his unique name (while I bet most of you don‚Äôt know who the third guy was). But technicalities of who landed where first and who had cool names aside
column3: Buzz Aldrin will forever be one of the world‚Äôs greatest historical figures because of his unrivaled accomplishments and will die a better man than the vast majority of us.

column1: But did you know Buzz Aldrin was an alcoholic? And after retiring he fell into a severe depression? And after his divorce his days consisted of drinking alone in his apartment
column2: fetching KFC and booze until he entered rehab?

column1: It‚Äôs a hard fact to believe. Where a man who seems to have everything (fame
column2: a super-accomplished career
column3: and least of all
column4: the titanium-strong professionalism and self-discipline to become an astronaut)
column5: yet he ends up down
column6: depressed
column7: drunk
column8: and perhaps even suicidal like any other ordinary piece of trailer trash. But while it doesn‚Äôt make sense at first
column9: and you can‚Äôt see how this relates to you
column10: realize there‚Äôs a VERY good and simple reason for this fall from great heights. The Buzz Aldrin Syndrome

column1: Understand as we use the internet to accumulate the wisdom and knowledge to rocket past our contemporaries and excel in life
column2: a problem is festering that you are unaware of. Additionally
column3: much like Alzheimer‚Äôs
column4: it is not prevalent today
column5: but as humans advance more and live longer
column6: it will become increasingly common. Therefore
column7: we have the option to identify it today
column8: prepare for it now
column9: and thus avoid the pain and insanity that comes with having a problem we can‚Äôt identify

column1: or
we can have it devastate our lives later.
It is the Buzz Aldrin Syndrome.
The Buzz Aldrin Syndrome is where a man achieves such greatness
column2: such accomplishments in life
column3: that he is truly unrivaled and peerless. While exhilarating at first
column4: perhaps even earning one fame
column5: riches
column6: and fortune
column7: the success also unintentionally alienates the person from the rest of society. At the time Buzz Aldrin only had three or four other astronauts who he could REALLY talk to
column8: confide in
column9: and relate to. The remaining 3 billion people on the planet (at the time) were just star-struck
column10: wide-eyed sheep. Alas
column11: Buzz Aldrin could be surrounded by scores of fans at a party
column12: but still be completely alone mentally.

column1: The syndrome is also exacerbated as one‚Äôs pinnacle achievements in life are likely correlated with retirement. You typically progress in your career
column2: right up until the day you retire. However
column3: here you leave the environment and network you‚Äôve come accustomed
column4: thrived in
column5: and derived your entire agency from. Thus
column6: in a very short period of time you go from the center of attention
column7: the life of the party
column8: the engine of the machine‚Ä¶to a retiree in California
column9: drinking scotch
column10: and eating KFC
column11: longing for the days you could go back to the office again. Without the environment you derived all your worth and value from
column12: you lose purpose in life
column13: you lose mental stimulation
column14: you lose your peers
column15: and very likely sink into a crippling depression. The Perfect Storm

column1: There are seven factors that
column2: when combined
column3: create the perfect storm for the Buzz Aldrin Syndrome to form. And most ROK readers either have these traits are affected by them: 1. Technological Advancements

column1: Technology has always advanced
column2: but in this particular case it affects us in two specific ways. Making living expenses cheaper and allowing for more and easier ways to make money.

column1: As opposed to the 1800‚Äôs
column2: most of a man‚Äôs life was spent toiling in the field. He didn‚Äôt have time to contemplate loftier or heavier subjects much like the purpose of life
column3: what is man‚Äôs reason for being
column4: etc. You had to worry about the plague
column5: tetanus
column6: your wife dying in labor
column7: and whether there‚Äôd be enough crops to survive the coming winter. But today
column8: through economics
column9: capitalism
column10: agricultural technology
column11: etc.
column12: a single man can basically eat for near-free at Wal-Mart or the local grocery store.

column1: Technology has also freed us from work. Not so much from the fact we have to work
column2: but in terms of how much time we need to spend on it in order to survive. No more than a decade ago a young man had to work 40 hours a week
column3: 10 for a commute
column4: and likely for an inept baby boomer boss who was never going to let you get past the cubicle plantation. Now
column5: with the internet not only can a man give the proverbial finger to rush hour and a commute
column6: but his boss as well
column7: making whatever minimalistic modicum of money he needs to survive through online entrepreneurship. In short
column8: it has never been easier to satisfy Maslow‚Äôs first three and vital hierarchy of needs
column9: freeing a man‚Äôs mind to pursue his own excellence
column10: not to mention ponder his point and purpose in being here. 2. Minimalism

column1: It is no secret that red pill men practice
column2: or at least pursue minimalism. We know that material things do not matter
column3: as it is the love and friendship from our fellow man
column4: friends
column5: family and loved ones that matter most. You know that it would be ‚Äúnice‚Äù to have that Shelby Super Snake Mustang
column6: but you‚Äôd never trade it in for a lifetime of conversations and cigars with your best friend. Additionally
column7: we value our freedom above all else and refuse to subjugate ourselves to becoming debt slaves by buying things we plain don‚Äôt need.

column1: Jettisoning these material desires liberates more of our finite lives from work and a commute
column2: to once again pursue our passions
column3: our fields
column4: our adventures
column5: and our lives. In simply refusing to buy a McMansion and take on a car loan
column6: we guarantee we will live more interesting and rewarding lives than 90% of our peers. 3. Avoiding Divorce And Unwanted Children

column2: we are fully aware of what to look for

column1: 8003;82678242567f585a51c3fed5802eb2490ca0e7f3;0;Roosh Valizadeh;2016-11-14T20:01:25.101+02:00;The Dangers Of Romantic Love;"Since we were children

column1: I began to question the notion of romantic love when thinking about its emotional root. Love is a fleeting emotion

column2: where partners are picked based on purely practical matters

column1: Romance was invented

column1: Romantics re-defined what relationships should be based on
Prior to the romantic era
column2: companionate love was the relationship form often described in literature and other historical writings.

column1: The modern era has doubled down on the notion of romantic love Jewish psychologist Robert Sternberg proposed the popular triangular theory of love
column2: which is often used today as defining the love ideal. This theory has caused immense harm for stating that all three forms of love are needed in equal measure for a successful relationship.

column2: or who reads a pop psychology book

column1: Romanticism and the rise of nationalism
If nationalism came out of the romantic era
column2: and passionate love was a mistake
column3: does that mean nationalism is also a mistake?

column1: One of Romanticism‚Äôs key ideas and most enduring legacies is the assertion of nationalism
column2: which became a central theme of Romantic art and political philosophy. From the earliest parts of the movement
column3: with their focus on development of national languages and folklore

column7: its role
column8: expression and meaning.

column1: [‚Ä¶] Patriotism
column2: nationalism

column1: Upon closer inspection
column2: it‚Äôs easy to see that the ruling agenda of today
column3: globalism
column4: is essentially ‚Äúworld nationalism.‚Äù Instead of loving your neighbor
column5: and only those who share your unique traditions or race

column1: How should men choose their life partners?

It‚Äôs clear that using romantic love and passion as your primary standard for long-term relationships will lead to failure and maybe even personal catastrophe. You‚Äôll easily come to this conclusion by evaluating your past relationships and the mistakes you‚Äôve made on women who you had intense passion for.
Instead

8004;59e49792e94ba759607f0d1ef5ffeb86c723a175;0;Quintus Curtius;2016-11-14T23:05:12.566+02:00;The Revolutionary Reforms Of Peter The Great;Peter the Great (1672-1725) was one of the pivotal figures of Russian history. His reforms were a product of his personality and his vision for what he wanted Russia to become; and sometimes in history
column2: personality matters more than those vague ‚Äúhistorical forces‚Äù that professional historians like to imagine as controlling the destinies of men.

column1: Russia in his day was still half-barbarous. To rule her he had to be an absolute monarch
column2: and never for a moment doubted his right to be so. His personal habits say much about him: he had little need for sleep
column3: regularly working for fourteen hours (or more) per day. Alcohol was considered
column4: then as now
column5: an acceptable escape from the drudgery of rule; but he knew when to limit his intake
column6: and forbade his ministers from excessive consumption. His sexual appetites were as normal as any man‚Äôs
column7: but he showed little interest in the kind of conspicuous indulgence that characterized most of his contemporaries in western Europe.

column1: He did make a point of choosing mistresses of lowly origin
column2: rather than from titled families; he had no desire for intellectual competition in the bedroom. When Frederick II of Denmark teased him about the type of women he chose
column3: his response was ‚ÄúBrother
column4: my women do not cost me much
column5: but yours cost you thousands of crowns which might be better spent elsewhere.‚Äù

column1: He chose to spend most of his time in the city that bore his name
column2: St. Petersburg. He liked maritime affairs
column3: and wanted to be near the sea. He disliked the atmosphere of Moscow
column4: with its abundance of clergy and freezing winters. It was the army that first felt the effect of his modernization programs. Peter introduced conscription
column5: a professional officer class
column6: and defined periods of service; his naval program was less effective
column7: and most of the vessels built during his reign were not of high quality.

column1: He realized that he would never be able to make Russia into a great power unless he changed the mentality and outlook of the people. And like many rulers before and after him
column2: he underestimated just how difficult this task would prove to be. After his death
column3: many of his reforms were permitted to wither on the vine; but at least some tentative first steps had been made that future monarchs might draw inspiration from. By imperial decree he banished beards in 1698 (an exception was made for the Orthodox Patriarch); this was a shocking step in a country where whiskers had become a symbol of piety and fidelity. Those who insisted on keeping them could do so by paying an income-adjusted annual tax. We are told that some distraught peasants obsessively saved their shaved facial hair
column4: lest they incur some disfavor from the saints.

column1: But there was method to Peter‚Äôs apparent madness. He understood that appearance and thought are connected
column2: and that if a man wished to change one
column3: he had to change the other. In 1700 Peter decreed that all royal officials had to adopt Western-style clothing. Trousers and cloaks were acceptable; caftans or overly ‚Äúoriental‚Äù garb was not. Like Kemal Ataturk two centuries later
column4: he had no patience for backsliders or protesters
column5: whom he swept aside ruthlessly. In social relations
column6: he ended for good the traditional practice of secluding women from public intercourse with men
column7: a habit that had probably been an inheritance from the Mongols.

column1: These reforms gained Peter some bitter enemies among the clergy. For centuries the Russian ecclesiastic establishment had held a near monopoly on education and rural social life; Peter‚Äôs reforms threatened to erode this base
column2: and they saw in him an implacable enemy of traditional belief. They also suspected him of having had too much contact with western Europeans
column3: a fact that‚Äìit seemed to them‚Äìmade him nearly an atheist. Peter did not help matters by openly mocking their rituals and folkways; as he saw matters
column4: it was his responsibility to bring Russia up to par with the other advanced nations of the day
column5: and resistance from obscurantist clerics could not be tolerated.

column1: Peter solved this problem for a time by making himself the head of the Orthodox Church in 1700 when Patriarch Adrian died. He did not appoint a successor
column2: and went one step further in 1721 by abolishing the title of patriarch altogether. In its place he formed a council of clerics that he himself would appoint; with this measure
column3: the Church effectively became an arm of the state. Ecclesiastical grumbling was audible
column4: but Peter wisely refused to venture into disputes with the priests over religious doctrine. He cared about power
column5: not theology.

column1: Slowly he made progress in industrialization. This frankly could only be done with dictatorial power
column2: and to this end he reorganized the traditional Russian boyar system. In place of the old aristocracy
column3: a new one arose that was based on military and civil function. His rule saw some success in mining and textile work: when Peter died in 1725
column4: Russia was exporting iron
column5: and state-sponsored factories made modest gains in cloth manufacture. Protective tariffs were used to shelter the new industries from suffocating foreign competition.To pay for all this
column6: Peter unashamedly taxed everyone in his realm to the limits of their tolerance. State tax revenues rose from 1.4 million rubles in 1680 to 8.5 million in 1724. The majority of this revenue went to the military.

column1: A Russian boyar
Ambitious plans existed for education
column2: too. Peter ordered the old Slavonic alphabet used by the Church to be replaced by a new system (based on Greek letters). He imported printing presses
column3: founded institutes
column4: and organized professional associations to spread the ideas that were current at the time in western Europe.

column1: What was the net result of all this effort? The picture was a mixed one. Reformers are not usually popular
column2: as by their very nature they are required to focus attentions in different directions. Men and horses do not appreciate new stirrups. The peasantry‚Äìalready used to a harsh existence‚Äìfound themselves taxed to exhaustion; Moscow became filled with paupers who alternated between banditry and begging. The nobles hated him with the same ferocity as the French nobles hated Richelieu
column3: and for the very same reason: because he forced them to serve the nation rather than each other.

column1: As his unpopularity grew
column2: Peter resorted more and more to the whip and the dungeon to implement his designs. Perhaps there was no other way. But at the very least
column3: his example pointed the way for future authoritarian leaders who would drag Russia
column4: kicking and screaming
column5: into the modern era. Some of his achievements were lasting and significant
column6: and some were not. In history
column7: even great men must contend with the limitations of their era
column8: and try to balance their own vision with the possibilities granted them by circumstance. It is on this precarious tightrope that all great men walk.

column3: as they should be.

column1: Jones then goes on to make a supremely ironic quote as he talks about a so-called white-lash: He says Trump‚Äôs campaign was based on ‚ÄúThrowing away some of us to appeal more deeply to others.‚Äù Umm
column2: isn‚Äôt that what the entire platform of the Democratic party is
column3: Van? Throwing away
column4: nay
column5: crucifying white men to appeal more deeply to others ? Your entire career is based on just that
column6: Mr. Jones.

column1: 1. CBS Does A Mea Culpa CBS published an article admitting how badly the press is biased

CBS was so stunned it did a full mea culpa on the network‚Äôs shoddy coverage of the 2016 election. This stunning article entitled ‚ÄúThe Unbearable Smugness of the Press‚Äù needed to be written 10 years ago. Better late than never. CBS actually echoed what we in the manosphere and alt-right have been saying since day one with the Op-Ed piece.
This is all symptomatic of modern journalism‚Äôs great moral and intellectual failing: its unbearable smugness . Had Hillary Clinton won
column2: there‚Äôd be a winking ‚Äúwe did it‚Äù feeling in the press
column3: a sense that we were brave and called Trump a liar and saved the republic.

column1: The Eyeball network even admitted the contempt the network has for men like us.
So much for that. The audience for our glib analysis and contempt for much of the electorate
column2: it turned out
column3: was rather limited. This was particularly true when it came to voters
column4: the ones who turned out by the millions to deliver not only a rebuke to the political system but also the people who cover it. Trump knew what he was doing when he invited his crowds to jeer and hiss the reporters covering him. They hate us
column5: and have for some time.

column1: And can you blame them? Journalists love mocking Trump supporters. We insult their appearances. We dismiss them as racists and sexists. We emote on Twitter about how this or that comment or policy makes us feel one way or the other
column2: and yet we reject their feelings as invalid.

column1: Damn. At least some people over there know why we hate them. (That includes this former mainstream media news anchor who defected!)
Shameless Activism Got Marxism? It‚Äôs the guiding philosophy of the alphabet channels

Anyone who has the capacity to perform an iota of critical thinking knows the mainstream media is NOT on the side of the average American. It hates and seethes at traditionalists and works to tear down every institution of Western civilization while attempting to impale the most hated of creatures on this planet
column2: the Evil White Male.

column1: The rebuke of a sorry candidate like Hillary when the socialist shills thought she was a shoe-in caught the smug son of a bitches off guard. Their reactions are priceless
column2: and need to be documented and remembered. These reactions are undeniable proof that blogs like Return Of Kings and web sites like Breitbart and Drudge are sorely needed
column3: indispensable resources in this day and age.

column1: We have not been getting the truth from media for generations. And now
column2: as alternative voices appear
column3: the rift between the two versions of reality grows wider and deeper. The once mainstream media have become nothing but shameless activists for New World Order socialism. The election night ‚Äúhorror show‚Äù only solidifies this point.

column1: We should be proud to be activists pushing our own agenda
column2: if nothing else to balance the scales. The media are NOT friends of the American public. Ultimately
column3: the tired old Socialist media must be dismantled in order for freedom and traditionalism to survive .

;english;2016-11-15T15:01:54.543+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;5 Ways The Media Responded With Butthurt To Donald Trump‚Äôs Victory;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate
8007;3cfc1996d48d111e9a56fed6e0b4999a06d7a0a1;0;Beau Albrecht;2016-11-16T04:00:00.000+02:00;The Sad Saga Of John Walker Lindh, Rebel Without A Clue;  The Sad Saga Of John Walker Lindh
column2: Rebel Without A Clue The Sad Saga Of John Walker Lindh
column3: Rebel Without A Clue Beau Albrecht

column1: My father was a high-ranking student radical poobah and still thinks Castro is the bees' knees. Although this makes me technically a red diaper baby
column2: I rejected all that baloney early on. These days
column3: I write stories - mostly comedy science fiction - as well as maintain a blog mainly about dating advice
column4: political commentary
column5: and my writing projects. November 15
column6: 2016 Culture

column1: John Walker Lindh grew up in the Washington
column2: D.C. area. His family brought him to California when he was ten. In another ten years
column3: he would become known as the American Taliban. While in Afghanistan
column4: he was known as Sulayman al-Faris
column5: one of several Arabic monikers he‚Äôs used over the years. Johnny joins the jihad There are moments when one realizes one‚Äôs vacation is really starting to suck.

column1: When he was twelve
column2: the young Lindh saw Spike Lee‚Äôs rather hagiographic film biography about Malcolm X. That began his fascination with Islam. While a teenager
column3: he used the evocative email [email protected] and made several postings about rap music on Usenet. Sometimes he pretended to be Black
column4: even having the nerve to ‚Äúdis‚Äù Dr. Dre :

column1: $hort Dog does hip hop no glory Wack like Dr Dre and his made-up gangster stories Sellout house nigga living honkey dory Saying he‚Äôs broke in his own pool doing laps All these playground MC‚Äôs fall off like scabs Skills disappear like alaka abracadab
Dr Dre‚Äôs a disgrace selling out to the talcolm He‚Äôll be left dead and naked in the outcome Word to brother Malcolm Dre shirts and hat‚Äôs when will we see his cereal?
So who‚Äôs the poseur there
column2: anyway? I‚Äôm not sure whether to laugh at the sheer impertinence
column3: or cry at the abuse of the English language.

column1: When he was sixteen
column2: he formally converted
column3: beginning his fateful journey. Meanwhile
column4: his family situation was on shaky ground. His father turned gay
column5: living part-time with his male lover
column6: and eventually divorced.

column1: John began his world travels
column2: twice venturing to Yemen
column3: both times for nearly a year. Later
column4: he stayed at a Pakistani madrassa. In May 2001
column5: he went to Afghanistan to fight on behalf of the Taliban. Unfortunately for him
column6: after September 11
column7: American forces went to war with the Taliban. He was captured on November 25 after his unit surrendered in Kunduz.

column1: The CIA questioned him
column2: and he claimed to be an Irishman. (That must have been an interesting conversation
column3: perhaps ‚ÄúAch
column4: begorrah
column5: top o‚Äô the mornin‚Äô to ye!‚Äù Presumably
column6: pretending to be black again wouldn‚Äôt have gotten him very far.) Shortly after
column7: the captive jihadis staged a bloody uprising
column8: and Lindh escaped. Hundreds died
column9: including Mike Spann
column10: one of his interrogators. After that
column11: he was recaptured and‚Äîfollowing some rough treatment
column12: not that I‚Äôm shedding any tears about it‚Äîquestioned again. He announced defiantly that he wasn‚Äôt in the Taliban
column13: but rather Al Qaeda. His actions sealed his doom.

column1: Fighting for the Taliban fruitcakes was a pretty dumb move on his part. His actions after being captured were even dumber. What could he have done differently? In the beginning
column2: he could‚Äôve said he was interested in Islam
column3: and his quest for discovering his spiritual roots took him abroad. Then he could have lied and told them he was press-ganged into the Taliban
column4: and he was quite happy to be freed by his countrymen.

column1: He could have tipped off his interrogators about the planned escape attempt‚Äîpotentially sparing many lives on both sides‚Äîas well as avoiding further criminal charges for himself. Had he given a helpful warning about the uprising
column2: likely they would‚Äôve concluded he was small fry and let him go. After that
column3: he could‚Äôve become the star of the daytime TV talk shows. Then he could‚Äôve given speeches on the anti-war circuit
column4: helping his jihadi buddies by saying they really aren‚Äôt that bad or whatever.

column1: Instead
column2: he ended up faced with ten criminal charges
column3: which could‚Äôve meant three life sentences plus ninety years. Finally getting smart
column4: he copped a plea for twenty years
column5: with the possibility of three off for good behavior. Now
column6: he‚Äôs in Federal prison
column7: making the news back in 2012 by suing for the right to be allowed group prayer . What went wrong?

column1: As Bush the Elder put it
column2: Lindh was ‚Äúsome misguided Marin County hot-tubber.‚Äù Later
column3: he apologized profusely for the remark. Still
column4: I have to say that Bush 41 was onto something with that one; all the criticism he got from that was because the truth hurts .

column1: Things could‚Äôve been different. Lindh didn‚Äôt have to become a renegade. If he‚Äôd made other choices
column2: he could be living a happy life as a productive member of society
column3: rather than counting the days in a prison cell. Still
column4: his environment bears some responsibility for what he became.

column1: He was raised in the Catholic faith
column2: but a stronger grounding in it‚Äîas well as explaining some of the unpleasant realities about Islam to balance out the picture ‚Äîmight have put the kibosh on his journey to jihad. (A liberal environment should at least be able to explain why all that‚Äôs bad. Or has liberalism become too wishy-washy to assert its own values?) There wasn‚Äôt much chance of parental guidance turning him from the wrong path; his mother converted to Buddhism and his father left for the gay community.

column1: For that matter
column2: if he had acquired an appreciation for good music‚Äîbe it Mozart or Metallica‚Äîperhaps he wouldn‚Äôt have been so fascinated by irritating rap music. What kind of white kid is so alienated from his heritage that he pretends to be Black and laughably accuses Dr. Dre of selling out? On that note
column3: as for Malcolm X
column4: didn‚Äôt Lindh have some cultural icons of his own? I have to wonder if he received much grounding in his own Irish-American heritage.

column1: All this is an illustration of what can happen when an impressionable adolescent is cast adrift in an ‚Äú anything goes ‚Äù environment. Islam speaks in absolutes
column2: enjoining right conduct and forbidding haram conduct
column3: and they fight for what they believe in. (I can‚Äôt fault them too much for that
column4: although I disagree with their theology and actions on many points.)

column1: Going further
column2: Islam offers paradise for believers‚Äîpromising seventy virgins to their martyrs‚Äîand eternal hellfire and brimstone for the damned; there‚Äôs nothing wishy-washy about it. Indeed
column3: embracing radical Islam could be interpreted as an utter rejection of the ‚Äúanything goes‚Äù world view. I certainly don‚Äôt agree with Lindh‚Äôs choices
column4: but I can see how he found that compelling in comparison to being at sea in moral relativism .

column1: This certainly isn‚Äôt the first time that people turned their backs on their countries and went abroad to give aid and comfort to the enemy. Jane Fonda‚Äôs North Vietnam adventure comes to mind; an action she now regrets. More recently
column2: there were about five hundred misguided youths who volunteered to be human shields in Iraq for their pal Saddam. For all their posturing
column3: none of them got themselves blown up over there. (Leaving aside the question of whether or not the resumption of war was justified
column4: 500 fewer Social Justice Warriors would‚Äôve helped cleanse the gene pool a bit.)

column1: Then there‚Äôs the odd case of Matthew Todd Miller
column2: a Californian who went to North Korea
column3: tore up his visa
column4: and announced he was seeking political asylum. That one‚Äôs an iffy case though; later he said ‚ÄúI just wanted to speak to an ordinary North Korean person about normal things.‚Äù Kids these days‚Ä¶ In summary Don‚Äôt let this happen to our youth. They must not grow up culturally bereft.

column1: In times past
column2: children were taught about their country‚Äôs heritage
column3: instructed in their culture
column4: and pride in their nation was instilled in them. It was a given that these were presented as good things. These days‚Äîat least in much of the Western world‚Äîthis isn‚Äôt happening. We can‚Äôt count on the educational system‚Äîand certainly the media‚Äîto do that any more.

column1: Because of decades of cultural Marxism
column2: young people are indoctrinated with a negative view of their own civilization. ‚ÄúAll societies
column3: beliefs
column4: and ways of life are equal
column5: except yours are terrible.‚Äù Those who don‚Äôt see through that baloney end up rootless
column6: alienated
column7: and disconnected from their own culture. Some even end up thinking that their homeland is the embodiment of all evil while repressive regimes abroad are wonderful. This is basically what Social Justice Weenies think
column8: something they have in common with young jihadi rebels without a clue.

column1: This will have to change
column2: of course. Hopefully
column3: the day will come when the media manipulators and educational bureaucrats who pushed cultural Marxism are standing in the unemployment line. For now
column4: we‚Äôll have to pay close attention to the messages that the young people in our lives are absorbing
column5: and help them learn to be secure in their faith and cultural identity. Teach them about their roots and why that‚Äôs important. Don‚Äôt let the TV be your child‚Äôs babysitter. ‚ÄúAnything goes‚Äù is not a standard by which to raise our youth.";english;2016-11-16T05:08:20.478+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;The Sad Saga Of John Walker Lindh
column6: Rebel Without A Clue;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 8008;6cbb712579a5fc859564621ecee3a80f0654ad4a;0;Roosh Valizadeh;2016-11-16T00:00:00.000+02:00;Shopify Erased Our Store From The Internet While I Was Fulfilling 55 Orders;"  Shopify Erased Our Store From The Internet While I Was Fulfilling 55 Orders Shopify Erased Our Store From The Internet While I Was Fulfilling 55 Orders November 15
column2: 2016 Work & Money

column1: To launch a Return Of Kings t-shirt shop
column2: I decided to go with Shopify because of how much easier it is to launch than a self-hosted store. I signed up with them
column3: paid for one year of service
column4: and did a pre-launch with a small group of readers
column5: which resulted in 55 orders. As I began fulfilling them
column6: Shopify pulled the plug on the entire store without warning
column7: both the public storefront and the administrative backend with all our data.

column1: Because of Shopify‚Äôs decision
column2: my customers couldn‚Äôt access their order status
column3: I had no way of informing them of what happened
column4: and I couldn‚Äôt fulfill remaining orders. They put both me and 55 individuals in the lurch for no legitamate reason
column5: forcing me to threaten legal action in order to get enough information to complete fulfillment of all orders. The Backstory

column1: There are many open source solutions for hosting a web store. The problem with them is that it takes extra time to create the store and maintain it
column2: compared to services like Shopify
column3: Squarespace
column4: Bigcommerce
column5: Magento
column6: and others. To get the ROK store up and running as quickly as possible
column7: I picked Shopify because of their competitive prices
column8: not knowing that I was in for a far greater price down the road.

column1: After I set up the store
column2: featuring photos of yours truly in our first t-shirt
column3: I collected email addresses of those who were most interested with participating in the pre-launch. I sent this group an email announcing the store and 55 of them took action
column4: ordering a t-shirt or two. The shirt in question

column1: During this time
column2: I received an email from a Shopify risk analyst by the name of Justin. He asked me to send in identification
column3: which I was happy to do
column4: and then asked me for more information:

column1: Thanks for signing up with Shopify Payments and providing your ID.
In order to complete this initial review and ensure payments continue to be sent to your account we would need a little bit more information.
If you could send me any documentation you may have to validate the business that would be great. Examples would be a business bank statement
column2: business license or business registration documents.

column1: Could you also confirm where you‚Äôre primarily operating your business from?
I sent in my business incorporation documents
column2: my IRS employer number designation
column3: a recent bank statement (from my US-based bank)
column4: and a note of how I often travel through Eastern Europe
column5: but that my business
column6: bank accounts
column7: and tax status all reside in the United States. In spite of that
column8: Shopify unjustly classified me as a foreign business and gave me no means to dispute it.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Shopify Payments is currently only available to companies that are based in Australia
column3: Canada
column4: United Kingdom and the United States
column5: so we are not able to help with payments for your site right now. It‚Äôs frustrating for us to have to turn down good businesses
column6: but we need to make sure we‚Äôre abiding by both US and international regulations. This means that any successful charges you have will be transferred to you on schedule
column7: but you won‚Äôt be able to use Shopify Payments to accept any further payments. [‚Ä¶]

column1: Despite the information provided
column2: our payment processing partner needs to ensure that the shops are based
column3: operating from and have a substantial presence in the United States.

column1: Ultimately
column2: their decision is final and we must respect it.

column1: According to the United States Federal Government and the IRS
column2: my company is American and liable to pay American taxes
column3: but to Shopify
column4: I‚Äôm not an American business. The repercussion from this was that I couldn‚Äôt use Shopify‚Äôs own payment system (Shopify Payments) and had to pay a 2% extra commision on all orders
column5: but this wasn‚Äôt a huge setback since there were many other payment options. I stayed the course because I wanted to do an on-time opening for my readers. I could always change stores later when it was convenient for me. The Disaster

column1: I have a worker based in the United States who maintains the shirt inventory and is charge of shipping them out. He printed most of the shipping labels for the first batch of orders and got ready for shipment. Before he was finished
column2: I tried to log into the admin area of the store to monitor his progress and saw this:

column1: The public storefront was also taken down. There was no longer any way for me to know who my customers were and what they ordered. I couldn‚Äôt even send them an email. I then received this from Justin:
Hello
I‚Äôm afraid that after reviewing your information and website we believe your business presents a level of risk for customer disputes that we will be unable to support on Shopify.
We will transfer your existing payments to you
column2: but will be unable to accept any additional payments on your behalf from Shopify Payments.

column1: I‚Äôm sorry we won‚Äôt be able to help with your business.
Regards
Justin
After I read this email
column2: I was absolutely livid. I‚Äôve been doing business on the internet for over fifteen years
column3: and have never had a situation where a company pulled the rug out from under me and my customers in a way that I would personally classify as fraud.

column1: They allowed me to take 55 orders
column2: begin processing them
column3: and then removed all access so I could not complete fulfillment. Imagine if you bought a shirt from me and then tried to access the store to see the status of your order. You would have no way to know what‚Äôs going on and would probably think that I took your money and ran. Shopify created a situation of unneeded worry for 55 individuals while directly hurting my reputation as if I‚Äôm running some sort a scam operation. The Phone Call To Support

column1: I called support and got on the line with a Level 1 support tech. I told him the situation as calmly as I could. His response: send an email reply to Justin. This was unacceptable because politely complying with him through email beforehand had only resulted in the deletion of my entire store without warning. I demanded to speak with someone from the risk department but the support tech told me there was no way to patch me through since he was working remotely. I was not calling Shopify‚Äôs main office but someone sitting in the middle of nowhere in his pajamas.
I also told the support tech that there was no further information asked of me
column2: that this was a unilateral closing of my shop while I was in the middle of fulfillment. If Shopify is so worried about fraud
column3: why would they leave 55 individuals in a position where they would believe they got defrauded and start initiating chargebacks with their credit card companies? I had no choice but to threaten legal action. I told the support tech that if Shopify doesn‚Äôt give me a way to complete these 55 orders
column4: I would pursue all legal means as a response to what I saw as fraud.

column1: The support tech put me on hold. After a few minutes of chatting with the risk team
column2: he said that they have given him permission to send me a CSV file of all my orders. I decided that this was enough to satisfy the 55 individuals who purchased from me
column3: but it still didn‚Äôt allow me an easyway to process exchanges or refunds if one of my customers was unsatisfied with the shirt.

column1: Before ending the call with the support tech
column2: I told him to relay to Justin and his team that they have created so much ill will by the way they have treated me that I will ensure that everyone knows exactly what they did
column3: not just to me but also to my customers
column4: who had an unfortunate experience because of their e-commerce platform.

column1: Using the CSV file I received
column2: I was able to contact my customers to let them know of the situation and complete fulfillment. Many of them have already received their t-shirts in the mail. The Lesson

column1: Shopify has every right to choose who to do business with
column2: and I would not be particularly upset if they said I have to go elsewhere after fulfilling open orders
column3: but the way they removed all access from my store is absolutely reprehensible and the stuff of nightmares for a business owner. No owner wants to wake up one day and find that everything is gone with no way to contact his customers. I have never been treated so poorly by an American internet business before
column4: and I‚Äôm confident that any business who treats people in this way won‚Äôt be in business for long.

column1: Maybe my situation was special
column2: as I am often abroad
column3: but Shopify operates as if its customers are not even allowed to take a vacation out of the country. If you log in from a certain IP address pool
column4: their algorithms go crazy and here comes Justin to hit the delete button on your store with one click.

column1: Whatever the reason
column2: it‚Äôs important for existing and potential Shopify customers to know that it doesn‚Äôt take much for them to shut you down at any moment and for any cause. They will take all your information and prevent you from contacting customers or fulfilling orders. Your only recourse to receive your data is to threaten legal action
column3: and that may be no guarantee of success. If any of my friends ask me about which web store platform to use
column4: I will strongly warn them against Shopify.

column1: As for the ROK store
column2: I‚Äôve decided to try the open source method. Hopefully we will be ready for orders again within two months. Nov 15
column3: 2016 Roosh Valizadeh";english;2016-11-16T05:08:21.717+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;Shopify Erased Our Store From The Internet While I Was Fulfilling 55 Orders;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 8009;8c6678322c8170b3124fe80995ae7b9891644040;0;Corey Savage;2016-11-14T19:00:00.000+02:00;8 Ways To Forge Strength Through Challenges;"  8 Ways To Forge Strength Through Challenges 8 Ways To Forge Strength Through Challenges
Corey is an aspiring iconoclast. He believes that the key to life is for men to honour their primal nature.
Learn more about his views at theprimalmale.com You can also follow him on Twitter . November 14
column2: 2016 Mind

column1: We
column2: modern men
column3: need to constantly improve ourselves in a hostile world like ours that tries to debase us. While the lesser ‚Äúmen‚Äù embrace weakness and degeneracy
column4: we must embrace strength and discipline. While whiners complain about how unfair the world is and how it‚Äôs better to just disengage
column5: we must engage the world with greater willpower and defeat our enemies. Towards this end
column6: I propose that we become both resilient and antifragile in every way possible.

column1: The following are ways you can turn a seemingly negative circumstances into strengths. 1. Stress
Although stress has been maligned as the plague of the modern world that wrecks our mental and physical health
column2: the way you perceive it makes a profound difference on how it affects you. New studies have shown that those who see stress as being toxic suffered damaging health effects while who saw it as being helpful were able to turn it into a source of energy to push them through their challenges.

column1: So
column2: next time you feel stressed from whatever trouble you may be facing
column3: remember that it is your friend. You must reframe the sensation and believe that it‚Äôs your body trying to help you. By changing how you processes stress
column4: you can use it to succeed in life. 2. Obstacles Your response to obstacles reveal the kind of man you really are.

column1: Whatever obstacles you may face in your endeavors
column2: you have two choices: become frustrated and discouraged by it
column3: or see it as an opportunity to grow stronger. Like stress
column4: it‚Äôs the weaker man‚Äôs inclination to view an obstacle as a confirmation of his own helplessness
column5: but you must do better and face up to whatever gets in your way. Use every occasion to grow stronger from your obstacles and if you aren‚Äôt facing enough of them in your life
column6: you need to get out and start doing more things.

column1: How you deal with obstacle will show your true nature as a man for the world to see. So
column2: don‚Äôt pussy out or moan about what you must overcome; instead
column3: be determined to rise above it. Your honor is at stake. 3. Failures

column1: Failures are inevitable in life. Although you should always try your best to succeed
column2: you shouldn‚Äôt be afraid to fail either. Just as with obstacles
column3: view every instance of failure as an opportunity to learn and adapt. It‚Äôs not failure itself that is bad
column4: but not learning from it or giving up so easily. Remember: winners don‚Äôt quit; they try to do better. 4. Rejection

column1: Rejection is a specific kind of failure that is often the most painful of them all. It‚Äôs especially difficult because it‚Äôs often unclear whether it was actually your fault or not. I would say that it‚Äôs best to assume full responsibility for all the rejections you face and see what area you can improve to better increase your chance next time. As long as you‚Äôre willing to learn and as long as you‚Äôre willing to try again
column2: you will grow. Master rejections and you‚Äôll be placing yourself far above other men. 5. Physical Discomfort This is why Russians are so tough.

column1: It‚Äôs well known that the human body is designed to be anti-fragile. Your bones get thicker with every blow and your skin gets tougher with every scrap. Pain and discomfort of all sorts also become more bearable the more you expose yourself to them. The more harshness you endure
column2: the stronger you become over time. But inversely
column3: the more comfortable you are
column4: the softer you turn and the weaker you get.

column1: One simple method you can implement to become more healthy and energized is to start taking cold showers. The benefits of doing it are many
column2: including: stronger immune system
column3: enhanced mood and energy
column4: better circulation
column5: boost in testosterone level
column6: and so on. If you are having trouble getting started
column7: start by doing just 30 seconds at the end of your usual warm shower and go from there. You want to train yourself until you can comfortably stand under the coldest water for at least five minutes. 6. Fear

column1: You can‚Äôt really turn fear itself into a positive
column2: but the process of conquering your fears can have a transformative effect on your life. Some of the proudest
column3: most exciting
column4: and memorable moments of my life were when I defied fears by doing a presentation in front of hundreds of people (I had a terrible stage-fright)
column5: going rock climbing (I have a terrible fear of heights)
column6: and traveling for the first time by myself to a foreign country.

column1: One thing you can do to completely turn your life around is to do what this man did and make a list of all the fears that you wish to defeat. Write them down in an order from the least fearful to the most and start knocking them down one by one. It‚Äôs impossible not to become a better man once you conquer them all. 7. Anger
Like fear
column2: anger is not something you can transform into a positive trait (I‚Äôve heard of people ‚Äútransmutating‚Äù their anger to re-channel the energy into other activities
column3: but I‚Äôve never had it work that way). However
column4: it is a good focal point to master your mind to become more stoic. It can also serve as your area of focus if you practice meditation.

column1: No matter how unpleasant
column2: your anger will teach you a lot about yourself and only if you allow it. It will reveal your weaknesses
column3: insecurities
column4: and any other areas of your life in need of improvement. As one of the most base and primal of human emotions
column5: you shouldn‚Äôt just shirk it as something that is unneeded; instead
column6: make it your friend. 8. Negativity And Pessimism

column1: For the longest time
column2: I felt guilty about being ‚Äúso negative‚Äù because I was constantly told by everyone else that it was a bad thing. Smile
column3: they said; think positively
column4: they said; your life will improve
column5: they said. I was constantly berated for not being part of the North American positivity cult. It‚Äôs no wonder why people there tend to say that they‚Äôre doing ‚Äúgreat‚Äù even when they‚Äôre feeling like shit (a habit I have yet to fix).

column1: But in contrary to the long held belief that positive thinking and attitude gives you a better life
column2: studies have shown just the opposite: Forced positivity can actually harm you . For some people (like me) positive thinking backfires and makes things worse. Also
column3: bad-tempered people who are pessimists have been shown to enjoy more successful marriages
column4: be healthier
column5: live longer
column6: be better at negotiating
column7: and more successful overall in life. So
column8: if you‚Äôre a natural grouch like me
column9: it‚Äôs time to embrace who you are and tell the fake-ass
column10: positivity people to shove it. Conclusion

column1: The road to self-improvement is an ugly and a bumpy one. I honestly can‚Äôt say that I enjoy it. But no matter what
column2: I know that it is a necessary part of being a man. I can‚Äôt imagine myself not trying to be better in spite of all the difficulties. I refuse to live a life of complacency. Some people mock and insult our efforts
column3: but know that their opinions don‚Äôt matter. Lesser men have no say on what it means to live. So
column4: fight on and prosper
