;english;2016-11-16T22:00:59.183+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;4 Goals For The Neomasculinity Movement During Trump‚Äôs First Term;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate
8012;d7ceb99fe83d5bb287303acb208acb45c0755b74;0;Luke Stranahan;2016-11-17T00:39:38.023+02:00;10 Things I Learned From Being My Own General Contractor;One of the foundations of living a good life in today‚Äôs times is having a good place to call home. Whether you want a solid
column2: comfortable place with which to pursue your hobbies
column3: recover from the day‚Äôs tribulations
column4: and just to be
column5: or whether you want a bachelor pad for your romantic pursuits
column6: or both; a good home is essential to the modern man.

column1: I purchased a home and I decided to be my own general contractor for the renovations. My home was an as-originally-furnished home of the 1970s
column2: and I brought its multi-color painted
column3: green shag carpeted datedness up to a sharply trimmed
column4: hardwood-floored modernity while being of a somewhat timeless style. A general contractor is a person hired by the architect or engineer to run the job site
column5: source the labor
column6: follow the schedule
column7: get the materials
column8: and execute the vision of the plan. Here are ten things I learned as my own general contractor.

column1: 1. There are good contractors
column2: and there are bad contractors

column1: You will run into both good and bad contractors out there. A good contractor does good work
column2: at good value
column3: follows the schedule
column4: and is honest and doesn‚Äôt lie to you. A bad contractor will do any or all of the above. I fired a contractor who had good value
column5: but did poor work
column6: could not follow the schedule
column7: and lied to me. I paid more for a later contractor who did excellent work
column8: hit the schedule on time
column9: and was a perfectionist. Give a bad contractor a second chance
column10: mainly to see how he corrects it; and
column11: if he fails to shape up
column12: cut him loose.

column1: A good contractor has the correct amount of paperwork
column2: but no more. Some firms I turned down did things by hand and had no contractor‚Äôs license
column3: and that is too little
column4: whereas a firm that gives you fifteen pages of legalese allowing them to take out an uncontested mechanic‚Äôs lien on your home if you do not pay is too much.

column1: A lot has to do with the presentation of the representative. Tradesmen are naturally rough people who work with their hands
column2: but a man that does not have a good handshake
column3: good eye contact
column4: and is evasive on important details is shady.

column1: 2. Good contractors cost more
column2: and they are busy The best indicator of a good contractor is that they have a busy schedule
column3: and I mean they are booked often a month or so in advance. The guy I fired kept trying to work me in on the weekends and at night
column4: which
column5: while it SEEMS like he‚Äôs busy
column6: he‚Äôs actually operating in the red and trying to use your funds to cover his other jobs.

column1: A good contractor will negotiate terms up front and not change them
column2: and he will
column3: when awarded the job
column4: put you in his schedule at an agreed-upon time. My best contractor was so busy that I had to do other things first before I could get his firm to bid my work
column5: and they did what good contractors do when they are too busy; they turned down my work until later.

column1: 3. You need to establish a reputation
General contractors in an area have a reputation amongst their customers and the contractors they sub-contract to
column2: and the only difference between those that do it for a living and you is that you have no reputation.

column1: A busy contractor will work with a GC who will give them work in the future over one who will not. I was an unknown
column2: so the busy guys during the busy season (fall and pre-holidays) would pass on me and work with ones they knew.

column1: However
column2: word got around to the others that I gave jobs of good scope
column3: and paid on time. I hired a sub contractor for a set of jobs
column4: and
column5: once they found out who I used as my electrician (it was who they subbed their own electrical jobs to)
column6: they called and the electricians vouched that I was picky as all hell
column7: but paid on time
column8: and let them run their own schedule and have the run of the house. At that point
column9: I was in.

column1: 4. Good contractors know other good contractors

Reputation works the other way too. A good roofer who I only turned down because he was too busy and wouldn‚Äôt meet my timetable has a brother who runs the electrical shop mentioned above. Although you should ALWAYS get multiple competing quotes (bid to three
column2: two will generally respond
column3: and pick the better one)
column4: the deciding factor was that his brother
column5: the roofer
column6: ran a good shop
column7: and it stood to reason he would
column8: too.

column1: My plumbers knew my AC guys and my chimney guy. My flooring guys knew my kitchen cabinets guys. Everyone works with and around everyone else
column2: and I saved all my paperwork and contact info for all my vendors so that
column3: on any future projects
column4: I know who to call for what
column5: and
column6: even if I don‚Äôt know
column7: I know who to ask for recommendations.

column1: 5. It will take more money than you think it will
Home renovation is expensive
column2: and it‚Äôs mainly for the nasty reason that
column3: once you commit to action
column4: you can get hit with extra costs. You can mitigate this with good bid scopes that you give to your contractors so all parties know what is what
column5: but you will find that the home will need things you didn‚Äôt think about
column6: or that the hourly rate of the laborers is higher than you budgeted
column7: or materials will simply cost more.

column1: Part of the balancing act that is required is you will learn what to spend money on now
column2: and what to spend money on later. Right now
column3: I live in the place (finally)
column4: but I still have construction paper down on my floors as I have not yet bought furniture pads or rugs for the high traffic areas. My bathrooms have plumbing in
column5: but no mirrors
column6: cabinets
column7: towel racks
column8: or toilet paper holders. Entire rooms are without furniture. All of these can
column9: and should
column10: be taken care of later
column11: but things like flooring and painting needed to happen earlier.

column1: 6. It will take more time than you think it will You may not need something this complicated
column2: but a Gantt chart shows dependency of one job on others.

column1: Contractors have their own schedules
column2: and there is also the time outside the work time where they have to arrange a site visit
column3: you have to juggle quotes
column4: they have to then write you in
column5: then they do the work
column6: then there‚Äôs follow-ups and punch-lists
column7: and then
column8: finally
column9: that job is done and you pay them.

column1: You can‚Äôt do some other jobs before you finish the first one. This is where having a master schedule and knowing who is doing what and affecting whom matters. My floor guys had to have the run of the place when they were finishing the floors
column2: but they did not when they were laying sub-floor
column3: and I was able to have plumbers in that day as well. Contrariwise
column4: I could not start the kitchen install until after the floors were done.

column1: 7. Some of your ideas are wrong
column2: some are right I had my own thoughts about what to do with the place. Sometimes I was wrong; it was stupid to try to reuse the baseboard that was over the carpet and put it over the hardwood (even though it was the same color) and I listened to my contractor and used new. Sometimes I was right
column3: my backsplash behind my sink was supposed to match the counter-tops‚Äô colors
column4: and the ratio of white I wanted was correct
column5: but I was persuaded to add more by my contractor.

column1: Know what is important in your vision and be able to explain your intent
column2: but the contractor might have a better way of how to do it in mind than if you had told them the how
column3: instead of the what. I have a rather creative way of running the drains on my basement fixtures; they did what I wanted
column4: but did it in a better way than I would have suggested
column5: and they got it almost completely right to my intent in the process.

column1: 8. There will be gaps in your manpower coverage
The one thing a professional general contractor does that you
column2: as a private operator
column3: will not is do all the basic stuff themselves. A GC will hire an electrician to wire fan boxes for mounting fans
column4: but he will install the boxes and hang the fans himself. My electricians did install and hang them for me anyway.

column1: This was for two reasons
column2: and this is how you can mitigate having little shit jobs that no one will want to do as a single job. The first is to provide all the materials yourself
column3: which also allows you to pick out what you want. I had a pile of fixtures
column4: fans
column5: and bulbs laid out for them with a plan of what went where
column6: and this helped them just throw them up after the technical wiring part was done.

column1: The second reason is to provide a good scope of work. Will a plumber come install a single faucet? Maybe. Will he come install five and a garbage disposal? Certainly
column2: that‚Äôs a good day‚Äôs work
column3: so
column4: if you have little jobs
column5: have a LOT of little jobs
column6: and you‚Äôll get more interest.

column1: 9. There are things with which you will not be satisfied; good enough is good enough
This house is old
column2: but renovated. Some things simply cannot be fixed without massive upheaval; I cannot have perfectly flat ceilings because the drywall is 40 years old and it had popcorn texture on it. Some things I did not address; I have new baseboard and new window trim
column3: but the door trim is original and has the nicks and stains of time.

column1: Some things were done
column2: but were not perfect. The drywall where my kitchen cabinets‚Äô bulkhead used to hang from the ceiling has one spot where
column3: even after two reworks
column4: still has a hairline paint crack. Some of the window film has pull away lines
column5: and there‚Äôs a couple things trapped under the film in places. One of the toilets will top itself off for a few seconds signifying a small seal issue. You cannot have perfection
column6: but you can go for reasonable excellence.

column1: 10. Code enforcement sucks The Man sucks. Someone called Code Enforcement on me
column2: and I had to go get a permit of a cost of X% of the renovation‚Äôs cost
column3: mainly so they can jack my taxes up.

column1: I got the permit
column2: and I expect my taxes to go up. The inspector was a real schmuck
column3: as most appointed officials are
column4: but the joke‚Äôs on him
column5: as I only got the permit on what I had left to do and I omitted some things that would still happen
column6: but weren‚Äôt too noticeable.

column1: With code enforcement and county ordinances
column2: the idea is reasonable cooperation and being able to explain things away with saying you were mistaken
column3: instead of flouting the law. I went and got the permit when I was busted for it
column4: but they only know a third of the story. Had I gotten a permit earlier
column5: perhaps whatever nosy neighbor that ratted me out might not have called at all. Another tactic
column6: which I will do on a future project I have planned
column7: is to get the permit months ahead of time
column8: then hit it hard over a few days and be done before anyone notices.

column1: Conclusion If you have the time
column2: the patience
column3: and the skill to know exactly what you want
column4: who to get for it
column5: and how to juggle a massive schedule
column6: running your own home renovation is a lot of fun and very educational. If you want it done faster and just want to deal with one person for everything
column7: then hiring a professional general contractor might be the way to go instead.

8014;eb47acef77e5a0b6576f9ba190f92d537b2ffbe8;0;Roosh Valizadeh;2016-11-17T00:00:00.000+02:00;How ‚ÄúThe Camp Of The Saints‚Äù Predicted The Migrant Destruction Of Europe;  How ‚ÄúThe Camp Of The Saints‚Äù Predicted The Migrant Destruction Of Europe How ‚ÄúThe Camp Of The Saints‚Äù Predicted The Migrant Destruction Of Europe
Daryush ""Roosh"" Valizadeh created ROK in October 2012. You can visit his blog at RooshV.com or follow him on Twitter and Facebook RSS November 16
column2: 2016 Books

column1: Written in 1973
column2: The Camp Of The Saints is a novel by Jean Raspail that predicted the European migrant crisis forty years before it began
column3: not only the actual invasion by brown migrants but also the leftist arguments that enabled it
column4: which ushered Europe to its doom.

column1: The story follows a one-million strong flotilla of Indians who are slowly making their way to Europe. The leaders and people of Europe have decided not to stop their arrival. Light on action
column2: the book focuses on the mood of the pending arrival
column3: particularly how Europeans were eager to cuck themselves into oblivion.

column1: After all your help‚Äîall the seeds
column2: and drugs
column3: and technology‚Äî[migrants] found it so much simpler just to say
column4: ‚ÄòHere‚Äôs my son
column5: here‚Äôs my daughter. Take them. Take me. Take us all to your country.‚Äô And the idea caught on. You thought it was fine. You encouraged it
column6: organized it. But now it‚Äôs too big
column7: now it‚Äôs out of your hands. It‚Äôs a flood. A deluge. And it‚Äôs out of control. [‚Ä¶]

column1: You‚Äôve gone and worked up a race problem out of whole cloth
column2: right in the heart of the white world
column3: just to destroy it. That‚Äôs what you‚Äôre after. You want to destroy our world
column4: our whole way of life.

column1: Raspail understood how the media whips the public into feeling immense guilt as a mechanism to introduce non-white migrants. Well before the globalist view on migration and equality was elucidated
column2: Raspail was steps ahead in predicting what the result of it would be
column3: as if he was reading into a crystal ball. He even knew that migrants would bring diseases like tuberculosis .

column1: And all at once whole sections of New York are deserted
column2: a score of American cities watch the flight to the suburbs‚Äîand half the historic Paris pavement too‚ÄîAmerican tots in their integrated schools fall five years behind
column3: tubercular Gauls flee in droves from our open-air clinics. ‚Ä¶ Tally-ho! Tally-ho! Just listen to that battering ram smash at the southern gate!

column1: The centuries-long segregation of the first and third-world brought great complacency upon Europe. No one could really get a grasp of what was in store once the third-world reached critical mass and started invading the West.
‚ÄúI can tell
column2: ‚Äù Vilsberg continued
column3: ‚Äúthat you really don‚Äôt believe how serious the situation is. After all
column4: we lived side by side with the Third World
column5: convinced that our hermetic coexistence
column6: our global segregation
column7: would last forever. What a deadly illusion! Now we see that the Third World is a great unbridled mass
column8: obeying only those impulsive urges that well up when millions of hapless wills come together in the grip of despair.

column1: In a bittersweet scene
column2: one of the prominent media leftists goes out with his wife to celebrate the arrival of the flotilla with joyous Africans. Towards the end of the party
column3: his wife gets brutally raped by them and he eventually dies in sorrow. The horde‚Äôs arrival suddenly awakened all the immigrants already in the country into asserting themselves. They began stealing directly from the native citizens by attacking their ‚Äúwhite privilege.‚Äù

column1: Now
column2: it‚Äôs a known fact that racism comes in two forms: that practiced by whites‚Äîheinous and inexcusable
column3: whatever its motives‚Äîand that practiced by blacks‚Äî‚Äîquite justified

column1: 8015;f5defdcf23391851cdb597788b4ab98201d1799c;0;Brock Robinson;2016-11-17T16:04:10.667+02:00;5 Reasons You Should Stop Using Facebook;"I remember signing up for Facebook ten years ago. At this point in time
column2: the new social media site was geared mostly toward college students and it was uncommon for anyone over the age of 25 to have an account.

column1: But over the last decade we‚Äôve seen Facebook morph into a $50 billion conglomerate and information kingpin acquiring massive power and wealth from the endless amounts of time users waste scrolling through their news feeds. This beast of a social media platform has gone on to consume the lives of millions
column2: gather nefarious amounts of data
column3: foster unnecessary personal dramas
column4: and often cause more harm than good for its users.

column1: It would be prudent to take a good hard look at your Facebook experience and ask yourself if it‚Äôs something that‚Äôs actually adding value to your life. Here are five reasons why you should think carefully before using the world‚Äôs largest social media site.
1. Your Facebook Feed Is A Black Hole Of Completely Worthless Information
I think it‚Äôs important to create streams of information that add real value to your life. Through platforms such as Twitter
column2: Feedly
column3: and YouTube
column4: I‚Äôve followed writers and content producers that have dedicated their lives to self-improvement
column5: entrepreneurship
column6: higher meaning
column7: and the search for truth.

column1: So you can probably imagine the stark difference between an intellectually curated Twitter feed and the dumbed-down Facebook community of people you went to high school with that peaked in the 12th grade.
Log into your Facebook and the most common information you‚Äôll likely find is who got married
column2: who had kids
column3: and who got fat. Scrolling through your Facebook feed is akin to flipping through a more personalized celebrity gossip magazine at the grocery store checkout line.

column1: Every time I log onto Facebook I‚Äôm immediately reminded why I never log onto Facebook.
2. It‚Äôs No Longer Useful For Dating
In college
column2: I gained some value out of the site by using its chat feature to build up attraction with girls in my social circle and get their phone numbers.

column1: But over the years
column2: most girls have attached the ‚Äúcreepy‚Äù stigma to guys who hit them up via Facebook messenger.

column1: In addition to that
column2: you don‚Äôt really need a Facebook profile for ‚Äúsocial proof‚Äù as you once did since Instagram is a better social media app for meeting girls .

column1: 3. Forfeiture Of Your Privacy

Most people have realized by now that the first thing a potential employer will do after interviewing you is look you up on Facebook. They‚Äôre basically searching for any and every reason not to hire you. Lock your account down as best you can with privacy functions. Don‚Äôt let that one drunk picture of you from 5 years ago ruin a potential job offer.
If that wasn‚Äôt enough
column2: Facebook has a long history of shady activities when it comes to privacy. They‚Äôve already been caught accessing your location without permission. We can only speculate what else they‚Äôve been infringing on.

column1: 4. Censorship
Although Facebook has a right to control the information broadcasted on it‚Äôs platform
column2: that doesn‚Äôt mean they should abuse that right by censoring anything they might find disagreeable or offensive.

column1: Much like an overbearing parent
column2: Facebook proactively controls the discourse of its children
column3: eagerly censoring content that might rub someone the wrong way. Facebook has so many overreaches that an entire website has been dedicated to documenting their affronts on freedom of opinion. You can probably guess which side of the political spectrum they try to stifle.

column1: 5. It Brings Out The Worst In People

Plenty of time has now passed for in-depth research to come out regarding the long-term effects that too much Facebook can have on a person‚Äôs mental well-being. It gives the illusion that everyone else has it better than you and that your life just isn‚Äôt fair. This is a slippery slope into a victim mindset and blaming others for your circumstances. How oppressed these chronic Facebook users are as they sip lattes from a comfy chair in Starbucks and scroll through their Facebook feeds on the latest Macbook.
I won‚Äôt completely deny the merits of Facebook. If you‚Äôre using it to build a brand or a business then it could be a good investment of your time
column2: simply because so many people actively use it. I‚Äôve also witnessed the joy it brings to older users for connecting with long lost friends they haven‚Äôt seen in decades.

column1: But the truth is that in many cases
column2: Facebook does cause more trouble than it‚Äôs worth. It‚Äôs never a bad idea to cut back on your usage or even just opt out entirely. You may no longer be the first to know about an upcoming dinner party or what Brad and Sarah from freshman year have been up to all these years
column3: but I suspect you might be better off as a person.

column2: South Korea has emerged as one of the wealthiest countries in all of Asia. Currently the OECD country is roughly on the same material and economic level as other affluent East Asian nations such as Japan

column1: In this article I do briefly describe the main characteristics of contemporary South Korea

column1: The emergence of modern South Korea Culturally
column2: politically
column3: technologically and economically
column4: South Korean development during the 20th century onward cannot be understood without to mention the strong ties to Japan and the United States. As much as Japan suppressed Korea between 1910-1945
column5: the material progression is nevertheless a direct and indirect consequence of the traumatic colonial period. Korean leaders were also inspired by the Japanese military dictatorship (which in turn was influenced by European militarism). column6: no matter how much money you spend on your mechanisms of control. The more you control what does not want to be controlled
column7: the more tension is created and then released in the great unraveling
column8: of which we are currently living through. In previous eras
column9: that tension resulted in victorious parades on the streets
column10: but in our modern era
column11: it is in the form of online celebrations with the use of tweets and memes.

column1: If you want to be a true leader of society
column2: create an environment where humans can associate with whom they want
column3: can freely engage in commerce
column4: can create families
column5: can live in safety
column6: can search for the truth without interference
column7: and can work and play and live according to their nature. Put stone walls blocking their righteous will and watch them be torn down. It may take a decade
column8: it may take 100 years
column9: but it will happen
column10: and the contraptions you used to control them will reveal not your strength but your own pathetic weakness.

column1: Conclusion We are tired of being controlled. Leave us alone. We are tired of institutions that are obsessed with controlling us
column2: of forcing us to believe in falsehoods
column3: of programming us to hate our country
column4: of pitting woman against man and black against white. Leave us alone! Let men be men
column5: and from that a new American renaissance will come forth. Men who are strong and good must be allowed to live their lives
column6: and if you prevent us from doing so
column7: we won‚Äôt allow you to live yours. We will humiliate your useful idiots
column8: we will destroy your institutions
column9: we will lash out with more than just memes.

column1: I‚Äôm afraid that those who stand against us are gearing up for even greater authoritarian control over us
column2: but at least now we have our man in the White House who can join us in a fight that we have already been battling for many years. I can‚Äôt wait to see where this fight takes us next.

8024;e181d90e896fc986452bf163e0606edce6d81c3a;0;Larsen Halleck;2016-11-21T01:06:05.219+02:00;How Effective Are Books On Fitness?;We‚Äôre all about self-improvement here at Return Of Kings. A man should always be seeking to improve himself in some fashion
column2: and when he has achieved one goal
column3: he should move onto the next one. In short
column4: never rest on your laurels.

column1: Combining this desire for self improvement with the masculine independence and minimalist lifestyle that other writers on this fine website should inculcate in you a desire to improve yourself while being thrifty and relatively solitary. As this article deals with fitness
column2: you know what I‚Äôm going to say: personal trainers
column3: or at the very least
column4: the ones at your average commercial gym
column5: should be avoided at all costs. And while most long-term fitness enthusiasts and professionals will likely either train by themselves or have one of the few trainers that knows what he‚Äôs doing
column6: most of us have to train alone
column7: especially beginners who have naught but common sense to light his path. But there is another option: books

column1: Yes
column2: books
column3: that simple yet elegant method of transferring knowledge directly to its viewer. There are certainly plenty of books out there pertaining to the various fields of fitness and athletics. But the question remains: how effective is a book in physical training?

column1: As an avid reader of fitness-related tomes (and many others
column2: but that‚Äôs neither here nor there)
column3: I own many of these books. And I feel that their effectiveness can be judged by grouping them based on ‚Äúgenre‚Äù.

column1: Weight Lifting and Calisthenics When I first started getting into physical culture as a young teenager
column2: I turned to the nearby commercial gym
column3: as most tyros tend to. In that commercial gym
column4: I quickly found myself being attached to a well-meaning jackass who gave me a machine-heavy program that
column5: according to him
column6: would ‚Äúdevelop strength
column7: size and endurance.‚Äù And like most naive young men
column8: I followed him
column9: developing none of those things
column10: but lining the trainer‚Äôs pockets.

column1: Eventually
column2: realizing that I had been lied to
column3: I embarked on a search for enlightenment
column4: coming to the various corners of the internet that deal in such interests. One of the first things that I came across were books that I have repeatedly referred to in these pages
column5: and still consider to be some of the best writing on general fitness out there‚Äîthe works of men such as Paul Wade and Pavel Tsatsouline. Upon reading books such as Power to the People and the Convict Condidtioning series
column6: and using a bit of common sense
column7: I deduced that these books were superior than the typical tomes on fitness that the commercial gyms would sell at the counter for a few reasons:

column1: One
column2: they advocated a physical philosophy of simplicity and ‚Äúpurity‚Äù. Rather than advocating a julienne of exercises; their routines were efficient and targeted all muscles of the body. Two
column3: the credentials of the men were a cut above the average writer: as a maximum security convict and a Spetsnaz veteran (respectively)
column4: I knew that these men needed to train their muscles to fighting trim for purposes of survival
column5: rather than ‚Äúdoing curls for the girls‚Äù. And third
column6: they referred to the strongmen of old like Maxick and Eugen Sandow
column7: ‚Äústanding on the shoulders of giants‚Äù and opening my eyes to the wider world of fitness writing
column8: much of which I have further consumed.

column1: In general
column2: I would argue that writing on weightlifting and calisthenics are the most effective books on fitness
column3: as these are solitary activities
column4: and the books are typically written by one man speaking to another man. Thus
column5: the techniques there in are written to be easily understood and practiced by the user without a partner.

column1: Martial Arts As I have repeatedly stated on this website
column2: martial arts in general should be taken with a massive grain of salt‚Äîwhile I‚Äôm not so stupid as to say ‚Äúthere‚Äôs no point in training any sort of refined fighting style because of adrenaline‚Äù (and yes I have seen this boneheaded argument made)
column3: I have also spent a substantial amount of time debunking the overly flowery and outright fictitious martial arts styles that many hack authors and film-makers propagate
column4: on my own website as well as my Youtube and Dailymotion channels. Sadly
column5: thanks to martial arts being more or less an unregulated market in the United States
column6: any clown has the full legal right to proclaim himself a ‚Äúmaster‚Äù.

column1: With that being said
column2: some martial arts books are effective
column3: thoroughly explaining the proper mechanics of a move and/or explaining proper situations in how to use them. While I have a background in ‚Äúproper‚Äù study
column4: I have also utilized books to teach aspects of martial arts that I was not formally taught‚Äîsuch as grappling. And again
column5: I sought out accomplished and legitimate fighters that were decorated in their field: men like Farmer Burns ( Lessons in Catch Wrestling and Physical Culture ) and Masao Takahashi ( Mastering Judo ) wrote detailed and efficient books for fighting ‚Äúin the clinch‚Äù
column6: and I have also used Dr. Sang Kim‚Äôs books on Taekwondo such as Complete Kicking for learning some of the more exotic kicks that my own background didn‚Äôt teach me. And of course I practiced on resisting opponents
column7: some of whom had been wrestlers themselves and thus could shore up my technique.

column1: The most important thing to bear in mind when using a martial arts book is that you MUST practice these techniques against a bag/dummy at the VERY least
column2: and preferably with a sparring partner that will put up a fight. And while this is also the case for any book on physical culture
column3: I would argue that it‚Äôs the most important for martial arts‚Äînamely because martial arts techniques are
column4: by definition
column5: used in panic situations. In contrast
column6: weightlifting is almost always done in a state of relative calmness‚Äînot counting the fake screaming idiots use to ‚Äúpump themselves up‚Äù.

column1: Mindset/Meditation/Etc Books such as the Kundalini Meditation Manual by Yogi Bhajan
column2: which I have only recently started to use
column3: are simultaneously the most simple and most complicated books on self-improvement to use. They are simple because in very basic terms the advice they give is basically ‚Äúthink really hard about something‚Äù
column4: but it is precisely that abstractness that can make them difficult-meditation is a nebulous concept for the best of us to grasp immediately
column5: and in some ways changing one‚Äôs mindset and behavior is the most difficult thing anybody can do.

column1: While I admittedly do not have the depth of knowledge in these that I do with the other two topics
column2: I would say that these are hard to grasp but easy to practice once they have been ‚Äúgrokked‚Äù in the words of Anthony Burgess: After all
column3: every second of every day of your life will involve you utilizing your mindset. And thus
column4: its difficulty lies in the original understanding.

column1: Conclusion Looking at these three broad ‚Äúgenres‚Äù of male self-improvement books
column2: we can see that they differ greatly in content
column3: but
column4: speaking from a position of experience
column5: I can safely say that to a great extent they are effective
column6: and they can teach you new things
column7: but only if you get one of the relatively few books that aren‚Äôt written by armchair alpha males
column8: and only if you diligently practice the information contained within them.

column1: 8026;dd539538680da563184571125b2c47897aa4864e;0;How Effective Are Books On Fitness?;2016-11-21T01:47:36.565+02:00;Comment on Why You Should Become a Minimalist by How Effective Are Books On Fitness?;"  Why You Should Become a Minimalist Why You Should Become a Minimalist February 21
column2: 2013 55 Comments Lifestyle

column1: The most abused word in the English language is ‚Äúneed.‚Äù If you‚Äôre reading this post
column2: I contend there is little that you actually ‚Äúneed‚Äù beyond what you currently possess. You have ample electricity to power your computer in a climate-controlled environment
column3: with running water and food in your well-stocked refrigerator. Why
column4: then
column5: do you always hear people talking about how they ‚Äúneed‚Äù more stuff?

column1: Humans have a deeply-rooted drive to compete with each other
column2: and advertisers capitalize on this impulse. Take a moment to picture the average person that you meet. What do they have to take pride in? Buying the newest thing allows them to join the club of consumers
column3: and for a fleeting moment to be measured on an equal playing field despite their personal shortcomings. The internal pain of their life‚Äôs problems dissipates for the split second they can boast superiority over everyone who doesn‚Äôt have the same shiny widget.

column1: This conspicuous consumption creates a self-fulfilling ego-investment in the broken system. Although borrowing money for useless luxury purchases subjugates people into debt slavery
column2: the mentality is ‚ÄúIf I paid $30
column3: 000 for this hunk of metal and I‚Äôm working overtime to pay it off
column4: it MUST be worth it ‚Äî and so are other things that the commercials are telling me to buy.‚Äù Quite literally
column5: we are working jobs we hate so we can buy shit we don‚Äôt need .

column1: If you‚Äôre reading this blog
column2: you are likely a male aged 25-35 who wants to do one or more of the following: quit your job
column3: travel
column4: explore a location-independent income
column5: get yourself in shape
column6: take charge of a relationship
column7: and learn valuable life skills. A minimalist mentality helps you do all of these things.

column1: Having fewer possessions forces you to properly place a higher value on experiences. This will make it safer and more fulfilling to travel because you are in touch with what truly makes you happy. If you‚Äôre working on a side hustle or starting a business
column2: the desire for needless possessions drains your disposable income levels and prevents you from taking risks. ‚ÄúIf my business fails
column3: will I have to give up my car lease?‚Äù Preempt this loss aversion by having less to lose.

column1: If you want to move to a better city with a higher cost of living
column2: having excess stuff sets a floor on how much rent you‚Äôll pay to house your crap
column3: and in turn how much you can spend on leisure activities. If you‚Äôre a distractable person like me
column4: removing visual ‚Äúnoise‚Äù from your area makes you more likely to create things with your mind
column5: and less likely to fixate on your environment .

column1: Throwing or giving useless things away is a good first step
column2: since possessions have a psychic weight that you may not realize until you rid yourself of them. To fully embrace this mindset
column3: you must also kill the desires that have been inculcated in you since birth. Cut down on your ‚Äúconsumer impressions‚Äù by watching less TV and trying to rationally dissect the techniques used in the few advertisements you encounter. Find fulfillment in hobbies and work
column4: rather than chasing the rush and eventual hedonic adaptation from consuming. Much like a drug
column5: successive bouts of consumerism create a higher baseline where your overall happiness is no different
column6: but you end up having a bunch of useless crap that ties you down.

column1: Girls can also be troublesome in this endeavor. Ever notice that when a girl spends extended time in your living space
column2: she beings to tell you that you ‚Äúneed‚Äù a new this
column3: or a replacement that? A good friend once told me ‚ÄúAll human beings have an innate desire to create ‚Äî most women can‚Äôt
column4: so they redecorate.‚Äù Limit your exposure to women who attempt to thwart a separation from consumerism. Ironically
column5: men likely to lead a minimalist/nomadic lifestyle are simply more attractive to prime-SMV women. Think about whether the starving artist or the bottle service guy throwing money around ends up getting more ass. As always
column6: watch how women behave rather than listening to what they say when they are protesting your lifestyle change.

column1: Ask yourself this: If your house burned down and you had nothing but the clothes on your back
column2: what would you be worth to society and to yourself? How would you feel about losing all of the possessions you own? Most people plugged into the matrix would rather die than think about replacing Aunt Gladys‚Äôs vase or baby pictures they haven‚Äôt looked at in a decade. This is an illusion. Once you begin to divorce yourself from this emotional investment to ‚Äústuff‚Äù you will implicitly place more value on your skills and past experiences.

column1: Minimalism is not a synonym for frugality or cheapness. I don‚Äôt wear a potato sack while pedaling a used tricycle to work every day ‚Äî I simply choose to allocate my money to experiences (and a few possessions) that will fulfill me and advance my life‚Äôs purpose
column2: rather than enslave myself into debt for trinkets that will collect dust somewhere.

column1: Taking the red pill is about learning to separate your priorities and desires from those that society forces upon you. I don‚Äôt promise that adopting this mindset will make everybody happy
column2: but it will certainly help to clarify what contributes to your individual sense of self
column3: and will allow you to focus on the internal and external traits that exemplify a man of value.";english;2016-11-21T01:47:36.565+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;Comment on Why You Should Become a Minimalist by How Effective Are Books On Fitness?;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 8027;1588eba1a19ec866177f84fdc214926cc3e8cfff;0;Quintus Curtius;2016-11-21T16:01:35.035+02:00;The Character Assassination Of Baseball Legend Ty Cobb;"By now everyone has been reminded that the media is not infallible. It is composed of very fallible human beings who make mistakes with the same regularity as all the rest of us. I was recently reading a bit about something in statistics called ‚ÄúGalton‚Äôs Problem
column2: ‚Äù an observational dynamic named after its discoverer
column3: Sir Francis Galton.

column1: To state it very crudely
column2: Galton‚Äôs Problem is a situation resulting when observers assume that certain things are separate and discrete
column3: when in fact they are not. For example
column4: those who failed to predict Donald Trump‚Äôs electoral victory assumed that social conditions in the United States were isolated from those of the rest of the world. Such people failed to notice the evidence of widespread public anger in many other countries
column5: most notably England
column6: Italy
column7: France
column8: and Hungary.

column1: Sir Francis Galton
Failure to take into consideration the ‚Äúbig picture‚Äù is still forgivable
column2: of course; no one can be right all the time
column3: or even most of the time. Systems in the modern world suffer from too much input and data
column4: rather than too little. But deliberate lying is quite another matter. And it is undeniable that some mainstream media outlets have deliberately sought to conceal the truth on a variety of domestic and foreign issues. Rather than act as a check on governmental power
column5: the media has actually become an arm of government power
column6: enforcing doctrinal orthodoxy with a variety of carrots and sticks that have proven to be reasonably effective.

column1: Individual journalists can play significant roles in this process. Consider a favorite example of mine
column2: the case of famed baseball player Ty Cobb. I‚Äôve been an admirer of Cobb for a very long time
column3: ever since reading his autobiography as a boy. Something never quite felt true about all those stories that other biographers would tell about him. The worst of these was sports writer Al Stump
column4: whose biography of Cobb has now been discredited as mostly fabrication.

column1: Stump was granted exclusive access to Ty Cobb in 1960 and 1961 for his biographical purposes. Cobb shared with him many intimate details of his life and career; but instead of faithfully reproducing those recollections
column2: Stump embellished
column3: slanted
column4: and outright fabricated numerous anecdotes designed to cast Cobb in the worst possible light. Stump portrayed Cobb as a southern racist (Cobb was from Georgia)
column5: a misogynist
column6: and even a murderer. Cobb was not alive at the time all these stories began to circulate and was unable to defend himself.

column1: To add insult to injury
column2: Stump‚Äôs writings were used as the basis for a terrible 1994 film called Cobb
column3: which starred Tommy Lee Jones. The film is a tissue of lies and distortions that deserved to‚Äîand did‚Äîflop at the box office. The real Ty Cobb was a complex
column4: driven
column5: and highly intelligent figure
column6: who knew how to court controversy when he had to
column7: but was actually a gentleman by the standards of the era. Readers interested in further reading should consult the wonderful biography by Charles Leerhsen entitled Ty Cobb: A Terrible Beauty .

column1: A famous photo of Cobb stealing third base
To begin with
column2: Cobb used brains rather than brawn to beat his opponents. He made careful studies of all the top players of his day and crafted strategies designed to exploit their weaknesses. For example
column3: when he learned that pitcher Walter Johnson hated hitting batters with pitches
column4: Cobb would crowd the plate to force Johnson to walk him. He learned how to get inside the heads of his adversaries
column5: forcing them to lose their tempers; when they did
column6: Cobb would steal bases right under their noses. He remains one of the few players in history who knew how to steal home base.

column1: One legend about Cobb that has persisted is that he was a violent brawler. This is simply not true. It is true that men of his era got into fistfights often‚Äîit was part of a healthy masculine culture back then‚Äîbut he never gratuitously assaulted or struck anyone. The few incidents that have been held out as examples of his misbehavior (e.g.
column2: a fight with a black groundskeeper and assorted hotel brawls) prove to be on closer inspection nothing more than the standard types of fights that physically-minded men like him became entangled with. Nearly all ballplayers of his era engaged in them
column3: including Babe Ruth.

column1: Al Stump‚Äôs character assassination of Cobb went even further
column2: painting him as an unreconstructed southern ‚Äúracist‚Äù who had a grudge against blacks. This is completely false. Cobb was actually one of the few early supporters of integration in the big leagues. When asked his opinion about subject by the Sporting News in 1952
column3: he said
column4: ‚ÄúThe negro has the right to compete in sports
column5: and who is to say he has not?‚Äù

column1: He had nothing but compliments for black athletes like Willie Mays and Jackie Robinson
column2: and players in the Negro League whom Cobb interacted with in the 1920s confirm that there was no trace of prejudice in Cobb‚Äôs makeup. Cobb mentored younger players
column3: corresponded with fans with personalized letters
column4: and helped found a hospital and a college education fund.

column1: Cobb was certainly no angel
column2: but in hindsight he was nothing more than an aggressive
column3: daring man who played professional sports at a time when things were much less regulated than they are now. Cobb himself may even have allowed spurious tales about himself to circulate in order to court publicity. But he had a limit
column4: and complete fairy tales he would not tolerate.

column1: Stump‚Äôs lies have been so pervasive and persistent that the mythology surrounding Cobb will take decades to undo. If anything
column2: Cobb was too trusting in letting a man like Stump into his confidence. Cobb was so angry with Stump‚Äôs hatchet job that he was preparing to sue to prevent publication of Stump‚Äôs writings in 1961
column3: just before his death. The terrible 1994 film Cobb only added more oil to the fire.

column1: Malicious journalism can do serious damage. Sometimes the damage comes from ignorance
column2: other times from deliberate peddling of falsehood. The motives for lying‚Äîwhether coming from money
column3: fame
column4: or the desire to ‚Äúvirtue signal‚Äù‚Äîcan always be found if one digs below the surface. In the modern era
column5: the default rule must be to seek independent confirmation of news stories
column6: and to remember that journalists are subject to the same human emotions and weaknesses as all the rest of us.

column1: This is what my fellow ROK contributors and manosphere bloggers were talking about when they mentioned the ‚Äútangible impact‚Äù of Trump voters. Hillary‚Äôs supporters lack the characteristics necessary to make change:
A burning passion and sense of purpose Moral fortitude and a sense of justice Self-confidence
column2: and the courage to stand up for your rights A fucking spine This is why we will win

column4: a victim complex

column1: Of course not! Who do you think all of the hard working businessmen are? All of the entrepreneurs? All of the people investing in the stock market in order to take control of their financial future? Hard working

column3: who don‚Äôt make excuses

column1: Why do you think the Dow Jones Industrial Average is at an all time high? Because Trump‚Äôs win restored faith in America.
3. Rise of the New Media
The mainstream media has repeatedly shown to be completely incompetent in regards to actually reporting on the issues; they are nothing more than a puppet show meant to distract
column2: entertain
column3: and brainwash the American public.

column1: They have consistently lied about candidates
column2: manipulated the evidence
column3: falsified facts
column4: skewed statistics and polls
column5: and defamed multiple individuals for a mere political opinion; this will happen no longer.

column1: With the rise of the new media
column2: more and more men have begun establishing outlets across all platforms: Reddit

column4: Facebook

column1: I firmly believe that the next eight years will be looked back on by historians as one of the most important times in all of humanity‚Äôs time on this earth.
America has brought the world stability; we have stood as a symbol and an ideal for other countries to follow. We are a monolith of free speech

column1: This is actually a sort of hypnosis trick and was certainly done deliberately. Scott Adams calls this word-thinking :

Word-Thinkers: Use labels

column1: He further describes the phenomenon of word-thinking :

4. I will echo what many others have said on the forum. MAKE FUN OF THEM. They‚Äôre a prime target for humor. Believe me when I say most people are sick of the special snowflakes on the street as well as the media.
This is a time of great opportunity

8036;9470e2e95caeb4614850a6b39f6014bfbf1596cf;0;Jacques de Seingalt;2016-11-24T03:01:28.961+02:00;An Exploration Of Finding Meaning In Life Through Logotherapy;What motivates you to live? What is the meaning of life?
For centuries
column2: mankind has questioned everything. Mankind‚Äôs quest for the answer to what drives us
column3: and what pushes us forward in times of darkness is not exempt from analysis. In fact
column4: it‚Äôs been a consistent theme since the dawn of time. Stoicism
column5: although not directly attributed to answering ‚Äòwhat drives us‚Äô
column6: skirts around the topic and creates a general set of principles to help us deal with negative externalities in life.

column1: While many philosophers have pontificated on the subject of mankind‚Äôs driving force
column2: and the ‚Äòwill to live‚Äô
column3: there‚Äôs a problem inherent with such an analysis. In order to research such a basic
column4: and instinctual topic
column5: one needs to experience a visceral
column6: cerebral experience that brings him or her to a basic
column7: instinctual level
column8: before having such an epiphany. One needs to examine our animalistic base
column9: and then explore logically from there.

column1: One such analysis is known as Logotherapy
column2: from the Greek word logos(wise) . Logotherapy
column3: developed by Viktor Frankl
column4: is an influential school of psychotherapy
column5: that is founded on the pillars of ‚Äòwhat motivates mankind‚Äô. Before we delve into Logotherapy
column6: however
column7: it‚Äôs important that we discuss Viktor Frankl‚Äîwho he was
column8: and why his unique perspective provides for an incredibly powerful source of credibility and authority.

column1: Viktor Frankl was born in 1905
column2: in what was at that time known as Austria-Hungary. Frankl was a neurologist
column3: and psychiatrist. His early life was relatively unspectacular
column4: but from an early age he displayed an interest in philosophy
column5: as well as psychotherapy. Initially interested in Freud and Adler‚Äôs work
column6: he began to see their faults
column7: and eventually diverged from their teachings‚Äîbecoming particularly interested in depression
column8: as well as suicide.

column1: During 1933-1937
column2: Frankl
column3: in completing his residency in neurology
column4: was responsible for setting up the Selbstm√∂rderpavillon
column5: translated in English to ‚Äúthe suicide pavilion‚Äù. It‚Äôs estimated that Frankl
column6: along with his staff
column7: treated upwards of 30
column8: 000 women who had suicidal tendencies.

column1: In September of 1942
column2: his life was shaken. Frankl
column3: along with his wife and family
column4: were deported to a Nazi concentration camp
column5: known as Theresienstadt ghetto. Whilst there
column6: and during his stay at Auschwitz
column7: Frankl worked as a doctor in the psychiatric care unit
column8: focusing on mental health
column9: helping newcomers deal with shock and grief.

column2: after three years in a concentration camp
column3: Frankl released his book entitled Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning
column4: which details his experiences as a holocaust survivor
column5: as well as his theory
column6: which became known as Logotherapy. The book is divided into two parts‚Äîpart one is a detailed account of his experiences
column7: whereas part two discusses Logotherapy.

column1: His time in the numerous concentration camps began to shape his philosophical
column2: and psychiatric theory. While he had read books on the subject of ‚Äòpsychological healing‚Äô prior to his imprisonment
column3: he had never experienced it to the degree in which he had become accustomed to. Particularly intrigued as to why some prisoners lived longer than others
column4: Frankl began to organize his thoughts and document how the average prisoner‚Äôs life in a concentration camp was reflected in their mind. As a doctor focusing on grief and shock-stricken inmates
column5: he was in a very unique position.

column1: Hundreds
column2: and during some weeks thousands
column3: of helpless inmates were carted in Auschwitz
column4: the most-feared concentration camp
column5: weekly. Between the inmates sleeping next to him
column6: and those seeking treatment
column7: Frankl noted that each prisoner
column8: without exception faced three stages of psychological reactions once entering the concentration camp. These stages were; shock
column9: apathy
column10: and depersonalization.

column1: While seemingly unimportant
column2: the noted documentation of these stages was very important for Frankl. As he began to notice
column3: while every inmate experienced these stages
column4: some experienced them to a less cerebral degree. Some inmates seemed less depressive than others
column5: and featured a happier disposition. These inmates‚Äîwith some expected variability‚Äîoutlived the other inmates.

column1: Discovery As he began to poke and prod
column2: Frankl noticed something that separated these individuals from others‚Äî hope. There is never not meaning in life. Every moment no matter how painful
column3: dehumanizing or horrendous it is
column4: has meaning. By extension
column5: Frankl suggests
column6: even suffering is meaningful. The inmates that survived the longest‚Äîthe ones that outlived the rest
column7: had hope. Frankl suggested that he could tell whether or not an inmate would live just by looking at their faces‚Äîthe face of a dejected
column8: depressed inmate was obvious and clear as day. Without hope
column9: they were doomed.

column1: ‚ÄúEverything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedoms‚Äîto choose one‚Äôs attitude in any given set of circumstances
column2: to choose one‚Äôs own way.‚Äù

column1: The next question that Frankl sought to answer was an important one
column2: and the foundational maxim of Logotherapy‚Äîwhy did some men have hope
column3: and others not?

column1: The answer
column2: was love.

column1: ‚ÄúThe truth ‚Äì that love is the ultimate and the highest goal to which Man can aspire. Then I grasped the meaning of the greatest secret that human poetry and human thought and belief have to impart: The salvation of Man is through love and in love. I understood how a man who has nothing left in this world still may know bliss
column2: be it only for a brief moment
column3: in the contemplation of his beloved.‚Äù

column1: Frankl
column2: in his book Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning recounted several instances where he would be driven into brief stints of depression; after a beating
column3: during a late-night march in bare feet
column4: or watching his friend get treated inhumanely. He‚Äôd vacillate from depression by thinking
column5: and longing for his wife. The men whom lasted the longest
column6: invariably had a wife
column7: or a job that they loved. It was this motivator
column8: the unquantifiable love
column9: that pushed men in inhuman circumstances to existentially escape the physical realm
column10: and put mind above body.

column1: What we can get from this To answer this
column2: Frankl codified three ways that he discovered is how we can find meaning in life ‚Äì A job
column3: love
column4: and how we react to suffering. It‚Äôs important to realize that while it‚Äôs easy to read this and assume that Frankl is saying we should all suffer in order to find meaning‚Äîhe‚Äôs not. He IS suggesting
column5: however
column6: that should we not have a job/deed
column7: or love that allow us to find meaning in life
column8: we can still find meaning by choosing how to react in a negative situation‚Äîour mental freedom is one of the only things that can never be taken from us
column9: theoretically speaking.

column1: The average man will never be faced with such a dire circumstance such as the atrocities that Frankl and so many others dealt with. What we can do
column2: however
column3: is choose how we react to life‚Äôs adversities.

column1: A fair assessment of Logotherapy is that it provides a simplistic solution to a complex question (life). Since life is such a complex series of events
column2: Logotherapy offers a solution that may not be representative of life‚Äôs true hardships and intricacies. In saying this
column3: my own personal evaluation is that
column4: this criticism in itself may have flaws
column5: by assuming that a complex question must have a complex solution. Even the assumption that life in complex can be debated. It‚Äôs a cliched saying that ‚Äòlife is hard‚Äô
column6: or complex‚Äîand even if it is
column7: it‚Äôs not out of the realm of possibility that a complex question has a simple solution ‚Äì sometimes the answer we seek is right in front of us.

column1: Viktor Frankl died in September 1997
column2: and his works are still read today. Several Logotherapy institutes exist today named after him.

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has reached a financial accomplishment that no other GOP candidate has before.
He has amassed the largest small-donor fundraising pack that has ever been seen in the Republican Party.
Zac Moffatt
column2: an online fundraising expert

column1: Romney and Sen. John McCain
column2: the 2008 GOP nominee
column3: each raised more overall in their respective campaigns than Trump has in total contributions.

column1: However
column2: Trump‚Äôs campaign has topped both of the former nominees in small individual contributions
column3: defined as $200 or less.

column1: In this category
column2: Trump has raised more than $78.6 million thus far
column3: based on data from the Federal Election Commission.

column1: In comparison
column2: McCain raised $65.5 million and Romney raised $44.8 million by this point in their election races.

column2: Trump‚Äôs small-donor income makes up 58 percent of his overall funds.

column4: occupation
column5: employer and ZIP code.

column1: 12431;fce69331fc1bd002721787150882b2bf9fc77a92;0;;2016-10-26T18:08:00.000+03:00;Money Laundering Scheme Exposed: 14 Pro-Clinton Super PACs
column2: Nonprofits Implicated;"

column1: There‚Äôs a reason David Brock
column2: founder of the liberal group Media Matters for America
column3: chooses to house an unregistered professional solicitor in his office to raise money for his conglomerate of super PACs and nonprofits.

column1: Professional solicitors are required to disclose their active solicitation contracts. Brock wants his unregistered solicitor
column2: the Bonner Group
column3: to keep its client list hidden for a very specific reason.

column1: David Brock is laundering money

Related Stories Consumers Need Protection From New Consumer Protection Bureau Rule Here‚Äôs What The Markets Are Telling Us‚Ä¶ Exposed: Profiteers Of Governing ‚Äì And These Are The Ones Who Got Caught! Brock has seven nonprofits
column2: three super PACs
column3: one 527 committee
column4: one LLC
column5: one joint fundraising committee and one unregistered solicitor crammed into his office in Washington .

column1: Uncovered records expose a constant flow of money between these organizations.
The Bonner Group
column2: his professional solicitor
column3: works off a commission. Every time money gets passed around
column4: Bonner receives a 12.5 percent cut.

column1: Follow the money
Nonprofits are required to disclose to whom they give cash grants.
But they aren‚Äôt required to disclose who gives them cash grants.
This weak system of one-way verification is being abused by Brock. He‚Äôs been cycling money between his organizations for years
column2: and the Bonner Group‚Äôs 12.5 percent commission gets triggered after every pass.

column1: Trending Stories Frustrated With Media Bias

column3: Media Matters for America raised more than $10 million.

column1: The Bonner Group was credited for raising these funds. Media Matters paid it a $1.1 million commission.
That same year
column2: Media Matters gave a $930
column3: 000 cash grant to Brock‚Äôs Franklin Education Forum
column4: an organization that shares office space with Media Matters.

column2: the Franklin Education Forum reported $994
column3: 000 in total contributions
column4: and 93.6 percent of that total came from Media Matters.

column1: Surprisingly
column2: though
column3: the Franklin Education Forum gave full credit to Bonner for raising that money. It paid the fundraiser a $124
column4: 250 commission in 2014.

column1: Notice what happened?
Brock‚Äôs Media Matters gave a $930
column2: 000 cash grant to Brock‚Äôs Franklin Education Forum. Brock‚Äôs Franklin Education Forum credited the Bonner Group for raising those funds
column3: triggering the 12.5 percent commission. Brock paid the Bonner Group a $124
column4: 250 commission to solicit a cash grant ‚Ä¶ from himself! It doesn‚Äôt stop there

column1: After the Franklin Education Forum retained $869
column3: it sent a $816
column4: 224 cash grant to Brock‚Äôs Franklin Forum .

column1: Note: The Franklin Education Forum is a 501(c)3
column2: and The Franklin Forum is a 501(c)4. They are not the same company.

column1: The Franklin Forum 501(c)4 paid Bonner a commission in 2013
column2: so it‚Äôs safe to assume the fundraiser received a $102
column3: 028 commission in 2014. Unfortunately
column4: it‚Äôs hard to tell for sure. It still hasn‚Äôt filed its taxes for 2014!

column1: Let‚Äôs recap
Say
column2: for example
column3: you donate $1
column5: 857 to Media Matters for America. This is how David Brock would have used your charitable donation in 2014:

column1: Media Matters would receive your $1
column3: 857 donation. The Bonner Group would earn a $132
column4: 857 commission. Media Matters would retain $930
column5: 000. Next
column6: Media Matters would give what‚Äôs left of your entire donation
column9: to the Franklin Education Forum. The Bonner Group would ‚Äúearn‚Äù a $116
column10: 250 commission. The Franklin Education Forum would retain $813
column11: 750. The Franklin Education Forum would then forward the remaining $813
column12: 750 to The Franklin Forum. The Bonner Group would ‚Äúearn‚Äù a $101
column13: 718 commission. The Franklin Forum would retain $712
column14: 031. In the end
column15: Brock‚Äôs solicitor would have pocketed $350
column17: almost a third of your initial donation. That‚Äôs a far cry from the advertised 12.5 percent commission.

column1: As bizarre as that scenario may sound
column2: this is exactly what Brock did in 2014.

column1: How can we be sure this is intentional?
Brock is the chairman for each of these organizations. How could he not know what‚Äôs going on?
He‚Äôs a hands-on chairman. According to their tax returns
column2: Brock allocates time
column3: weekly
column4: to his organizations:

column1: Media Matters: 31.50 hours per week Franklin Education Forum: three hours per week The Franklin Forum: one hour per week Furthermore
column2: The New York Times reports that Brock shares a summer rental in the Hamptons with Mary Pat Bonner
column3: the president of the Bonner Group.

column1: Brock would have a hard time claiming ignorance on this. These transfers are intentional. He vacations with his solicitor. Case closed.
Still not convinced?
Brock didn‚Äôt even bother to give his organizations different phone numbers. They all share the same number.
What if ‚Ä¶?
We even located the Bonner Group‚Äôs solicitation agreement with Media Matters on Florida‚Äôs Gift Givers‚Äô Guide . Clarification on the commission can be found on page 2:
In English: Contractually
column2: Brock has the option to exclude certain contributions from triggering the commission. In spite of this option
column3: he intentionally chooses to trigger the 12.5 percent commission for money grants between his organizations.

column1: Note: Yes

column3: board members and telephone number
column4: we feel it‚Äôs safe to assume they also share the same solicitation agreement.

This is all from just one year! No further commentary required.

column1: If it looks like a duck

column1: We‚Äôve spent months trying to find some sort of loophole to justify this activity. But there aren‚Äôt any loopholes. David Brock has something to hide. Just last month
column2: The Daily Caller reported the following:

column3: Delaware
column4: to come up with the money. This certainly seems to indicate that Brock was terrified about what the authorities would uncover.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúGrey accused Brock of ‚Äòfinancial malfeasance‚Äô and threatened to undermine Brock‚Äôs fundraising efforts.
‚Äú‚ÄòNext step is I contact all your donors and the IRS
column2: ‚Äô Grey wrote in an email dated May 19
column3: 2010. ‚ÄòThis is going to stink for you if you do not resolve this now.'‚Äù

column1: We believe that the information presented in this article is what has Brock so terrified. We feel confident in saying
column2: with close to absolute certainty
column3: that David Brock is laundering money through his Media Matters conglomerate.

column1: 12433;ab83f5ed702ff7df9c2d568cd979bbffa64ae4e3;0;;2016-10-26T17:45:00.000+03:00;13 Years Later Elizabeth Smart Realizes Kidnapping Was Even Worse For Her Parents;"

column2: Elizabeth Smart was abducted during the night at knifepoint from her bedroom at only 14-years-old.

column1: Her kidnapping quickly garnered national media attention. Her media savvy parents worked overtime to keep her story in the news throughout the ordeal.
During her 9 months in captivity she was raped repeatedly
column2: often as many as 3-4 times per day. Each day was a mental and physical war for her to survive at the hands of her kidnapper and rapist
column3: Brian David Mitchell.

column1: Related Stories American Student Presumed Dead Turns Up In North Korea As Kim Jong Un‚Äôs Personal Tutor With the help of an America‚Äôs Most Wanted television broadcast
column2: the police were able to locate and free her on March 12
column3: 2003. Her disappearance and subsequent miraculous return to her family made her one of the best known teenagers in America at the time.

column1: Justice wasn‚Äôt finally served until 2011 when Mitchell received two life-terms in a federal prison.
Smart
column2: now 28 years old
column3: is married and a mother with a family of her own. Her daughter
column4: Chloe is now 20 months old.

column1: After a long day of working I like to slip back to my happy place
column2: with Chlo√© on horseback. #daydreaming

column1: A photo posted by Elizabeth Smart (@elizabeth_smart_official) on Aug 15
column2: 2016 at 7:30pm PDT

column1: Now as a parent herself
column2: Smart has realized how horrible the kidnapping was for her parents.

column1: ‚ÄúWhen I go back to my own situation
column2: I almost think it was worse for my parents than for me because I knew that I was alive
column3: but they didn‚Äôt know
column4: ‚Äù she told People magazine.

column1: ‚ÄúI always knew how much they loved me
column2: but until I had my own daughter I didn‚Äôt realize how all-consuming that is. The worst thing in the world would be if something happened to my little girl
column3: ‚Äù she continued.

column1: Smart has made it her life‚Äôs work as a reporter
column2: teacher and activist to make sure other parents
column3: families
column4: victims and survivors are supported
column5: ‚ÄúNobody should have to go through the aftermath of a terrible crime alone.‚Äù

column1: Call if you or someone you know needs help. Report it! #StopChildAbuse w/ @helpspreadthis https://t.co/FUqHbDoyoJ pic.twitter.com/laWxOfcu9G
‚Äî Elizabeth Smart (@ElizSmart) August 14
Smart now works for Crime Watch Daily a program hosted by Chris Hansen. With one season under belt
column2: she‚Äôs signed on for a second season.

After the release of a WikiLeaks email chain from March 2015 on Tuesday in which a top Clinton aide admitted President Barack Obama falsely claimed he did not know about Hillary Clinton‚Äôs private server use while she was secretary of state
column2: White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest sprung into action to deny that the president had lied about the issue.

column1: ‚ÄúWhat the president said was an entirely factual response
column2: ‚Äù Earnest said to a group of reporters in Los Angeles where Obama was attending Democratic fundraisers.

column1: Earnest then attempted to explain away all criticism of the president‚Äôs actions as mere conspiracies.

column1: ‚ÄúOf course the president had possession of Secretary Clinton‚Äôs email address

column1: The state of Georgia is demanding copies of the sermons and related notes of a lay pastor who was fired by the Department of Public Health after it investigated what he said in his church.
But Dr. Eric Walsh is resisting
column2: issuing a statement via his legal team that he will not comply with the demand from state lawyers.

column1: The state‚Äôs demand is in response to a lawsuit filed by Walsh against the Department of Health charging discrimination based on his religion and other civil rights violations.
He‚Äôs getting support from a pastor who successfully fought off a demand by Houston officials for copies of his sermons.
Walsh‚Äôs ordeal began in May 2014 when he accepted an offer as to become district health director with the state agency. Only a week later
column2: a state official asked him to provide copies of sermons he had preached as a lay minister with a Seventh-day Adventist Church.

column1: Lee Rudd
column2: the agency‚Äôs human resources director
column3: then assigned staff members to listen to the YouTube recordings immediately. Two days later
column4: Walsh was fired.

column1: At that point
column2: lawyers with First Liberty Institute joined forces with the Atlanta legal team of Parks
column3: Chesin & Walbert to file a federal lawsuit against the state agency.

column1: The state of Georgia is demanding copies of the sermons and related notes of a lay pastor who was fired by the Department of Public Health after it investigated what he said in his church.
But Dr. Eric Walsh is resisting
column2: issuing a statement via his legal team that he will not comply with the demand from state lawyers.

column1: The state‚Äôs demand is in response to a lawsuit filed by Walsh against the Department of Health charging discrimination based on his religion and other civil rights violations.
He‚Äôs getting support from a pastor who successfully fought off a demand by Houston officials for copies of his sermons.
Walsh‚Äôs ordeal began in May 2014 when he accepted an offer as to become district health director with the state agency. Only a week later
column2: a state official asked him to provide copies of sermons he had preached as a lay minister with a Seventh-day Adventist Church.

column1: Lee Rudd
column2: the agency‚Äôs human resources director
column3: then assigned staff members to listen to the YouTube recordings immediately. Two days later
column4: Walsh was fired.

column1: At that point
column2: lawyers with First Liberty Institute joined forces with the Atlanta legal team of Parks
column3: Chesin & Walbert to file a federal lawsuit against the state agency.

column1: ‚ÄúPolice State USA: How Orwell‚Äôs Nightmare Is Becoming Our Reality‚Äù chronicles how America has arrived at the point of being a de facto police state

column4: among a flood of other paperwork
column5: ‚Äúcopies of his sermon notes and transcripts.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúThis is an excessive display of the government overreaching its authority and violating the sanctity of the church
column2: ‚Äù said Jeremy Dys
column3: senior counsel for First Liberty.

column1: ‚ÄúNo government has the right to require a pastor to turn over his sermons
column2: ‚Äù said Walsh in a statement released by his lawyers. ‚ÄúI cannot and will not give up my sermons unless I am forced to do so.‚Äù

column3: who did not respond to a request for comment.

column1: 12606;a07c5ae5e10f44f364c6f98dd794d27f13714148;0;Joe Kovacs;2016-10-26T22:54:58.597+03:00;Limbaugh: Democrats would 'destroy Jesus Christ';"Actor Jim Caviezel portraying Jesus in ‚ÄúThe Passion of the Christ.‚Äù

But if He were
column2: Democrats would try to ‚Äúdestroy‚Äù Him in the same manner they‚Äôre attacking the 2016 GOP candidate
column3: Donald Trump.

column1: That‚Äôs according to radio host Rush Limbaugh
column2: who hypothesized what this year‚Äôs race would look like if the Son of God were at the top of the Republican ticket.

column1: Should President Trump try to prosecute Hillary? Sign the hottest petition in America now to show your support!
‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter who the Republicans would have nominated
column2: they were gonna get the treatment Trump‚Äôs getting. It wouldn‚Äôt have mattered
column3: ‚Äù Limbaugh said Wednesday.

column1: ‚ÄúThey would go out of their way to find ways to destroy Jesus Christ if he could be nominated as a Republican. The Democrats would do everything they could
column2: include calling Him a liar
column3: the Bible a fake book
column4: whatever it took.‚Äù Rush Limbaugh

column1: And despite the fact the Bible never indicates Jesus was married or had sex out of wedlock
column2: Limbaugh suggested Democrats would do their best effort in trying to find any of His offspring:

column1: ‚ÄúThey would scour the historical record looking for children He had fathered
column2: anything they could do to disapprove the gospel to discredit Jesus. That‚Äôs who they are. That‚Äôs what they would do.‚Äù

column1: Limbaugh said the point he was stressing was that Republicans would never escape ‚Äúthis kind of media assault based on who we nominate.‚Äù Donald Trump‚Äôs RNC acceptance speech (Photo: Screenshot from RNC live feed)
‚ÄúI say this because a lot of you Never Trumpers are out there claiming that this is exactly what you get when you nominate a guy like Trump. No
column2: it‚Äôs exactly what you get when you nominate a Republican. Whenever there is any opposition to the Democrats
column3: this is what they do. It doesn‚Äôt matter. They‚Äôre gonna do it. They did it to Romney ‚Ä¶

column1: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve made this point ‚Äôtil I blue in the face. They turned Romney
column2: who is mild-mannered Mr. Gosh
column3: Can‚Äôt Even Get Noticed into the biggest walking Satan
column4: El Diablo politics had ever seen at that time
column5: and they made it stick So this is why I think Trump has so many people supporting him. He‚Äôs fighting back against it when most Republicans haven‚Äôt and don‚Äôt.‚Äù

column1: As an example of how media treatment of Republicans has not changed
column2: Limbaugh played an excerpt of 1980 election-night coverage from CBS. Commentator Bill Moyers characterized the race before it was known that Republican Ronald Reagan would easily defeat Democrat Jimmy Carter. Moyers stated:

column1: ‚ÄúThose of you who might speak Spanish
column2: who might be black
column3: who might be women
column4: remember
column5: ‚Äù said Carter
column6: ‚Äúwho‚Äôs been your friend.‚Äù And there under the California sun in San Diego at a shopping center

column8: ‚ÄúAw
column9: shut up!‚Äù

column1: And thousands of supporters roared their approval. Those are the people for whom Ronald Reagan is the apostle of the rollback

column3: and
column4: if he wins at all tonight

column6: ‚ÄúEnough‚Äôs enough.‚Äù

Jesus Christ of Nazareth is not the Republican nominee for president in this election cycle.
But if He were
column2: Democrats would try to ‚Äúdestroy‚Äù Him in the same manner they‚Äôre attacking the 2016 GOP candidate
column3: Donald Trump.

column1: That‚Äôs according to radio host Rush Limbaugh
column2: who hypothesized what this year‚Äôs race would look like if the Son of God were at the top of the Republican ticket.

column1: Should President Trump try to prosecute Hillary? Sign the hottest petition in America now to show your support!
‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter who the Republicans would have nominated

column1: ‚ÄúThey would go out of their way to find ways to destroy Jesus Christ if he could be nominated as a Republican. The Democrats would do everything they could
column2: include calling Him a liar
column3: the Bible a fake book
column4: whatever it took.‚Äù Rush Limbaugh

column1: And despite the fact the Bible never indicates Jesus was married or had sex out of wedlock
column2: Limbaugh suggested Democrats would do their best effort in trying to find any of His offspring:

column1: ‚ÄúThey would scour the historical record looking for children He had fathered
column2: anything they could do to disapprove the gospel to discredit Jesus. That‚Äôs who they are. That‚Äôs what they would do.‚Äù

column1: Limbaugh said the point he was stressing was that Republicans would never escape ‚Äúthis kind of media assault based on who we nominate.‚Äù Donald Trump‚Äôs RNC acceptance speech (Photo: Screenshot from RNC live feed)
‚ÄúI say this because a lot of you Never Trumpers are out there claiming that this is exactly what you get when you nominate a guy like Trump. No
column2: it‚Äôs exactly what you get when you nominate a Republican. Whenever there is any opposition to the Democrats
column3: this is what they do. It doesn‚Äôt matter. They‚Äôre gonna do it. They did it to Romney ‚Ä¶

column2: who is mild-mannered Mr. Gosh
column3: Can‚Äôt Even Get Noticed into the biggest walking Satan
column4: El Diablo politics had ever seen at that time
column5: and they made it stick So this is why I think Trump has so many people supporting him. He‚Äôs fighting back against it when most Republicans haven‚Äôt and don‚Äôt.‚Äù

column1: As an example of how media treatment of Republicans has not changed
column2: Limbaugh played an excerpt of 1980 election-night coverage from CBS. Commentator Bill Moyers characterized the race before it was known that Republican Ronald Reagan would easily defeat Democrat Jimmy Carter. Moyers stated:

column1: ‚ÄúThose of you who might speak Spanish
column2: who might be black
column3: who might be women
column4: remember
column5: ‚Äù said Carter
column6: ‚Äúwho‚Äôs been your friend.‚Äù And there under the California sun in San Diego at a shopping center
column7: Ronald Reagan was delivering himself of one of those patriotic soliloquies at which he‚Äôs been a master since his days at Eureka College. Suddenly hecklers in the crowd started shouting and waving their ERA signs. Reagan took his cue and snapped back
column8: ‚ÄúAw
column9: shut up!‚Äù

column1: And thousands of supporters roared their approval. Those are the people for whom Ronald Reagan is the apostle of the rollback
column2: the knight who promises finally to slay the dragon of liberal government. Jimmy Carter won four years ago as an outsider
column3: and
column4: if he wins at all tonight

column6: ‚ÄúEnough‚Äôs enough.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúDoes it sound like anything has changed in the way these people see the world?‚Äù Limbaugh asked. ‚ÄúNot an iota!‚Äù
