column1: ‚ÄúObergefell is the product of unelected and unaccountable judges
column2: ‚Äù he said.

column1: He was arguing over a decision by the state court on its next move in a case brought by Chief Justice Roy Moore
column2: who was suspended for his actions regarding a marriage-based case that the court was reviewing when the Obergefell case
column3: which created same-sex ‚Äúmarriage‚Äù nationwide
column4: was announced.

column1: Moore
column2: who is challenging the punishment
column3: insisted that the state court justices who previously were involved in his case recuse themselves. They did
column4: with the exception of the acting chief justice who was allowed to work with the governor to pick a panel of retired judges to hear Moore‚Äôs arguments.

column1: Parker said active judges should have been included in the panel
column2: because retired judges
column3: too
column4: are ‚Äúunelected and unaccountable.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúUnelected and unaccountable judges are empowered to impose their agenda
column2: instead of faithfully applying the rule of law
column3: ‚Äù Parker warned. ‚ÄúObergefell is not the first case concerning same-sex marriage to prove this principle true. Before the United States Supreme Court decided Obergefell
column4: the constitutionality of state laws defining marriage as between one man and one woman had been litigated before numerous courts throughout the United States.

column1: Don‚Äôt miss Phyllis Schlafly‚Äôs book
column2: now available autographed at the WND Superstore: ‚ÄúWho Killed The American Family?‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúBefore Obergefell
column2: 40 states passed laws affirming traditional marriage. In 37 of those states
column3: the traditional marriage laws were challenged in the courts as unconstitutional. Of the 37 state laws affirming traditional marriage that were challenged in the courts
column4: 24 of those laws were struck down by the judiciary as unconstitutional. Each of the 24 courts that struck down the traditional marriage laws as unconstitutional was composed of judges who were unelected and thus unacountable.‚Äù

column1: He explained what happens when activist judges are held to account
column2: citing the situation that developed in Iowa.

column1: ‚ÄúThe Supreme Court of Iowa was one of the unelected courts that struck down Iowa‚Äôs traditional marriage law as unconstitutional. The judges of the Supreme Court of Iowa are appointed by the governor of Iowa. However
column2: although the judges are initially appointed
column3: they must stand for retention elections once their initial term expires.‚Äù

column1: He explained that after the Iowa Legislature adopted one-man-one-woman marriage as law
column2: in April 2009
column3: in ‚Äúa decision largely viewed as judicial activism
column4: the Supreme Court of Iowa unanimously overruled the democratic will of the people of Iowa and held [the law] unconstitutional.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúThe very next year
column2: three of the judges ‚Ä¶ who had concurred in Varnum had to stand for a retention election; all three were removed from office by vote of the people of Iowa. This was the first time since Iowa adopted its retention-election system that any judge had ever failed to be retained. The people of Iowa held accountable those judges who failed to uphold the rule of law.‚Äù

column1: Mathew Staver
column2: chairman of of Liberty Counsel
column3: which is representing Moore
column4: said huge questions remain of impropriety regarding the judicial system‚Äôs handling of Moore‚Äôs case.

column1: ‚ÄúChief Justice Moore is merely asking for the same thing any citizen is entitled to receive ‚Äì equal justice under the law. He wants his case to be heard by an objective and fair panel of judges who will adhere to the rule of law
column2: ‚Äù he said.

column1: ‚ÄúThe people of Alabama have increasingly called upon their judges to be accountable. At every turn
column2: this case presents new twists and turns that have never occurred in the history of Alabama. Never has there been a requirement that replacement judges all be retired. We hope this case moves quickly to a final and just resolution. The Court of the Judiciary violated the law when it suspended Chief Justice Moore for life even though it lacked the 9-0 vote. Never before under the unanimity requirement of COJ Rule 16 has any judge ever been suspended for the rest of the term. A sexting judge gets six months and a judge who writes a four-page order that is not unethical or unlawful gets suspended for life. This is not right.‚Äù

column1: Supporters of Moore also have filed an ethics complaint against Lyn Stuart
column2: who has been acting as Alabama‚Äôs chief justice.

column1: She is accused of ‚Äúviolating multiple cannons of ethics in her mishandling of the cases surrounding Chief Justice Roy Moore.‚Äù
The complaint comes from the Sanctity of Marriage Alabama organization.
‚ÄúIf the Judicial Inquiry commission really cares about ethics
column2: fairness and upholding the integrity and impartiality of the Alabama judiciary
column3: they will no doubt take our complaint seriously
column4: as will organizations which filed ethics complaints on Chief Justice Moore
column5: ‚Äù said Tom Ford
column6: a spokesman for the group.

column1: The complaints
column2: the group said
column3: outline ‚Äúhow acting Chief Justice Lyn Stuart has repeatedly failed to avoid impropriety or the appearance of impropriety
column4: failed to perform the duties of her office impartially
column5: failed to avoid conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice that brings the judicial office into disrepute
column6: and failed to conduct herself at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary.‚Äù

column1: Parker was not the first to cite the dangers of the judiciary.
Daniel Horowitz
column2: senior editor at Conservative Review
column3: told WND that the nation is going through a ‚Äúsocial transformation without representation.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúIt is the unelected branches of government that are deciding our most important issues
column2: whether it‚Äôs the bureaucrats
column3: whether it‚Äôs the courts
column4: and as it relates to even religious liberty
column5: even property rights
column6: immigration
column7: our voting rights
column8: who gets to vote
column9: ‚Äù he said.

column1: Horowitz tackles the topic of ‚Äúsocial transformation without representation‚Äù in his book ‚ÄúStolen Sovereignty: How to Stop Unelected Judges From Transforming America.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did we get here?‚Äù Horowitz asked rhetorically. ‚ÄúAnd the sad reality is nobody ever voted for this. This was all foisted upon the people by unelected judges
column2: the legal profession
column3: and unelected bureaucrats. That is social transformation without representation
column4: which
column5: as Scalia warned
column6: is something much worse than even taxation without representation that served as the impetus for our first American Revolution.‚Äù

column1: Same-sex marriage was mandated for the nation in 2015 by the bare 5-4 majority made up of Anthony Kennedy
column2: Ruth Ginsburg
column3: Stephen Breyer
column4: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan. John Roberts
column5: Clarence Thomas
column6: Samuel Alito and the late Antonin Scalia opposed it.

column1: The majority found in the Constitution a right to same-sex marriage
column2: overturning millennia of established legal precedent regarding marriage as well as the will of tens of millions of voters in dozens of states.

column1: It elicited remarkably harsh criticism of the five justices in the U.S. Supreme Court majority.
For one
column2: two of the justices in the majority
column3: Kagan and Ginsburg
column4: were asked to recuse themselves from the case because they had openly advocated for same-sex marriage
column5: apparently violating standards to preserve judicial impartiality. Without their votes
column6: the case would have gone the other way.

column1: They refused.
Then there was the U.S. Supreme Court‚Äôs own opinion just two years earlier
column2: in the Defense of Marriage Act case
column3: in which the court said states have exclusive power over marriage.

column1: And there also are those who point out that the Constitution doesn‚Äôt mention marriage but does dictate that everything not mentioned in the document is left to the states and the people.
As WND reported
column2: Ginsburg
column3: who voted in favor of same-sex marriage
column4: has performed same-sex wedding ceremonies and made supportive public statements. Justice Elena Kagan also has performed same-sex weddings and promoted ‚Äúgay‚Äù rights at Harvard‚Äôs law school while she was at its helm.

column1: Critics contend the two justice appear to be violating judicial ethics rules that require recusal from a case in which there is even the appearance of a conflict of interest.
The Foundation for Moral Law asked the justices to excuse themselves from the case
column2: but they refused to acknowledge the request. The Foundation explained that Canon 3A(6) of the Code of Conduct for United States Judges provides: ‚ÄúA judge should not make public comment on the merits of a matter pending or impending in any court.‚Äù 28 U.S.C. sec 455(a) mandates that a justice ‚Äúshall disqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned.‚Äù

column1: Rabbi Jonathan Cahn
column2: author of the New York Times bestseller ‚ÄúThe Harbinger‚Äù and the inspiration behind the ‚ÄúIsaiah 9:10 Judgment‚Äù movie
column3: has criticized the Supreme Court‚Äôs assumption that it has the authority to redefine marriage.

column1: At a prayer event in Washington
column2: he said: ‚ÄúThe justices of the Supreme Court took up their seats [in a hearing] on whether they should strike down the biblical and historic definition of marriage. That the event should even take place is a sign this is America of [George] Washington‚Äôs warning ‚Ä¶ a nation at war against its own foundation.‚Äù

column1: Washington warned the smiles of heaven can never be expected on a nation ‚Äúthat disregards the eternal rules of order and right which heaven itself hath ordained.‚Äù
‚ÄúJustices
column2: can you judge the ways of God? There is another court and there is another judge
column3: where all men and all judges will give account
column4: ‚Äù he warned.

column1: ‚ÄúIf a nation‚Äôs high court should pass judgment on the Almighty
column2: should you then be surprised God will pass judgment on the court and that nation? We are doing that which Israel did on the altars of Baal
column3: ‚Äù he said.

column1: See Jonathan‚Äôs Cahn‚Äôs message at Washington: Man of Prayer event at the Capitol.
The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops is calling ‚Äúsame-sex marriage‚Äù an ‚Äúintrinsic evil.‚Äù
And officials from several counties in Tennessee have adopted statements opposing the Supreme Court.
WND also reported when dozens of top legal scholars from the likes of Washington & Lee
column2: Boston College
column3: Kansas State
column4: Notre Dame
column5: University of Texas
column6: Villanova
column7: Vanderbilt
column8: Hillsdale
column9: University of Nebraska

column1: ‚ÄúIt cannot ‚Ä¶ be taken to have settled the law of the United States
column2: ‚Äù said the statement from the American Principles Project .

column1: ‚ÄúWe call on all federal and state officeholders: To refuse to accept Obergefell as binding precedent for all but the specific plaintiffs in that case. To recognize the authority of states to define marriage
column2: and the right of federal and state officeholders to act in accordance with those definitions. To pledge full and mutual legal and political assistance to anyone who refuses to follow Obergefell for constitutionally protected reasons. column1: ‚ÄúBefore Obergefell
column2: 40 states passed laws affirming traditional marriage. In 37 of those states
column3: the traditional marriage laws were challenged in the courts as unconstitutional. Of the 37 state laws affirming traditional marriage that were challenged in the courts
column4: 24 of those laws were struck down by the judiciary as unconstitutional. Each of the 24 courts that struck down the traditional marriage laws as unconstitutional was composed of judges who were unelected and thus unacountable.‚Äù

column1: He explained what happens when activist judges are held to account
column2: citing the situation that developed in Iowa.

column1: ‚ÄúThe Supreme Court of Iowa was one of the unelected courts that struck down Iowa‚Äôs traditional marriage law as unconstitutional. The judges of the Supreme Court of Iowa are appointed by the governor of Iowa. However
column2: although the judges are initially appointed
column3: they must stand for retention elections once their initial term expires.‚Äù

column1: He explained that after the Iowa Legislature adopted one-man-one-woman marriage as law
column2: in April 2009
column3: in ‚Äúa decision largely viewed as judicial activism
column4: the Supreme Court of Iowa unanimously overruled the democratic will of the people of Iowa and held [the law] unconstitutional.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúThe very next year
column2: three of the judges ‚Ä¶ who had concurred in Varnum had to stand for a retention election; all three were removed from office by vote of the people of Iowa. This was the first time since Iowa adopted its retention-election system that any judge had ever failed to be retained. The people of Iowa held accountable those judges who failed to uphold the rule of law.‚Äù

column1: Mathew Staver
column2: chairman of of Liberty Counsel
column3: which is representing Moore
column4: said huge questions remain of impropriety regarding the judicial system‚Äôs handling of Moore‚Äôs case.

column1: ‚ÄúChief Justice Moore is merely asking for the same thing any citizen is entitled to receive ‚Äì equal justice under the law. He wants his case to be heard by an objective and fair panel of judges who will adhere to the rule of law
column2: ‚Äù he said.

column1: ‚ÄúThe people of Alabama have increasingly called upon their judges to be accountable. At every turn
column2: this case presents new twists and turns that have never occurred in the history of Alabama. Never has there been a requirement that replacement judges all be retired. We hope this case moves quickly to a final and just resolution. The Court of the Judiciary violated the law when it suspended Chief Justice Moore for life even though it lacked the 9-0 vote. Never before under the unanimity requirement of COJ Rule 16 has any judge ever been suspended for the rest of the term. A sexting judge gets six months and a judge who writes a four-page order that is not unethical or unlawful gets suspended for life. This is not right.‚Äù

column1: Supporters of Moore also have filed an ethics complaint against Lyn Stuart
column2: who has been acting as Alabama‚Äôs chief justice.

column1: She is accused of ‚Äúviolating multiple cannons of ethics in her mishandling of the cases surrounding Chief Justice Roy Moore.‚Äù
The complaint comes from the Sanctity of Marriage Alabama organization.
‚ÄúIf the Judicial Inquiry commission really cares about ethics
column2: fairness and upholding the integrity and impartiality of the Alabama judiciary
column3: they will no doubt take our complaint seriously
column4: as will organizations which filed ethics complaints on Chief Justice Moore
column5: ‚Äù said Tom Ford
column6: a spokesman for the group.

column1: The complaints
column2: the group said
column3: outline ‚Äúhow acting Chief Justice Lyn Stuart has repeatedly failed to avoid impropriety or the appearance of impropriety
column4: failed to perform the duties of her office impartially
column5: failed to avoid conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice that brings the judicial office into disrepute
column6: and failed to conduct herself at all times in a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of the judiciary.‚Äù

column1: Parker was not the first to cite the dangers of the judiciary.
Daniel Horowitz
column2: senior editor at Conservative Review
column3: told WND that the nation is going through a ‚Äúsocial transformation without representation.‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúIt is the unelected branches of government that are deciding our most important issues
column2: whether it‚Äôs the bureaucrats
column3: whether it‚Äôs the courts
column4: and as it relates to even religious liberty
column5: even property rights
column6: immigration
column7: our voting rights
column8: who gets to vote
column9: ‚Äù he said.

column1: Horowitz tackles the topic of ‚Äúsocial transformation without representation‚Äù in his book ‚ÄúStolen Sovereignty: How to Stop Unelected Judges From Transforming America.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did we get here?‚Äù Horowitz asked rhetorically. ‚ÄúAnd the sad reality is nobody ever voted for this. This was all foisted upon the people by unelected judges
column2: the legal profession
column3: and unelected bureaucrats. That is social transformation without representation
column4: which
column5: as Scalia warned
column6: is something much worse than even taxation without representation that served as the impetus for our first American Revolution.‚Äù

column1: Same-sex marriage was mandated for the nation in 2015 by the bare 5-4 majority made up of Anthony Kennedy
column2: Ruth Ginsburg
column3: Stephen Breyer
column4: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan. John Roberts
column5: Clarence Thomas
column6: Samuel Alito and the late Antonin Scalia opposed it.

column1: The majority found in the Constitution a right to same-sex marriage
column2: overturning millennia of established legal precedent regarding marriage as well as the will of tens of millions of voters in dozens of states.

column1: It elicited remarkably harsh criticism of the five justices in the U.S. Supreme Court majority.
For one
column2: two of the justices in the majority
column3: Kagan and Ginsburg
column4: were asked to recuse themselves from the case because they had openly advocated for same-sex marriage
column5: apparently violating standards to preserve judicial impartiality. Without their votes
column6: the case would have gone the other way.

column1: They refused.
Then there was the U.S. Supreme Court‚Äôs own opinion just two years earlier
column2: in the Defense of Marriage Act case
column3: in which the court said states have exclusive power over marriage.

column1: And there also are those who point out that the Constitution doesn‚Äôt mention marriage but does dictate that everything not mentioned in the document is left to the states and the people.
As WND reported
column2: Ginsburg
column3: who voted in favor of same-sex marriage
column4: has performed same-sex wedding ceremonies and made supportive public statements. Justice Elena Kagan also has performed same-sex weddings and promoted ‚Äúgay‚Äù rights at Harvard‚Äôs law school while she was at its helm.

column1: Critics contend the two justice appear to be violating judicial ethics rules that require recusal from a case in which there is even the appearance of a conflict of interest.
The Foundation for Moral Law asked the justices to excuse themselves from the case
column2: but they refused to acknowledge the request. The Foundation explained that Canon 3A(6) of the Code of Conduct for United States Judges provides: ‚ÄúA judge should not make public comment on the merits of a matter pending or impending in any court.‚Äù 28 U.S.C. sec 455(a) mandates that a justice ‚Äúshall disqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned.‚Äù

column1: Rabbi Jonathan Cahn
column2: author of the New York Times bestseller ‚ÄúThe Harbinger‚Äù and the inspiration behind the ‚ÄúIsaiah 9:10 Judgment‚Äù movie
column3: has criticized the Supreme Court‚Äôs assumption that it has the authority to redefine marriage.

column1: At a prayer event in Washington
column2: he said: ‚ÄúThe justices of the Supreme Court took up their seats [in a hearing] on whether they should strike down the biblical and historic definition of marriage. That the event should even take place is a sign this is America of [George] Washington‚Äôs warning ‚Ä¶ a nation at war against its own foundation.‚Äù

column1: Washington warned the smiles of heaven can never be expected on a nation ‚Äúthat disregards the eternal rules of order and right which heaven itself hath ordained.‚Äù
‚ÄúJustices
column2: can you judge the ways of God? There is another court and there is another judge
column3: where all men and all judges will give account
column4: ‚Äù he warned.

column1: ‚ÄúIf a nation‚Äôs high court should pass judgment on the Almighty
column2: should you then be surprised God will pass judgment on the court and that nation? We are doing that which Israel did on the altars of Baal
column3: ‚Äù he said.

column1: See Jonathan‚Äôs Cahn‚Äôs message at Washington: Man of Prayer event at the Capitol.
The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops is calling ‚Äúsame-sex marriage‚Äù an ‚Äúintrinsic evil.‚Äù
And officials from several counties in Tennessee have adopted statements opposing the Supreme Court.
WND also reported when dozens of top legal scholars from the likes of Washington & Lee

column1: ‚ÄúIt cannot ‚Ä¶ be taken to have settled the law of the United States
column2: ‚Äù said the statement from the American Principles Project .

column1: ‚ÄúWe call on all federal and state officeholders: To refuse to accept Obergefell as binding precedent for all but the specific plaintiffs in that case. To recognize the authority of states to define marriage
column2: and the right of federal and state officeholders to act in accordance with those definitions. To pledge full and mutual legal and political assistance to anyone who refuses to follow Obergefell for constitutionally protected reasons. To open forthwith a broad and honest conversation on the means by which Americans may constitutionally resist and overturn the judicial usurpations evidence in Obergefell.‚Äù";english;2016-10-27T04:38:33.848+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;Judge warns of dangers of appointed judiciary;0.0;http://www.wnd.com/files/2012/03/wedding_rings.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 12664;a77e44d66444c9b8e42d61b7770c2d1189207a88;0;-NO AUTHOR-;2016-10-27T04:38:38.554+03:00;Bellwether? Trump kippas outselling Hillary yarmulkes;"Bellwether? Trump kippas outselling Hillary yarmulkes Company sees preference as 'early exit poll of Orthodox Jews' Published: 24 mins ago Print
WASHINGTON ‚Äì The campaigns of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are looking for signs anywhere and everywhere that might suggest who will move into the White House in January.

A company that makes Trump and Hillary kippas or yarmulkes has some good news for one of the presidential hopefuls ‚Äì Trump head coverings are winning in a landslide among the Orthodox Jewish clientele.
So far
column2: the company
column3: Pic-A-Kippa
column4: has sold 331 Trump yarmulkes to 65 for Clinton.

column1: ‚ÄúMy kippa (yarmulke) company sells Trump and Hillary kippas and are keeping track of who is selling more
column2: ‚Äù Uri Turk
column3: founder and ‚Äúchief kippa officer
column4: ‚Äù told WND. ‚ÄúWe see it as an early exit poll of the Orthodox Jews
column5: a type of bellwether of where this important community is leaning. Once the first debate came around
column6: the orders started flying in
column7: with much more interest in the Trump kippas.‚Äù

column1: Pic-A-Kippa is the brainstorm of two former elite red beret IDF soldiers from Miami. Turk says the company is the leader in the kippa market and has been selling Trump and Hillary custom kippas on its site since August
column2: all the while keeping a running tally of which one has sold more.

column1: ‚ÄúOur mission is to help Jews everywhere show and wear their Jewish pride
column2: with our beautifully unique and completely customizable picture kippas
column3: ‚Äù the company says on its website.

column1: It donates 10 percent of every kippa sale to the Lone Soldier Center in Israel
column2: assisting young lone soldiers during difficult times.

column1: Turk said while American Jews have leaned heavily Democratic for decades
column2: the past few presidential races have seen Orthodox Jews
column3: who make up over 10 percent of American Jewry
column4: vote Republican in ever increasing numbers. He attributes that fact to the Democrats putting ‚Äúdaylight between America and Israel.‚Äù

column1: A number of influential Jewish pro-Trump organizations have emerged
column2: chief among them ‚ÄúJews Choose Trump‚Äù and ‚ÄúJewish Democrats For Trump.‚Äù A recent poll of Florida Jews showed Orthodox voters are leaning toward Trump by a 3-1 margin.

column1: According to Turk
column2: Pic-A-Kippa has sold many Trump kippas to a congregant of Ivanka Trump‚Äôs synagogue on the liberal Upper East Side of Manhattan and has gotten orders for Trump kippas from Israel
column3: Australia
column4: Britain and even Mexico. Pic-A-Kippa has also gotten hate mail from Jews unhappy they are selling the Trump designs
column5: he says.";english;2016-10-27T04:38:38.554+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;Bellwether? Trump kippas outselling Hillary yarmulkes;0.0;http://mobile.wnd.com/files/2016/10/3rd-debate-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-3-600.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 12666;c68c0ce8a6d0a853da518ed492bce63f754f32b0;0;Marisa Martin;2016-10-27T04:38:47.161+03:00;Paintings 'almost no one else seemed to be doing';"Print
When Judith Gait met ‚ÄúFather X
column2: ‚Äù it was a lopsided grief that drew them together. He had lost his only chance at fatherhood through an abortion years ago. Gait is a married mother of five
column3: and long-term American resident in Britain. Her support of the pro-life movement is driven by ‚Äúthankfulness and praise‚Äù for life and her Christian faith.

column1: Witnessing abortion‚Äôs heavy toll on the living and dead
column2: Gait began to make the paintings almost no one else seemed to be doing. Subtle and working entirely with symbolism
column3: these simple artworks avoid screaming about abortion. Rather
column4: they mourn in color
column5: symbol and tone with single shoes
column6: broken cord
column7: dead flowers and other lonely and broken things. ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column8: commentary by Father X

column1: When a friend first visited Gait‚Äôs studio
column2: he was struck by her abortion paintings. Confessing years of torment after his partner aborted his child
column3: he wrote: ‚ÄúI realize your work comes from a place of great love
column4: for it attempts to give defenseless life the dignity and protection it never knew in our throw away culture.‚Äù

column1: Gait invited him to pray with her for his lost child. It happened to be the anniversary of the death of his baby
column2: five years to the day. Father X remembers every detail.

column1: Their conversation grew into a joint effort
column2: culminating in a book
column3: ‚Äú Troubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas: Meditations on Post Abortion Trauma .‚Äù Father X wanted to remain anonymous
column4: as a place-setter for millions of unconsidered fathers in the acts of abortion. He wrote poetic and powerful statements for each of Gait‚Äôs 30 paintings in this book
column5: which have also been shown together in art exhibits.

column1: Time and neglect does not necessarily heal the wounds of abortion
column2: Gait claims. Rather
column3: ‚Äúthe past refocuses into a sharper image and the pain through an iterative process of silence
column4: guilt and remorse has not abated.‚Äù You can see that in the words of Father X
column5: which run the gamut of human emotions. ‚ÄúOn Abortion: Shoe
column6: Pot and Crosses‚Äùfrom ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúJonah of Nineveh‚Äù features an upended
column2: single rose with red cords and funereal foliage. Flowers are ‚Äúalready in the birth position
column3: head down and waiting to be born.‚Äù Torn and shroud-like ribbons hang across the painting. Spirals represent a child‚Äôs DNA helix and the ‚Äúveil of the Temple which has just been so rudely shaken down to its foundation.‚Äù Father X makes an analogy between Jonah fleeing ‚Äúparental responsibility‚Äù and eventual redemption ‚Äì then veers off to his own personal engulfment in almost a stream of consciousness: ‚ÄúIt was her wedding dress
column4: my sea green empress
column5: this blue lagoon princess she slipped into her own heart of darkness on that day she decided to abort and when time really stopped in our lives. She was full of fear. ‚Ä¶‚Äù

column1: In some of these works
column2: hammers incongruently hang with flowers. They are bloody or blackened
column3: some submerged underwater or hanging from a noose. Father X interprets these tools as decision markers
column4: to either build or tear down. In ‚ÄúHammer of Decision
column5: ‚Äù it belongs to Thor
column6: the war god ‚Äúinfested with his one eyed wisdom of intrigue and destruction.‚Äù Wagner
column7: the Olympics
column8: ‚Äúsperm races
column9: ‚Äù Thomas Moore and Valkyries are all inducted into this choice by the author. Either the Carpenter‚Äôs ‚Äúhammer of wisdom‚Äù or Thor‚Äôs ‚Äútool of chaos‚Äù will be chosen by expectant parents. ‚ÄúHammer
column10: Suspended‚Äù

column1: ‚Äú Troubadours ‚Äù runs from elegant poetry to sentiment over babies and an ad hoc theology. Striving to extend lives of children lost to abortion
column2: the authors create a fantasy universe of possibilities. This includes moonlighting for angels
column3: celestial games
column4: ‚Äúinterstellar wind-jammers‚Äù and a ‚Äúbaby steamer sailing on children‚Äôs seas
column5: ‚Äù among other delightful prospects. Lost and murdered infants in these tales pine for love or for a family in their Limbos.

column1: Father X occasionally speculates on spiritual issues outside the Bible or the treatment of abortion in other religions. Running from nursery rhymes and quotes to historical characters
column2: these are not theological statements
column3: but a type of literary yearning that seeks an answer to abortion.

column1: In Gait‚Äôs ‚ÄúPink Rose‚Äù and ‚ÄúStardust
column2: ‚Äù we see empty fields
column3: withered plants and other tokens. Father X takes off from here on fanciful trips for the lost children. He places them in a cosmic waiting rooms or dancing in circles
column4: which is reflected in the painting. Children are disfigured
column5: or missing eyes or arms and singing in ‚Äúlow mournful tones‚Äù so as not to disturb their parents. Music is ‚Äúintense
column6: equivalent to the sound created by Hildegard von Bingen (a 12th-century nun and composer). ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column7: commentary by Father X

column1: References to Mary as a mother are common
column2: as well as other scriptural allusions. ‚ÄúAll babies jump for Jesus‚Äù in the womb (or in ‚Äúits sack of nibbling yoke‚Äù) writes Father X. Elizabeth‚Äôs child John ‚Äúleapt for joy
column3: just as his ancestor David did before the ark of the covenant
column4: ‚Äù he continues.

column1: Gait addresses the human embryo
column2: finding Biblical
column3: ethical or emotional arguments for its worth at all stages. Her ‚ÄúAbbey Target Beginning‚Äù has a crosshair target
column4: which is interpreted spiritually: ‚ÄúThe first target blastula conflates the first cellular divisions with the laver bread ‚Äì the bread on fire with the Holy Spirit the same stage of development as the child in Mary‚Äôs womb when she arrived at her cousin Elizabeth‚Äôs house.‚Äù

column1: Post-abort guilt isn‚Äôt rationalized or downplayed
column2: but emotionally reacted to in art and word. Father X describes bats as whirling about ‚Äúin circles at the pitiful sound the [aborted] children make‚Äù because they are tuned to such distressing signals. This contrasts with many parents who are ‚Äústill stone deaf‚Äù to such mournful sounds. At another point
column3: Father-X imputes the collective white noise of guilt to attacks of tinnitus
column4: a roar of unwanted thoughts. ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column5: commentary by Father X

column1: Father X elaborates on what Gait hints in her paintings: the injustice and evil of abortion. He cites a world built on slavery before Christ‚Äôs advent
column2: and the works of such men as William Wilberforce and John Brown in furthering Christ‚Äôs gospel of justice and peace. All this is contrasted to abortion throughout.

column1: Ruminating on Gait‚Äôs ‚ÄúPalms of our Lord
column2: ‚Äù Father X claims ‚Äúthe face of the baby is in the midst of the ruins of the abortion. ‚ÄúPalms‚Äù is murky
column3: with a single
column4: red hand print. ‚ÄúTo look at the after birth of an abortion is to read the Tarot of Ruins
column5: ‚Äù he continues.

column1: ‚ÄúSuicide‚Äù advances this dark theme
column2: where Gait and Father X criticize the death industry and it‚Äôs euphemistically named ‚Äúclinics.‚Äù He takes a few swings at the girl gangs of the glass ceilings: ‚Äú‚Ä¶ a caricature of a woman who made a mistake
column3: who got herself in trouble
column4: who has had an abortion and afterwards committed suicide in her heart.‚Äù

column1: But all isn‚Äôt baleful and sad here. In ‚ÄúCloud Children
column2: ‚Äù Father X muses on paper dolls in Gait‚Äôs paintings with this lovely thought: ‚ÄúWhere children go ‚Ä¶ is a mystery. ‚Ä¶ Some say they take their daytime rest in Christ‚Äôs tomb in Jerusalem
column3: and like him when their time is come they will ascend into heaven before a quire of angels and assembled Star Ships.‚Äù

column1: ‚Äú Troubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas ‚Äù is a work of meditation
column2: grief counseling
column3: poetry
column4: social commentary and visual art. Father X may not reveal his identity here
column5: but the reader comes to know intimate details about relationships and emotions surrounding the death of his only child. Gait and Father X describe their efforts as a ‚Äúsilent prayer of witness for all the ghost families
column6: those Phantoms of Sorrows
column7: who will never laugh or cry together as a family
column8: because of an abortion.‚Äù They hope that prying open the tightly locked matter of abortion will help to heal those who have had abortions or are victimized in some way.

column1: Judith Gait is a graduate of California College of Arts and Crafts and received a Masters at Oxford‚Äôs Ruskin School of Fine Drawing. Her work is in public and private collections in America and abroad. She is an American citizen
column2: residing in Britain. Father X is an addictions counselor and writer in Great Britain
column3: who prefers to remain anonymous.

column1: ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas:Meditations on Post Abortion Trauma‚Äù is a coffee-table size
column2: 103-page paper book
column3: with 33 color-illustrations and related commentary. You can purchase it at Amazon U.S.";english;2016-10-27T04:38:47.161+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;Paintings 'almost no one else seemed to be doing';0.0;http://www.wnd.com/files/2016/10/Weeping-angel.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

When Judith Gait met ‚ÄúFather X
column2: ‚Äù it was a lopsided grief that drew them together. He had lost his only chance at fatherhood through an abortion years ago. Gait is a married mother of five
column3: and long-term American resident in Britain. Her support of the pro-life movement is driven by ‚Äúthankfulness and praise‚Äù for life and her Christian faith.

column1: Witnessing abortion‚Äôs heavy toll on the living and dead
column2: Gait began to make the paintings almost no one else seemed to be doing. Subtle and working entirely with symbolism
column3: these simple artworks avoid screaming about abortion. Rather
column4: they mourn in color
column5: symbol and tone with single shoes
column6: broken cord
column7: dead flowers and other lonely and broken things. ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column8: commentary by Father X

column1: When a friend first visited Gait‚Äôs studio
column2: he was struck by her abortion paintings. Confessing years of torment after his partner aborted his child
column3: he wrote: ‚ÄúI realize your work comes from a place of great love
column4: for it attempts to give defenseless life the dignity and protection it never knew in our throw away culture.‚Äù

column1: Gait invited him to pray with her for his lost child. It happened to be the anniversary of the death of his baby
column2: five years to the day. Father X remembers every detail.

column1: Their conversation grew into a joint effort
column2: culminating in a book
column3: ‚Äú Troubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas: Meditations on Post Abortion Trauma .‚Äù Father X wanted to remain anonymous
column4: as a place-setter for millions of unconsidered fathers in the acts of abortion. He wrote poetic and powerful statements for each of Gait‚Äôs 30 paintings in this book
column5: which have also been shown together in art exhibits.

column1: Time and neglect does not necessarily heal the wounds of abortion
column2: Gait claims. Rather
column3: ‚Äúthe past refocuses into a sharper image and the pain through an iterative process of silence
column4: guilt and remorse has not abated.‚Äù You can see that in the words of Father X
column5: which run the gamut of human emotions. ‚ÄúOn Abortion: Shoe
column6: Pot and Crosses‚Äùfrom ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äù

column1: ‚ÄúJonah of Nineveh‚Äù features an upended
column2: single rose with red cords and funereal foliage. Flowers are ‚Äúalready in the birth position
column3: head down and waiting to be born.‚Äù Torn and shroud-like ribbons hang across the painting. Spirals represent a child‚Äôs DNA helix and the ‚Äúveil of the Temple which has just been so rudely shaken down to its foundation.‚Äù Father X makes an analogy between Jonah fleeing ‚Äúparental responsibility‚Äù and eventual redemption ‚Äì then veers off to his own personal engulfment in almost a stream of consciousness: ‚ÄúIt was her wedding dress
column4: my sea green empress
column5: this blue lagoon princess she slipped into her own heart of darkness on that day she decided to abort and when time really stopped in our lives. She was full of fear. ‚Ä¶‚Äù

column1: In some of these works
column2: hammers incongruently hang with flowers. They are bloody or blackened
column3: some submerged underwater or hanging from a noose. Father X interprets these tools as decision markers
column4: to either build or tear down. In ‚ÄúHammer of Decision
column5: ‚Äù it belongs to Thor
column6: the war god ‚Äúinfested with his one eyed wisdom of intrigue and destruction.‚Äù Wagner
column7: the Olympics
column8: ‚Äúsperm races
column9: ‚Äù Thomas Moore and Valkyries are all inducted into this choice by the author. Either the Carpenter‚Äôs ‚Äúhammer of wisdom‚Äù or Thor‚Äôs ‚Äútool of chaos‚Äù will be chosen by expectant parents. ‚ÄúHammer
column10: Suspended‚Äù

column1: ‚Äú Troubadours ‚Äù runs from elegant poetry to sentiment over babies and an ad hoc theology. Striving to extend lives of children lost to abortion
column2: the authors create a fantasy universe of possibilities. This includes moonlighting for angels
column3: celestial games
column4: ‚Äúinterstellar wind-jammers‚Äù and a ‚Äúbaby steamer sailing on children‚Äôs seas
column5: ‚Äù among other delightful prospects. Lost and murdered infants in these tales pine for love or for a family in their Limbos.

column1: Father X occasionally speculates on spiritual issues outside the Bible or the treatment of abortion in other religions. Running from nursery rhymes and quotes to historical characters
column2: these are not theological statements
column3: but a type of literary yearning that seeks an answer to abortion.

column1: In Gait‚Äôs ‚ÄúPink Rose‚Äù and ‚ÄúStardust
column2: ‚Äù we see empty fields
column3: withered plants and other tokens. Father X takes off from here on fanciful trips for the lost children. He places them in a cosmic waiting rooms or dancing in circles
column4: which is reflected in the painting. Children are disfigured
column5: or missing eyes or arms and singing in ‚Äúlow mournful tones‚Äù so as not to disturb their parents. Music is ‚Äúintense
column6: equivalent to the sound created by Hildegard von Bingen (a 12th-century nun and composer). ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column7: commentary by Father X

column1: References to Mary as a mother are common
column2: as well as other scriptural allusions. ‚ÄúAll babies jump for Jesus‚Äù in the womb (or in ‚Äúits sack of nibbling yoke‚Äù) writes Father X. Elizabeth‚Äôs child John ‚Äúleapt for joy
column3: just as his ancestor David did before the ark of the covenant
column4: ‚Äù he continues.

column1: Gait addresses the human embryo
column2: finding Biblical
column3: ethical or emotional arguments for its worth at all stages. Her ‚ÄúAbbey Target Beginning‚Äù has a crosshair target
column4: which is interpreted spiritually: ‚ÄúThe first target blastula conflates the first cellular divisions with the laver bread ‚Äì the bread on fire with the Holy Spirit the same stage of development as the child in Mary‚Äôs womb when she arrived at her cousin Elizabeth‚Äôs house.‚Äù

column1: Post-abort guilt isn‚Äôt rationalized or downplayed
column2: but emotionally reacted to in art and word. Father X describes bats as whirling about ‚Äúin circles at the pitiful sound the [aborted] children make‚Äù because they are tuned to such distressing signals. This contrasts with many parents who are ‚Äústill stone deaf‚Äù to such mournful sounds. At another point
column3: Father-X imputes the collective white noise of guilt to attacks of tinnitus
column4: a roar of unwanted thoughts. ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas‚Äùpainting by Judith Gait
column5: commentary by Father X

column1: Father X elaborates on what Gait hints in her paintings: the injustice and evil of abortion. He cites a world built on slavery before Christ‚Äôs advent
column2: and the works of such men as William Wilberforce and John Brown in furthering Christ‚Äôs gospel of justice and peace. All this is contrasted to abortion throughout.

column1: Ruminating on Gait‚Äôs ‚ÄúPalms of our Lord
column2: ‚Äù Father X claims ‚Äúthe face of the baby is in the midst of the ruins of the abortion. ‚ÄúPalms‚Äù is murky
column3: with a single
column4: red hand print. ‚ÄúTo look at the after birth of an abortion is to read the Tarot of Ruins
column5: ‚Äù he continues.

column1: ‚ÄúSuicide‚Äù advances this dark theme
column2: where Gait and Father X criticize the death industry and it‚Äôs euphemistically named ‚Äúclinics.‚Äù He takes a few swings at the girl gangs of the glass ceilings: ‚Äú‚Ä¶ a caricature of a woman who made a mistake
column3: who got herself in trouble
column4: who has had an abortion and afterwards committed suicide in her heart.‚Äù

column1: But all isn‚Äôt baleful and sad here. In ‚ÄúCloud Children
column2: ‚Äù Father X muses on paper dolls in Gait‚Äôs paintings with this lovely thought: ‚ÄúWhere children go ‚Ä¶ is a mystery. ‚Ä¶ Some say they take their daytime rest in Christ‚Äôs tomb in Jerusalem
column3: and like him when their time is come they will ascend into heaven before a quire of angels and assembled Star Ships.‚Äù

column1: ‚Äú Troubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas ‚Äù is a work of meditation
column2: grief counseling
column3: poetry
column4: social commentary and visual art. Father X may not reveal his identity here
column5: but the reader comes to know intimate details about relationships and emotions surrounding the death of his only child. Gait and Father X describe their efforts as a ‚Äúsilent prayer of witness for all the ghost families
column6: those Phantoms of Sorrows
column7: who will never laugh or cry together as a family
column8: because of an abortion.‚Äù They hope that prying open the tightly locked matter of abortion will help to heal those who have had abortions or are victimized in some way.

column1: Judith Gait is a graduate of California College of Arts and Crafts and received a Masters at Oxford‚Äôs Ruskin School of Fine Drawing. Her work is in public and private collections in America and abroad. She is an American citizen
column2: residing in Britain. Father X is an addictions counselor and writer in Great Britain
column3: who prefers to remain anonymous.

column1: ‚ÄúTroubadours Sailing Hibiscus Seas:Meditations on Post Abortion Trauma‚Äù is a coffee-table size
column2: 103-page paper book
column3: with 33 color-illustrations and related commentary. You can purchase it at Amazon U.S.";english;2016-10-27T05:07:15.712+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;Paintings 'almost no one else seemed to be doing';0.0;http://mobile.wnd.com/files/2016/10/Weeping-angel.jpg;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column3: the ‚Äúwhitelisting‚Äù safeguard means Clinton and other contacts would have had to be approved as secure for data transmission ‚Äì covering everything from emails to texts to phone calls. The Obama BlackBerry would have also been configured to accept the communications.

column2: according to a new Gallup poll released on Wednesday. The poll showed that 61 percent of American adults now oppose a ban. That level of opposition is the highest ever recorded.

column1: Increasing opposition to the 1990‚Äôs-era gun ban isn‚Äôt just limited to Republicans. Gallup‚Äôs data show that opposition to the ban has increased across the board. Barely 50 percent of Democrats currently support the ban today
column2: compared to 63 percent support from Democrats in 1996
